articleText:
THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD

Rockbampton

THURSDAY, JUNE 23, 1949

MAP-MAKING IN EARLY QUEENSLAND ,

THE first Queensland map to

be mentioned was con-

structed about 1860 by Leopold Franz Landsberg, Government surveyor for the Port Curtis district. Its scale was 14.5 miles to the inch, and the area was the "settled part ol the colony south of Cape Pal- marston, including parts of the Leichhardt and Maranoa dis-

tricts." Many of the data used were from official sources, and having regard to the times and crude facilities, the map was "reasonably accur- ate"

This map was followed in 1863 by one of the whole of Queensland, which was Litho-

graphed by Thos. Ham and: Co, and published by J. W. Buxton. Its scale was 41 1/4 miles to the inch and It set out the principal pastoral dis- tricts, as well as the explor- ing routes of Landsborough, Walker, Burke and Wills and

Kennedy. It will probably never be known why it did not show Leichhardt's wanderings.

The third map was publish- ed in 1871 by the Government. The scale was about 24 miles to an Inch, the .compilation was by Thos. Ham, the en- graving by Wm. Knight, and "everything considered, this was an excellent production." A map showing the pastoral runs southwards from Broad- sound as far west as Long- reach and Thargomindah was brought out by the Govern- ment in 1872, the scale being 12 miles to the inch. The next map, prepared for the Educational Department in 1877, was of the whole State, on a scale of 27 miles to the inch, and was used in its or- iginal and reduced form "for various useful purposes" for many years.

A 16-mile to the inch map of the whole State was pub- lished in 1881, and "showed most of the main features in approximately correct posi- tions." But with surveys ex- tending as settlement expand- ed maps of this nature were soon out of date, so that in 1883 a complete reconstruc- tion of the State map was contemplated. This was ne- cessary in order to fix accur-

ately the western part of the

State with the South Austra- lian boundary, to which end the positions of Boulia, Black- all and Roma were determin-

ed astronomically. Unfortun- ately, Nemesis overtook the unbalanced land boom tha bad raged for years before anything could be started, and other than a vote of £500 to engrave the 1881 map little was done. But the engraving was never done, because photo- graphy was so developed that

maps "practically as good as engravings could be produced at far less cost, and can, be .more easily revised and im- proved."

By 1882 the financial storm was abating, and the syste- matic compilation of maps was inaugurated. It was arranged for all maps to be drawn on the same projection, uniformly divided into sheets on a stan- dard scale of 2 miles to an inch, and from this photo- graphic reductions to 4 miles,

8 miles and 16 miles to an inch were readily obtained. But owing to staff shortages, this project did not get past the planning stage, and to keep pace with growing demands the 1881 map was "thoroughly revised, extended to include New Guinea and an inset map of Australasia" and published in 1894. A school map "very complete for educational purposes" was published in 1883. It was on a scale of 27 miles to an inch, and was printed in colours on four sheets, the 3250 complete maps occupying 65 days in printing alone.

By now the 1883 reconstruc-

tion plan was taking shape, and the production of accurate maps for a large State the size of Queensland was progressing steadily. World War 11 so near to our door gave us the magnificent military maps which it is a sheer delight to read, and a veritable Cook's tour to study The pioneering days of map making are now but a distant memory; but as we have seen they had their riddles, their tribulations and also their triumphs.

WORLD FOOD AND SOIL FERTILITY

IT Is not safe to generalise about so diverse a problem

as feeding a world. There is so vide a variety ol tastes an.1 ef population denstity, of pro ductive areas and of sentimen tal clinging to congested areas, of wasting empty and of des troying occupied lands; of hoarding and of wasting food that the matter ceases to be one of simple arithmetic and to present itself in all its as pects of bewildering complex ity. For instance, more than half ot all the people in the world live in Asia, and more tijSK half cf th? remainder are crowded in Europe; yet the great wheat producing areas excluding USSR-are in North and South America and Aus tralia. In itself, this simple fact reveals a transport job of shift ing- more than 10,000,003 tons of wheat long distances by sea. On the other hand, ver min and insects destroy more than three times that amount ot stored grain eacn year, so It appears that man might with profit intensify his war against these never-sleeping

insld'ous enemies.

Aldous Huxley stresses what he calls the "double crisis which the world is hopelessly facing today," i.e., the declin ing fertility of the soil as op posed to the increasing fertil ity of mankind. He designates this a "low level crisis" as against the high Isvel on poli tical crises and while he con ceded the importance of the latter, 4ie laments that it should almost completely ob scure the former. He also claims that solution of the

higher level crises is Impos sible without first making some effort to solve those on his lower level.

But the greatest of all fac tors in food supply will be the education of man to the fact that It Is a science, and not a catch-as-can job. The stand ards of life are maintained at the point of food production without which all other pro duction is as Dead Sea fruit. A ton of potatoes could easily be worth more than a whoi? shipment of fluid-drive Chrys lers, yet popular emphasis to day is on the fluid-drive car. Just how long we shall be able to live in that Fool's Castle depends upon for how much longer there will oe found virgin soils to take the place of those which we ruin. Only eight per . cent of the total surface of the earth is arable, land, and man must bs taught that h® cannot waste it as he has done in the past, and as he is now doing in Australia.

It is no accident that the maize yield per acre for Aus tralia is down 21 per cent on that of 75 years ago, that of oats by 52 per cent, that af wheat by Ave per cent and that of hay by eight per cent. The comparison was between a 10-year average at e^ch end of the period, so there is nothing haphazard about it. especially as in the Interim millions of tons of imported fertiliser have been, used to arrest the rot! Truly, indeed is the emphasis today upon food, and the manner of its production

snippet: THE first Queensland map to be mentioned was constructed about 1860 by Leopold Franz Landsberg, Government

articleText:
THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD

Bockbamptoo

THURSDAY. JUNE . 16, 1948

QUEENSLAND IS MORE THAN BRISBANE.

rpHE chief disability suffered

today by North Queensland -and by Central Queens land to an equal degree . is that both Federal and State Governments have fallen down hopelessly on their ' decentralisation poli cies. The Governments seem to be quite satisfied with filling up the vast empty spaces of former munitions factories at Bocklea and Fisherman's Bend with private firms. There was nothing to prevent many of these new industries open ing up in country towns like Townsville and Rcckhampton, if the Governments hud raised the question with the firms and had offered them special Inducements to go outside the capitals.'

- Last fiscal year the State Statistician reports Queensland industry turned out work valued at £125,000,000-an in crease of 25 per. cent above the previous record year. TWs out. put employed 76,000 hands, and it is noteworthy that the majority of them worked. in Email factories. Another £7,500, 000 was invested in Queens land industry last year and the result of that will be reported in the future. At first glance thl% appears to be a satisfac tory result. And so it is-for Brisbane. But it is not so satisfactory to Central and Northern Queensland, oi to discerning people In the South itself, Including the Govern, ment Statistician and econ omic adviser. He points out that more than half of all the State's industry is centred in Brisbane. Only 7 per cent is in Central Queensland and 20 per cent each in the Southern and Northern Divisions. Com menting on these statistics the Brisbane "Courier-Mail," which can hardly be regarded t an ardent advocate of taking any thing away from the metro polis, says editorially: '"Hiis unhealthy centralisation can be blamed in part on the Gov

ernment's differential railway rates which, favour Brisbane and place country manufac turers at a serious disadvant

age '.If rates, were adjusted to

encourage decentralisation it would greatly benefit the State

as a whole."

That is something of an ad mission from that source, and it seems to be shared by other journalists. Writing recently the "Bulletin's" Brisbane cor. respondent remarked: "If the Northern people only realised it they have behind them a big body of public opinion in Brisbane. They would do well to send a team of speakers here to call public meetings, at which their claims could be properly preseiited. Illustrated by films and stills, such meet ings could do immense good to the cause of # the great North of the State, because the people

of Brisbane themselves and other people in the southern part of the State want to see them receive full justice. The remedy for unfair discrimina tion lies in constant pressure on the people responsible-the

Government."

This is a most unprecedented trend, and one to be welcomed. Is it that the cities are at last beginning to realise that the goose that lays the golden egg can be starved into not laying at all? Now that there is a sign of awakening, what measure of aid is the South disposed to give? Something more, it is to be hoped, than the advice of the president of the Chamber of Commerce to develop our land and mineral resources and provldfe more amenities to attract popula tion. We must not expect to go to the Government for everything; there has already been too strong* a tendency in that direction. But there re quires to be a radical change in matters for which the Gov ernments can be held rerpons. ible.

FINDING PLACES FOR THE DISPLACED.

rptHE Minister for Migration

has issued a statement set ting out the manner in which displaced persons from Eur ope are being absorbed into Australian industry. This shows that more than 50 per cent of all D.P's. brought out thus far are working in ccyntry areas-on road awl railway construction, farming, water storage1, afforestation, timber getting "and other es sential jobs foT which suffi cient Australian labour is not offering." Of more than 20,000 such persons, 14,529 are thus employed, of whom NSW has 4359, South Australia 3586, Victoria 3217, Tasmania 1811, Westralia 1090 and Queensland -the most dependent of all the States on rural industry brings up the rear with 937.

A survey of the contribu tion displaced persons labour is making to rural areas shows that 2001 are employed on railway construction, mostly in the country, 1506 on water storage and reticulation, 414 on road construction and maintenance in outlying areas, 781 on afforestation, and' 959 on timber getting and milling. Fruit and vegetable produc tion gives occupation to 116 permanently, and 714 season ally. There are 430 employed in dairying and in the pig farm ing, wheat, poultry, sugar and pastoral industries. The con tribution of these people to the solution of Australia's labour problem has been a notable one, says Mr Calwell. They have been particularly valu able in industries which, be cause of arduous work or iso lated localities, could not at tract and hold sufficient Aus

tralian labour

In all cases the new settlers are adapting themselves well to their work, and their ser vices have been applauded by employers. Not the least of the* advantages is that country centres enjoy extra spending power in their communities, whilst the infusion of people with a background of culture is bound to bring many bene fits. The Minister says tfie Commonwealth Government hopes to assist rural centres ?further with labour from the European migrant stream. Ad ditional categories in which they can be employed have

i been framed and an appeal is made to employers to avail

themselves of this labour. |

Perhaps the most gratifying feature of the Ministerial statement is the knowledge that Australia's new citizens are of a type who are willing and eager to adapt themselves to new conditions and take, on work which in the words of the Minister "cannot attract and hold Australian labour." But it can hardly escape observation that Mr Calwell's survey cov ers the comparatively limited number who have come out on the first wave, and an exam ination of the callings into which they have been absorb ed suggests that'such avenues of employment will soon reach saturation point.

What of the coal mines, iron and steel works and building industry, which languish for labour? Kalgoorlie, Queens town and Mildura have bright fires and warm hearths this winter because new recruits to avemanship have become woodcutters. Sydney, Mel bourne and Adelaide people shiver because of light and power rationing imposed through an insufficiency of coal, in a land more abund antly endowed with that com modity than any other on earth. The very rural indus tries that have absorbed the first influx of migrants are handicapped against expans ion because of a lack of fenc ing and implements, held back by curtailed steel production. One of the greatest drawbacks to the accommodation of new citizens, in country and town, is the housing shortage, and houses can not be supplied due in the first place to under manned coal and steel indus tries.
heading: THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD Rockhampton THURSDAY, JUNE 16, 1949  QUEENSLAND IS MORE THAN BRISBANE.
snippet: THE chief disability suffered today by North Queensland-and by Central Queensland to an equal degree—

articleText:
) TUG CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD \

Rock him p to a

THURSDAY, APRIL 14. 1949.

MAKING THE MAN FOR THE JOB

fpHERB was never a time

when vocational guidance would not have been of the greatest value, but today It Is * national necessity to any country faced with a labour .hostage. Once the wastage caused by fitting square pegs was accepted as one of the minor tragedies of life, and It

was not considered worth while going to much trouble to avoid It. That Is not now the case. A scarcity of train ed personnel exists In practic ally all trades In Australia, and the number of boys and girls who are willing to enter what are regarded as "dirty" trades Is comparatively fear alongside those attracted to other callings, including dead end jobs. It is a problem which is causing headaches to employers, and many de vices have been tried to at tract youth to learn trades to which at one time

their parents would almost have' gone op. their knees to have them apprenticed. Op portunities have been made available to apprentices to at tend technical schools on a lib erality never before heard of by older tradesmen, whilst

high wages are offered and

accepted as a matter of course.

The same thing Is occurring In .Britain, where the drive to attract young people to skilled trades has become urgent In view of the nation's fight for survival through her export trade. Young people, with a talent for skilled crafts, who live In districts where train ing Is not normally available are offered grants to enable them to train in areas away from their homes. Juveniles receiving this opportunity are those who are Just about to start work, are unemployed or are in dead-end Jobs. This Is not.fNurt of a general plan to transfer large numbers of juveniles to work away form their homes, but Is merely an attempt to give the same chances to train for skilled crafts as Is already provided through scholarships to those

who aim at entering the pro

fessions.

>? Provision 1B made for the payment of initial expenses, "settllng-in" grants, for a week ly board and lodgings allow ance, mid-day meals, laundry and fares between lodgings and work. Contributions to wards the coet of the weekly allowances will be sought from the employer, and, according to family income, may be. also required from the parent or guardian. Local Juvenile em ployment officials have been instructed to look out for school children with marked aptitude for skilled jobs. TTiat is a government scheme, but private employers are equally keen and alive to the necessity of ensuring a supply of train ed artisans. One firm of Nottingham furniture manu facturers enables boy and girl employees to attend .the firm's own school at the works. They spend one day a week during working hours and on each day there is a lecture by one of the directors or a de partmental manager, followed by practical work In well equipped classrooms.

This part of the British scheme for training rural ycuth could have beneficial results in Australia, apart from training personnel for the skilled trades. If provi sion could be made to train .country children in trades , 'away from home there would be far less Inclination foi country dwellers to pull up stakes and move the entire; family to the city in order "to. give the children a chance" which is perhaps the most potent force of all in the much bemoaned drift to the towns.

Altogether the current trends in respect of youth employment show that at last, serious attention is being given to wtnt hitherto has been the

most wasteful field in industry; and employment - excepting always Communist inspires sabotage by incessant rtrikes and stoppages.

... m

mw LAW WILL BUMP MOTORISTS

TF-pr when-the Traffic Bill

becomes law we shall be well on the way to the police State, end many of the prisxl liber ties won for us by our forbears will have vanished. Setting out to line up tlie hilarious drunken driver, the Bill rounds up the Innocent with the guilty, thft sheep with the coats, and excepting for the cost there Is Utile merit in re maining sober, because all of us who offend will be liable so open arrest. No longer will it be a- case of taking the -name and - address-the sozzled cul prit who has just knocked down a child and the sinner who-lies under the "reasonabfc suspicion" of having evaded payment of the correct tare will boui be hurried off to the w^jtch-houcs and, if unabVs lo supply ball, will remain there the night. In one giant stride Queensland has slipped back a century or so, and elevated tha simple offence of tare evasion into the category of treason,! felony or a breach of the peace. ? Not even a drunken,driver is! Uabft to morp than open ar rest for a start, which if no mote than befalls the conscien tious. driver who absent mindedly drives against the traffio signals. If they may not

share the same cell-though If; . everyone ,tfhom the Bill makes

a criminal is arrested the single etfU luxury will soon become an impossibility-they can and may share the same lock-up.

in court if-or when-the Bill goes on the Statute Book will be«ven more savage- in its assaults on our traditional rights. Gone are the days when even the villain seen commit ting his crime was held by law to be Innocent until proved oy evidence produced in open court to be guilty. Ttils in genious reversion to the Dark Ages plicea the prosecutor be yond the reach of cross ex amination, and it Is very many years since thugs In courts In Britain were In like plight, Re cognition by the Bill of £ police averment as evidence means, too, that the defendant has now to prove himself innocent where hitherto It was the Job of his prosecutor to prove him guilt?. Apart from the cost the Job of oollectlng evldenoe to

break down the imueati of a really determined prosecutor this is a terrifying prospect, and is quite foreign to tbo traditional concepts of British Justice.

Another pleasing attribute in the BUI is that even the most prejudiced, embittered police map can do no traffic wrong. All right of appeal against a police decision has been taken from the cittsen - other than to the Commissioner whose de partment will administer the mi. The Commissioner's de partment will, therefore, be both prosecutor and Judge, with powers far in excess of those held by military com manders on active service. In fact, so far as traffic offence* are concerned, when-or If the Bill becomes law we may as well be under Martial Lav According to C. O. Wans tall, MLA (Toowong), who is also a barrister, to such an extent are the police protected from the acts of over-offlciousness under the blanket exemption which provides that:

"The provisions of (his Act relating,to offences shall not apply to any member of tne Police Force while acting in the execution of any power or duty Imposed upon him by this Act or by any other Act or law."

that a policeman, on duty driv

ing a police car while drunk j

would be indemnified under this exception against the con

sequences of anything he did!1

articleText:
THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD

SOMETHING ABOUT THE RAILWAYS

Tp 1* a wise taxpayer who»

regards the frothy "hand outs by Government spokes men, u something which it will be'good for the Govern ment if the taxpayer can be got to believe it What It will mean to the taxpayer Is quite another matter. For instance, only a very dull day passes Into the limbo of other days without some reference to some mighty project to divert riven through tunnels piercing the very bowels of mountains, or to take the variety out of our railway gauges, or to throw bridges across mountain tor rents or sullen mangrove mud flats. The tale loses nothing In the telling, and unless the taxpayer happens to be wait ing for a roof to an unfinished house or a handful of spring headed Halls to repair the roof he already has he might be induced to believe the son i orouB tale.

^ Oddly enough, a story

worthy the telling and which the taxpayer should be told Is the cold fact that, between June 30, 1947 and June 30,1948, he lost 136 miles of existing railway standing on the book In die aggregate £887,000! What is more, such is the secrecy surrounding this drop ping of our national assets that it encourages the sup position that In the nine months to March last he might have dropped a lot more. The statistician states that in 1947 the Australian taxpayer owned 37,179 miles of open railway and in 1948 he owned only 37,054 miles. The loss was not oommon throughout the six States, for neither New South Wales nor South Australia nor Weston Australia lost any and Queensland-booming Just now with vast labour and material .wallowing projects-lost 75 mites or 00 per cent of the total' Incidentally, these stat istics are those of the Com ' monwealth Statistician. The

only line shown as closed in

the Queensland Railway Com missioner's annual report to June Jut was 0.49 miles be tween Quanaba and Pemberton in the Southern Division. Tasmania lost 27 miles and Victoria 23, they apparently being leas expansive down that way than in the Hanlon State.

Of the seven Government railway systems (our of them are badly in the red and th» other three are edging that way. For the year ending June 90, 1947, their aggregate expenditures-not counting in terest, depreciation and like trifles-ate up 91.7 per cent of all revenue, and last year they ataup 93.2 per cent of all such expenditure, and that despite the fact that there had been an over-til increase of revenue per train mile amounting to 10.7 per cent. Obviously John Public had hot been overlooked when It came to carrying the debt overflow from these So cialist undertakings. He was there, too, to accept Interest responsibility for 226,700,000 of railway capital dropped in Victoria, 08.000,000 hi Queens land'£3.100,000 in" South Aus tralia and £4,700,000 in Tas mania or £61,000,000 in all be tween 1937 and 1937, and he is still carrying it.

Despite til this, John Public had to carry the staggering loss of £6,517,044 In the year to June end 1947, and only the stars know»what it was to June end 1948, or what it will be at June end next when the 40-hour week will have proved how it Is possible to do as much or more work in less time. Nobody but the Soc ialist-minded believed it Communists swore by it-and the first reaction of Govern ments running Socialised rail ways is to unload dead rail ways on to the taxpayer, it

almost seems as if we are In line for a new era of decen tralisation, when Governments shed thtfj liabilities, -begin ning In the empty country.

REDS STILL GETTING AWAY WITH IT

TT lano me disguising the fact

that in spite of all the talk about them being check* mated by moderate elements in the unions, and of a stiffening attitude towards them by th-» governments, the Reds in Aus tralia are raging as rampantly as em they have done. They have not succeeded in getting McPhtlllps out of gaol-that is probably the least of their concerns-but they tape dis rupted jcey industries, set In dustrial laws at defiance and ridden roughshod over every democratic .right 'possessed hy tht rank and file. Nor is this surprising in view of the feeble attitude of Federal Acting At torney-General McKenna, a worthy disciple of Mr Chlfley. When urged by the Coal Tri bunal to tab: legal proceedings against the perpetrators of the trick on the members, re *e> quired "more information" and more time for consideration.

If ever there was justification for matters relating to work stoppages, ballots and the election of union officials to be placed under the control of the Registrar of the Arbitration Court, as has been asked, It Is here 'provided. Until this Is done such scandals will be re peated. It la not sufficient tor an overwhelming majority of workers to be against striksp,

or even for their executive bod& to give orders against a stop' page-u In tto^case of the

waterside worker*. Both can be flagrantly disregarded by th» Communist minority, acting in what the Coal Tribunal de scribed as "a sneaking under hand manner" in order to bring industry to a standstill. They can do it and are allowed to get- away with It.

It is amaslng that these oc currences have not caused k wave of indignation in every community In the Common wealth, with a demand that tin perpetrators be brought to book. What the Communists are doing in the industrial field today they will do in other ways affecting the daily lives of the people just as soon as they have the power. They have neither fhame nor scrapie. The power to check them no>r, when it is almost too late, resides in the hands of weaklings like the Chlfleys and McKennas, who talk about the need of time for reflection, when the case is one for swift, drastic action, even U it means calling Parliament to gether to pass special legisla tion. Nero fiddling whilst Rome burned has never found a stronger analogy than Aus tralia's handling of the Com munist menace.

articleText:
THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD

11

fiockbamptoa

Thursday, May 12,1949.

MAKING A PLACE FOR THE MIGRANT

JjOOAL authorities in. Central

Queensland, no doubt, to common with the rest of the State, are be* ing circularised by the Department of Labour and In dustry that 1600 displaced per .o"i have been allotted to Queensland in July, and be* tween that date and June next 4000 more will be on hand. It is anticipated, says the de partmental advice, that most of the 1600 will be absorbed into the northern sugar Indus try and industries occupied in the production of building ma terials, but some will be avail able for public works, and it Is desired to know what will be the requirements of the local authority addressed.

The purport of this com munication is unmistakable. There soon will be a consider able labour force available and the authorities naturally are concerned with the problem of Its absorption, hence the ap proach to local authorities and other semi-governmental ag ensies whose activities involve employment. The displaced persons do not represent all. or even the major portion, of new people entering the Com monwealth in an ever-growing volume. The greatest migra tion movement in the history of Australia is now taking place. More than 25,000 mig rants are on their way here. Twelve liners are bringing in a record number of 13. J Brit ish, and 11,000 displaced per sons are coming from Europe In thirteen transports. By next year the Influx will reach 160,000 per annum, and it is calculated that at the end of I960 Australia's population will have swelled to 8,000,000.

Perhaps it is not unnatural that here and there it should be questioned whether we are not going a'little too fast in this matter. One Federal Min ister has called for r halt, and the Prime Minister, who has just returned from Britain, ad mits that such a rate of In flow cannot be attempted with out creating acute problems In

[housing and absorption into

industry. Perhaps the Incon veniences will not be confined to the newcomers, but will have to be shared In some de r ' by the present population. Tet Australia needs these people, and it is realised by the Government that if we do not get them now they will be lost to this country. Next year the International Refugee Organ isation, the most important ag ency engaged in the distribu tion of displaced persons,, will

close down.

The letter to local authori ties is the first hint that the Central Division is under re view as a possible field for the settlement of new citizens. The

| feeler in respect of openings in

public works undertakings Is not likely to earn an encour aging response. Practically all of the local authority works in this region ace fully manned, and when the loan money with which they are being largely financed comes to an end a contraction rather than an ex pansion of the labour force must be expected.

The field offering the best openings for migrants must he the rural industries and such secondary industries as emerge from the decentralisation pol icy. Instead of merely circu larising local authorities there should be put in hand an ac tlv departmental investiga tion of the labour require ments of public bodies, private corporations and individuals 00 that the Information will be ready when labour is avail able. There should also be a decentralisation of r 'ministra tion in this matter, as present arrangements suggest that the whole business is to be con ducted from the capitals. In the days of pioneer immigra tion the divisional centres, la eluding Roekhampton, had their own depots, which re ceived the migrants and saw to their distribution to em ployers. If it was necessary then it is more essential still in the present case.

HOUSING STILL A MAJOR SHORTAGE

"E^IOM July, 1946, to De

cember, 1948, 120,000 new houses and flats were completed in Australia. Prob ably 140,000 dwellings, in cluding some of a, tem porary nature, have been completed since the war, pro Tiding housing for 600,000 per sons. Queensland makes a aomewhat extraordinary con tribution to these totals. Whilst this State completed propor tionately more dwellings since the war than any other Stat? It was the only one to show a decrease last year as com pared with 1947 - 300 fewer houses and flats being com pleted during the latter period. Zt would be gratifying if this could be interpreted as an in dication that we had over taken the housing lag.

This, however, i6 not the case, but in the words of the Commonwealth Director is "due to a marked reduction in activity of owner builders." And that simply bears out the oft reiterated complaint that 'building costs have got so high as to place owning a home beyond the reach of most wage and salary earners, so that they have "given away" the idea and are con triving to make shift In some other way. Thus practically the only building activity is that -conducted by the Hour ing Commission and other gov ernmental agencies, which Is one of the least healthy sign.* of the whole business.

This is the state we have reached three years after the

end of the war. If there was j one phase of post-war recon- j

struction which was looked to with confidence It was that re

lating to the housing problem.; Its urgency had clearly Im pressed Itself on the public

mind before the end of hos tilities, and it had seemingly received (he closest attention of the relevant Government

1 agencies, so that the task ap l peared to be thoroughly envis aged and the necessary meas ures planned to meet It. The training scheme, to turn out skilled and semi-skilled build ing artisans captured the pub lic imagination and appealed strongly to ex-service person nel, as was shown by the heavy enrolment of young men who wished to become carpen ters, plumbers and bricklayers But alas for these bright hopes. The Government allowed itself to be bullied into dropping the training scheme, and that practically sealed the fate of the housing programme, though it was not the sole

cause.

It has now become painfully clear that Australia will have a housing problem lor many years to come. The rate of building has got down to about 60,000 a year. That number will be commenced this year, but the Commonwealth Direc tor holds out no hope of more than 56,000 being completed. This is a sad falling away from the original yearly target of 80,000 new dwellings by the third post-war year, of which only 50,000 materialised. The Commonwealth Rousing Com mission estimated the shortage of houses in Australia, includ ing sub-standard dwellings, to be 300,000 at January, IMS, and hoped to catch up with the ar rears by 1055. With only 120,000 completed up to the end of last year we have fallen further into arrears, and It looks as though It will be nearer 15 years than five be fore the housing position be

comes normal.

articleText:
THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD

Boekbampt on

THURSDAY, DECEMBER 3

LOOKING OVER THE LANDSLIDE .

rPHE dominant thought in

Australian Labour Party

temples throughout Australia as Ministerial heads continue to topple, is "Who duninit," Many and varied are the ver sions. dark and sinister are some of the suspicions, but the growing tendency, as increas ing light breaks through the election murk, is to follow the oldest-known example and, with Adam, blame "the wlm mln." Certain it is that women under Labour rule have de generated into the family pack-horse, the impact of all out strikes falls most- deyast atingly on them, and the job of trying to balance a shrunk en £1 against crazlly soaring prices is also theirs; hence it 'would be a slight on the;? in telligence did they not do a little political thinking on their

own account. >.

However this may be it will Answer few questions In Cau cus, the Privy Council of Lab our, when the lads foregather amid the ruins to ascertiin which props stood up and which fell down. It" will be no mutual admiration society either, for ALP branches all over Australia will be asking savagely - what caused the greatest cataclysm in the hist ory of the Labour movement. The rot was not with thorn. Xt floated in upon them from outside, descended upon them

from overhead. It nullified their efforts and frustrated their hopes, leaving them im potent but Important cogs in the wheel of a machine that, once all-powerful, was dead. Not unnaturally, all eyes will be turned to-the man who brought them to this sorry pass.

Critical observers claim that the Chlfley form of adminis tration had done more thah cause Australia-wide stagna tion. \ It has engulfed Chlfley In an avalanche ol details, and like CurUn and Lyons before him, he has allowed Canberra to Overwhelm him with the small things of Canberra while he lost sight of the big things of Australia. That may ex plain Ws "take-it-or-leave-lt" attitude when politics con fronted him with the Aus tralian people. He did not know them, and was not con cerned about their condition. It was enough for him that he ' told them they were prosper

ous, and it was no concern of I his if they disbelieved him.

He provided neither hope for . them nor leadership for his

tnxious disciples..'

His two predecessors who ' mistook the Intrigues of the

lob&es for the voice of the Austrtslain people wereveiriov ed by tSiath, where Mr Chlfley has been removed by the Aus tralian people. His removal was less ataolufc than theirs, however, as lis is still leader of the political section- of the ALP-an Uneasy perch for either a temperamental or phy sical weakling-so that Mr

Chifley has not only to Justify

his leadership. He has also to retain it and his strongest, implacable opponent is Arthur Augustus Calwell. Calwell is Ettong because where Ourtin stood up to him Chifley- has given way. and is Implacable, because as he stated on his How-to-Vote cards, he believes he is "one of Australia's great est statesmen." Both Chifley and Curtin knew of the Calwell attacks on the Manila girls, the O'Keefe case, the G&mboa incident and a host of other assaults ' upon the human rights of those and other Asiatic- people, but they stood aside and Calwell got away with it

The sinister point here Is that Calwell has flouted Chif leys leadership in a manner that ;he would not have dared with Curtin. In the closing hours of the last Parliament Chifley twice gave the sign to Holloway to answer a question, and twice Calwell took-It and supplied the answer. The pub lic clash of wills was brief but decisive, and it was Calwell who survived. His all-consum ing ambition is to be Prime Minister of Australia, and the debacle of Saturday last in no manner diminishes that ambi tion. Bather in the scramble for leadership does he hope to see at least one obstacle re moved, and himself installed In leadership of political Lab

our.

On figures showing the per centage of enrolled electors who voted for him up to the end of counting on Saturday last, Calwell stood second In a list of five of file top-liners. Holloway with 59. per cent was first with Calweli S3 per cent, and they were the only two to be over the half way mark. Chifley with 42 per cent was lowest, Evatt with 48 per cent was next, and Ward with 49 per cent was third. What IS more, both Chifley and Evatt slumped heavily on their 1946 showing. If Caucus is statist ically Inclined its members can hardly avoid seeing how badly in the esteem of electors, the high , priests of the political Labour Party have slipped. We can Be sure that, unless Mr

Calwell falls into a trance or under a tram, Caucus will hardly fall to note how well he has held the support of his public.

It is the strong belief that the bell is tolling for Joseph Benedict Chifley, whose string of office records has been sup plemented by another: Under no previous leader has political Labour plumbed such abyssmal depths, and whether that came about through Ineptitude ' or mere "fedupness" is . immat erial to Caucus. Xt wants no body committing political hara kiri among its political proper ties, and Arthur Augustus Cal well will be there to say that he has no Intention of com mitting political suicide to please anybody.

articleText:
I .

1 TOE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND BERALD

BockJbamp to 11

THURSDAY,DECEMBER 2Cv 7 ' : ? mnm, lIII'.h-^

THJE pvmc SIM^ PI^URIMi

? rPHE growth of government

and semi-government ser vices in Australia in the 10 years to 1848 has lw$n scandalous. In that timOv the Curtin Chifley dynasties increased the Commonwealth Civil Service by 33,069 more than It accumu lated in the whole of its near 50 years existence, and nearly trebled the 1939 figure! The increase among- State Govern ment civil servants, in that dizzy io years, was just on One third the total of such servients accumulated over more than 150 years of the existence of such States! Local authorities, on the other hand, who carry out the actual work of road

making, providing amenities if all kinds for people trying" to stay on the land, actually had 770 fewer employees in 1948 than they had* in 183K

The Invasion was by no meanika stay-at-home affair. Expenditure oh the office of the High Commissioner, Lon don. with its; staff ' of BOO, more than trebled: Then the general expenditure of Dr Evatt's department increased in the 10 glorious years, by al most 11-fold, from £20,129 In 1939 to £292,200 in 1948, and the total expenditure of the department increased from £70,168 in 1939 to £1.032,000 last year, or about 15-fold. Con sular representation abroad was nil in 1945. but in 1946, with defeated Labourites for whom provision had to be made, the expenditure was £22,000 and last year it was a men shade under £200,000! "Other repre sentation abroad" also started in 1946 with £30.895. and reach ed £75,600 last year.

. Nor was Mr Calwell's depart ment behind in the scramble for notoriety in the' majestic build-up. In lb4Q there were two permanent and 98 tem porary employees, but by 1948 the permanents had increased to 19 and the temporaries to 293. In like maimer the mag nificence of the Calwell admin istration grew with the years from an expenditure of £21,758 in 1940 to £324,409 last year, an increase of better than 15 fold. We have consulates in Eire, in Chile and in Brasll, t£ie cost of each of them run ning' Into tens of thousands,

and. the worth of each of them

best represented by a note <4 interrogation. ,

'There Is no lack of dead woodto be topped off, with a commensurate release of man power to other and more pun ductive work, much of it dis guised behind a son&rous name and any amount of brasen auo aclfcy.- There are control boards galore, In which for thd main part, are Chifley nam-; ' inees, and there are seven

I Conciliation Commissioners 91

£1600 peraanujit each, plus their staffs, whose appoint ment wasa covert attack on the integrity of the Arbitra tion Court.

On top of it all. most of the Icey posts .are held, by men who

owed their ^meteoric rise to the

Influence ofChifley. Governor Gtaend McRell, with a year to goi whomustbe guided by the advice of his Ministeft, - jrtjl npw be advised by mien who objected bitterly i to his ap pointment. Commonwealth Bank Governor Dr H. C.

tinfchbs is another Chifley ap pointee, who. according to the Chifley Banking'Act, must sub ordinate . his will to that of the Treasurer, but it will now be a different Treasurer with a vastly different financial hori zon from that of his prede cessor. Where he will stand under Menzies* projected Bank Qoard Act'.will take' some sjaoo thing out if he is unable t6 accommodate himself to the new policy. ' Director-General of Agriculture Bulcock has re cently been given another seven years* appointment, and if nobody has yet discovered just what is the function of this post, other than as figure head to an utterly inexplicable Commonwealth Council-of Ag riculture, most informed people wilt fear that it will take some finding out.

It will be found, no doubt, that many of these key ap pointees have been made secure in their jobs by statutory rights. These men were the Chifley Government advisers, and Mr Menzif6 will have to dfecide whether or not he wants to have about him the Br&ins Trust, with which Chif ley surrounded himself. If he decides that he. does not, one of his toughest problems will be to decide what he is. to do

about them.

. rf*| QUEENSLAND BERALD ; / Jj? " :-l ^;">-.|Io-e|; b a'-01 pl.o'ii^ ..

[CTTHALES at urgtag others to

. subscribe to strike fufids, the Communist pollcy.is to con etry$ fighting funds to pay stooges, or to~bribe,/olk ? who are really traitors to Aus tralia.*Mr-Chifley seems { not to have noticed that, ordered to piy Into the ^itoitration Court their Btrayihg' reserves, the guileless Communists have paid them back into their own account. This pre-occupation or Mr Chlttey may have been the tact of a great ' general bent upon getting his own way ^simply by letting his op ponwit do as he Uk^s; but Dr Evatt's security police who

pounced on Brisbane's Ixjrd Mayor to question him: about a rumoured League of Freedom would be more likely to regard itf as trafficking with the

enemy.

Mr Chifley made the card inal error of branding every miner that refused to return to work as a Communist, and turned against him all the might and power of the Com . monwealth Government. He

claimed he did so to break the strike, whereas what it did was to pulverise^ the miner while the Communist, ack nowledged by Mr Chifley to be thj» prime mover in the busi ness, went scot free. Nor did Mr Chifley visit the coal fields to try to separate the sheep from the goats, having apparency up his mind that there simply were no sheep, It Is true that a few Cominunist leaders went to gaol for periods of up td one year for contempt of court, but as" they may gain remission of the unserved portion of their sentence by expressing their repentance, the whole school of them te llable to be abroad shortly. Anyw,ay, it is warmer >ln gaol during a black out than in Sydney. When It comes to expressing repent ance so -as to get back to his work pf Wrecking a civilisation,

the. Communist ftw few

equals.

The winner of the strike was

not Mr Chlfley'p Government, which, could. and should have prevented it happening. It was ^iot the. miner, who lost seven weeks' jiay and a yast amount of public sympathy, in addition to being revealed by unpractised servicemen as being ft novice at his own game. Never again will Mr Chifley be fible to say that obne but a miner can win coal. Ike real winner was in fact the Communist, who lost

rio^wages, Buttered none of the agonies of .the "below the bread-line" section of the community, and goes back' to business with his .fighting ap pliances unimpaired.. The Tri

bune of 13th instant said:

"Seftctlon'j main aim, to emash ' tne" Miners' Federation, has not

been realised. The federation hat. not been weakened, but greatly, strengthened by the strjiggle, which has : mercilessly epppsed '. the , miners' .enemies inside add outside

the federation and taught them who are their true friends."

The Communist qbjectlves were* to -cany a. step further the smashing of .the arbitra tion system, together wittfthe Australian Workers' Union. He did, not expect to achieve these objectives at once, but he does reckon on having weakened faith in both of these Institutions, and out of the disaffection and confusion to pick up many mote con verts. In the . meantime, the! Miners' Federation remains,

intact and the Communist is still top dog there. The latter has power to call a mass-= or

"aggregate" - meeting or or

der a vote, and the former has power only to do as he is di rected by the latter! If any> :body knows a more abject be

trayal, b$ a 'Government, of an important and trusting body of men/ it would sadden the heart of any believer in .human nature to hear of it.

articleText:
[ THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD 1

TyHATEVl&K may lie the fu

ture of the Freedom. league launched at a public meeting Attended by 3500 persons at Brisbane's City Hall last week tbe mere fact of its lnaugura tion Is a noteworthy happening from more angles than one That at this stage of our de velopment It should have,been deemed necessary, by people who are acknowledged leaders in the community, to convene . such a meeting Is a significant

commentary on certain trends

of the times.

Whilst the people have chafed under irksome, unduly pro

longed war-time controls of. matay things affecting 'their daily lives,' have resented being "pushed round" by an ever growing bureaucracy and have become exasperated at the weakness of both State and Federal Governments in deal ing with subversive elements which are damaging the eco nomic life of the country, it ts doubtful it there was any yery strong feeling on thejoeed for banding together to assert Che rights of the community until Lord Mayor Chandler broached the subject in an ad* dras to Ipswich Rotary Club. The general view, or at least the hope, was that these were mere irritations that would one day pass.

x One. thing s the Brisbane

meeting dldwas .forth thefreedoms which are ttafe Inherent right of Australian*, and which it Is cpnsidered are in danger of being filled away. Ttoe league meS» tin preserve freedom from want, freedom fromfear, freedom of expression, freedoin of religion,

freedofn of assembly and afso*

ciatJon*nd frfcedomto worfcr and to chopsethatwork. "Be lieving that sou» or all of these freedoms are Imperilled," declared the main, resolution passed at the Inaugural meet ing "we pledge ourselves to strive for the preservation and maintenance, and to dedicate ourselves to the task of pro tecting our democratic way of life and of opposing by any lawful means totalitarianism in any shape or form, and to do our best to foster trust, respect and cooperation among all Australian citizens." The line of action proposed would riot involve any move that will be subversive or seditious, nor will it contravene the laws of the, country in any way. But all constitutional means would be taken to influence public opinion by folding public meetings, lectures and. ad dresses. by radio talks, the issue of leaflets, "and vtork by personal contact, personal sin cerity, personal determination1 and enthusiasm". > .

articleText:
j TOE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD 1

Bockbamploo

THURSDAY, October 27. " 1049

tAND VALVES AND THE LAND COURT

|A U# wealth stems from the

land, fret few people, and it U surprising to learn that tht majority include many en* wm in rural industry, know anything of the intricate re lationship - between land rent als, operating costs and re Jurps. costing systems have

Men reduced to a fltte art in many fields of Industry, but they appear to have been largely neglected In the one which more than any other'

Mils for the. application of system. Hence the Rockhamp ton Court last week was under the-necessity of remarking that whilst the general, prosperity

of the pastoral Industry was acknowledged no figures had been produced by the Crown, which was seeking Increased rentals, - in showing ' the ac tual production costs on in dividual holdings In relation to the higher profits, nor to the effect of .'age increases,; shortages of labour and ma terial, and increased mainten ance costs in keeping down suckers and- seedlings on ringbarked country. Nor had toy such figures been produced by the lessees. Thus s the Court had been left with*

out much material Informa tion.

In seeking Increased rentals the Chief -Assessor of the Df {Mrtanent of lands contended that the rent charges now prevailing were seriously out of relationship to the prosper ity of the sheep and cattle In dustries. Crown rentals had Increased overall by 16 per Cent from the depression per iod-19S1-5-and the price of greasy wool had advanced 179 per rant, fat bullocks 135 per Cent, the total value of sheep production 133 per . cent, total value of cattle production 205 per cent and the total value

of pastoral production \ by 148 per cent. The prosperity in

dex adopted showed an aver age bf 80d. per lb. for greasy wool and £16/10/- for fat bul locks which was considerably less than the prices prevailing, over the past two years and at present. It was not con tended that the rental value of Crown lands was governed solely by the market value of the products derived from them, but It was maintained that the two were closely re

lated.

On a superficial examina tion the general taxpayer, who has a very clear under standing of the relation of

the market value of his own product, whether It be goods or labour, and the demands of foe crown, will be Inclined to say "Well, that's lair enough." But complaint is made that In the matter ot liupd values the Crown is spiking with two voices. Tbe" President of the United Glac iers Association points out that on the one hand the Crown is demanding: higher rentals because a new stand

values has arisen. But

wnjSi it comes to "freezing"

land for soldier settlement compensation to prestent hold ers Is based on 1642 values.

This does 'not' present the

Crown in a favourable, or even a consistent light, and there is ground for the contention that if'owners of frozen land are to Quit their holdings at 1642 values and seek fresh fields at the new values .based on the present exceptional prices they are virtually pre-, vented from re-entering the

Industry. ^

That could be a serious loss to the State, even though the Crown might be the gainer in the first Instance. This Is endorsed by the rational view taken .by the Land Court at ftpckhampton which laid It down that whilst it was de sirable that the Lands De partment be given full scope to improve valuation methods, continued and increasing pro duction should not be sacri ficed to revenue considera tions. "In the scale of rela tive importance to the com munity increased Crown rents weigh lightly in comparison with Increased production and progressive development," ob served Mr Payne. "Queens land would become a poorer

place In which to live if rural progress and production were not to keep abreast of ln durtcial development and poi&nUon."

. That embodies a" sound principle which could profit ably be absorbed by many people outside tbe Lands De partment and those engaged in rural industry, not ex cluding the trade's unions. In deed, taking a line through the current sittings it Is pos sible that the Land Court will have a greater influence on the stability and prosperity of the State than the industrial tribunals wftlch loom sb much more prominently in the pub lic eye.

MILLIONS PAID OUT FOR MILK

"WITH Central Queensland's

dairying industry cetebra thg its 60th birthday, the announcement that the Port Curtis cooperative Dairy Association Ltd has approved a big programme of modernisation estimated to cost £200,000, to include the erection of a new £100,000,fac tory in Rockhampton, is pleas .ing news to all who are share

holders In the prosperity of the district. Such expansion proves that the industry has faith Mi - Itself, and is testimony to the

importance to which it has grown in recent years. Today dairying is one of our .basic: securities. It has brought con sistent prosperity to the small landowner and, despite Its ups and downs,-has survived where some others have failed. Its

steady growth Is the kind that I sends its roots deep down and j

becomes permanent. --

It is interesting to recall that this great industry had its birth at Matcham, near Grace mere, towards the end of the

last century. Messrs Archer j Bros introduced Ayrshire cows to meet the milk needs of the growing city of Rockhampton, and surplus milk was made into butter at Matcham before refrigeration was introduced to Central Queensland. A butter factory was buiit at Cap&la about the beginning of the cen

|tury. Messrs Conaghan Bros commenced commercial ice manufacture and butter mak ing in Rockhampton in 1904. From these small, hazardous beginnings the industry has grown to one of the greatest Importance. Today, butter, milk, cheese and ice cream are processed and the 2614 sup pliers are paid over £2,51)0,000

for raw cream and milk. Hje Association annually manufac tures 7000 tons of butter and 328 tons of cheese. Suppliers are paid £103,748 for milk for pasteurisation.

In these days of high cost manufacture and living the milk producer's success de pends upon his ability to pro cess cheaply and'to market all he produces. Allied to such fundamental things are . the uses to which milk can be put. In the last-named connexion there has been a tremendous expansion in pasteurised milk and ice cream consump tion in the last decade. But such things are comparatively simple and, scarcely new. So' to kee£> pace with the demands

of .other industries and to ex pand the uses of milk, the in dustry has followed the coal, oil and soya bean producer and taken milk to bits. It is from its by-products and constitu ents that new outlets are found.

articleText:
f.1^4fcfTl j

*'.{£ B l>c k fa a m p «

"* x^ ' BCWKEM0tt»T0N/^Y,J.

HARDER WORK WOULD OMAR THE ROAD

AUSTRALIA Mid other Com*

fri^ireidtb countries will be

Miked bluntly how far they are prepared to help Britain and the Copimonwealth sterl ing pool. Canberra' political Circles. . are canvassing 4he likelihood of Mr. Chlfley going to Londbn, and this is inter t'l'ntea M an indication that;

the Outlook must be particu larly grave. The London re ports that'Australia's tobacco,, petrol, films and 'raw mat erials may be affected have caused ^alarm, '

Tbe first impulse'may be to brush these things aside as 'something to exercise the minds only of financiers and economists, and as> having little concern for the man inl thestreet. That would be thej gravest possible error. The man in the street may not understand the dollar ques» U6n any more than he under stood the economic forces that brought about the depression, but he can not escape their effects. And when such a confirmed . stay-at-home as the Prime

Minister 4s contemplating a

second visit to England with in three months it piust be realised that whatever is hap pening In Britain to-day has a very vital meaning to Aus tralia and its people. , '

Admitting a complete grasp of the dollar position and its Implications to Australia, the first question that arises is what 'can be done to meet the . situation 'tot; combat its pos

sible .effects? The answer is that Australia must set about producing more of the things that other countries, especial ly dollar countries, are pre pared to take from us. Fur ther we must produce at a cost that will encourage them to buy. The time is passing, If It has not already passed, When overseas countries are so starved of the things which Australia can provide that

they are prepared to take them at any price. J

la future we must produce wool and wheat and,, dairy produce and other exportable commodities, including sted and goods, In greatw qu*ntltjrt>aixl at rea*

sonatde^^ «2^'be prepMed

to transput and ship them with promptness and 'tie* epateh. We must endeavour to capture and bold fresh markets whilst there is oppor tunity to do so. All the open* lags for expanded trade have not yet been filled, though we seem to be doing our best to close the door to friendly trdbe relations with our near est neighbours. The other day-a visiting South African Parliamentarian pointed to the opportunities for a larger volume of trade with tbat country if we went out after it. One of the products he spec ially mentioned was steel, but Just now Australia would ap pear to be out to destroy its iron and steel industry if it is humanly possible.

This greater production at competitive prices must fail of achievement so long as there is a continuance of strikes and stoppages in in dustry such as Australia has experienced ever since the war, and which has reached its peak with the current gen eral stoppage due to the coal strike. Today v Australia should be bracing up to what ever may be in store for us from the dollar crisis, instead of which we are flat out to bring all production to a standstill and to create con ditions from which recovery will be long and costly. The incredible thing is that work ers who will suffe^ most from

an economic set-back are tolerant of, if not aiding and abetting, the men who are fashioning this rod for their

backs.
heading: THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD Rockhampton ROCKHAMPTON, JULY 7. HARDER WORK WOULD CLEAR THE ROAD
snippet: AUSTRALIA and other Commonwealth countries will be asked bluntly how far they are prepared to help Britain

articleText:
THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD

R o c k fa am ptoo

THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 3,

Employment For The Middle Aged

A RECENT canvass of em

ployment officers, welfare workers, union officials and business men in Sydney re vealed that many employers are prejudiced against taking on men over 40, so that the latter are finding It increas

ingly hard to get Jobs. The chief employment officer of the R8L says that a steady stream of men over 40-26 per cent of all who apply-come to the bureau each month - for employment and some .diffi culty Is experienced in placing them. The Regional Director of Commonwealth Employment Service reports the demand for young workers to be roost acute, but older men, partic ularly those over 50, are hard to place. The general position is that many men over 40 find It difficult, but the biggest per centage ultimately manage to get Jobs.' ?

Whilst all were agreed as to the position none ventured to offer a specific reason', ex cepting an AWU secretary. He characteristically was prepared to lay the whole blame on the shoulders of employers, charg ing them with seeking the en gagement of youths of 20 "be cause they did as much work at less pay" than the older men. That biassed theory will not .be supported generally, and least of all by employers. If union leaders were to ex amine the mote in their own eye they might be able to sup ply some contributing causes. As a fact, average middle-aged Australians who have not abused their health are to all intents and purposes young men, alert, active, experienced and as physically fit as many men half their age. As for re

liability on the Job and will ingness to give the best of which they are capable, the war record of middle-aged men and women who kept the wheels of industry moving when the younger, elements were absent on war service, speaks for itself. A good many managers of Industrial plants and buslnessess would like again to be enjoying those hannontous, if more strenuous

times.

Middle agers of both sexes

should be able to procure em ployment in Australia today without having to conceal their age and resort to hair dyes, whilst they allege that employ ers are "going on their knees supplicating the services of teenagers who prance about from one place of employment to another through sheer rest lessness, or to enjoy more lav ish amenities."

Meanwhile there goes forth appeals to "save" children of school-leaving age from enter ing dead-end Jobs. Parents are being charged with "short sighted selfishness" in allowing their children to thus cut short their schooling, to take one of the well-paid Jobs offering in such abundance. On behalf of the parents It might be urged that with many of theta It is much less a matter of short sightedness and selfishness than of necessity, though It Is probably true, as asserted by Archbishop Duhig, that thous ands of gifted youths are drift ing yearly Into unsuitable oc cupations little calculated to benefit themselves or their country.

On the face of these things Australia would appear to be heading for a state when the elderly - and largest-section of the community will be on the pension, the middle-aged * are unable to secure employ ment, and the youth of the country has gone htto dead end work. What a picture to present after" 60 years of trades

union effort for the betterment of the workers; iti view of the Government's much vaunted full employment; and consider ing the surfeit of tribunals of one kind and another designed to improve the social and in

dustrial mechanism)

In a better ordered State the talented youth of the country would be absorbed into oc cupations for which they are fitted, the middle-aged would have no need to lie about their age and dye their hair to sec ure Job* which they are as well equipped as ever to perform, and the elderly would not be counting the days that wilt make them eligible for the pension.

"Advance Australia**-But Whither?

'JTTREE years ago the Prime

Minister prophesied that Australia was about to embarlr on a Golden Age. What has happened to that confident prediction ? Are we on the way to its realisation In our economic, political and social life, in the growth of our in ternational stature and the advancement of our cultures ? It Is true that, due to the prices which our expdrt com modities command, we are rid ing on a wave of unexampled prosperity, but there are fre cuent warnings that it cannot last and the placing of leisure before work lends little encour agement to the hope that we are on the way to a contented social life. Undoubtedly our international stature has grown tut it has been at the expense of drifting away from our kinsmen and friends and lin ing up with elements which, rightly or wrongly, are blamed for much of today's world un rest. Culturally. Australia Day this year coincides with the reactionary step of bar ring all but a few foreign born from admission to the musical, ranks of the Commonwealth.

On these and other matters, warnings that all Is not well with Australia are coming from far too many quarters to be ignored. The time has come when the question to what is wrong must be faced. We can not hope to drift along on a

tide of superficial prosperity. Greater and stronger nations have foundered on those rocks. Lacking from the Australian scene today is the sturdy in dependence of the pioneer, the spirit of service and sacrifice shown by our young men in two world wars; leisure is pre ferred to work; we think all is well because national Income continues to rise, our export products achieve new high levels and full employment is boasted of, whilst overlooking that insufficient coal is pro duced for national needs, the disastrous effect of the 40 hour week on production, the machinations of Communists and the indiscipline of labour generally; also the acceptance, of discomforts and shortages rather than make any effort to overcome them. There is a poverty In political leader ship and a general failure to assume the responsibilities of citizenship.

This broadly is where we stand on Australia Day, 1949. If the thoughts of the com munity are deeply stirred to day, it will not be by any inspiring messages from the national leaders, but by the knowledge that we again lead the world by paying treble time for work of national need. In thesa circumstances the national slogan " Advance

Australia Fair" carries a ring of mockery.
heading: THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD Rockhampton THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 3, Employment For The Middle Aged
snippet: A RECENT canvass of employment officers, welfare workers, union officials and business men in Sydney

articleText:
| THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD {

Rockbampton

THURSDAV, JANUARY 13.

PARTY SCRAPPING IN ELECTION YEAR

TN Queensland the dispute A over the number of seats to be contested by .Liberal and C.P. candidates respectively under the Federal redistribu tion 1b stlU unsettled, despite the pressing need to have an nounced the names of candi dates. WhrV;»p the Liberal or

Country nYdis should put up the greater number of candi dates Is a question which prac tically the whole of the rank and file of their supporters and

the middle-of-the-road voters who are eager to turn out the Chifley Government do not care a rap. If asked to point to differences in policy on any material bolnt it is doubtful if any of them could do so; Indeed, the same would apply to a good many of the people who are stirring the embers of disagreement. The fact is ' there are no essential differ

ences, and the only irrecon cilable elements are personal feelings or the vested interest of rival political machines.#

In Victoria Liberal-Country Party differences have assumed a more acute form, to the point of an almost open de - fetation of war. Whether or f not the CP. Acting-Premier

handled the recent industrial

crisis competently, or the Lib eral Premier (Mr Hollway) "sold out" when he returned from abroad and took over, is not now a matter of great Im portance to anyone, but the hard feelings engendered in ministerial ranks persist, de spite the lapse of sufficient time for everyone to cool off.

The Victorian Parliament is in recess, but matters are ex pected to come to a head as soon as the legislature reas sembles. Indeed, a lot of back stage work Is allegedly going on and In spite of the most emphatic denials the charge is made that there has been some dickering between Country Party and Labour interests with the aim of ending Mr Hollway's reign. Whatever truth lies In these charges, the fact that the wily ex-Premier Dunsten Is Involved Is bound to endow them with some col our. Th$t Premier Hollway has some pretty convincing evi dence on the point Is the only explanation that can be offered for the drastic course which the Liberal .Party announced; Le, precipitating an election and contesting all seats against both Labour and Country Party.

SOME "IFS" THAT SPELL PROSPERITY

?A USTRALIAN8 can consider

themselves among the moat fortunate of civilised peoples. Other less favoured nations envy us. Moreover, they want ail the food and other com modities we can produce for export Most of the things we lack ourselves could be bad by a little more effort on pur nart. A year free of stoppage* on the coalfields would get sufficient coal to feed the power plants aad keep' the manufacturing works operating at capacity. If the steelworks and other manufacturing resources were allowed to perate without In terruption there would be no occasion to restrict building en terprises and public works. If there were fewer hold-ups on the wharves, and the unload ing and loadir', of ships went on uninterruptedly and at a reasonable pace, there would be a freer distribution of the things which the community requires. Above all there W"ild be no occasion for 'Australia, as she is now compelled to do, to go to other countries, in a worse position to supply them than ve ourselves should be, for cement and steel to permit

carrying out essential work*. Instead of Australia having to go to Belgium and France and other war-Tom countries for these things <ve should be supplying them.

In the lace of such condi tions the odds would seem to be against Australia taking ^ad vantage of a new era of pros perity comparable with the gold rush days, assuming such an era Invites exploitation. No part of the Commonwealth is better able than Rockhamp ton to provide an Illustration of the type of people who made the gold rush epoch. Zt was the courage and determina tion to seise, and to make; op portunities by the hardy re sourceful people left stranded after the Canoona gold rush, that gave this city its greatest impetus and developed the dis trict more rapidly and to a greater degree than would have 'occurred under normal condi tions. Many of these pioneers were Australian-born, but many more came from distant lands. They had to light to sur vive. What would be the re action of this generation in 'similar circumstances?

WHAT HAS TEMPERANCE TO OFFER ?

TT temperance-a vague In*

conclusive term-is losing pound It la because In face of j a vast thirst it offers nothing j on a scale approaching that of j "liquor interests" organisation to alleviate It. Australia is n thirsty land, and all da; and every day there are millions of people who are unable to ob tain a cheap, cold, satisfying, healthy drink. This presents to temperance interests a vast

opportunity to supply just that; kind of drink, and thus place themselves In the role of min is Urine angels instead of waging a formless war against "drink." Every year many hundreds of tons of good fruit art taken to dumps all over Australia, when thousands of gallons of fresh fruit drinks might be expressed therefrom. Millions of gallons of skimmed milk go to waste yearly when they could be utilised to build up young Australians. The op portunities on offer to quench

the great Australian thirst arc breath-taking, but so long as they remain unexploited on a nation-wide scale, so long will the publican remain a move Ahead of the temperance re former.

If truth there be in statis tics and 111 there be In beer, the Australian is drinking more of that glib liquid than Is good, not only for him but lor fu ture generations. They also re veal that If reformers have no better way to combat the evil than that used in the past, they will have but little option to letting the Australian com munity drift comfortably to perdition on a growing malty stream. On the other hand,, the publican can be put In his proper place and a health giving service of vast magni tude rendered to the Australian community If temperance re formers will accept the chal lenge of the great, but very natural Australian thirst.

articleText:
THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND BERALD

GRAZIERS AND CLOSER SETTLEMENT

Jj «wsi»APER readers open

ing their papers one day last week could be ex cused if they turned bade to fe-read a news item Appearling under the head line: "Graziers Urge Closer Settlement." Perusing fur ther they would have learn* *d that a meeting of the Graders' Association of south-western Queensland held at Toowoomba. a'motion was! canted urging "that the land ownfed and leased by the Bri

tish Food Corporation inj

Queensland be made available for closer settlement, includ

ing soldier settlement, on thei ground that private enterprise I

is more efficient than Govern ment operated business under taking*. "

Taking it at face value thl« attitude of the south-western graziers towards closer settle ment suggests one of the most startling conversion* since St Paul. Indeed one suspects that the pronounce ment is one that may arouse rude questionings amongst graders in other section* of the State and Common wealth; especially it it pre sumes to speak for them all The fact is, that the pastoral lst and grazier, individually and collectively, never has been a champion of closer settlement. Quibe the reverse In fact, and some of the less* to-be admired phases of the country's land development has had to do with the acqui sition, holding on to and re sistance to releasing large tracts of country that were being put to less than their full use. Zt took many yean of advocacy and a good deal of persistence on the part ot successive Governments to bring in more enlightened and progressive land laws. Nor has the ultimate goal yet been reached, for there la still a considerable area in Australia lending itself to similar treat ment-and it is not all situa ted in the mid-west of Central Queensland.

The ostensible ground for the Toowoomba resolution was

that "private enterprise is

more efficient than Govern ment operated business under takings." Whilst that may hold good as a general prin ciple the south-western gra ziers might be at some loss to prove their point in the case of the " land acauired by the British Pood Corporation. It is Just~100 years since explor ers went through the country under discussion, and for two thirds of the intervening period the area was in the hands of private owners, yet they had made such use

of It and vert sollttte ac quainted with Its potentiali ties that they showed the eagerness to sell out to the .Corporation. Nor have them selves given any Indication of regretting the transaction Which fact makes It all the .nore extraordinary that others outside . the district Should be worrying over it. Is it out of consideration' for the British taxpayer, who will have to pay the piper for any miscalculation on the part of the sponsors of the scheme, or for some other reasq» that Is less apparent and perhaps less laudable."

It will not escape notice that this proposal to make over the British Food Corpor ation's purchase! to closer settlement emanates from the graaiers of the south-west who, in any case, have no connexion with the central mid-west They are not advocating closer settlement, for soldiers or anv one else, in their own region. Zs It because they wish to re tain Intact their own holdings, Whilst satisfying the needs of the landless at the expense of someone who has bought and paid his price, and is putting the land to the uses for which he bought it-the raising of food for Britain?

But it will be trusted this Is not the underlying motive of the graders' resolution, which has somehow a familiar ring about it. It.recalls the criti cism, not to say open hostility, towards the Food Corpora tion's operations that has oeen manifest in southern Queensland for some time past, particularly amongst cer tain State Parliamentarians representing rural constituen cies. It would appear that Queensland's contribution to wards the campaign of provi ding more food for Britain is a very line thing so long as none but the present produ cers are required to produce It When the waterside or mine workers insist that they and they alone shall do -certain work regardless of who else may be prejudiced, there Is a cry to high Heaven of the in iquity of such things. Hie general attitude of certain politicians, and now of the South-Western graziers to wards the operations of the Food Corporation-which in cidentally has done much for the benefit of local graders by showing them what grain sor ghum can mean to thena in the way of drought insurance and stock fattening-suggests that they are somewhat in need of observing the injunc tion to remove the mote from their own eye.
heading: THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD Rockhampton ROCKHAMPTON, AUGUST 4. GRAZIERS AND CLOSER SETTLEMENT
snippet: NEWSPAPER readers opening their papers one day last week could be excused if they turned back
