articleText:
Boelt bam pion

THURSDAY. AUGUST 18, IMP.

4* ?? ? ?? mj m -?

NEWCOMERS ARE NEW AUSTRALIANS

A large number of' people ^wfao have some difficulty In finding themselves In agree* ment with Mr Calwell Odin later for Migration) will en*, dorse tils pronouncement tn respect of displaced persons1 and otbe? migrants who are about to begin a new lite in Australia. Speaking at Can berra last week he de clared that expressions such as "Baits," "Displaced Per

sons" and "DP6" should be I outlawed. j

Once they reach Australia,!

Mr Calwell holds, these people j are no longer displaced per-1 sons, but ore "newcomers,":

"new settlers," or,. preferably,]

"new Australians." The dan ger of perpetuating the terms now used is that in time they can take on the unpleasant; undertone of such words as j "Dago," "RefTo" and the like, ! and this must prove inimical to the smooth assimilation ol the newcomers. The Immi gration Department has given instructions that terms "Salts," "Displace! Persons," etc., must not be used in official com* municatlons. "The Australian people," says Mr Gatwell, "have already given an example to the world in their friendly re ception to these rrew settlers. Let us make that reception even more pleasing to the 'newcomers by avoiding the use of these ^expressions, which can, be distasteful to them and det rimental to the best interests of the nation."

This is'a very wholsome sen timent and is deserving of the widest propagation. From the general body . of Australian people it will meet with ready acceptance. If we have fallen into the habit of alluding to the* new arrivals as "Baits"

and "DPs" lt~ has hpea un consciously brought about 6ua ply by acceptance of terms Currently used. But there are now 60,000 of these people in Australia, and they are still coming in," as they will con tinue to do for a long time, it is desirable that tiieybe assimi lated into the life of the com munity as thoroughly as pos sible, to which end erery ob stacle tnust be removed.

The tehn New Australia* is a happy suggestion and should appeal both to the/ migrant who aims to commence a new life here, and also to the "old" Australian, to whom it implies a kind of "big brother" respon sibility, which is by no means displeasing. Thefe will be no difficulty about bodies such as the New Settlers' League and various social and religious or ganisations concerned with the reception of migrants to fall into line with the Department of Immigration in eschewing the terms "Bait" and "DP." It may not be so readily adopt* ed by some other elements in the community, over which the Minister for Migration and his colleagues should have some influence. There has been a lukewarmness, sometimes open antagonism, in the atti tude of certain union leaders Cowards the Baltic folk in par ticular. They have done their best, and with almost com plete success, towards keeping them out of key industries such as coalmining, iron and steel and bwlWlng trades. Such

discrlmir ' .i ,)ifi^le to do mow tipper added

traliatm waiter planted thief'f adoptive restaurant of the i ^ difficult . ?*>$ i&tttsr ip j ti<j could be pinned on to %j

from thoughtlessness, lgn«i ca

ance .or ipalice. . ^

articleText:
TBE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD

ft oek b a mptoQ

, THXJR8DAY, SEPTSMBBR 16

; .- . r - ~i ? r ? ; ? -

THE "PEOPLE'S" BANK AS PHOFiT-MAKtfR

'THE Commonwealth (Peo

ple?* Bank, established to function-tn the quaint jargon o( Labour purveyors of the Golden Age-"for use and not tor profit" - disgraced the Socialist cause last year fey turning In a profit of £6,244,198 on a capital of - £17,161,178, which Is near enough to 36 per cent per annum to satisfy even the hungriest profiteer. It truth there ' be In the changes levelled against jthe private banks this profit comes from the pockets of the people ot Australia, and- nobody else. Two-thirds of it comes from the note issue, now-lour years after the end of flghttag higher than ever before, ifttlcfe gtfea to show that the

ittbterranean black market is thriving even more happily than ever. Without resorting to clumsy barter, the black marketeer could not operate without ample supplies of of ficial bank notes, and the Commonwealth Bank has is sued into hot, , unhallowed . hands nearly five times more

notes, than sufficed to carry on tig* legitimate business of Aus tralia In 1830. Nothing thrives under Labour quite- so luxur iously as underground ramps, and nothing is more merciless ly "slugged" than legitimate companies, that provide the major portion of employment.

St might be argued that while the "People's" bank ir»de .financial hay tn all r sathers last year, much-curs ed private banks did . them selves as well-or even better. Unfortunately, the latest comparable figures are for 1947-most official statistics are least two years astern ct current happenings-when the tilne trading banks with a capital of £73,540,000 turned In a profit of £2,830,872, or a, mere 3JB per cent The "People's" bank, on the other hand, with a capital of £16, 390,000, turned in a profit of £6,083,493 or a beggarly-com pared with this year-81 per cent! : C

Another point of argument Is that because more is heard about it the Commonwealth ("People's") bank is doing all the .business, spreading Its benefits over a felder surface and raking in its profits from a greater number of people. [Anything is good enough If It Is sufficiently plausible to ccpfttse the popular mind

about election time-andthls is abouts election time. Based upon deposits,' confluence of the people in'bankingsystems Is expressed in willingness to entrust their spare maney to

strangers. On this bjf m the predominating and ffiOrtfesing tendency of people is to by pass the "People's" bank and repose their .faith In the mucb-malignea private banks. This Is. rewe&led in that in 1946 private banks. held P1.4 per cent ..of the total £683,800,000 deposits In cheque paying banks, and at the end of June last they held 92.9 per cent of the total £887,300,000 deposits in all cheque-paying banks. That means that, .while the Commonwealth Bank In creased its deposits-many of them from governmental and semi-governmental customers -by £11,700,000 the nine trad ing banks Increased theirs by £191,800,000. This Is despite the fact-or,'maybe, because of It -that the "People's" bank Is empowered under the 1945 Banking Act to supervise pri vate bonks, and push, them around generally. It may "draw off from the banking system" considerable part of their de posits-It held £381,200,000 of them at the end of June last -on which it pays 15/- per -ent interest; but when any trading bank is In urgent need of funds it may be "granted short-period Central Bank loans at a rate. of in terest-3i per cent at present -designed primarily to dis courage reliance on this form of finance." That Is. to my. It costs a private bank 2i per cent per annum to use what Is virtually Its own »money 1

I

articleText:
] THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD \

LINES FOR COTTON INDUSTRY INQUIRY

A COORDINO to Senator

Courtice he hcus given "a

high priority io a TariB Board inquiry into the re habilitation of the cotton industry." That statement could be taken to mean that Uie Australian history of the industry is to be probed to ascertain what it was that caused cotton-growing to droop and so need rehabilitation; but being election ye?.r it is much more likely to mean finding an e:.cu:;e for pouring om more taxpayers' money to in duce unsuspecting farmers to walk into the disaster v.h'ch overtook so many of their pre decessors. If (he intention is to ascertain why cotton, after 25 years of aids of varying kinds, is u?iuble to provide the grower with a living, then some heed should be paid to official sta tisUcfl.

Foremost among these re cords is the fact that avcvagcci over the 11 years 1916-26 the yield of cotton whs 376.8 lb. per acrc, six of the ysars averag ing more than 300 lb. per acr* nnd the other five years under that figure Eleven years later -1526-3$-the yield per acr: ha<5 increased by 20 percent v> 451.8 lb. per acre, there being nine years with a yield of over 400 lb. per acre and only two under that figure. In ths fol lowing 10 years 1937-45 the averase yield dropped by 38 per cent to 277.4 lb. per acre, there being only three years with returns of over 3t)0 lb. per acrc, and seven yean: vith yields under that figure. 0>ver practically the whole-«f not all-of ft period of 22 years attempts have been made at the BUoela Regional Experi mental Station presumably tc breed a cotton plant into thu Australian environment, with v. hat results the Common wealth Statistician reverJs in this paragraph, i.e., over 33

years of cotton growing, mostly' In Queensland, the yield per acre has dropped by 26 per cent I

One hope for cotton growing in Australia is to determine if the plant cannot Ik grown on the uplands behind Newcastle and Sydney. According to lati tude, that is much nearer to the cilmatologlcal environment of all cotton growing in Amer ica, though the manager of the Queensland Cotton Board ap pears not to have realised th«t during his visit there last year If he had discovered that Uncle Sara grows most of his cotton upwards of 1000 miles nearer the Pole than we have tried for 25 pears to grow ourv there would be far less need now for Senator Courtice'* costly probe into a "problem" that the Commonwealth Sta tistician goes so far to solv° He cannot hope to "rehabili tate" a plant that, with In creasing persistence, refuses to grow, or having grown,(is im mediately devoured by Insect.* One obvious thing is to trv growing it in areas with win ters of sufficient Severity to prevent the over-wintering of insect pests.

Twenty-five years ago we had high hopes for the cotton* industry, but just as growers were unable to stand against the disabilities which availed their industry, so have we been compelled to accept the verdict of those 25 years of grim ex perience. We would be as pleased today as then to see cotton a thriving industry, but no industry can thrive if It stands on any feet but Its own and despite the harrowing agony of thousands of broken men, 25 years of bleeding th>> taxpayer and as many years of earnest effort of Biloela plant breeders, cotton shows no signs of'having a stable economy, based upon the correct environ ment for a plant of its kind.

RIDING HIGHER OIS THE SHEEP'S BACK

tjyiE atmosphere surrounding

Xvaol nnd sheep dealings to day is reminiscent of a gold fcoam, and not the transactions of a settled Industry whose re turns and hazards have teen established by Jong experience. Heticc it is natural that many people. In and outside the world of commerce, are pre dicting that trns kind of thing

cannot go on. and that the market will one day break and uaher in the debacle.

In view of these apprehen sions it Is surprising to And competent opinion holding that the high values will continue for at least some Mine to come. One who holds that view is Dr Booth, w'.»o has just retired frotn the chairmanship of the i International Wool Secretariat,

and returns to Australia with cheery predictions about long * term prospects for wool. The

value for this season's clip 1} estimated to be about £186,000, 000, as against £155,000,000 last year. These figures are bas:d on an estimated production of 3,180,000 bales, and Or Bsoth says there is no reason why Australia should not produce £200.000,000 worth of wool an nually. As to our capacity to grow that quantity there should be little question. The 3,163,000 bales marketed this year will come from approximately 102, 000,000 sheep. This year pro duction is 548,212 bales less than the record established in 1843-4 and the number of sheep on the runs Is 23,000,003 fewer than the record flocks cf 1J41.

Perhaps the strongest point favouring a continuance of'the keen demand and high prices is th&t all the ?lne merino wool, of .which Australia Is the prin cipal grower, has been sold frotn the stock plies accumu lated during the war. Con sumption needs for merino wool are 40 per cent above the qufthtlty toeing produced, while the d.emand for all types of wool Is 20 per cent above pro duction. Underlying assump tions are that the spending power of wool-buying countries will not give out, and that*no Independent substitutes can be produced on a large enough scale and cheaply enough to

Arc consuming public will be

.j ' J-j

able and willing to purchase the finished goods at the price 1 which must be asked for them. If the cost of the raw material goes on mounting the time can be foreseen when woollen fab rics will become prohibitive for many of those who have helped towards their popularity in the past. The trend in men's suit ings is a case in print.

Incidentally, it would be or Interest to read the present thoughts of Australian State governments and their coun sellors on price control who re cently ordered a reduction of 71 per cent in the retail price of soft goods, since many of the lines affected must contain wool. The creation -of new wool-selling records following hard upon the heels of this mandatory reduction lays em phasis upon the futility of at tempting to ccntrol the price of the finished product whilst leaving raw material to soar. Townsville is without meat to day because. someone believes that the price of meat over the counter can be controlled with out regulating the cost of cattle on the hoof.

However, in the face of such authoritative opinion as the chairman of the Wool Secre tariat and the statistical posi tion of the industry, it is dif ficult to take a pessimistic view on the future of wool. At the same time it may oe as well to take a glance at an other commodity, which has been riding on the crest of the wave, and now looks like hav ing to face less favourable con ditions. Australian wheat has been selling to Britain at 17/6 per bushel, but owing tp better harvests in Europe and other countries, no desire is being shown by the British food au thorities to renew at that price. There is also a feeling that, for this season's surplus, we may be lucky to get 12/6, whilst some forecasts go lower.

Warnings have been plenti ful that Australia's greatest era of prosperity will recede when the prices being paid overseas for our wool and wheat drop to lower levels. Wheat appar ently is on the way down, but in the case of wool it seems certain that we will continue to ride-«ventb jovrlde--ML

to oomt.,

articleText:
- * I

THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD [

fiockbamptoo

THURSDAY, MARCH 3.

DETERMINED STEP FOR NEW STATES

ALTHOUGH New States Is

not a live question today in Central Queensland, its birth place - even the recent ABO forum of the air debate felled to do more than arouse a ripple of-Interest-the Northern NSW New State convention held at Armldale last week will arouse sympathetic interest amongst a large number of people In this division. There can be no question of the serious purpose of the convention, and lte de termination to force the Issue

hat endowed the New States i movement with more vitality than it has ever Shown before. Success in the creation of a new State In northern NSW would have a tremendous In fluence on .the rest of Aus

«

tralla and would doubtless start off many other regions on a similar quest.

One thing the convention re vealed, outside the Immediate question, was that the drift from country to city is much more serious than is shown by the census returns. It was declared that the Northern region of NSW did not gain 4667 people as the census showed, out had actually lost 76,000 of whom most had mi grated to the metropolis.

The Northern .New state convention was a serious as sembly, and clearly emerging from it is «vidence that the most serious effort to secure new' States in Australia is about to be made.

TEST CASE FOR DECENTRALISATION

i

TT wh carried by the O.Q.

Advancement League at Its last meeting to write the Hon. J. I-ui combe, State 1re.u>irw nt»d member (nr Rocstiampton, asking him to Iniorm the Lea gue In What Specific manner the State Government hid moved towards the implemen tation of its professed policy of decentralisation of Industry, fend what, If any. were its plans for the future. The point Wus well taken. Before and since the close of the war both Fed* eral and State Governments have proclaimed that, for eco nomic and defence reasons alone, their one great aim and desire is to see Australian in dustry decentralised; factories established In other than ur ban areas and a better balance of population maintained. Al most in the next breath the prophets of decentralisation are proclaiming the acquisition or some new enterprise by one or other of the capitals, secur ed invariably by the Federal Government making available at nominal charge the site an1 buildings of some wartime es

tablishment.

At the end of the war Hock hampton also had a large number of war buildings, some of which could have formed the- nucleus of a factory, but instead of any effort being made to that end they were promptly placed under the hammer and have been demol ished or removed whilst those at Rocklea, and other centres, can still be offered, as was done by the Premier only last week, as an inducement to a new enterprise to'take up Its

home there.

Hit present is an appropri ate time to take up this mat

ter with the State Govern ment because of another de velopment project that came before the League at its last meeting. This is the opening up of the far western Channel country by rail communication in -order to bring into use the vast areas of rich fattening country known to exist there, the utilisation of which Is held up mainly through lack of transport. The figures quoted concerning the turn-off of fat cattle, provided stores can be got In and the fats taken oif promptly, are almost incred ible; yet they are attested by competent people In the live stock business who have made first hand examination.

Today, when cattle have to be walked in and out over dis tances as far as 600 miles, the turn-off of fat cattle from the Channel country Is approxi mately 26,000 head annually. Given rail communication so that stores can be taken from the Far North and Territory in a matter of days where it now takes many weeks, the num bers can be increased to 400,000

after a normal flood year, -ris ing to 600,000 and even 800,000 in a flush season after a major flood in the rivers which water this atnadng tract When It is realised that the total, kill at Lakes Creek is about 120,000 head a year, and that at Glad stone considerably less, the im portance of bringing the Chan nel country into fuller use be comes self evident. The cen tral meatworks would not, of course, take all the fat cattle turned off, but they would have access to an additional source of supply which would guaran tee greater continuity of opera tions and minimise. If not to tally avoid, the present bug-, bear of the meat packing in dustry-a peak season for a few months and then men laid off and jriant idle.

Here then is a golden oppor- ' tunlty for both State and Fed eral Governments to render

something more than lip ser- - vice to the principle of decen tralisation of industry. If we cannot - share in the new fac tories we at least have a right to processing the primary pro ducts raised in our region. The case for access to this source of raw material for the meat wtorks Is strengthened by Its link with the British Food Mission's pig meats project. Pigs cannot be fattened on grain alone. They must have a meatmeal .ration and It ta questionable whether the large quantity that soon will be re quired can be derived from the present meatworks killings. Hence the need for opening up this country to raise the large number of additional fits that it would make available.

TTie immediate object Is to get the Yaraka-Wlndorah ex tension completed, *> that stores can be taken in and fats brought out in a minimum of time. It would not be a substi tute for the bigger scheme of uniting the Channel country with a strategic railway, but if would form part of that scheme. It may be tnany years before Federal and State Gov ernments are agreed on a Joint undertaking, but in the mean time the Yaraka-Windorah ex tension could be gpne oh with.

The Advancement league will be wise in linking Its re quest with decentralisation of industry. It will at least either test the bona fides of the Gov ernments or expose their pro fessions as a sham. All possible local aid is to be enlisted and should be forthcoming. Reali sation of the scheme will mean more work and wages for meatworks, railwaymen and jothers and its influence on the commercial life of the central division must be tremendous. The part it could play in stem ming the drift to the cities and increasing rural population is not the least of the factors that can be urged in its favour.

articleText:
i TBE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND BERALD I

R'ockbamptoo

ROCKHAMPTON, JULY 21

COAL STRIKE RESULTS AND REMEDIES

I? VERY day the coal stop

page continues the losses snowball at a, rate that must speedily wipe out reserves, not only of soc ial service funds and private savings, but what Is of most vital concern, that of manu facturing and commercial or ganisations, which are the principal source of private em ployment. Practically all of them are endeavouring to hold on to their key operatives by keeping them employed on non-productive work. Even if they can continue to do this until the end of the strike they are faced with the prob lem of restarting and carry ing'on until business revives. The incidence of company taxation has prevented the ac cumulation of substantial re

serves, and financial circles' fear that, unless bank accom modation is made available, the smaller industries will re ceive an. irrecoverable blow which will be followed by sub sequent loss of employment.

In the meantime what is being done to remove the threats. The two Governments mainly concerned are still chasing a few thousand pounds that would never have left the banks if the Common wealth Government had not bungled the "freezing" opera tion by letting out its inten tions In time for the accounts to be. emptied. There is a timid move to bring into use a few thousand tons of coal

lying at grass, after first < stressing that it is "white" and not "black" coal, by reason of having been mined and loaded before the strike call went out. The Queensland State secretary of the AWU has is sued a valorous statement, de claring that his executive "will not hesitate to throw its weight on the side of the nat ion if the winning of addition al coal will ultimately save

Australia from Communist domination." There is some whittling down of the force of this anouncement when he adds that they have not yet considered the matter formal ly, "and it is safe to say we will not interfere unless production of additional coal becomes a

vlfa! factor in deciding the

the. fight between international Communism as expressed by certain officials of the Miners' Federation and the Australian people."

It is time someone reminded Mr Fallon and his executive!

that coal production in Aus-j tralla has already become more than a factor in deciding the fight against international Communism. It is vital to the solvency and economic exist ence of Australia and the well

being of its people. i

j There is one Government,

however, which has set about getting: coal for Its Industries and is making a good job of It South Australia, which has no jdeposlts of Its own to speak of, is standing up to the crisis better than any .of the other States, thanks to the vigorous action of its Government and -the coojveraticn of its workers. Always in the past, when there was a coal stoppage in NSW, South Australia was the first to feel its effect by way of unemployment and domes tic restrictions. AH that it had on hand to render itself in dependent of New South Wales was a despised brown coal deposit at Leigh Creek. Some years ago Premier Play ford . determined on the ex ploitation of this deposit for what it was worth. Today it is worth more to South Aus tralia than the much vaunted 90 ft open cut coal face at Blair Athol is to Queensland. Leigh Creek is worked by AWU members, who have stubornly resisted all attempts by the Miners' Federation to get a foothold. By working the round of the clocs since the strike, output has been trebled bringing it to one-third of the State's needs of fuel for pro duction of light and power.

This has enabled South Aus tralia to reopen 650 of its'fac* tories. Formerly Leigh Creek coal was unsuitable for rail way locomotives unless mixed with a proportion of NSW black coal. This has been overcome by simply spraying a small quantity of oil on a thin bed of burning coal in the Are box, thereby main taining steam pressure.' The cost of installation in labour

jand money is small. More en ' gines are being converted dally, so that the paralysis which threatened passenger and freight transport throughout the State has vir tually disappeared. The work ers in Adelaide have shown a1 spirit of cooperation by con senting to the general adop tion of a night-shift in factor ies and this has lightened the load on power supplies to a de gree where the introduction of a limited day shift is permis

sible.

South Australia has shown that the attack on the com munity, launched by the Com munists through the Miners' Federation, can .be beaten if it is tackled courageously and if:

the general body or workers' get a lead they can follow. It|

never will be beaten by Gov-i ernments who are looking overseas for coal, and by un ion leaders who will not give to their members the lead that is necessary to save Aus tralia and themselves from disaster.

TARIFF POLICIES AND THE DOLLAR

«pHE whole emphasis in the

periodic "dollar crisis"-we had one two years ago - is upon money which means nothing if it will purchase nothing, or if certain kinds of It retire from world com merce. If we are to have stable world commerce the emphasis must be on com modities, and commerce means tariffs which have been im posed for every reason that the wit of man could suggest or his malignity tlesign. By increasing the cost of goods, tariffs narrow down the circle of consumers. More money is required to purchase a given number of food calories or of square inches of body covering, and this condemns countless millions' whose money earn ings are low to exist below the bar of minimum nutrition and covering. They are so condem ed, not because of faulty la bour-which can be corrected -or because the given number of calories or square inches of covering h,.ve altered but be cauj p if »n entirely extraneous import or viff by which coun tries me, tor much longer thru good for humanity, foteht K-tti ':-s with each other. One <?( '.t.r most powerful fac tors :i i-'ie European Recovery Plan ir tvp-t it is based, not upon none - but upon com moJ :f«s-f<*»d calories and bod;.' ptc'e-: ion and not upon tart'f or l m-called "trade pro

tectic

3i ii" ,-reat mass of, cro

nouncements that have em anated from United Nations since the defeat of the Axis, international trade has ever

had an adequately important place. The International Trade Organisation is sufficient earn est of the fact that the na tions are agreed upon taking anarchy out of world trade relations, and the work of that body indicates that its members do not regard its functions as purely nominal. That being so. the constant emphasis upon the dollar sterling and the dark hints that Britain should devalue sterling are so many erratic kites, flown maybe for credu lous consumption, but indicat ing little of the actual current flowing beneath the surface. If the I.T.O. is not merely a I dead letter, then the wild] flurry over dollars is so much

[ political eyewash.

articleText:
Bockbamptoa

? ?

" THURSDAY, 8KTEMBER 29.

H ? 'I ' ii I i i ? 11? ii." I. I I'IIII i ' ff

mi - ? i ?? n ???»????? i ?!

WORLD FOOD PRODUCTION CAPACITY

TB the food producing jcapac

ity of the world declining? The chief avidence quoted In support of the contentlpn Is the 'danger or coll erosion. It Is true that fertile lands can . turn Into deserts; it has hap pened before and nothing has been done about it Today, however, there U such a thing as .reclamation, and protective measures against further en croachment are very much in evidence. The oft-quoted United ^ftates Dustbowl Is today growing more wheat than. before soil erosion was heard of In that coiwexion. Tht truth is that soil erosion is fib longer the menace to food production that it once w«i It has been so talked about, and so many influences have been stirred to , acton that the menace hfcs been ef fectively tackled.

?he. statement that there are no more potential sources of Jood supply left to tap is challenged. Various experts have estimated that about 30 per cent of the land surface of the globe i« climatically suited1 for food production, that about 10 per cent of it is & used, and about 4 per cent actually used for food crops. Hie possibilities for irrigation in njl'immense. Moreover tha land now farmed could produce much more than it does. Hie application to the whole world of fanning stand aids that now prevail in the most efficient Countries could possibly double the food sup

pi/. Behind these practices lie tfca- unefcplored front of science; the art of artificially stimulating fertility is still in its Infancy, and some biolog ists lielieve thfey are on the brink of some Jar reaching

dlsooveries.

Australia is* cited as an .nispte of an exporting coun- j try that is now eating its own1

food. During the war ' that ww partly true, but lack of overseas transport and a big: Influx of temporary popula tion had something to do with that. Since the»war plans are being made, jmd can be car ried out, for.. larger . exports thap ever.. Then there Is the argument that all oyer the World countries which were formerly content to be prim ary producers are industrial ising themselves, and that this will lead to less food produc tion. It is sot denied (bat many countries are industrial ising themselves, or that there Is a steady drift of population from the country to the towns; but that has been go ing on since man's advent on earth and It has been accom panied by a steady rise, not fall, in the output of agricul ture. «

The possibility of Britain, the world's* greatest buyer of

food, being unable to pay for more food imports is conceded, but tha effect of the swarming Asiatic* populations on the world's food resources Is dealt with by the statement that they can be the recipients of large - scale and continuous charity, or they can buy the food they want by sel ling to the food producers something of which they are In need. .On neither count is there at present any hopeful sign and the conclusion Is of fered that Asia' will have to solve her own problem-by birth control, by scientific agriculture, or by famine, finally the "Economist" be lieves It to be safe in saying that, In the world as a whole, the market In food will before long revert to Its -traditional state of supply in excels of 'effective demand. Man m* blow; himself up, " but he xv.

'not starve himself to death, j

aum NEW AUSTRALIANS FEEL AT HOME

yifJLTiuN Australia there ex

lata a lively appreciation of the responsibility devolving upon the present community to giro the Hew Aus tralians a warn and sin cere welcome and to as sist them in fitting into the life , of the community. These activities are open to expan sion in region* which have not yet, but soon must experience the Impaet of the migration flow. Hence a mwt that is to be commended is one aiming at co-ordinating the work of re ligious, citizen, settlers and patriotic organisations who want to help the immigrants to settle. To this end an Aus tralian Citizens' Convention -wlU.be held in Canberra - in January, to promote nation wide movements towards a deeper appreciation of the privileges and responsibilities of-Australia^ citizenship." It is hoped to establish good neigh bour committees in every town and settlement to assist in ths assimilation of the New Aus tralians into our way of lift..

The social and economic, consequences of the populatlc | drive will be big, and the prob

lems of absorption can be serl-j ous If there is no advanced planning to- minimise them. Such an objective is sound sociologically, end it has ' other recommendations that are obvious. We have every

thing to gain from a rapid: integration of the New Australians into our own way

of life. It must also be obvi- j ous that they will do their best j to facilitate this process if they i are made to feel that they are |

r wanted; that their fellow citl

fcens, already established, are anxious to help them; and that $hls Is their future home land hi the fullest sense. The more they are made to fee] and appreciate the privileges of Australian citizenship the readier will they be to accept lt& responsibilities.

A most gratifying factor is the production records of the newcomers since the first #atch of displaced persons ar rived in 1947. Perhaps the most exacting test as a work er to which a newcomsr to Australia could be put is that of cane cutting. To this in dustry the early arrivals from the Baltic States were al located. last, season they cut cane worth more than a mil lion pounds, and tided the cane industry ovter of its worst periods of labour shortage. Mi grant labour.has also Improved the output of cement, bricks, timber and other necessary commodities, and would have done much more had they been permitted to enter certain in dustries. One In every ten is engaged in nursing or domestic Work in hospitals and similar Institutions. . Nor must it be overlooked" that the wave of migration, if it involves somev temporary difficulties, will also bring numerous industrial Ad vantages to improve Australia's economic structure. The home market for necessities such as food, clothing and housing will naturally expand; there will be better scope for mass pro duction and a mora diversified industry is likely to result | from imported tastes.

articleText:
THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD

Boe It ir'a m p t~o a

THURSDAY,, September 32.

WEST'S WILD PIGS AND PIE MELONS

TN ,over *at least one-third

. of the arfea of the whoie < State - about 200J600 square tulles - the wild pig is in his most suitable . environ ment. It seems equally true that over quite a large part of that vast area from Hughen den in the north -to Goondi windl In the souths and from Torllla on the coast to Black all inland the pie-melon Is no less happily suited. There is also a patch of gherkin-like wild gourds In the Alpha area of which nobody seems to know either the area of the patch or the economic possi bilities of the fruit What wb do know, "however, is that whatever happens tp other domestic crops /and animals during drought, the wild pig and pie-melon survive to wel come, later incursions of ob servant folk who might read, from impressive signs, econom|c truths of vast Impor

tance. We know. that unless he was. shot the wild pig did not add his skeleton to the tragic array of those lately of sheep and cattle, and also that while drought and bush fires decimated forests and pastures the first rains brought along the pie melon, little the worse for Its experience.

Of the wild pig as human food there Is no question. In his correct class as either pork or bacon he concedes little to his more stodgy, domesticated brother. Of his numbers there is no estimate, but they must run into millions. Last year the Hughenden Shire Council made bonus payments on'2000 pig shouts, and In July last he was outlawed by the Duarlnga Shire Council, with no doubt a price upon his head-pr snout. Of the,' pie-melon as pig food there is even less question. While grazing is good . the wild pig will not trouble to break them open, merely turning to thenv-as do sheep-when grazing goes ofll. Nobody pretends that pork could be produced on a pie melon diet any more than It can on a purely grass ration. It has about two-thirds the nutritive value of pumpkin which is 89 per cent water

(

Yetfarmerawho grow pump kins lor pig feed are openly scornful of the. - pte-Jnelon which grows itself and while the pumpkin daring drought It unprocurable fit othiftc than prohibitive cost, the pie-melons litter the ground If there are ?ot wild pigs to eat them or sheep are too weak to break them open. :

. The truth is that both the pig and the pie-melon are In their correct environment and man has for many years dissi pated, his energies and sub stance In trying to produce beef and wool irom animals that are hot Heariy BO happily placed. Environment plays an enormously greater part in animal and vegetable life than i* credited to it in Australia,

where husbandry problems are: solved mostly by importing "newblood" which cures noth ing hut perpetuates the orig inal disabilities. Sheep walked into their environment! In a wide ranee of Australian con ditions, English cattle main tain their native characteris

tics for varying periods in dlf-j ferent parts of Australia, but never overcome the difference between their natural environ ment and that in any part of Australia. Sooner or later he has to be "pump primed" from

italn. The case of the horse even more pronounced, as less than one-third of race horses winning oVer £1000 In any year in stakes do not have one or other of their parents Imported.

It is not unlikely that the wild pig population of Queens land is 10 times that of hand fed pigs. He Is trying to prove to us that, from the. point of view of environment, freedom from disease and ability to sustain himself during the most rigorous of our climatic periods, he can not only sus tain life but, aided by the ple nrelon, can do "himself quite handsomely. He 1$ in fact try ing to proclaim, that as a po tential producer of the pig and his products, the State of Queensland haft no. peer, and purblind man refuses to be

lieve It.

articleText:
THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD

Boekbamptoa

THURSDAY, OCTOBER 20.

TARIFF BOARD'S RE?ORTs ON COTTON

p* a search of the entire

records of government in Australia were to be made it 1« doubtful if a parallel could be found for the Tariff Board's report on the cotton growing industry, which has been released at long last. It is one of the most abject con fessions of failure and lack of vision that could be cited in any connexion. If accepted as the final word the report means the end of cotton growing in Australia, for no "one will be jdecelved by the "at present" inserted to sugar coat the pill. This is a death blow and the Canberra Gov ernment intends it to be just

that.

"Cotton growing has for all practical purposes ceased in Queensland," says the report. "This result is not due to lack of assistance by the ..Com monwealth and State Govern

ments or to any lack of effort by the Queensland Department

of Agriculture or Cotton Mar- . keting Board, but to the fact that the farmers will not grow cottontwhile they receive, very

high prices for wheat, meat ; end dairy produce." Note how £11 responsibility is shifted from the Governments and neatly deposited on the shoul ders of the farmer. If it is true that cotton is not grown because better and more stable returns are procurable from wheat, meat and datry-prod uce does not that place the

responsibility fairly and . squarely on the shoulders of those whom the Tariff Board would exonerate?' Farmers have asked no more than that cotton shall be made a paying crop over-a specified perfed in order to give it the stability that is assured wheat, sugar, tobacco and other staple crops.

The Tariff Board's report, which is open to challenge both for its . conclusions and Its recommendations, and it might be added, for its con tradictions, professes to ex amine the changes put for ward as necessary to prevent a continuance of the decline and create an upward trend in production, namely, wider use of irrigation, mechanisation of methods of culture and har vesting, and a guaranteed price to the grower of 91d per lb of seed cotton. The answers come just a little too "pat." It is contended that present ir rigation plans are not designed for the cotton industry, and in any case the crop should be allied with dairying, so that any expansion would be 'more likel/ to occur in dry farming, areas; the saving from the use of move mechanical aids would be relatively small; the re-establishment of the indus try on the price level suggest ed would mean a costly outlay by the Commonwealth in the shape of subsidy or bounty. Moreover, it is considered that the maximum advantage in three years' time would be the production of about . 5 per cent of Australia's require

ments. '

Then follows this astound ing paragraph: "The granting of assistance on the scale re quested would tend to create the impression amongst those

engaged In the industry that as a commercial proposition It Is worth risk and outlay. The Board does not believe that it is" Yet after this damning conclusion concerning an es sential commodity of which more than £3,000,000 worth is imported each year, the state ment is made that "the Board has not failed to recognise the va}ue to Australia of a soundly established cotton industry and it admits that the education of farmers in the advantages of cotton growing must be the basis of any plans for stabil ity. . . Efforts to develop pro duction on the most efficient

lines should 3* be continued with the object of securing the highest possible yields per

acre "

Following these admissions, which reblly should have been the basis of constructive re commendations for the reha bilitation of the industry, 1t goes on to recommend with holding of any greater guar antee, the closure of the Gladstone and Rockhampton ginneries and storage of their machinery .at Whlnstanes, and the exploration of further economies at the latter mill. Thus the report blows hot and cold, $t one moment talking of educating the farmer and mating every effort to develop production on efficient lines, and then throwing buckets ot sold water around by remark ing that it would be foolish to lead anyone to believe the Industry can be made ai com mercial proposition. And there is the Board's concern for ex ercising economy In the inter ests of a Government which throws millions around as though the future did not exist On the very day that the Tariff Board delivered a death blow to cotton the Labour Caucus at Canberra approved legislation to place id per ton excise on coal In order to provide long service leave for coalminers, who al ready enjoy Conditions of em ployment that no cotton grower has ever dreamed of. No money can be spared to foster cotton growing whilst we import £3,000,000 worth an nually, much of it from dol lar countries, in' order to keep Australia's spinning mills go ing.

This, report cannot be ac septed, and must be challenged by every interest possessing any influence, in Queensland In particular. The State Gov ernment should place itself in the van of the forces arrayed against it. If it has to make the guarantee Itself, Queens Land must ensure that the in dustry is not permitted to go out. Central Queensland is vitally interested In this mat ter. One of the first local moves should be to oppose the suggested closure of the Glen more ginnery. If any ginnery is to be closed let It be Whln stanes, and its oil plant shifted to a centre closer to the so-called Cotton Belt. That at least would make less of a hollow mockery of the profes sions of both Commonwealth and State Governments In re

spect of decentralisation of in-1

dustry.

articleText:
THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND BERALD

Rockbampton

THURSDAY, JUNE 30, 1848

A SETTING FOR STATESMANSHIP

lyfR HANLOta promised ai

Rockhampton deputation that he will "examine the long haul rates,*' in which there are as many headaches as proved to be in Pandora's box. We had ventured to hope that he would have taken thte matter out of the civil servant category, and dealt with it on a nation al or statesman's basis. The two differ vastly and this district has suffered greatly over the years because of the insistence of Governments to be influenced more by the former than by the latter.

The question Is not so much whether, departmental^, it is a sound economic proposition to rail freight for long distances past developed ports; as whet her, from the viewpoint of making the best use of the vast area of Queensland and its wide diversity of potentialities, such a policy is excusable. The departmental view could be as well used to Justify haul ing freight past Brisbane to Sydney, as it Is to justify haul ing freight past Townsville, Bowen, Mackay, Rockhampton and Gladstone to Brisbane. On the other hand, the'state man's view must reach fcieyond the practically empty spaces of Central and Northern Queensland, and set himself to think up a reason that will survive challenge when it comes-as come it surely will -from the packed areas of

Asia. .

The statesman must also reason In retrospect, when he wllf learn that the depart mental argument was decided 40 years ago by statesmen against Sydney in favour of Brisbane. He will also find that the same excuses were used for carrying Queensland wool past Brisbane to be sold in Sydney, as are being used today to justify hauling Cent ral and North Queensland past five developed Queensland ports to be sold in Brisbane. It was atyso being argued and rightly too-that wool sold in Brisbane would be ship ped thence direct to its over seas destination; Just as it is Being argued today- and rightly too-that wool sold at Townsville or Rockhampton would also be shipped thence direct to its overseas destination To deny the force of this ar gument is to claim the right of Southern Queensland to be governed by statesmen, while condemning Central and North Queensland to be governed by civil servants.

Mr Hanlon was in critical veip when he instanced the lack of central and northern initiative in investing capital to develop resources of which

each division 1$ so justly proud. He might even have reminded us of his having acceded to a request that the cost of pro ducing a booklet, shortly to toe;

issued to proclaim those very;

resources In Central Queens land, be met by the Govern ment Instead of by local enter prise backed by local faith.

Or that more than 20 years! ago a scheme to establish In RockHampton a much-needed

wool-tops factoiy perished "on j that vety account, and it would 1

seemingly be difficult to blame, any Government, past or pre sent, for that.

On the other hand, consist

ent refusal of governments j over the past 40 or so yean to

accord to Central Queensland]

its geographic?1 rights as a' potential major trading centre instead of a mere whistling station, has been-and still is -a most disquietening cir cumstance. When such con sistent refusal Is backed by denartmental use of the State's railways to destroy that geo graphical factor Mr Hanlon will, we feel convinced, be the first to concede such a circum stance to be a most substan tial factor in Inducing such timidity. To argue otherwise is to say that Brisbane invest ors are enterprising even to the point of boldness merely because they live In. Brisbane: whjle Northern and Centra) potential Investors are caut ious to the point of timidity merely because they live In Central Queensland. The ele mentary fact is that the for-i mer live, at the place choscn by the Railway Department to dump the trade which It garners from North and Central Queensland, and Mr Hanlon will not need to be told of the vastly different out look Induced respectively in the mind of the plunderer and the plundered. He might even concede that it requires a higher quality of courage In a man to live and be plundered of his trade in Central Queens land, than is needed to be tampered with other people'6 trade In Brisbane.

The decentralising way be fore Premier Hanlon is no longer one of complacency in duced by believing all-that he is told. He has the choice of the civil servants' road and Its tangle of long haul rates, or the statesman's way that ie bestrewn with the problems of what is best for a greatly underdeveloped rich land sit uated next door to over-crowd ed Asia. With some reputa tion to uphold, we Intend to believe-until our faith Is shat tered-that Mr Hanlon's choice will be the latter, the harder way.

articleText:
THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD

Bockbam ptoo ^

THURSDAY, October 13.

«»»? 111 ? i ?!

COTTON A fOOU MAN'S CROP

T 0CAL concern at the possi

bility of a. virtual close down of Glenmore cotton ginnery because of lack of raw material to ensure a reason

able run can ^scarcely have oome as a shoH. There has been a steady decline In pro duction from 7646' bales in 1935 to 400 bales In 1040, and the staunchest advocate, of decentralisation of industry will find it hard to sfiow that a. production of 400 bales Is sufficient to sustain a local sinning industry. Yet , it would be.one of the greatest tragedies In rural and secon dary Industry were this to -life permitted to happen. ' The decline* In production has been much more rapid than Its growth. In 1022 when the' present phase of the Industry was v launched production stood at 1572 bales. From that point there was a fairly

consistent Increase, varied only by seasonal conditions, but when the decline set In nothing served to check the downward trend. v

Cotton in Queensland has had a chequered career.; Its spread through the country was great because propaganda tunes were pleasant to listen to. It was "fed at the breast," and being a new Industry, Its natural enemies, such as the pink boll worm, had .not time to build up their numbers to pett proportions. But as the pests built up, the acreage went down. 86 to foster a declining; Industry, or at least a static one, Injections of life-sustalnihg subsidies were " administered. The grower was promised many things. He was taken for numerous rides on political merry-go -rounds but, after, a few giddy turns, was always dumped somewhere close to where he started.

Out of these years of for mative experience cotton be came known as the "poor man's crop." Being harvested by hand, the machinery re quirement* were simple and oi low cost. Indeed a brush hook, axe, walking-stick plan ter and a packing needle were the only requirements to bring seed cotton to a stage ready fot dispatch to the gin nery. As a fact It was during

.

.those yean of gathering Ex

perience that tb« industry grew. Farmers in the Callide and Dawson 1 Valleys, and other districts, too, found it profitable to grow cotton on a share system. The farmer isuppUed virgin scrub land, fceed and cartage, while the share farmer felled and burn ed the scrub, planted and picked the cotton. Such a system was profitable to the farmer because his scrub was cleared at small cost to him self. But even in those com paratively , palmy pre-war years pf low cost cotton grow ing the farmer cctdd not be induced to increase acreage, other than through share farming, ^t is true the sys tem did much to open up the new lands of the Callide and Dawson for the small holder, tout It did not increase per manent production. - Cotton remained, aB it always had been* a poor man'*. crop, and it is largely for that reason that the industry has declin ed to its present 400 bales of

lint.

, In these days of abundant employment at 40 hours a week, and in the absence ol scrub - felling share growers willing to tackle anything in1 preference to swag carrying, the cotton Industry cannot keep pace with (he more profitable primary Industries. With an Increased, price for I butter, the trend of the small

farmer today is to produce more of it. Where he once grew cotton, he now plans to grow fodder, and he find* it pays better. He also finds he cannot grow butter and cot ton; to ~ do so is to neglect both. It was never a good combination because the busi est times of both occur to gether. So with butter more profitable, and no reservoir of labour available, cotton takes the count, notwithstanding the 7d per lb for the seed orop, which is <ahead of pre-war, though still well below the 9id that is being asked tor.

Until irrigation and mechani cal harvesting have been eco nomically proved cotton grow ing must remain a poor man's crop, and there are no poor men to take it up.

articleText:
THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD

Bo cfcbamplon

THURSDAY, DECEMBER 8.

WHY PRIMARY PRODUCERS ARE LUCKY t

f|1HE primary producer who

listens to what the wild waves-long and short-are say lng these nights will profit im-' mensely from- the entertain ment, but will hear some rot ten arguments. For the swan-song of Labour lads is that he Is a mighty fortunate being, with a cornucopia of plenty pouring its assorted wealth on his plate before his astonished eyes.

Well might he *be astonished, for if what the wild waves are churning out be true he simply must, have dreamt about all those shortages of labour and material, it could have been that his lament over there be ing no fencing netting or wire, no galvanised iron to make new or repair old troughing, or reDair his roof, no water piping to irrigate his crops, no spare parts for his windmill or his utility was merely an artful dodge to cover 'his disin clination to do any of these jobs. His labour shortage - either because none is offering or is too costly - must also be a bad dream, and the story that country youth - his own, among them -is attracted by the bright lights and 40-hour week of the city is merely an other wicked Tory invention. His wife and young children, who have to help him feed the city multitude and in so doing

make less than the basic wage, might tell another story, but he cannot get past what the wireless waves are saying. II tie seeks classical musical In terlude he runs Into a phifley lad saying that Labour' Is the; sole benefactor of the primary producer. The hungry world that Australian producers try ; to feed was provided by the Chifley Government, but the slow turn round of 6hips, the strife on the water front and all the Communist-Labour dodges to prevent hi? offering! reaching Britain are all flg-i ments of dreadful Tory imag

ination. And yet- j

Since September of 1948 less than 15 months ago - there have been six determina tions at Brisbane increasing the basic wage from 113/" to 125/- per week or 10.6 per cent. The dairyman knows, too, that everything he buys for hi* farm or his wife buys for the house has gone up by that amount; but over the same period the retail prices of but ter and cheese - which he produced - have remained unaltered. He did not hear these stark truths over the wireless waves, they not being included in the repertoire of

Mr Ohlfley"8 brisk lads who] tread the ether. But he knows! they are no less true on that

account «- j

articleText:
THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD ]

Rock bamptoD

THURSDAY, JANUARY 27.

LONGER*VIEW MIGHT REPAY SHEARERS

J?EFE?y"llNG to the shearing

Industry In his annual report to the A.W.U. Mr Fallon claims that the rates for flock sheep In the Queensland shear fug Industry are the highest In the world. In view of that as sertion, It Is of more than pass ing Interest to note that the shearers are still unsatisfied. The annual branch convention of Mr Fallon's union will begin its sittings at Melbourne on January 25 and the agenda in cludes quite a number of claims on behalf of the wool industry. A motion from the NSW branch asks that the employer should be responsible for bringing the snaoko lunch to the shed, In stead of the cook, as at present, "Irrespective of distance" Other branches seek the pro vision of a reception room apart from the dining room, hot water systems and refrig erators In shearers' quarters^ power irons for members in all shearing sheds, writing tables in each room, and telephones to be installed in the huts for use by employees on their agreeing to pay for them. Taken Individually, It may be contended there is nothing revolutionary, or particularly costly, in these extra amenities* but collectively tl.ey add to the steadily mounting costs which burden the industry and, inbre over, provide a convenient handle for agitation and step page of work.

If the branch secretary added to Jiis observations that Queens f shearers were getting the it aest rates in the world, and if he advised that, instead of going for fresh gains they would be well advised to con solidate their position and that of the industry which means so much to them and to the nation's economic security, no mention is made of it In the summary released, yet some thing along that line should b« the main objective of Aus tralian union leaders today. By 110 other way can union members be made to see that they have travelled as far as it is safe to go along the patl> of hisher wages and shorter hours, and that the next s«3 is to raise product'in to m.3et the demand for Roods and bring a halt to the rapidly splraling prices, when they might yet hold all that they have gained. To carry conviction in these matters many 60.000-word re

ports could be issued and not a word would be wasted. But the trend today is to place stone upon stone, and this will go on until the edifice collapses amidst the ruins of Inflation or some other economic disaster.

Hie wool industry may be the "one to provide the classic "last straw" example. Prom the claims to come before the Melbourne conference it is ap parent that the shed employees are not yet satisfied they are getting the most that can tw drawn from the Industry, but feel that the good times Which now endow wool growing with unexampled prosperity will con tinue. In this view, of course, they are not different from many growers, and they have expert opinion to back them up, as witness the optimism of the former president of the In ternational Wool Secretariat. At the same time, there is a still small voice that warns of other possibilities.

It is unlikely that Mr Fal lon) lengthy report in its ref erence to the shearing Industry took any cognisance of a cabled item that appeared in the news whilst the ink was still drying on his own composition. It was to the effect that scientists and inventors had evolved a ma chine, then going into produc tion in Prance, which would greatly reduce the quantity of wool required for the manufac ture of fabrics of comparable' quality, and this agency was expected to have a big influence on the future outlay for raw wool. Union leaders are not in the habit of seeking and coup ling up remote causes and effects, and if anyone had quoted this news message as a reason to go easy on the writ ing tables and telephones and endeavoured to make a cer tainty of retaining the world's highest shearing rates for Sock sheep, he would have been ac corded none too patient a hear ing.

In what may be his valedic tory address to the members of Queensland's largest union there Is talk of his early eleva tion to the Industrial Court bench-Mr Fallon had a fav ourable opportunity to speak come home truths to the work ers of thjs State. To what extent he has availed himself of that opportunity we must await the full text of his mam moth report.

TRUMAN AND THE DEMOCRATIC WAY

JJRESIDENT TRUMAN has

issued (i four-point pro gramme lor resistance to Communism and for the attainment of world peace. This programme undertakes to give unwavering sup port to the United Nations' Organisation, to continue pro grammes for world recovery, to strengthen freedom-loving nations against dangers of aggression, and to make the benefits of American scientific advances and industrial pro gress available for the im provement of undeveloped areas. "Our aim," he say,s, "should be to hClp the free peoples of the world through their own efforts to produce more food, more clothing, more materials for housing and more mechanical power to lighten their burdens. We Invite other countries to pool their techni cal resources in this under taking ... it must be a world wide effort for the achieve ment of peace, plenty and freedom. Greater production is the key to prosperity and peace, and the key to greater production is wider and more vigorous application of modern scientific and technical know ledge. Only by helping the less fortunate of its members to help themselves can the human family achieve a de cent satisfying life. Democracy alone can supply the vitails-' Jng force to stir peoples of

| the world into triumphant ac

tion, not only against their human oppressors. but also against their ancient enemies -hunger, misery and despair."

The Presidential assertion thtft the initiative for an ac tive campaign along these lines vests with the United States has been received with a gasp in American political circlec, and everywhere there is taking place an intensive study to interpret one of the most Important political pro nouncements of modern times. That it will come in for wide discussion and there will be great divergence of opinion in its interpretation goes without saying, but out side of all that may happen in connexion'with the imple mentation of the four-point programme, the Inaugural speech in which it is embodied will have rendered one great; service to the world. It has held up in the clear light of day, as rarely before in such simple terms, the deep unfathomable gulf that lies between the Communist and Democratic ways of life. If in the light of this exposure any country,-particularly Australia, the freest and in many ways the most favoured land on earth, allows itself to become enmeshed in the tolls of Com munism, it will do so with its eyes fully opened.

New South Wales also has enjoyed bounteous rains and th« profits accruing irom wool an1 livestock being what they are cwnere are reluctant to sell at any price. Lucky is the sheep man who -was able to bold on to his breeding stockthrough the drought. . It( is declared that it will be Impossible lor districts Jlke Wlntoo. -which were almost denuded of sheep before the drought ended, to restock to anything like the extent desired. But the recu

perative powers of the livestock industry are almost as great as the country Itself, and tt *111 not surprise to see.* fe oovery tn numbers far plater

and In 4 shorter tfme.thiuk is predicted In the more pass!" mlstlc estimates now he^ng

offered.

Perhaps the brightest aspect of /the bounteous season is that no matter what increases occur In wool, beef and dairy output a ready and profitable market awaits these commodi ties. It has not always been thus, .for flush seasons have too- often meant : overproduc tion and glutted markets With aH the acknowledged handicaps It will hardly be challenged that the pastoral and dairying Industries are better placed than for' many years, and nothing In the foreseeable future should in tervene to prevent. those en gsged therein reaping the fruits of their labour and per severance. If there is one cloud on the horizon it lies tn the current rumours of the in trusion of Socialistic-minded Governments into the live stock Industry on lines not

Nptfcii^ li ,#oopcr itfWTptten than the memoryM dmpht. end It la easy ^rwegaie. to

centty as January ins our own!

owners, Including dalrybien, j

Haiai and other nutritious ghwses that would make splendid hay for future u*£ But labour Shortage tor one thlng.and perhaps a fed In? that there is nothing to worry' about now, are respon sible for little attempt being made to-preserve this valuable

arset.

. Itt respect of Its rural Indus tri^tientral Queensland faces ohe oftbfebrightest periods in its history, lhat is not to aay that either those on the land. or city folk whose pros perity depends upon the for mer, can afford to rest easy. One thing emphasised by the flood rains in the far west is that the projected Channel i all way should be pressed to the fullest, for of all the re gions benefiting from the season none has been more favoured and. on the other hand, none can turn it to less advantage, due to the handl

obviated with rail connexion.

?f: r \: -.- a

COULD SO MUCH BE SURRENDERED t

TH *pite of many bitter ex

jnrtences and warnings, no unlae today Is safe cram In* filtftttan and control by the familiar method of a min ority group first gaining entry to executive office, then ex panding their numbers and influence until they are strong enough to control the union executive, and finally to manipulate the union rules governing voting and ballots bo that their displacement la a virtual impossibility. That, no doubt, Is why only a few days ago the president of the Boot Trade Employees' Federation, addressing the Council ot <the Urikm. felt caortrataW feMfcy: "X urge members to. be lncreas ingly on the sSert for eo-oalled progressives or militants "who hypocritically pose as cham pions of Labour when, in ac tual fact, they are a sinister and fatal iqenaoe to basic rights of unions and union

ists."

Id this predicament a move has been launched by ALP grotips, In Victoria and NBW, for. legislative action to lie taken which will combat Com munist influence la the unions. One aim is to get 50,000 sig natures to a petition praying the Federal Government to take action to ensure that all union elections shall be con

to say do thing of freedom to indulge in malpractices, from ?Mnh puny ballots in

put have not been free of sus picion. Nor is it surprising that, in marshalling resistance, they we appealing to tradi tional opponent* nidi as the AWU likewise to oppose what they contend is legislation that threatens to encroach on the right of unionist* to oon duct their a&aini in their own

w*y.

What will surprise a good many people is that this argu ment is meeting with accept ance from the leaders' of unions which are as yet free from Communist domination. Ameesage from Canberra states that industrial leaden in the ALP are at loggerheads op the question of Common wealth control of ballots. Vic* tori* and NSW favour tti proposal, but Queensland, where industrial matters are largely controlled by the non» Communist AWU. Is described a* being "bitterly opposed to the .move, as is Western Aus tralia, where the ALP com pletely wnjtyolw union, affairs. This suggests that whether or not they axe tarred with the Communist brush, the small coterie at the bead of the nnlnm , h&YC OU6 thingr in common: a reluct ance to surrender their power, no matter through , what agency. ' Apparently unions into which tbne has been no Communist infiltration Vould sooner run ^ risk of that happening than seek safe guards against it, if it means taking the conduct of ballots, including those for. office, out ot their h^dr,.

articleText:
/

\ THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD |

R o ck b a mp ton

Thursday, April 28,184B

WHAT HAPPENS TO HUSH AUSTRALIANS ?

AT 10 a4Q. Eastern Austra

lian standard time on April 18 Sire severed all remaining links with the British Com monwealth of Nations to set up bouse on her own account. The common belief Is that the also made of herself a foreign nation, though there is a ten dency to cling to the opinion that Eire's eligibility for im perial preference "depends upon whether she would oe regarded in International law i as a foreign country."

The matter is one for indi vidual Dominions, and It Is one of, law rather than of senU» mint. Eire's Government has

made of Eire a foreign coua-! try, and It remains for the people of the several British Dominions to declare what their relevant laws have made

of IrUh-born folk In their] midst. The problem is com plicated by the fact of the Irish people having migrated to many lands, and so to have acquitted themselves that they occupy high administrative poets there. If by an act of the Elran Government they have become foreigners In the land of their adoption, uie

question of which allegiance to j whom becomes of paramount

importance. If tbey are mi

countries outside of the Brit ish Commonwealth of Nations the change of nationality means little; but If they are within that group each indi vidual is at once face£ with a choice that only he can make. From being a British subject while living In, say Australia, be has by law De come a foreigner, and his only way to recover his status toat he acquired on birth fcs a mat ter of course will be through naturalisation. Then are about 70,000 Ireland-born Irish people In Australia, many of them In the services and/or professions who, prior to the 18th Instant were British citi zens through birth within the British Empire. Their status should receive prompt atten tion, and the Commonwealth Government should lose no

time clarifying the position. It

is no more tbe fault of Aus

tralia than it is of these folk that they have been turned Into foreigners by an act of the Government of the land of their birth; but they can no more permit anyone else to de cide for them to which Gov ernment they will give their allegiance than Canberra may Ignore tbe many complications that are showing up.

BLACKENING WHITE AUSTRALIA POUCY

TV"© community, and very few |

Individuals, profess a

few of (he intrusion of col- I owed peoples to tbe point of i creating a problem, either ecn-! nomle or racial. As a fact. In most Australian communities tbe coloured person is suffici ently rare to be almost a curi oflty-much more so than was the ease 40 yeejp ago: when there was a considerable Chinese colony and a residue of the Island labour recruited for the caneflelds. The Com munist menace fomented by traitorous whites Is a much more serious thought to Aus tralians than Is that of a pos sible racial problem. But In the mind of the Minister for Migration there seemingly ex ists a belief that the Austra lian way of life Is endangered by the continued residence In Australia of the OTCeefe family, by a visit to his wife and family of the Filipino soldier Oamboa, by the pres ence of a Siamese nurse In Adelaide

The commonsense view must be that these individual cases have been given a prominence out of all proportion to their /importance and general influ ence on tbe Immigration laws. If the Minister's first object was to gain a little publicity and notoriety he has succeed ed beyond the most sanguine hopes, and he has landed not only himself and his Govern ment, but Australia Into a nasty predicament.

Tbe more serious aspect of the business Is that the Phil ippines Reciprocal Immigra tion Bill is a challenge to the White Australia policy, the first that has been launched by another Government whose people are affected. Whilst the introduction of extreme retaliatory legislation may be questioned as the wisest course

to follow In the rectification of differences between govern

jaunts, it cannot be overlook

ed that our own Minister** administration ofthe immi gration laws has provoked this retaliation. A matter for concern la to what trtent it

may be followed fgr other gov

ernments, whose resentment against the application of the White Australia policy on tb» grounds of colour is no lea* acute.

If a similar measure is adopted by other Asiatic countries it could have serious repercussions for Australia, other than the expulsion of our people now residing in these parts. We have great hopes of trade expansion with

Asia, but this could be foster ed only by having resident agents who can assist with knowledge of local condition* and requirements If all our nationals were barred com" raerce would have to rely on such representations as could be made from Australia.

This blunder, along with some others, has been made without any consideration as to Australia's dangerous posi tion in the Pacific. We first antagonise the Dutch -by al lowing a Communist-bossed trades union to take over the conduct of foreign affairs. Little has been done to foster cooperation with the United States, and we have allowed our defences to drift to de plorable ineffectiveness. Now we are needlessly provoking our Asiatic neighbours.

The Prime Minister should long ago hfcve curbed his im petuous Minister, instead of condoning his rashness. The complete results cannot yet be foreseen, but it can be said the 'Reciprocal Immigration Bill is a most unwelcome chicken come home to roost.

articleText:
Rock bamptoo

THURSDAY, OCTOBER 9.

IANDTAX INIQUITIES

fyiK of the few blessings of

.income tax Is Out there can b« no tax without profit, one of tin oomforts of sales tax Is that without a sale there can b» no tax,' but mere owper mp bf land creates liability to pay land tax. A man is not tatosd because he owns thou aands of cattle or fleets of motor cars Unless he derives profit from their use or sale: but it he owns land he is taxed on Its unimproved value even if .it lies idle, and .taxed again* oq any profit made by using the land in his business be fit whatsoever* it might. Land tax is declared by law to be a prior claim on the land, so that if that tax remains t unpaid the Ttaatioft Commissioner may register charges in the Real Property Office against the offending land. While the Commissioner is a preferential creditor in the case of unpaid inpome tax, he must at least proceed by the age-old method af : levy and distress: but in the case of outstanding land tax he may, as we have seen, virtual]? execute a mortgage ovfcr the land until his claim la met.

Land tax started In Victoria in 1877 when "by rich and poor with the aid of the Govern ment, the State was de frauded" through the gentle art of the land jobber. The idea was to "make lucrative tenure of .large estates im possible". Hungry Treasurers followed In Tasmania (1880), and four years later In South Australia, while George Reid fought and won an election on the Issue in New South Wales la IBM. Western Australia had three . shots at bringing, ltt . thls unwelcome impost be fore the Act was passed in 1P0T, and it was left to Labour to wing it in in Queensland la 1016. The main objective, was unashamedly to produce revenue, and It was not untu the Fisher Act "conceived in a spirit of political hate and born In falsehood" became law on November 17, 1910, that the: intention of land tax "to burst up the big estates" came again to the fore. .Treasurer Theodore stated, when intro

ducing the Bill in 1815, that; the purpose mi to break up large country estates, and "to, extract from the large (city)

landholders a revenue which they could afford to "pay". Many a plausible highwayman Justified his pistol-point exac tions no less unctuously.

Hut was over 30 years ago and today six State and one Commonwealth Government all tax the land, while the local authorities on whose shoulders fall the.. task of

administering the land, fall into line for mere crumbs from the unhallowed feast For sflve years to 1MB the seven Government* collected £25,340, 000 and because it was alleg edly conducting an ail-out war the Commonwealth Govern

ment collected 35 per cent of

the total. But it was not the weight of the ' ax that incur red the greatest hostility.

was the implacable collection of It, whether this land made a loss or a profit; that raised the ire -of reasonable mat. In one case a number of ooastal cattlemen In < Southern Queensland showed their ag gregate trading losses to have been £2406,- yet Federal and State land tax amounting to ?5780 was demanded of them. We have surely reached a high pinnacle of legalised plunder when the losses of primary producers are taxed. In an other case where sheepmen were concerned, their trading profits amounted to £32,863, while the Federal and State land tax amounted to £54,743 I

If the object of land tax is to "break up the big estates" it ,1s producing some queer results. In the 10 years to 1946-7 the number of males employed «erma)nently in primary production through out Australia decreased by 40,030, and a number of females EO employed increased by 16,888. If breaking up the luge estates by imposing land tax has the effect of driving men off the land and women on to It, Labour disciples who have defended it through thick and thin have a very queer concept of dev;i ;-;'"3 a new land.
heading: THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD Rockhampton THURSDAY, OCTOBER 6. LAND TAX INIQUITIES
