articleText:
IRociib a m p4 o o

THt/iU3DAY, DECEMBER 13.'

SEAMEN AND SEASON OF GOODWILL

JJAVE we reached the poinl

where the Australian coastal shipping industry is to follow in the footsteps of the coal mines and close down at the very period of tfye year when both are most needed by the community and by other in dustries then . at the peak of their activities? It begins to look that way.

First Jt was that a vessel anxiously awaited at some distant port, missed its sailing and instead of arriving a few days* before Christmas did not turn up until early in the New Tear, By degrees it became manifest that these delayed sailings were not always due to unavoidable circumstances, and that the principal cause was the determination of the sea men. or a considerable portion of them, to spend Christmas at their homes which mostly happen to be Sydney or Mel bourne. It was so "slmpNf to ensure that the ship was shortr manned, and therefore could not sail, that it .grew and reached its greatest height of absurdity last year in the famous voyage of s£. lime, which left Melbourne early in December and -made Rock hamptcwi towards the end of January.

From single vessels the spirit , of Christmas seems this year

to have assailed the 1 whole mercantile fleet at a very early date. Even coalminers were content to start Christmas on December 16 by taking their self allotted three weeks holi

day from that date; but pract ically from the beginning of December seamen have been falling to turn up to man coast ships, and as a consequ ence, city ports are jammed With vessels loaded with Christinas goods that cannot sail for lack of crews. Indeed a ludicrous position'exists, in that members of crews willing to sail are actually being paid off by owners ^because of in ability to make up. the com plement whilst the laden ves sel5 are lying at the wharves. Surely this is without parallel In the annals of the Australian shipping industry, unless one

'goes back to the time of thej early gold rushes. 1

Last Friday (December 9),

seamen who refused to man! coastal vessels were Warned by

the Maritime Industry Com- j

mission that they "might lose

their jobs." The acting chair-! man of the Commission said that a number of ships loaded with Christmas^ goods were tied up 'in .ports because they could not get crews. Seamen were entitled to choose the ships in which they served, but they should not abuse this freedom of choice. The Com

& mission #iulred seamen to do

rcjular service at sea, other wise they might be forced to consider removing them from' the industry.

So much for the seamen. Ttie wharf labourers are not the kind' to allow them to have things fill their own way in sUch a matter. Last -Week Mel bourne dock were so jammed with ships that eight' vessels had to anchor in the bay over night. A stretch of -wet weather mainly contributed to this con gestion-one of the worst in history-since watereifler work-, era do not work when.it rains. To make matters worse, they wanted to hold a stop-work meeting on Monday to consider whether 350 new. members should be admitted to the union to cope with the water front labour shortage.' »

If such a state of affairs applied only to Christmas sallfhgs it would be serious enough and quite indefensible, but it transplrR that the gen eral shortage of goods and materials that is holding up development, in Queensland in particulars, is largely due to "go slow" on' the ships and city wharves. Last week it was complained that thousands of tomutff essential steel did not aijpjve, not because it was un available but on account of the lack of transport. Shipping in terests in their defence placed the blame on the slow turn round of ships, which has so scandalously deteriorated since 1939. - - '

| The general effect of th&e 'things Is to be observed in 'every ramification of < Austral lia's industrial and commercial {life. In the same paper that {reported the complaint and

threat of the Maritime Indus try Commission, it was shown that dairy farmers in the Mao kay district were being hind ered In production owing to material shortages. Some were even being forced out of the industry by lack of: fencing wire, roofing Iron ahd water reticulation piping.. Parsers who had Just started in the industry had withdrawn from it Because they would not in stall milking machines in un roofed sheds.

Thus we see that because spoonfed seamen and water front workers want, to start Christmas at the beginning of December even such a vital in dustry as dairying is Jeopard ised. The same thing applies in a greater "or lesser degree to scores of other enterprises. And to check this evil all that the Maritime Commission can do is to timidly insinuate that the men responsible "might" lose their jobs.
heading: THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD Rockhampton THURSDAY, DECEMBER 13. SEAMEN AND SEASON OF GOODWILL

articleText:
THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND QERALD J

Rockhsmpl oo

THURSDAY. APRIL 7, 1M»

WHY PENSION PAYMENTS SOAR

PpKB loss of initiative and en

terprise, which matte repug nant the thought of ever hav ing to seek the old age pension to a vast majority of jthe people of Australia, took root during the depression. Xt gained ground during thrf war yean, when' bo many derived their sustenance from war ser vice allotments and other forms of Government payment, so that it was almost a dis

agreeable shook again to be-' come dependent merely on a ciriHan pay envelope.

Staoe the war the loss of inltatlve and enterprise has made s further alarming pro gress, due to several factors which have nothing to do with lack of employment. High taxation has had a shattering effect upon sell-reliance, be* cause it has destroyed the in centive to work harder, people who have always been inde pendent find It impossible to save or at any rate, present conditions make saving seem to be not worth while. It takes a large amount of capital to return interact equal to tho old age pension. There are still many people of moderate means who have always been proud to pay their.own way, but they are growing fewer,

and It is getting harder to find anyone who Is not pre pared to join In the scramble to set aa much as possible from Government hand-outs. Looking at the rate of taxa tion and social service taxes it is atfays hard to blame them.

The net mult is that whilst the industrious and enterpris ing are being repressed by high taxation and government restrictions, increasing num bers of the x unstable direct their energies to gambling, the unscrupulous exploit the black market, and the unenterpris ing seek security in the Public Servioe. All the time the ranks of those who carry the burden are being thinned. How long will Australia be able to carry on with caring for everyone-or nearly every one-from the cradle to the gfave ? Only so long as the present abnormally high prices for our export commodities al low. That consideration is not likely to weigh heavily with the Queensland Pensioners' League out for its £4/10/- per week, or the politician eager to survive another election to make him eligible for his £8. All they hope for is that it will see out their time.

DECENTRALISATION COVLD WORK

A CLASSIC example of the

Up service that is ren dered to the principle of decentralisation of indus try la provided by Rock hampton and the wool Indus* try. There is little in common between the Couley Govern aent and the wool-selling in terests, but on one point they appear to be in complete har mony-there shall be no more wool disposals centres in Queensland if it can possibly be prevented. The strongest argument for decentralisation »f. industry is that country re jtfauu shall have secondary in dustries corresponding with their primary industries. If any centre in Australia has & claim to come within the framework of this principle, it is Rockhampton's aspiration U> participate in some maimer in the handling, and processing of tne large quantity of wool and hides grown in '\e district. Yet today every h is sent away a be treated i. be sbuth, and determined opp sltion is being shown towards any attempt tr participate in the handling and disposal of the central wool clip in the region where it u produced.

Wf may never reach the ex

treme point where lack of pro

I

auction will expose tbe big cities to the tide of stam tioo, but we are heading (or a condition when there will br insufficient population In coun

try areas to provide that pro-' taction to rural industries that is necessary for both govern ment* and Mr businesses to enjoy the benefits from those Industries that is now theirs. If any doubts ehould exist on this point a visit to the mllitaiy training camp now In opera tion Jost outside Rockhamp ton would be Illuminating.

What practical remedy Is there for this dangerous trend, outside the education rag* tested, and whictyat best & bound to be a long prooess^ Regional councils subdivided into smaller councils to con sider problems and projects

and place them before the , Governments was proposed at Cairns. That might be worth trying, but it Is not for want of the strongest representa tions that so little has been done to stem the drift to the cities. Indeed, the only legisla tive measure that has emerged is the very dubious Sectoral Redistribution Bill now before the State Assembly, which many believe will aggravate rather than better the position

ELECTRICITY EXPANSION RETARDED

ELECTRICAL plant Is «

field of manufacture into which Australia would. have entered to a far greater 'degree ilnce the war, were it not tor the unbroken series of strike* throughout the period, both on the coalfields and in the iron the steel Industry. As to the prospects for development in the future the Commonwealth Division of Industrial Develop ment. In a recent review of tin* heavy electrical Industry, shows the useage of electrical power in Australia has doub led in the last decade. If supply is to meet demand in the next 10 years the installa tion of new plant will have to be considerably greater than pre-war. Present " installed capacity is considerably below requirements, the total capac ity at June 1M? being 2,174. 4M kilowatts, and in the inter vening 12 months orders were placed for new plant with i wpaclty of 1,628,000 kilowatts, between now and 195? it te )lanned to order additional tew generating plant amount ng to 3,090,000 kilowatts, thus lving an overall increase of .600,000 ks. in ten years.

These expansion plans will naturally require large quan itles of high capacity equip ment such u generators rantformera and switch-gear Vs yet Australian manufac turers can supply only part of the requirements for low to medluti capacity transformers and switch-gear, generators and large capacity equipment hiving to be Imported. Even within the range of Australian production local manufactur ers are unable to meet re

ptramitrmM deliveries can,

not be promised for two or three years.

This, of course, means tiu; . lot of other things we held back In the absence of ade quate electrical power, which Is the basis of further general Industrial development. This would be highly regrettable in the most unavoidable circum stances but It becomes almost criminal when it Is known that the output of plant which Australia is in a position to manufacture. Is only 60 per cent of capacity due to short ages of materials and labour and especially whea w? -MIect upon the teal cause of the shortages.

Nor can relief be looked for from overseas as is the case with coal, steel and cement, even If we are prepared to im port regardless of cost. The Division of Industrial Devel opment says tt may be difficult for major overseas manufac turers to supply Australia with all the generating capacity needed over the next 10 years.

In short it resolves Itself into a house that Jack built If Australia is to get the elec trical power which is neces sary to permit of her develop ment in all fields of primary and secondary industry, rite must first be supplied with the coal, steel and labour neoes sary to provide herself with the required power.

. BRISBANE, March 31.-Mr | A. J, Clelland has been ap pointed a member of the Banana Hospitals Board tar place of Mr W. J. Gardiner, resigned.

articleText:
THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND BERALd I

nockbampioa

THURSDAY, JUNE 9, 1MB.

|,n-, .

NEW CHARGES WILL HIT EVERYONE

flpHE staggering rise in post

and telegraph charges an nounced by the Federal Gov .rnment comes as a bolt from the blue. All shades of opta *°n. - political,^ commercial,

producers and even militant unionism - have jolnes in protest and in demanding a fuller explanation of the rea sons for the totally unex pected increases.

The Government as usual has attempted to escape crit icism from * its acknowledged supporters by allowing the let ter postage rate ana the 2d. telephone call to remain un altered, thereby giving the im pression that the £xtra charges will be shouldered oy "Big Business" and others "best able to bear them." But this blinks the undeniable fact that in whatever guise they are imposed the increases wu. ultimately have to be met by the general community, just as sales tax, customs and excise duties and -other indirect taxes are passed on.

Not the least defensible as pect Is the extent of the rises. Manufacturers and producers, such as bakers and dairymen, have to prove that they are on the verge of bankrupcy, and others have to make vlg

orous, representations to price fixing. authorities, to secure a rise of 5 or 10 per cent .on their commodities, yet the Government, without- being required to put its case to 'anyone, announces whole sale increases ranging up to 100 per cent, in almost every branch of its activities. The fee for registered letters and parcels is doubled, tele grains within a 16 mile radius have gone up 75 per cent and for longer distances 50 per cept, the same as (he increase on printed matter. For re quiring a particular person to answpr a telephone call you pay twice*as much as formerly notwithstanding that without the person being found the call would in most cases be worthless. One of the most objectionable departures is the abolition of the reduced rale for trunk line calls at night, litis service was of great value to, and came within the means of, families separated by distanoe, and who were thus able to keep in personal touch. The Increase in annual rentals, extensions and tolls will serve to debar many house holders of moderate income from installing What has come to be regarded as a modem amenity.

articleText:
THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD

1

R o c k b B id p I o a

ROCKHAMPTON, DEO. 1.

KEEPING STATE COAL MINES GOING -

'? -11 mis Socialist coal mines of

Queensland have been living for the greater part ' of the last nine years upon

the protection and taxes of private enterprise. There ere four in this . money-losing string, and over the past nine years the taxpayer of Queens land-who Is also private en terprise-had to put up £255,341 to balance their ac counts, and that after the lot of them, on an average, had just on doubled their cost prices to the community. By 1948 the "loss motive" had be come chronic, for the whole four of them were In that im pecunious condition.

1 The Ogmore mine, at Styx,

in nine years had one profit j year and nine loss years, the aggregate loss amounting to £96,720 after the selling price .of its coal had been more than doubled during the period. That is to say, to keep full the miners' pay envelopes to award level, private enterprise users of Styx coal had in 1948 lo pay 136 per cent more than they paid in 1940, and private enterprise taxpayers had to pay the* foregoing losses to keep the mine going. Anyone who, on that showing, says that Socialism in Queensland does not pay those who are lucky enough to be practising it should have his eyesight tested. Private enterprise must be wonderfully well founded to stand such a strain on its ef-1 flclency. j

The State coke-works at Bowen have not in their nine years of operation to 1948 man aged to get "out of the red" into the profit-earning column, and that despite the fact that the {nice of coke at the works was increased by 90 per cent.

i The aggregate loss over the nine years to 1948 was £79,449, and again It was private enter prise-or capitalism-that ob liged.'

Next oil the sorry string is the. Cofflnsville State . coal mine, of which'the Davidson report said "ventilation Is poor and temperatures are often'ex cessive with high humidity. The dust problem is also m evidence, and the roads are Ill-kept and dirty. . .the town is one of the poorest mining towns tof which this board has had experience." But bad as was this Socialist mine, the board stated that that at Styx was far worse. Colllnsvllle mine showed four profitable years and Ave of loss, the net result, being -a loss of £64,499 and that after the price of its coal had been Increased in the nine years by 94 per cent.

Last of the lot was Mt Mul ligan State coal mine, which showed two profitable years and seven "In the red." The price of coal was Increased by 71 per cent, and the net loss to be met by capitalist tax payers was £14,673.

Here,' then, is Socialism in our midst in all its glory and our 6oclalisers, the Chlfleys and Hanlons, are desperately aiut lous to land us with more of It. In the short space of nine years Queensland Socialism has just on doubled the price to the community of its coal, and the capitalistic-or private enterprise-taxpayer has had to pay £255,341 to keep the pay envelope ol/ the Socialises from collapsing. They do things dif ferently In Russia but fortun ately for^sur Socialist coal miners we have not the equiv alent of a Siberia here.

articleText:
THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD \

HOW TO MAKE NEIGHBOURS UNFRIENDLY

TH® administration of our

Immigration laws in the cbm of the O'Keefe deporta tions has started something that will not end soon, notwith standing the deadline fixed oy the responsible Minister.

Where racial resentment has not flared up Australia is being laughed at , ac cording to the testimony of Australians' on the spot. Sin gapore posters describe it as one of the worst cases of racial discrimination committed by Australia. Indian intellectuals are said to be pondering whether our Government U playing a double game. Com monwealth representation at the Delhi conference was in terpreted as a sign of friend ship towards Asiatics and there followed a cordial reaction. This has been shattered, and Indium and others are asking who speaks for Australia: Dr Kvatt when he protests good will and friendship for colour ed races, or Mr Calwell when he rounds them up and turns them out of . the country? What a great many Austra lians would like to. know is who determines Australia's course of action in this and other matters. Dr Evatt ap pears to have a free hand in practically all matters of foreign policy, and Mr Calwell acts as though he is a law unto himself in the same field.

Immediate repercussions are likely to be unpleasant if there be any substance to the reports epianatlng from the head of the Malay Nationalist Party at

Singapore, hinting at the im minent launching of a "secret counter"; but it is the long range effects from which most can be apprehended. Whilst the steps for these deporta tions were being launched there appeared a significant commentary on Australia'*, position and safety by a world authority on population.

, Dr Warren Thompson, USA. who is attached to General Mac Arthur's natural resources *ectlon, Is of the opinion that Australia may expect to hold New Guinea and her other unpopulated inlands for ao more than a further 25 years in the face of growing Asian population. By that time either China or Japan - probably China-will be in a position to .elw New Guinea by forcn. Only a population of 30,000,000 or more will make Australia and New Zealand safe, and he sees no real hope of this figure being reached. There is noth ing very reassuring about such a report, and still less about Dr Thompson's Anal conclu sion. He "very much doubts whether America will be inter ested In going to the defence of Australia in a war fought over regional colonisation"

Dr Thompson cannot speak for what the United, States may do 25 years hence, but he probably gives a pretty ac curate Interpretation of cur rent American opinion on these matters, and it is soirfe thing that our own political leaders can hardly afford to

ignore. j

THE FANTASTIC TURN IN SHORTAGES

jtVTTH the most extensive * coalfields In the world.

Australia is under the nece* elty of Importing fuel from Britain and other countries to keep up the inadequate ration which is available to our In dustrial plants and essential services. With every ingredient essential to local manufacture we are importing cement at many times the cost at which It should be produced her?. Having proved conclusively that we can manufacture steel at lower cost than any other country we are now bringing It In from outside at tremen dously higher cost to avoid public works coming to a standstill. These things arc directly traceable to the re duced working week and to the reduced output per man

hour.

So far, Australia has readi ed the point Where only coal, steel, cement and timber must be Imported. A stage further can be yet reached, and the first to achieve It are the wireworkers at Newcastle. It is almost too fantastic to have to rejate that the employees in this Industry are only partly employed, in view of Austra lia's position in respect to wire supplies. Yet such is the case, In their predicament the wire workers have protested to the governments against the Im portation from America of 2100,000 worth of rabbit proof netting. This £100,000 will buy

leu than 1000 miles pf netting, whereas Australia needs 300, 000 miles! In 1B39 the Com monwealth produced 250 miles of wire netting a week; now production is down to less than 100 miles per week. We are forced to buy in America and Europe because local out put cannot meet the demand. The demand cannot be met locally because rod steel is scarce, and rod steel is scarce because coal supplies do not meet the nation's demand.

The wire workers ask that the importations of rabbit proof netting be stopped. Pas toralists and agricultural and stock expert# declare that un less they can renew their net ting the pastoral industry will go under to the rabbit. What the wire workers should be doing is to get their fellow unionists to produce more coal and steel, otherwise what is happening to them today will happen to those employed in other in dustries tomorrow. The ques tion is how far must we drift before there is an all-out cam paign to bring these things home to the people of Austra lia. They are learning by the hard way what shorter hours and lower production means to their dinner table. It Is only a matter of time when it must catch, up with them in their jobs. If Australia imbibed these lessons and acted on them this would indeed be a vital year in our progress to wards nationhood.
heading: THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD Rockhampton THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 10 HOW TO MAKE NEIGHBOURS UNFRIENDLY

articleText:
THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD

Rockba mpton

THURSDAY, APQWBT11.

- -mum

A STEP IN PASTURE REGENERATION

WHS Queensland-British Food

Oorpor»tlon has completed its first harvest In the Central West, and In common with other Queensland sorghum growers would have fared

- much better but ior ftn un

precedented frost in mid-June that killed 6turdy bloodwoods and cracked motor engine cylinders from Maura to Peak Downs. This circumstance win encourage critics of the fcheme, of which therie have been many; some of them fearful of change and there fore hopeless m a moving world; some of them political and therefore prone to preju dice; and some of them of the chronic 'it can't be done school" who are perennial Like critics flourished 1800 rears ago when, having plan led abroad their standards

.'ictorious Roman legions re turned to And their homr lands ruined by erosion and neglect. But stout, hearts among them turned to Mago's reatise on farming theseml arid Carthage lands and Just as QBFO will feed Britain, *9 did Mago's technique (whiurt QBFO is using) feed Rome for centuries, the main difference in that where QBFO is using tractors the tlomans used slaves.

Td think of increased beef production for Britain from pastures that, after upwards of a century of indiscriminate Kraslng are inevitably run down, comes of using the blind eye and the .closed mind. To talk of costly new railways through low rainfall areas to open questionably "good country" when, for a fraction of the cost, land within better known rainfall and existing railway areas can be restored, by proved methods, to its tenner productivity is econ omic madness. Modern road transport will effectively prove any prospective new meat producing areas, and even railways have made few gar dens of Eden in Australia. Indeed, the pastoral degenera tion from which we now suffer took place largely within the range of existing railway. sys tems. It would not be true to ;ay that such pastoral degen eration took place because of such railwayed though it is quite true to say that it oc curred in spite of them-a fact not tp be lightly overlooked when airily planning new rail ways.

Fifty years ago the Central ist grazed 28 per cent of Central Queensland's sheep and 29 per cent of its cattle; but 39 years later it had only 14 per cent of the sheep and 15 per cent of the cattle Spfear grass and liver fluke drove out the sheep and pasture degeneration dimin ished the cattle. The district has thus passed through the 'sheep era, was well on the way

through the cattle era and ready, when the QBFO ap- I

peared, for the cultivation or I

regeneration era. The readi

ness with which owners of1 historic properties sold out is evidence that, if they did not' know or could not apply the remedy, they were poignantly aware of the disease.

Australia is the last civilised country on earth where beef is largely born, reared, and fat tened on the property from which it walks on its way to the meatworks. To the extent o! the feed' that, in the last century has produced many millions of pounds worth of beef, such beef was a gift from Provi dence, and the technique of its

production little above, that' employed by African native*. Zt is true that while the latter produced beet '? to trade tor wives, the former grew it-In the main-for the London market. But changing public demands higher quality beef, and weariness of soil and de cadence of pasture demands the revivifying touch of the magic plough. What the QBFO is doing in the Central-west, Is therefore not the gret breath of incipient Socialism, but the start of a mighty era of pas ture regeneration that, if Aus tralia is successfully to meet competition in pastoral pro ducts, must extend to the whole of her worn-out pas tures. In other words, the emphasis today is on the plough rather than on the rail way construction gang:

Because spectacular grain producing operations have monopolised the scene the im portance of grazing, to a com bined scheme of food produc tion and pasture regeneration, escapee general notice. But neither would get far without the-, other. The best open downs Central-west country averages about 60 per cent gloughable and the balance un ploughable; but operation of the essential 3-year crop rota tion-of which the best now in sight is gracing-will ultim ately reverse that ratio. With out reckoning stubble grazing (which is highly profitable* the half million acres now held by QBFO will have to be kept fully organised to maintain 200,000 acres under grain Hie balance will be grazing partly hand-fed stock on 60 per cent of the area,

and breeding and feeding pigs on the grain-growing remain der. As stubble grazing is specialised^ grasing, QBFC will no doubt avoid dependence upon public' sales for it* store cattle by breeding some of its

own.

Starting operations so ex pansive and comprehensive makes heavy demands on plant even in the ratio of one trictor per plough per seeder per header per 1000 acres; but it should be possible to work plant exchanges between sum mer harvesting Darling Downs and winter harvesting Peak Downs. In any case, to keep QBFO costs in touch with those outside it may be advis able not to cut out aD con tract ploughing. Complacency arising out of being comfort ably self-contained can play the very devil with efficiency.

So far QBFC has secured eight properties aggregating just under 500,000 acres: CulMn-to-ringa, Xbdert, Mag enta, MarmadlUa, Orion Downs, Peak Downs, Retro and Wolfgang, only six of which had head stations. Under sheep they probably carried an average yearly population of 50 souls per property, and fewer under cattle. This would

aggregate at most 500, or about one human per 5000 acres. Al ready Capella, Emerald and Springsure register a far dif ferent economic story, and the scheme is now just swinging into organised shape.

The main essentials to EUC cess in a venture such as this are basically sound planning, honerty of purpose and vigour of execution, and faith in the reviving power of regeneration. QBFC has them all, and only carping critics seem prepared to pit their doubts against a new era to breathe new life, where the old eras brought only lingering death.
heading: THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD Rockhampton THURSDAY, AUGUST 11. A STEP IN PASTURE REGENERATION

articleText:
-I,.I..I ..Ml I . . "'I

r THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD |

| B oc It b a m pi op

. ?? ..I . I ? l|." I ill III " ' .nil* ' III" l'

THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 3 ^

&REAT AUSTRALIAN PETROL MYSTERY

TPVSR since the relntroduc

tlon of rationing was moot ed the petrol baby has been tos sed about from one Interest to another, all seeking to avoid blame and, if possible, to de rive some special benefit for themselves. Responsibility for the shortage which . became Imminent as soon as ration Ins* and a possible price rise, was mentioned, was first level led at the hoarders-the self

ish and greedy with the money]

and the influence to buy many! 44 gallon drums so that they should have more than they could possibly require whoever else went short. The charge also was made that this type of hoarder was aided by cer tain oil companies who were , ready to make direct rales. A

further allegation was that the petrol famine was part of a political game, a reprisal "by the federal Government for having been deprived of con trol earlier in the year. If the lastnamed charge held it was the most reprehensible ' and indefensible act that

could be levelled against any responsible Government. The Prime Minister in his latest Sunday night talk tp the nation had much, to say about petrol. The burden of his song was that the oil companies were to blame for not playing the game as agreed upon. He said nothing about a political reprisal, " though others are barging it against him.

The common or garden

motorist, concerned only tfith keeping his commercial 'or private vehicle <f& the road*. j rightly or - wrongly believes thatthe key to thfe mysteryte price. Proclaim mat 3d. par gallon more can be chanted, or that from the date of ratton* lns a price reduction will be enforced, ahd they Relieve a miracle unparalleled since the rod of Moses 'emote the rock

will be performed overnight

What truth there resides in this, or in the chaises and countercharges, the position reflects little credit on'anyone, but tends point to the conten tion that what- Australia needs more-than anything else is a wholesome dose of -plain old fashioned'hohesty In dealings, and that goes for all sections of the community.

Here is one of the most pro sperous countries on earth. In no. imminent danger of war. faced'with insufficient liquid fuel to carry on the normal functions of industry and transport, and . with its next harvest in jeopardy. If the petrolis pot here it points to criminal neglect and incom petence on. the part of every one concerned. If the petrol is here and is being . deliber ately, withheld for private gain or political advantage those responsible are equally open to condemnation. The position l{i exasperating to all who have need of petrol and is be wildering and upsetting to the' public.

articleText:
THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD |

NATIONAL EFFORT AT HALF SPEED

r|T is no longer challenged

that Australian production at present is about 70 per

cent of Its capacity. A warn-1 liig. note is struck by the Katlonal Bank of Australia In Its monthly commentary. Capi tal expenditure on projects al mdy commenced need not necessarily be curtailed, since many of them are well ad vanced and founded on real needs. But greater selectivity and probably some reduction In planning of new ventures are required. Tha need In Aus tralia today is not so much lor capital equipment which uses more labour, but for that which saves labour. Labour ahortage is causing much exist

capltal equipment to stand . or to be only partly used. While month by month idle machinery is reported In the textile Industry, the printing Industry and metal trades it is paradoxical that plans for expansion which will require more labour in such industries should still be initiated. It seems scarcely less warranted to plan and develop new coal mines while costly machinery established In existing mines Is being worked no more than . single shift a day. Only if the rate of industrial expan sion slows down can increases to the' labour force provide .van a partial remedy. The reaction to this condition of affairs is becoming manifest in . most important respect. In vestors fire viewing Industrial prospects In Australia with greater reserve. The more favourable terms at. which Shares of new ventures and right* to new issues can be

bought suggest that Industrial expansion is regarded with waning enthusiasm by those who normally finance it.

Thus do the fruits of the five-day week, absenteeism and "go-slow" manliest themselves. The "greater leisure" for work ers has been achieved at the cost of idle plants when they should be running at futf capacity for the save of the industry and tbe needs of the community. One tiling that cannot escape notice is that these things are happening in the large centres of population. Textile and* other factories lie idle whilst ? fantastic induce ments are offered to workers to flit from one job to another.

Had the governments been sincere in their advocacy of decentralisation of industry and had made any serious en deavour to bring it about a different tale would be told. Wherever new Industries have been established In country centres, as In Victoria, there is a minimum of absenteeism, operatives are satisfied with their steady employment and good wage*, and the manage ments have expressed satisfac tion with labour of employ

ees.

Nowhere has the concentra tion of industries in the cities been fostered more than in Queensland. Hie other day the Premier returned from England with the promise of another overseas company coming to this State. Where is the factory to be estab lished? Rockhampton, Towns ville, Toowoomba ? No, it will I go to Rockies, a site that no I doubt was recommended.

DISCOVERING THE COUNTRY MAN

[pHEREare signs, which soon

must become distinguishable to the most casual in these things that Australian poli

ticians are becoming more | rural conscious than has been their wont. Perhaps the most striking instance of this is the pronouncement made by Mr R. G. Mens es, Leader of the Federal opposi tion, after a meeting of the Liberal Party's Joint standing committee on Federal policy on Monday. The committee had been considering recommenda tions from the Party's Federal rural committee on the popu lation drift, decline in exports of primary products, and the need for increased primary production.

At this meeting it was re vealed that in the three pre war years the average expoitb of meat, potatoes, raw sugar, cheese, butter, eggs, preserved milk, citrus fruits and dried fruits amounted to 866,000 tons. In the three post-war years this total had fallen to 606,030 tons. By 1955 it was estimated the total will be only 143,000 tons, unless the trend is check ed. if the population increases to 0.000,000 by 1955. as is ex pected. Australia will then be In the position of having to Import some primary products, especially potatoes and citrus fruits, in order to maintain the people at the present rate or consumption.

NB.W. can be taken as typi cal of the drift to the cities

ana the decline in rural popu- | latton and production. Sixty; years ago only one person In

three in NJ3.W. lived In 8yd-1

ney, but today the urban popu lation of Sydney end Newcastle accounts (or three fifths of the State's total Inhabitants. This, one of the most unhealthy economic balances that can be found anywhere In the world, is clc:ely related to water con servation. soil erosion and dim-. inlshlng occuplable land. Aus tralia is itn agricultural coun try, but unlike other agrarian cones Its birth-rate on the land Is slow and steadily decreasing. No Improvement in rural popu lation or birth-rate Is expected until soil and water conserva tion schemes stabilise the out back.-NJS.W. is lft years ahead of other States on its soil and water conservation caiapalgn, but it Is admitted authorita tively that it is still far short of what it should be.

What of the other 8tates, including Queensland? Re plying to a statement by the head or the State graziers' or ganisation. that the Queens land cattle industry was at the cross 'roads the Minister for Lands (Mr Foley) offered the opinion that Instead of being in danger the cattle industry was on the upgrade due to pasture improvement, caused by Government assistance since 1B33 In encouraging grai ltrs to rinsb&rk, create more water facilities and subdivide land by fencing. If that rep resents the highest point reached by the Queensland Government it will not do much towards saving rural in

dustry in this State. Some ? thing more than encourage Iment to rlngbarklng, conserv ilng water and subdividing pad j docks is required.

WHO IS AN AUSTRALIAN CITIZEN?

A RE you an Australian

cltieen? This question Is rais ed by the passing or the Nat tonality and Citlsenshlp Act 1MB, put came into force last month on the eve of Founda tion Day, on account of which Mr Oalwell held a seance vr

Investiture or something to turn j alien immigrants into Austra lian citizens, and also to make one of Australia"? Prime Minister.

Until now everyone In Aus tralia who gave thought to the matter believed that the mere fact of birth within Aus tralia gave to each child all the Australian rights it ever had. they will think different ly now that the Prime Minist er of, and a Cabinet Minister in, the OhUley Government have signified publicly that Jhm right* »c« oonferrad tg>

a Ministerial act In signing; a certificate of registration. They will think, too, that if the Min ister can confer such rights, so' also can he withhold them or even take them away. Upper most in the mind conies the query: "What rights do this square of Calwell parchment confer?" or what rights does non-registration withhold? Does it carry with It the equivalent of the American Bill of Bights, of which the Commonwealth of the Constitution is com pletely neglectful?" Yet all of these things are -the element* ary rights of every Australian by virtue of his being a subject of the British Empire. He need no Ministerial certificate to confer them, nor can-un less we so permit-Ministerial .diet tike them away.

articleText:
TOE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD $

ft o ,c k b ii m p t o p

THRU8DAY, MARCH 10.

- - ? . .

SCOUTING AS A DEMOCRATIC FORCE

.A *reat feature of the Scout

movement is its universal appeal to youth- Eskimo boys In the Arctic, like others in Darkest Africa, play the same games and are guided by the same principles m lads brought up In the world's most civilis ed countries. Country, race, creed, colour, all the things that have divided men and nations from time immemorial, have no meaning ty the Scout Code. This strikingly de monstrated at the recent in ternational Jamboree, when the flags of India and Pakis tan flew side by side, linked ? by the Scout emblem.

In view of these things It is encouraging to learn from its titular head that the Soout

movement is just beginning instead of being on the de cline. With this in mlpd and looking back, Jt Is easy to re alise why it was marked out for execution by the enemies of freedom. With Mussolini

and Hitler the Scout move ment vu declared tobe enemy Mo. 3, giving place only to Communism. With the Com munists It is glveri a similar rating, Fascism alone taking priority, ,

The leaders of Scouting are not alone alive to the tremen dous power Inherent in youth movements, as -the lata war amply demonstrated. Even in Australia there has .sprouted youth organisations of ques

re

m:

Iviebiment* Into

Scout organisation itself which is perhap*4be best com pliment that cdtild be paid to It, These,things.Impose a re sponsibility on parents and custodians of children in their tender years to see -that they are rightly guided in their af

filiations.

A COAL MINER THAT WILL NOT STRIKE

gACKED by many years of

patient labour that was fin anced by someone-in private enterprise-who was willing t*> risk money on an klea that might be right, "Colmol," a new coal winning and loading machine, has passed its num erous testa in USA and is moving Into mass production. The machine, Which was de monstrated at New Lexington, Ohio, In October last and at Finleyvllle. Pennsylvania, «n December, revaaled how to get more coal out of the ground with fewer men. It a'eo illustrated the formula oy which, under the capitalist system of free enterprise, "work can be made easier and the products of industry more plentiful and cheaper." It is claimed for the machines that cut and load In continuous operations which eliminate both drilling and blasting, that an output of 80 to 100 tons per man shift Is not onjy possible, but likely, as against .6.11 tons In USA, 2S tons In Australia, 1.11 tons In Britain and O-iU tons in France and Germany. Each machine requires a gang of four men, and produced when at work more than two tons of coal per minute!

"Colmor Is a further sign post on the road to progress. Just as was James Watt's dis covery that coal and wood could be converted into power to sbpplant thf limited physi cal capacities of men and their domestic animals. Labour saving machinery is the essen tial basis for the rise that has taken place over the years In USA more than anywhere In the general standard of liv ing. the reduced working hour.® and the lessened industrial, hazards. Without machinery the world's present population could not be fed, and its abo lition would put tack the clock of progress by BOO years to the days of the rush light and feu

dalism.

Hie attitude of rulers in Australia towards machinery Is akin to that of the mach inery . smashing Luddites of Britain of over 100 years age. On May 6, 1938, Mr Forde (now our High Commissioner in Canada) was at some pairs

I to tell the House of Repre

sentatives of the menace to mankind of the machine. HP showed that wlifc 2868 fever

I employees in 1929 tin-can jmakers In IJSA turned out

7.750,000 more cans than In 1916. and that the man-hours occupied were decreased h? more than one third. Another of our High Commissioners (Mr Beasley, London) moved the adjournment of the House on October 3, 1836, to urgfe the appointment of a committer to Investigate under sis heads, the aljWrs ofBroken Hill Coy. Ptjr.Vthe 6th of which was:

"To lorMtlcaU .the proposal of tbl» oompvxr farther to m>cfa»nlm tlH eMl-bwtrlo* ttpodti 1b tin NeviuU* tinu mating more unMplormcat."

8o far as the rack and file of-Australians know, this at titude towards the use of machinery to take the drud gery out of some, of the world's hardest work is still the offic ial - attitude therito of the Australian Labour Party. For all that most people know, that wooden plough technique gained for these two Labour stalwarts their present high posts-the highest outside of Australia-and Is still the ac cepted gospel of the Chifley regime. Any doubts on this head are silenced by the Chlfley attitude towards tax ation allowances on mechan isation, that are so Inade quate that income tax is fre quently paid on capital spent for this purpose.

Mr Baddeley, Minister for Mines in the McKell Labour Government refused permis sion on January 7, 1944. for Abermaln No 2 colliery, NSW, I to use mechanical appliances I to win and. load coal from [pillars. He also refused per I mission to the Commonwealth

Goal Commissioner for the tase of mechanical appliances for loading coal from a new pillar section . at Coalcliff colliery " with . A view to Increasing coal, production for defence purposes."

With such a record put up by High Priests of Labour, prospects of an adequately mechanised coal industry in Australia are remote.

articleText:
TEE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND BWULD

BockbamptoD

^ HOCKHAMPTON, JULY 14. \

?iWii-- I1I»I- I«<ww»i-«-i»i'ii«iw

DOWN TO EARTH IIS WORLD COMMERCE

f*DMXNO on top of an insis . tent demand that Britain . Coming on top of an insist ent demand that Britain should add to her Import dif ficulties Jay devaluing sterling, the Anglo-Argentine trade pact, which virtually amounts to barter is a clear reminder that, hard-up as she is and desperate as her food position, die Is not disposed to accept easily the role of the world's financial scape-goat. It should also remind Australia that the easiest way to. meet rising costs and prices is no longer merely to pass them on to Britain. Argentina is not a member of the Bretton Woods financial agreement and is free, therefore, to make the best bargain possible with any other country for her export able surplus, and If between herself and another country there exists "a double coin cidence of wants," she may get aldng quite nicely. But such trade flows through very con stricted channels, the balance, is exposed to cross currents, that. are not always predict able, and restoration of world financial conditions to more; stable levels would result in; conditions through which1 both contracting parties might1

do much bettor for themselves If their trading operations were linked with stabilised national currencies.

The world has moved a long way since practically all non Axis powers met In confer ence at Bretton Woods, USA, just five years ago to de vise plans for a world monetary fund and reduction of trade barriers. Much dead wood has been cut away, many obstacles have been surmounted, many fallacies exploded and much hot air, hae been dissipated. Now as; never before Bretton Woods the countries face each other

across a series of 'irreducible problems that resolve them-,

selves into such awkward dls-j

closures as that full employ ment does not mean less em ployment, such as emerged In Australia soon after die sign ed the pact; that capitalism works only when its units work, and when socialism works It la because dictators see to It that all hands work; that if It Is everybody's re sponsibility to find work for others, it is no bos the re sponsibility of "others" to do It. There is a growing acceptance of the elementary fact that the wealth of a country Is its people and the work of those people; that the success of democracy depends jupon our will and courage, our Imag ination and unselfishness.

The simple fact is that so much has been stripped from the International monet ary and trade problems that only the hard core remains, and it Is a very hard core in deed. It amounts to get ting world economy down from its precarious perch to saner, more stable levels. Divested of Its trimmings, world economy simply means the' Interchange of goods and services on terms that are mutually beneficial, when the difference between a buyers' and a sellers' mar ket is . not a profitable haven for marketeers. The popular idea that the happiest way out of* money shortage Is to print more of It Is really on the wrong side of the equa tion, for the only real way out of a goods shortage Is to work harder and produce more of them. There never was any alternative to really hard work, supplemented with , the best mechanical labour savers that the ingenuity of 'man can devise and the lab

our of his hands can turn out.

articleText:
TBE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD

RockVatn pt o to t THUR8QAY, MAY 38

MIGRANTS COULD HELP C.Q. PROGRESS

J^IETARY it du king an »v»,r i

- Increasing demand on ex pert direction because of the needs of hospitals, kinder gartena, day nurseries and other public and private Institutions N.8.W has two training schools for die titians-one each at Newc<>stlo and North Shore Royal Ho*pi tals North Shore took up this branch only this year. Com

pared with the large number 1 of Jobs offering, plU3 the fa«t that students are paid £5/14.' per week whUe training, the number of trainee dietitians i.» small. The course lasts ii months and all trainees are required to have a 8Sc degree, and to have specialised in physiology and bio-chemistry.

The importance or expert opinion In dietary and nutri tion is recognised in most parts of the world. Governmental health departments have a nu trition branch, the primary task of which is to educate the public in nutrition, to show them how to correct Ill balanced diets, how to over come foolish food fallacies, and how to make raealc inter esting and varied. Consider ing the time ir.inklnd has been engaged in the business of ab sorbing food, and the fact that the average person spends about five years of his lifetime in eating. It might be sugges ted Out he should require very little teaching as to what he should eat and drink for his health and general wel!-beinp. But such is not the case. As a fact nutrition Is something about which the .average per son knows little or nothing, and those who have given som-: study to the subject are often dubbed "food faddists."

) For the rest, much illness and permanent Incapacity are trace able to indulgence in wrong foods. A recent report issued by the Commonwealth Bureau of Statistics showed that Aus tralians today were getting less Vitamin A in their diet than was hitherto the case. This was traced to a decreased con sumption of tomatoes and green

vegetable, una also to a teaser

| ration of cgss and iiuiter. Aue | trla produ ;ej all thsse foods In [ abundance, p.nd whilst in cieaaecl prices v.r>:icubt#«:U7 had an inrtyenoe on itlllng con sumprfon, Jtpu.V .'gnoririice of the vatae of these- foods and I thstr neemsIt)- for the main

tenance of health was the matt: reason for the decline. Australia'* eating habits also show *Jut the intake of cal cium if less than it should he. .specially in the case of grow ing children. Foods rich in calcium are milk, cheese, eggs, crecnleaf vegetables and nubs. Cheese is a food that is Ig nored as a regular item of die tary by a very large number of people. It seldom is included in -their grocery order, and their only acquaintance with It is when it is served with a biscuit at some informal party involving light refreshments.

According to the dietitian of the New 8outh Wales Health Department, a great deal of the Australian diet is a hit-or mlss affair. In order to eat wisely wis must know which foods are essential for normal health and growth, which groups of foods are equivalent, so that they can be substituted

one for another in the inter ests of variety, and what quan tities of each are needed by persons in different age groups and engaged in different kinds

of work.

Hence the need for more die titians. But this is something in which the individual can render a great deal of self help, if he Is encouraged to do so. There Is available a not inconsiderable literature on diet and nutrition; it should be made even more readily acces sible in pamphlet form. A wider knowledge of this Im portant subject would not only hare e marked Improvement in national health, but would mean a tremendous saving, by avoiding the wrongful use of foodstuffs that have now as sumed a value never before ac corded them.

TEACHING THE PEOPLE WHAT TO EAT

rpHERE is doubtless much

truth in the assertion that a revival of the pioneer spirit would b« a most valuable fac tor in the progress of this or any other district, especially now that the accent is so much on food production and the need for development of our primary industries. But the question naturally arises as to where it may be sought None is so optimistic as to believe that now conditions on the land have been immeasurably Improved, It will put into re verse the drift to the cities.

Fortunately there is another source which holds possibilities of meeting the need- No

one can foretell the results j

that will ultimately come from i the great inflow of immigrants I

that da now gaining Impetus. But ft ts reasonable to assume that, amongst the thousands

seeking to begin a new life In Australia, will be many from land-hungry countries who would be prepared to make al most any sacrifice to aettle themselves on the land and win security and prosperity. The migration flow suggests a source from which a fresh wave of pioneer settlers may be recruited, and it is for local and governmental "agencies to offer every encouragement in this direction. Otherwise in 30 years' time we may still be talking about the ' wonderful potentialities" of Central Queensland, in the meantime having done little about devel oping and exploiting them.

articleText:
IF

THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND BERALD j

v n OckfalUptOO

THURSDAY, JANUARY, 6,

?0RE MOVES OUT OF COMMONWEALTH

. «

*fWENTY-SIX year* ago uo

tier the OOvernment of Ire land Act, 1930, at amended by the Irish Free State {Conse quential Provisions) Act; 1923, a separate Parliament and executive government were es tablished for Ulster, or North* era Ireland, which includes the counties of Antrim, Armagh, Down, Fermanagh, London ' derry and Tyrone, and the

boroughs of Belfast and Lon donderry, It Is this that the Irish mean when they speak at "Partition" with much the saw fervour that their forbears used 50 or so years ago In relation to Home mile. Critical observers declare that friend' ship between the two countries U never likely to be complete and unreserved so long as par tition remains. But wlta that so typically Irish Inconsequen tial attitude towards even vital problems, the fact that (he Roman Catholics form the largest **lngle community In Ulster does not mean that they share the mama of their southern co-religionists for partition. There seems to be far more In it than that, and the 600,000 or so other relig ionists-largely Presbyterians is by no means the answer.

Tan years ago prophets were abroad who preached both in , and out of season the Inevit

ability of Eire's economic doom, and produced logic to prove they could not be wrong. Tbey are not eo sure now, even though Mr Bean Lemass, Min ister for Industry, admits that the people of Eire have not always shot up to his produc tion targets. The main reason for that was emigration, by which Sire lost each year from 25,000 to MXHO of her best yotmg men and women, and it adds another to the long list of Irish incongruities that most of them went to Britain. One ration for that was higher \ Wfges, another was that, de

?' tpne war ravages, it was easier

to get a house in Britain than in Eire. Britain made her houses while Eire imported Hum or the material to make them. Then Kir Lemass de cided that as Eire has abund

.

FIRST STEP COULD I

rrag New Year commences

* with many urgent problems to be faced by Australia. In certain quarters a desire has been shown, backed with all the enthusiasm of a Mew Year resolution. to tackle tbem earn estly. Unfortunately there also are discouraging signs of an equally strong determination 1© pull in the opposite direc

tion.

The gravest questions to be tackled in the coming year concern halting rising prices * goes on without cessation,

and reversing the falling rate of production that has done so nuich to upset the economic equilibrium In the last 12 - mfrhihs- The State Govern

ment*. acting In accord, have made (he first move to check rising prices by ordering a H per cent reduction in soft goods lines and by instituting

inquiry with a view to ex tending the reductions to other ^taring and furnishing com

modities.

Whether or not this will do very much good remains <b be seen> It is sincerely to be 1 toped that it is not another com of rushing into one of those ill-considered, half-baked

.nee of limestone she would get farther along the road to self sufficiency If she built come cement factories.

It vu then that somebody discovered that one of tbe main planks In tbe Eire platform on breaking away from Britain was to protect tbe village and village life. The result of this discovery was truly astonish ing, for people interested in constructing factories were shepherded into the eounipy, with tbe result that today fac tories are spread all over rural Eire.

Another factor in stabilising Eire life Was the Inability dur ing the war to import coal and petrol, and again an economic blackout produced tbe discov ery. It was that Eire has abundance of potential power In turf and water, and already vast schemes are well in hand. By 1951 it Is estimated that the whole of the country's farms and factories will be electrified. The Shannon is to produce 273,000,000 units, tbe *rne about 900,000,000 and the same from other streams, while two turf-burning stations are to produce riother 200,000,000 units.

These are important facts, reaching as they do into domestic, economic and political realms, and permeating every comer of the Eire national life. Ifo longer is it Inescapable that at least one in every family of four must emigrate. Hie dis tribution of population and in dustry will soon be such that a youth will emigrate now not because he must, but because be so wishes.

Tbe changed economy In Hre will result in an Improved liv ipg standard, making for a more contented people, who will in turn be better fitted to meet tbe cross-currents of nation hood. For cross-currents there will be, for tbe Slrean Govern ment has undoubtedly made Eire a foreign country, and these axe anxious days for small States Whose greatest asset is

a fierce desire for Independ-j anee without tbe corresponding power to defend It.

i IAVE BEEN iN TUNE

schemes of which introduction or tbe 40-hour week, is the j most tragic example. In any i case, It Is something that j should, if possible, be brought about after tbe fullest consul tation permissible with the tracers.

It may be questioned, there-: fore, whether tbe Acting Prem ier's ungracious refusal of a request for a month's respite in Queensland, as In the other States, Is the best augury for success. Mr Oair has bluntly indicated that tbe cuts must operate from tbe proclaimed date, and traders must extri cate themselves as best they can from any difficulties in which they become Involved. That is the best possible way to create hostility and start a quest for loopholes, where the exhibition of a little toleration; and an appeal for cooperation might bring far better results, j If the 71 per cent reduction in soft goods is to be tbe first:

check to the splr&l of rising'

prices, and the possible fore runner of a more stable domestic economy in Australia, a few weeks longer in getting It under way without friction would have been well worth achieving.

articleText:
. . - - - ?? .-v. tr -r^r t

p THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD

H o c k h a m p t\> n

THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 10,

_ _ ? . ' ' ___ _ _

COLOURED ENGINES-AND WHY NOW?

RAILWAYS are vested with

a romasce for many people. In Britain boys colelct -engine names and numbers with .the same zest as others . accumu late postage stamps and birds' egfts. Many thousands of tw'sicis containing the names and number it every .engine, and their photographs, are sold each week. One publish ing house devotes its entire output to railway books alone. People with a passion for rail ways are to be ?ound in every class of society. It is to be found also among thousands of

railway servants; it. was in i some measure this strange ro

mantic power of inspiration ; which saw them through the. strain of the war and drew from them something closely : skin to heroism. i

It is claimed that it is the railway engine which creates this thrill and invests the op eration of a railway with a strong sense of romance. People who habitually watch railways may find all sorts of things to interest them-the intricacy of working, the load ing of goods and malls, the innumerable types of human beings to be found amongst the travelling public; but the locomotive is the real magnet. Hence there resides a danger that too great a degree of standardisation in railway en gines may be economical. in working but wasteful in this

hidden asset.

"On the day that the steam locomotive is ousted from the railway," writes Canon Roger Lloyd in "Time and Tide" '"the intangible asset of romance and thrill will go too, and it may be found that the rail ways have lost something of

immense value to them andto the community. It would al most be as though they had lost their soul. It Is quite im possible to invest an engine less electric train, however gaily painted, with what the same string of coaches has if only there is an engine in front of It. When the steam engines go it may be found that for utilitarian efficiency there is a very high price to be paid." Nearly all drivers and firemen and cleaners

have a deep, interest and pride in their Job, and their sense of craftsman ship is to some extent tied to the type of engine with which they are connected. The work on the footplate is often rough, but it Is never dull or monotonous, and If they were to start work again as a boy, it would be the locomotive sheds for them once more.

So it would appear there is something to be said for the colour- scheme which Queens land's Transport Minister will ' attach to his railway engines. I It recognises something pf value iboth from the point of view lof the service and the public.

Not the least important aspect is that it indicates a desire to give'the railways a more per sonal Interest to those who use as well as those who work them. To achieve this in full measure it will be necessary, of course, to do something more than paint* the engines bright colours, and it is to be hoped that Mr Duggaa's seal will induce him to explore fresh paths, in which laudable aim he will not lack aid from outside, where the obvious does not force itself upon his notice.

articleText:
THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD j

STATE AND COMMONWEALTH POWERS

-- - - \

.THE prevailing Common

wealth-Stats Bet-up is caus ing thoughtful folk seriously to think whither the seven Par liaments ate leading Australia, and what arc the constitu tional checks between the people and the greed or ag gression of any one of the seven- The question really boils down to the relations between Commonwealth and State Governments, and the extent to which power is moving from one to the other. Since the coming into power of the Curtln-Chlfley regimes * the Constitution of the Common wealth has been strained and tested as never before, nor have there been many monthi during which the Common wealth Government has not been before either the High Ccurt of Australia or the Privy Council, through en*" deavouring to assume powers which are not contained in the Constitution, and have furthermore been resolutely refused by electors -when asked for them by referendum. In short, the Federal Labour Government has tried as h*i no other Government before It to over-ride the powers of the States, and circumvent the wishes of the electorate.

One factor In the feeling of constitutional security Is the operation of the State Grant* (Income Tax Reimbursement) Act, 1042, better known as the system of uniform rates and tax collection. This Act came into force on July 1, 1942, and Is to continue in operation "until the last day of the first financial year to commence after the end of the present war." It was unsuccessfully challenged by the Government of Victoria, and the feeling - reinforced by a tactless claim by the Federal Treasurer - is that its operation will be

permanent, as so many things have happened since the shooting oeased that few people realise that, technically, the war is still on. It is quite competent, however, (tor the Commonwealth Government prematurely to repeal the Act, and so restore to the States their fundamental tights of taxation; but that is not thf Chifley way. There is not even the beginnings of discussion* regarding what is to happen when the Act falls to the ground through effluxion of time, and this adds colour to the growing belief that the present system is here for good -If the Chifley Government has anything to say in th* matter. »

There are many aspects of uniform taxation that should «emaln, though experience of fjje power-grabbing proclivities of Canberra suggest that such : permanent retention would

[create more problems than it

solves. We can pay too much for uniformity of anything, and when with any kind of uniformity goes increased cen tralisation of power the cobt can easily be tragic. Arguments for perfect forms of govern ment of human affairs are al

ways based upon the assump tion that perfect individuals will be on hand to run the show; but even a casual student of history is quick to realise that power always be gets arrogance. In any case, uniform taxation should neither be taken for granted by the Commonwealth Gov ernment, nor surrendered without protest by the States. The matter should be settled less with a view to conferring power on either State or Fed eral Governments, than 1th regard to what is best for the Australian people.

VICTORIAN PROBE INTO COMMUNISM

*pHE terms of reference In

the Bill appointing a royal commission to conduct en In quiry Into Communist activi ties In the State of Victoria, permit of a probe Into the very things on which an over whelming majority of the Aus tralian people desire to have unimpeachable testimony. Hiare is no better machinery than a royal commission to elicit such evidence, as is be ing demonstrated at the pres

ent moment in connexion with the* complicated saga of the Mew Ouinea timber aeal.

In introducing the BUI the Premier (.Mr Hallway ex plained that the terms of ref erence require th« commis sioner to Inquire into and re port upon the origins, alms and objects of the Communist Party In Victoria, the activities and operations of the party and its members in Viotoria. and of associated organisations and persons. In particular, the commissioner will bi re quired to Inquire whether the party, by its constitution or propaganda or any of its mem ben, by propaganda or other wise, advocates or encourages the overthrow by force or vio lence of established govern ment; whether the activities of the party or its members arte designed to effect or accom plish the overthrow or disrup tion of representative or demo cratic institutions, subversion of law and order, attainment of social, economic, Industrial or political ends by force, vio lence. Intimidation or fraudu lent practices; dislocation or disruption of .services safe guarding or essential to the maintenance of the life, health and welfare bf the commun ity; dislocation, disruption of ntardatton of Industrial pro

ductlon; Indoctrination of children and young people with beliefs or ideas calculated or likely to result in activities and operations of the natur* already referred to.

That there should be a howl against the Bill from the Yarra Bank and from Com munist-controlled unions, with a threat of a paralysation of the economic lire of the Stat* if the Commission is appoint ed. was to be expected. Apart from their fears .of the reper cussions It provides another weapon to create a stoppage in industry, with consequent loss and hardship; and that after all. Is their' first charge.

This line that would be fol i lowed by the Communists could i be foreseen, but it is incredible

that objection to the measure has Deeh taken by the Oppo sition (Country and Labour) parties in the Victorian As sembly, since their interest in having these matters cleared up Is as vital as that of the Government of the day. Coun try and Labour members kept up a continuous fire of inter jections while Mr Hollway was explaining the BUI. HP appealed to them not to make a political crisis out of the measure, and warned that If they did so the responsibility would rest upon them. Th? purpose of the royal commis sion, he emphasised, is to dis close to the public the exact nature of the Communist dan ger* it was no use saying they knew all about the Commun ist dahger, and to combat It they must have an educated public behind the Government. The important thtoft was to let the people know Just what 'Communism is, and a Royal Commission was the most ef-. fective means of doing this.

articleText:
| THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND UERALD\

Rock bamp.too

THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 17.

HOW MANY DOCTORS SHOULD WE HAVE?

TJECURHINO reports of some

country hospital or township being without a regular medi cal service owing to the de parture of the resident doctor and inability to replace him

has created an impression In |

the minds of many people that medicine must "be one of the under-manned professions and that there will be an Insuffi ciency of doctors not only to meet present demands, but to satisfy the requirements of a growing population. Conse quently it Is Illuminating to learn that the problem of the medical profession presents it self in a directly opposite light to its leaders and to the uni versity authorities.

The question is discussed with frankness in a recent article in the "Sydney Morn ing Herald" by Dr Herbert Schllnk, chairman of the Royal Prince Alfred Hospital Board. What is the total number of medical men required to give the people of Australia an efficient medical service? Di verse opinions prevail on this point, and in seeking the answer the ratio of doctors per 10,000 of population in various countries is examined. The United States tops the list wltn 14.0. New South Wales cornea next with 10.3, the United Kingdom 9.5. Canada (1929) 8.1. Britain proposes to in crease her ratio to 11.8 to meet the requirements of the National Service Act and the USA is seeking to reduce hers to 13.5 as it is considered the present number is beyond the country's normal requirements.

Dr Schllnk considers i Aus tralia would be wise to adopt a ratio of one doctor to every 1000 of population, which would ensure an adequate and high standard of service to the public. The Commonwealth's population at January, 1949, was «sUmated at 7,710.110, so that the 7,710 doctors regis tered In the various 8tates work out at the desired ratio. Assuming last year's popula tion Increase of 130,871 to be maintained or increased in the

next 10 years, the population of Australia at the end of that period will be 9,000,000, re quiring 9000 doctors.

How many medical schools will be required to satisfy re placements when the popula tion reaches that figure? Ac cording to the highest British

authorities, one medical school to approximately 2,250,000 of the population is the ideal standard. There are at pre sent four medical schools (n Australia-Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide and Bhsbane-and Western Australia and Tas mania are each proposing to es tablish one. Dr Schllnk it strongly of opinion that addi tional schools tihould not be con templated until the population reaches the 94)00,000 mare. British medical authorities lay down a maximum standard of one medical student to 23,000 of population. On that basis Australia's 9,000,000 people would require 387 to 400 stu dents distributed over the four existing medical schools. How should they be apportioned? Already there is overcrowding, especially at the Sydney school. On the present population the distribution of students should be: Sydney 130, Melbourne 108, Brisbane 42, Adelaide 20; and in 1969 the respective figures should be: Sydney 176, Mel bourne 140, Brisbane 55 and Adelaide 30.

It has been suggested, ob serves Dr Schllnk, that the

flooding of the profession has 1 been designedly brought about 1 in the interests of the Fed- 1 eral Government's contem- < plated scheme of socialisation

of the medical profession; but ' a more obvious reason Is the < ignorance and lack of actual 1 study of a problem which, if i wisdom prevailed,'should have < been left to the faculty deans : of the various universities. Still, the modern habit is tot powerful unions to take over foreign, policy and politicians, legal luminaries, big business and union secretaries to direct the medical profession.

HIGH COST OF SICKNESS IN INDUSTRY

rTHE general impression is

that, notwithstanding free medicine schemes and the like, Australia is, on the whole, a very healthy country and ex cepting for the periodical in fluenza epidemics, which de plete staffs for a time, the loss to industry on account of ill ness is negligible. Consequently it must come as a surprise to learn from such a reliable authority as the bulletin of the Queensland Bureau of In dustry that Australia lost about £40,000,000 from sickness during 1648. an amount that represents 2} per cent of the national Income.

An investigation into the nature of the sicknesses which occasioned this considerable loss reveals that, for the most part, minor ailments are the chief contributing cause. A high production loss is caused by illnesses which are not ser ious enough to cause incapac ity, and this has raised the question of the necessity of an all-out drive to minimise the incidence of minor ailments. To achieve this it is considered that nursing and medical at tention on the spot would p'ay a very big part in saving the

national loss. I

The influence of health on industry is a condition that is not, of course, peculiar to Aus tralia. It affects other indus trial countries and has invited similar investigation as to causes and remedial measures. A recent survey of sickness in England and Wales revealed some interesting points. The survey showed that the inci dence of sickness increased with age. and is greater for females than for males. The risk of injury falls with age for males, and for females falls to a minimum at ages between 35 and 44, and then rises steeply. Despite the greater number of Illnesses, the days of Incapacity per illness for females Is lower than for males, particularly at ages between 25 and 64. This is a reflection of the fact that incapacity for males and for young women means absence from work,

while for housewives it means ? being confined to bed. Higher , figures for incapacity and con- , sultatlons per Illness for the , 16-24 age group suggest that ; young people have fewer minor , ailments, and the smaller num ber of total ailments recorded contains a higher proportion of more serious illnesses.

LIBERAL-CP MEN FIX BATTLEFIELDS

rJTHE Liberal-Country Party

election agreement is of special interest to Central Queensland voters, in that it clears the air concerning the electorates of Capricornia and Dawson. Common sense has pre%'ailed in allocating one each to Liberals and Country Party. Mr Davidson, sitting member fof Capricornia, re tains his party affiliation and about 11,000 Capricornia voters by accepting the Dawson nom ination. As his own farming interests also reside in the electorate he should win the new seat for the Country Party. What remains of old Capricornia should be won by the Liberals, since the consid erable number of voters who Indicated their desire for a change of Government at the last election are likely to be added to ifrther than dimim Ished. to ensure that result.

it Is imperative that the great est possible care be taken in the selection of a suitable can didate, one who is known and will command a solid vote in all the main centres. Caprl cornia is now a compact area which can be completely cov ered in an active, well con ducted campaign.

It is highly gratifying that agreement has been reached in ample time to permit can didates '.and organisations thoroughly to organise their electorates. The Federal elec tion is not expected before De cember. To hold it earlier would be advantageous to the Government in some respects, but it would not give time for the taxation cuts and social benefits to show tnelr full ef fects, and it is a well-recog nised political axiom that the events of the last nine months in the life of a Parliament

r

count most in determining the result of an election.

Whilst the outcome of Lib eral-Country Party differences in Queensland is a happy one, the necessity remains for simi lar adjustments elsewhere. A complete merger is being aimed at in Victoria. If that is not possible there should be no obstacles, excepting those of a

personal nature, to an election' agreement similar to that I

achieved here. The important thing is to heal all breaches and settle down to the task of winning the election, and giv ing the people of Australia the alternative to a socialistic gov ernment for which there has been shown an unmistakable deelr*.

articleText:
TBE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD

-J? o c k b a m p i.V|>

"rttCRgPAY, NOVEMBER, 17.

COAL WILL REIGN KING fOR Y^ARS YET

JT IB ironical, that, in the

face of Australia's unprece dented anxiety to get coal, many miners and some own ers fear a slump in the de mand for their product. These misgivings are not shared, by the Coal Board, which has told mine owners of NSW that all the coal won in* the next" ten years will have a market There is no indication, that coal will be superseded in Aus tralia by other sources t of power. OH- and petrol are- more expensive and they have to be imported. Hydro electric schetaes such as the Snowy Mountain and Burdekin Dams admittedly will provide a lot of electric power, but it will be a long time before they art* functioning, at anything like capacity. Commercialised atomic energy lies In an in definite period. in the future. In any case certain industries, especially steel manufacture, must always rely on coal.

As far as can be seen ahead coal will continue to be icing in the industrial world, and the problem for Australii is how to get enough of It. With our unbounded deposits, that should be the least Instead of the greatest of our industrial problems. Yet the* difficulties lying in the path of the ex ploitation of the Central Queensland deposits afford the strongest evidence of how real are the handicaps. They ore not insoluble for many of them are njan made, and should be the more easily re moved on that account. On the general outlook there Is no ground-for discouragement at the prospects for Central Queensland coal. With proper attention to production and handling costs they will yet play their full pqrt in the nation's progress and pros perity.
