articleText:
| THE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD }

R o ck b a up ton

Thursday, ~ *£48

LONG-STANDING CHARGES CONFIRMED

fTTHE astonishing aspect of the

Sharpley apostasy Is its meagre fruits, though this may be more than matched by the avidity with which his betrayal of .colleagues of 14 years has been swallowed. Yesterday he was Communist leader in full enjoyment of the confidence of men who are sworn to over throw .the existing rule of law in Australia, and as such was abhorred of all right-thlnklnp Australians. Today, he is an .ex-communist informer sob bing out his story on the Shoul der of his formerin tended vic tim, and we have it that Can berra is. rqshlng to the ram parts every available defender "against the risk of Commun

ist sabotage In naval dock- I yards, military establishments

and research stations." The1

trouble will be to discover how I

many of the Government's so- j

called "defenders" are not in faot ardent Communists,

In view of the fact that!

the absent Prime Minister has refused to regard Com

munism as other than a i

political philosophy, and the i Acting prime Minister hasI likened it to the philosophy of Christ.

The fact of the matter Is that with alert-minded Gov ernments who paid even the most cursory attention to their vows to maintain Australian laws and the Australian way of life,- there was no need for 'gentlemen of the Sharpley cal

ibre. But so Government pledged to "the socialisation of Industry, production, distribu tion and exchange" could stem

the Communist onslaught, tor this «as a Communist objeo? tire from its first acceptance by the Australian Labour Party more than 36 yean ago. Communism and <ab our have shared ' that ob jective ever since 1922 aad they £bare it nov. * For the first time in history Labour got con trol at the national Parliament in 1946, since when Commun Ist-Labour collaboration has been increasingly close.* Com munist assaults on the Com monwealth Arbitration Court were met by creation of Courts of Conciliation Commissioners, many of whom-appointed by the Chifleys-were fhrot-llne Communists or union agita tors! As well sack the faithful kelpie ana employ a p^k of dingoes, yet In sober truth that is what tiie Chifley Govern ment actually did.

For his part, the Communist has moved according to sche dule. For the five years to IMS under the Curtin-Chlfley regimes the average number of days lost through strikes amounted to 737,800 per an num, and at no time did any year go over the million mark. For the two years 1948 and 1947 the average number of days lost per annum through strikes was 1,643,290; but for the first sis months of 1948 the number of days lost through strikes was 1.161,190! Mr. Chifley, In his efforts to na tionalise Australia, has no cause for complaint -or lack of Industry of his Comhnmlst collaborators.

, CLIMATE AND LIVING CONDITIONS

rTNDKR the direction of the

'Professor of Physiology

Queensland University is con ducting -experiments on the re actions of man and beast to climatic conditions In the

tropics in order to secure use ful data on adaptation prob lems connected with the more Intensive colonisation of the region. The University isr to spend £10.000 under a three year programme, to study the

behaviour of humans and ani mals. , .

Hie value of such a study can hardly be over-stressed, especially in view of the in flow of migrants from other countries and the desirability of establishing a large number of than In the under-populat ed vulnerable tropical'north.' The Inevitable hardships as sociated with such transfers must be minimised if the new cbmers can be instructed on

I scientifically based lines on [ houslAg, clothing, food and

other Important details affect* ting their neW wayofllfe. To attempt to settle people from [the temperate dimes of Bur

ope bnd America in the steam

ing tropical belt, or the blister- 1 tag dry heat of Cloncurry,

without some such aid 1 to their . wxOimattsation, <

i? tO >|MflB)(i^l011E- 1 ly to the <llffleulae«,tf not ; to oourt failure-notwltiMtand ing fffilttMf TfWffj fff the Baltic cane cutters and th« mannftr 4n which 'our plonper settlers pulled.thnmgh. In

deed, it Js surprising ttat such : astudyvwfiot rnxfr^ia ago Xt would June savedliiin suf fering amongst people wtto re

tained the hotting, food. and

clothing fcabltrofthe land of their ttith' undtt tilniAtte con

dittons totatijr nnrait^d to :

articleText:
????-I-I- iW

TBE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD 1

R o $ ltha m p t on

ttOCKHAMPTON, JUNE i.

UMVERSAL SERVICE REFERENDUM

WITH the headlines pro?

claiming .' the fall of Shanghai to the Commun ists, the Reds gaining ground in Japan, the bitter anti Australian note in Philip pine legislative debates, and the unsettled and uncertain conditions in Indonesia and Malaya, it do. ' not encourage the contemplation with equan Unity of Australian defence problems. On the contrary,

these things endo<v the matter I with a senre of urgency, be sides lending point to the re vival of discussions on uni versal service now taking place

It is beyond challenge that i the voluntary system of re

cruiting for the services has ' proved deficient almost to the j point of complete breakdown, !

for enlistment figures have fal

len woefully short of the very I low. targets fixed. Every de vice of attractive uniforms, promises of high pay and' easy times have failed-in their <£i

Ject; yet there still must be ]

someone in the famy Depart

ment who clings to the hope of : bringing in recruits with the1 aid of the big drum and loud speaker, since another mobile column Is soon to' be turned loose. Qf course'there is the usual official spokesman who speaks optimistically, of the an

ticipation of good results. 1 v

60 much for the Army. In the case.of the Air Force, men are being sought in Britain, and the RAN has had to waive some of its physical and med ical. standards to* admit cer tain ratings. This is Aus tralia's position it a time when the question of a Pacific secur ity. pact is occupying the thoughts of all the countries to whom it is a matter'of con

cern.

It -has now been made' clear that the United States, for the present at all events, will not negotiate a Pacific defence agreement on the lines of the Atlantic Pact. This intima tion will be received with dis appointment by all who . had hopes that America would place herself in the forefront of Pacific defence. Instead of do ing so the United States has said in effect that, whtyst ap proving the principle of de fence cooperation in the Pacific; she /already has her

hands full and others can go

ahead and devise a plan into

which she can enter later.

To some competent observers this put? it up to Australia to take the lead in the Pacific, since it can no longer be ex pected that Britain, will shoul der the Pacific burdens site has in the past. Any such de fence agreement must embrace not only Australian, British, American, Dutch and French interests, but must give cog nizance to India and Ceylon. In what position is Australia

tc^ undertake this lead an# to request other nations to pre pare themselves for defensive action? Enlistment -figures for defence services give the best answer to that query. *

How other countries regard the urgency of Pacific de fence preparedness may be gathered from current develop ments in New Zealand. The Labour Cabinet is unanimous that universal service is the plain duty of the Dominion, and whilst the Labour confer ence has rejected the Govern ment's recommendation to that end the Prime Minister (Mr. Praser) has announced that a referendum of the people will be taken as soon as Parlia ment authorises tne necessary expenditure. At the same time the Leader of the Opposition has made a declaration that his Party is prepared to ac cept it as a duty to carry a full share of burden, and when it assumes the respon sibility of government It will make full provision for univer sal defence training.

What of Australia? The deputy Leader of the Liberal Party has urged the Govern ment to follow the lead of New Zealand «nd> hold a referen dum on universal training "in view'of the sorry failure of re cruiting drives and the defence programme, for which the Gov ernment must be held crimin ally responsible." It Is evident that Mr. Frawr returned from the Commonwealth Prime Min isters' Conference Imbued with a sense of urgency in regard to Pacific defence, but all we have heard from Mr. Chifiey is something vague about "ap propriate arrangements" and Mr. Dedman (Minister for De fence) has talked with equal vagueness about the develop? ment of Australians plans.

Allowing that the Govern ment has not the courage, or does not see the necessity, of bringing in universal service, whht possible objection can it have to giving the people of the Commonwealth the right to express their views on the matter? In fact, the aston-. ishlng tiling is that they do not welcome such an opportun ity. They are adept enough at "passing the buck" In other things and in this instance they would have some justifica tion for throwing on to the shoulders of those most direct ly concerned responsibility for deciding the most vital prob lem they are ever likely to be faced with. The answer, of course, that the Government is under the thumb of outside influences. In the case of New Zealand the Labour conference rejected recommendation for a referendum, but the Govern ment intends to hold it never theless.

articleText:
TBE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD

, ?CE o c k b a m p t o n

THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 24

PLACING THE FIRST AUSTRALIANS

TN THE ultimate acocuntlng

perhaps Australia's strong- j est-claims to greatness wlH not reside in our dealings with the native races that have come within our sphere. There are some incidents recorded in pioneer history that we would like to forget, though the cir cumstances of the time can be advanced in extenuation No where is the story of colonisa tion one of peaceful penetra tion with happiness and con tentment for all parties. We had almost begun to think however, we had lived down the less glamorous chapters of our dealings with the original owners of Australia, and made considerable amends in present policies and administration of native affairs. But every once in a while there comes a sharp reminder that little ground for complacency exists. One such occasion was the recent airing of complaints, before UNO, of the Commonwealth's handling of the New Guinea m-ndate in so far as it affected the native

population. |

Striking nearer home Harold Blair, aboriginal ' singer, ad

ministers another mild shock. On his arrival in New York whither he was enabled to go largely ttirottgh the Interest of an American singer who recog nised his gifts-he gave a Press conference. The "Herald Tribune" quotes Blair as say ing: "There are only 80,000 aborigines leftt in Australia out of 700,000. ' That speaks for Itself, doesn't it? They now live on reservations where they teach .you nothing but to be come labourers. You know

nothing about the outside and It's a wonder to get out and find there is a world."

That indictment la open to some rebuttal, as the sympath etic encouragement given to the development of Blair's tal ent could be called as evidence,. bub- it is not the kind of thing! we like to hear iise5 to our disparagement by those of a mind to do so. As a fact,j when Mr Blair has had time to examine his present "new world" more closely he Willi find perhaps from unhappy I experience, how rigidly the j colour line can be enforced in USA. If his theatrical travels

should later take him to South I Africa, with the Malan regime j still holding sway, he will re ceive further enlightenment on/ this head - sufficient to fill him with nostalgic yearning for the treatment of natives In his homeland.

Nevertheless the interview does question whether suffic ient attention is given to fos tering the uplift of the abor iginal and half caste popula tion to the extent that is pos sible. The case or Harold Blair and others in different walks has revealed that there exists a degree of native talent, amongst the present genera tion of aborigines, that rare ly gets an opportunity of com ing to the front. We hear much these day6 of what should be done for the New Australians. Harold Blair's in dictment suggests that there is still a lot to be done for the first Australians, befort we have discharged our obligations

to them.

articleText:
<pwwwiw |1 ?IHWHiHWIIIilMIMIWIWlWiW

THE CMTRAL QUBBNSLAtiD HERALD

Boo kJ> amp ton

THtmaPAT.KABCH 17

i'W»l -IW iMIUMIWll

WHERE DOBS CENT. Q'LAfiD COMB IN T

.TBS Electoral BUI now before

; Parliament provides for the creation of M additional seats, thereby increasing the legisla ture from 82 to 76 members, the largest Assembly in the State'* history. The metropolis tan area It to have four ad ditional members,, bringing the representation of Brisbane up to 34. The coastal strip, from the border as far waft as Dalby and extending north to Broadsound, will have 28 mem* ben as against 25 in the old House. North Queensland, from Broadsound to Cape York Pen insula, and including CblHagoe tad Burketown, will hare ten In place of seven members, piul the remaining portion of the State, which embraces the far West, will likewise secure an increase from seven to ten. The quota of electors for metropoli tan seats will be MMMO, the coastal region MM, Northern 7889; and Western 478J-with a 30 per cent margin in all

case*.

to introducing the Bill tfce Premier rendered a good deal of Up service to such themes as New States, decentralisation, balance of representation and keeping in close touch with the people, implying that these were the underlying mottvfes for the enlargement of Parlia ment. Opposition members, however, tost no time in de molishing this pretence and exposing the measure as a scheme to enable the govern-, mem to "dig in" for a further term of office

Where does the Central Di vision enter into the scheme?

.

We. am Included in the "COM* it!atrip" extending flum the border to Broadeotmd. Ainoe the itrutnt incumbents are rt canled as 'la Jfte bac" the Central mti appear to have given the government little oonoern, end ooe thing oertaln Is that our lOOmm to the new FUllmMt islfloety to ** leu ttwua tt was to theold. Yet the ffssttilist'a '£|e^

ReaSS?*that ^within tbe

snt the creation 'of new States «m inevitable he ptooeefled to tadioato the re gions which rib ootuideMd would suooeed to selfgovern men*. Ibeyere North Queens land, the Northern Territory

and North-West Australia. That neatly disposes of any aspirations on the part of Cen tral Queensland. Apparently we are to be tacked on to Brie* bane f«r all time-that is if llr Anton's itowaeo the trend

of tot aeirMato MwreaHetwej

tonr imrynitf, ?

But then la food reason to doubt the clnoerlty of the Pre mier in this matter, II he be lieves that Now States win come within tbe next ten years, he is losing no time in erecting the bfggast possible nlnlifli to thru acnievement. The last peorfte to vote away their privileges, which now In clude pentoa rtttats, art the members of wrteHng Btate pais liaments. With the paSeoge of the new Electoral BUI TO to steadof <9 win have to be con vinced on tfa* new State Issue.

WEAK SPOTS IN WEATHER WARNINGS

'AB « contribution towards

making people weather* minded In the cyclone belt, lit* week's performance toy time two Commonwealth Institutions vu little below their usual manner ol con* tact wit the public. The CMB adopts the tone ot a gacette notice-believe it or not at your peril-*ad the ABO fatic to appreciate that a dy namic cyclone poised ever the mouth of Wide Bay Is in finitely more dangerous than 1000 hungry lions loose In Toorak or In Bellevue HilL They each use consistently the word "One" when they mean dry weather, tram* their weather broadcasts with In finitely more regard for the susceptibilities of the Joy-rider and pleasure hunter than for thbse of the primary producer, and not uncommonly speak encouragingly of "improved" conditions when they mean that only too sadly for the pri mary producer, a seeming, drought-breaking rain will soon «nd. Most astonishing of all, the Australian Country Party has remained quite pas sive in regard to so unrealistic an approach to a subject that (fleets vitally thousands of its members throughout Australia. The Queensland Department of Public Instruction Is not with out responsibility in the matter, for it Includes In Its cyclone belt currlcuium no more of

the elfwnmUry law of ttpins and the use el relevant instru ments Hub it taught on the Darling Downs. Records of bundreda of thousands of (Me nmtoorses to tbt Mwit ipltt stoood an known throughout the length .Bl .lmttb of Australia, tout the habtta and psrtormanoee of tbe brisk cyelooe wo as a Mated book to MJ per cent of ON rooal population.

Meanwhile, tb* red pennant strained valiantly at its hal liard* on tt» Post Office flag* pola throughout tbe recent blow, a- fitting symbol of the era when men knew only the things that they saw or felt, which era was only om jump ahead of the nook* Mid] menage stick. But tb* fcaro graphthat for many yean was open to public view at the port Office has been banished, as If In fear that the ootnmon herd might gat to team more of thdr weather than has been aaslibtlatad by their weather lords. Radar, wireless, tele phone and the swift motor oar ban all come since those archaic days; bat the GBM is oomfortably esoonoed behind a system when a red pennant tails of the existence, some* whsre or other, of a eyekme that wlil announoa Ms arrival and Intentions in terms of fty tng roofs. and an un warrant

aide 'ton of discomfort and even death.

S1SOWY RIVER LINE FOR OUR DEFENCE

T>HI Federal Labour Caucus

baa suddenly become seised with concern for Australia's defence. To ensure that the country shall be made safe against a potential Invader it feel* that It must commence Immediately the Snowy River hydro-electric scheme and to establish the Commonwealth shipping line, both costly pro jects of questionable economic

value.

Bo anxious Is the Caucus to "get cracking" with the Snowy River scheme that it waved aside the counsel of some Min isters to hasten slowly, and it cannot wait for an agreement on the question of control be tween the Commonwealth and Interested States. One would think the enemy was already battering at the door and only the Snowy River scheme ~ whlch will take 30 years to ac complish In any -case-could keep them at bay. Yet the obvious point about such a scheme, which incidentally, on present estimates, will cost £168,000,000, Is that control should reside In Che hands of a national authority similar to that of the famous TVA of the Vtatfcrt State*. But that will

net ratt Mr Ohlfley and his oolleaguet. Sole oontrol must be vested in the Common wealth Commission and In one else.

Whilst ttals wrangle goes forward between the Govern ments of the Commonwealth and the States concerned, the people of Australia can with reason ask why there is such a bursting hurry to get started with a scheme that will' cost so much and tain JO long to put through. Xt may be a tfieer coincidence that this Is Federal election year, and that many of the redraft ed electorates in tttt key States of NSW and Victoria are af

fected by the scheme. A pro-! Ject to cost nearly £300,000,000 which will spread Its benefits over two decadfea is a tatty eleotion bait -to offer on the eve of the- election of the Commonwealth's laiytr Parlia ment. Little wonder that the Caucus has suddenly become defence»mindeal

As to the Government's in trusion into the shipping in dustry also undertaken in the name of defence, powers under which are being ua«d to strengthen the Oablnet's hand,

this attempt to telng the mer cantile murine in time of peace, within the sphere of de fence activities, la purely a political move designed to fa cilitate interference with privately-owned shipping. Cer tainly the last thing the people of the Commonwealth desire after the previous calamitous experience in this field Is to see the Government embark on another Federal Govern ment-owned shipping line. But they are as determined to go ahead with this as with the banking legislation and the air lines. j

articleText:
I TBE CENTRAL QUEENSLAND HERALD |

fiockhamploo

THURSDAY, JULY 28, 1Mft.

SALES TAX MAKES LIVING DEARER

fpO the lay mind nurtured in

experience and bed-feilow with, common sense, the idea of trying to defeat rising coste by increasing wages is merely to set one dog chasing an other's tail. Unless the inten tion is to exterminate private employers - as Indeed it well might be - increased wages can find no other repository than rising costs, which in turn calls expensively and tardily for another dose. If there existed no other alter native, nothing would remain but to grin and bear the dreadful business. But where taxes imposed by the Govern ment react directly on pro duction and distribution costs, those taxes inevitably come out of the purse of every wage-earner in Australia.

The worst offender in di

rectly increasing living costs is the. sales tax, which is a direct'tax upon every consum er of every-day commodities throughout Australia. There is no escaping Jt as Income tax may be escaped simply by not wording, and so not earn ing income. Unless he lives like an anchorite or a. black fellow no consumer can for long escape paying sales tax, whereas thousands have dodg ed paying Income tax and are Still dodging it by simply slow ing down. The smoker who open a packet !of cigarettes finds that, be only gets one sixth of title contents, as Mr Chifley has forestalled him and taken the other five in import duty, primage, ex cise and sales tax. The

man who pays 1/- tor a

sohooner of beer would have paid only 7d. had not Mr Chifley wanted the other 6d. The man who buys nine boxes of matches finds that the re tailer got the cost of only -five of. them and Mr Chifley got the rest. The man who builds a home costing £1000 finds that the builder got £900 and Mr Chifley the rest. In this case, as in all others, Mr Chif ley renders no service in re

turn tor his Impost. Where others supply food and drink, shelter, - services and like amenities Mr Chifley supplies nothing.

Edmund Burke said that taxing was an easy business. Anyone can contrive* new im positions; any bungler can add to the old: "But it is alto gether wise to have no other bounds to your impositions than the patience of those who are to bear them?" That is as pertinent today as it was when enunciated 200 years ago, and it is no less clumsy to tax the food and covering of people while pretending to ease the tax burden by reduc ing income tax that people may - and do - reduce for themselves. If the Govern ment is sincere in its oft stated desire to lighten the tax burden throughout the community, it would abolish both the pay-roll tax and the sales tax through which it col-1

lected £51,323,000 last year, orj

about £15,000,000 more than it

pretended to give back to tax-j payers in reduced taxes. |

Bureaucracy with a Job to hold could no doubt Justify! taxing ? pay-rolls and also, -through sales tax-all forms; of commodities that minister

to human needs, to enable de

ductions of income tax to be made to a few; but to the layman aforesaid it is sheer! Stupidity. It costs effort, and money te collect pay-roll and sales taxes, also more effort and money to distribute them. In the interval between col lecting and distribution the . ambitious price spiral has

crept upwards, so that a ne«r

| -listributlon in the form of aL

increased basic wage is neces sary before the last one has

j become operative. Ifee set-up

is not preventive of rising costs and prices and also, .what is morally bad, the .Government stands to profit

I even from the very feeble ma (chlnery that is sent out to trip I up the rising cost of living.

articleText:
What The 42nd Did In World Warn

?cir families remained untouched by World War H. So far' as Centra! Queensland Is ooncerned, the personal link with a particular fighting unit waa established largely by the representation of most parts of the district in, the

42nd battalion.

The story of the men of the 42nd and their cam paigns in New Guinea and Bougainville is now told in "The History of the 42nd Battalion in the Second World Wax," which "The Central Queensland Her ald" will publish by Instal ments, commencing: on January, 5 next.'

It is written by Mr. S. E. Benson, a journalist, form erly on the staff of the

"Morning Bulletin" and a'

member of the 42nd bat talion's Intelligence Sec tion for the greatet part of of the unit's combat his

tory. In the writing of it - he has consulted official mlr diaries and other re cords, v drawn on personal experiences and gathered and pieced together in numerable stories from other 42nd men.

A foreword by Btigadier R. F. Monaghan, comman der of the 29th infantry brigade (of. which the 42nd was a unit) says of the battalion: "I. .. will never cease to remember their work and glory in their achievements ... . they fought as they trained, fiercely and grimly ..."

Accompanying the his tory will be a large num ber of photographs show ing scenes ard personalities in the 42nd war record.

Readers should . order ' copies early from news agents or write direct to the Bockhampton News paper Co. Pty. Ltd., Quay Street, Bockhampton.
heading: What The 42nd Did In World Warn II

*The History of the 42nd. Battalion in tbe Second World War." which will be published In the "Central) Queensland' Herald," commencing on Jannery 5,1s -not * < *m densed account but a book-length story which tnwei the fortunes of the b^tt-?iata from the, camp at Yeppoon In 1989 until demobilisation. The cam paigns In New Guinea and Bougainville are treated In detail >- the New Guinea story, for ex ample^ runs to 10 chap ters. Besides giving the general picture of the battalion's role In those areas colour is added to the narrative by the In clusion of Individual ex periences.

Lieut - Colonel C.' W. Davidson, C.O. of the 42nd In the New Guinea cam paten. commends this his* tory as "a faithful ac count of the battalion's many exploits.

To ensure regular de livery of Instalments, readers should Immedi ately place orders with newsagents. or with the Rockhampton Newspaper Co. Pty Ltd.

articleText:
THE PORT OF ROCKHAMPTON: ITS

ORIGIN AND DEVELOPMENT

(Written for the "Herald" bjr "Historian.")

T®. election under the:

1014 amended franchise for the Barbour Board took place on February 9, and Messrs R. B. Archer, C, E, Cro

z2:'+L\ p* I«ndsbei*, and A.

Mfecfarlane were returned by Rockhampton ratepayers, It. E Hartley by those of . North Rtekhampton, A. L. Macdon

®Jd by those of the shires of

Fltzroy and Livingstone, and 8. Gray by those of Mt. Mor gan.

A loan of £18,000 to dredge

[the river "above Rocky point

tc a minimum depth otj.6 feet

(With a bottom width of 300

[ feet, and for completing and

| repairing walls" was granted

by the Government during February.

Councillors for the shires of Banana, Bauhinla, Belyando, Calllungal, Clermont, Dua rlnga, Emerald and Peak Downs elected Messrs C. P. Copland and W. H. Kettle on April 36 to represent those shires on the Harbour Board; Mid those of Ar&mac, Barcal dlne, Barcoo, Blackall, Dai manttoa, nfracombe, Isisford, Kargoolnah, Longreach,

Tambo elected Messrs R. Don aldson and S. Williams.

REQUEST FOR GRANT

The last loan brought the Hwbourt Indebtedness near to the limit of Its borrowing Powers, so a deputation waited on the Treasurer in Brisbane to July with a request tor a (grant in aid. "The precedent

a previous grant to

.Harbour Boards in the

£tate^ and the knowledge that

the Brisbane harbour had re

ceived better treatment thas ours at the hands of the State Government, justified our re quest."

The Treasurer (Mr E. o. Theodore) denied preferential treatment to Brisbane, object ed that a grant In aid could not be made to bodies other than those under Government control, and finally agreed to raising the board's borrowing iowea to <400,000.

The board deputation also

I malted on the Minister for

I Railways in relation to its ! Tuarantee covering the Port Uma railway. This applied to '. minimum tonnage to pass 3ver the line on which the railway based their charges, though operations resulted in a loss even though the min imum tonnage was exceeded. This loss was recouped from the board, but relief was given In the general repeal of the Railway Guarantee Act.

Increase in the bill for in terest and redemption led in evitably to Increased dues tariffs. "It is evident" wrote the chairman (Mr R. 8. Arc her) "that if the proportion of wool sent to Brisbane by rail increases at the co6t of that sent by water there will be a further loss of revenue to be made up by a further Increase of the dues on im ports."

Matters which the chairman considered merited Govern ment attention were: (1) sim plificaton in the maimer of electing members and chair man; (3) the Government to accept responsibility for dam age caused by vessels in charge of a compulsory (Gov ernment) pilot; (S) an alter ation in the manner In which long haulage rates are applied on the Government railways; and (4) establishment of local

wool sales.

No, 4 be held to be a matter of great importance,

«ul "should be beneficial to she wool-grower by re ducing- his cost of market bVi 'Md to the port and district by Mnitaf tbem into greater prominence." Be held that the opening of Port Alma removed the obstacle of shipping- diffi

culties.

During the year a 304 ft extension was provided on the downstream end of the deep

water wharf.

Berthing at Broadmount during 1815 were the steamer*: Commonwealth (4172), Dorert I (4827), Middlesex (4638) ami [ Palma (4913) aU one berthing j each.

Berthage charges came into force on February 1, s and brought in £1666 of revenue. The shipping companies pas sfed this on to the public through a stacking and sort ing charge of 1/- per ton on all cargo, which was only slightly undo: one-third of ths total charge per ton collected by the Harbour Board.

BACKING FOR POET ALMA

On March 13 the Harbour Board wrote to Mr H. W. Hamer, civil Engineer of Auckland, asking his advice on the be# means "of Improv ing the deep water accommod ation for vessels trading to the port of Rockhampton" pur suant to which he had "sev eral interviews and consult ations" with the board's of

ficials.

Mr Hamer^ report, dated April 18, stated that he had no hesitation in recommend ing the development of Port Alma as against Broadmount

because:

"1. It permits of easiest ac cess for deep ocean, ships in a wide channel that naturally maintains its depth. .

"2Jt avoids Intricate nav igation to Broadmount wharf through a channel of very re stricted width, of shallow depth, of hard bottom, that will always need attention and maintenance, that is unwork

able at low water and will!

never find favour with mas ters of large vessels, and the depths at Broadmount wharf require considerable Improve ment even for present draft

of vessels.

" *9. Railage from Port Alma i to Bockhampton is only a few miles more than from Broad mount, the time in transit but little longer, and the railage charge no greater."

He strongly recommended bringing shipping to the heart of the city as in the case of Glasgow, Liverpool, London, and Manchester-not to men tion foreign river ports-but further expenditure in train ing and dredging the Flteroy might not be practicable for seme years, hence "it is neces sary to develop a terminal port nearer the entrance," and this he concluded was Port

Alma.

On June 10 the Harbour Board appointed Itself a com mittee of the whole to con sider its financial position and also the advisability of rating the benefited area. The com mittee of the whole met on July 17, and decided, after considerable descussion, to form a sub-committee, that would consider the port dev elopment rate proposal and report back to the committee of the whole. The sub-com mlttee met on August 21, aqd addressed Itself to consider ation of the port improvement

rate proposal. No decision was reached, and the com mittee adjourned for a month. On September 18 the sub committee met again and it was proposed that a port Im provement rate of id in the £ be struck on the rateable value of all land within the Harbour Board area. An amendment to this was that the sub-committee recommend an increase of inward an-.l outward harbour dues by an amount that would Increase the total revenue by 40 per cent. This was lost. A sec ond amendment was then moved "that In view of the financial position of the board we ask to be relieved of our indebtedness to the Govern ment." The original motion was then withdrawn, and the amendment on being put as a motion was carried.

At its. monthly meeting on October 17 the Barbour Board accepted the recommendation of its committee of the whole, and it was decided to form a representative deputation, from within the Harbour Board area, to place the mat ter before the Treasurer in

Brisbane.

The Engineer for Harbours and Rivers stated In his an nual report that the minimum depth in the Fitzroy River was lift 61ns In Pirate Point cut. Proposals: for extending Gladstone jetty by 400 feet were in abeyanco during 1817, and the proposed new freezing works had not beeu comnra ced. The Engineer for Har bours and Rivers stated that fresh water had been laid on tc the Jetty.

BARBOUR ASSOCIATION

Queensland Harbour Boards -with the exception of Cairns -met at Rockhampton during August and fanned a Harbour Board's Association, through which it is intended to take Joint action in regard to <aj payment of date on Govern ment goods, <b) compensation for damage done to wharves by ships wider compulsory pilotage, (c) prevention of depositing spoil or leading drainage Into the harbour (d) removal of wrecks, and (e) election of board members and chairman.

The gap In Satellite wall was completed in September, and its height above high water was raised. A berthage by-law was passed during, November "for the facilities supplied" I.e. for services to the ship as against to cargo landed or shipped.

In his annual report for 1916 the board, chairman sounded a note of'warning: 1 do not think that anyone will dis agree with the statements that a port is necessary for Central Queensland, and that the establishment of the ship ping facilities for such a put, wherever situated, will require the expenditure of money. Money has so far been raised by tonnage dues on cargo car ried in and out, but if the Government railways continue to compete, with the shipping companies, and so reduce the Harbour Board's re venue _ the method of raising money must be altered, or the work or Im proving the harbour must

cease.

During 1917 Parliament al tered the shire of Blackall to the town'of Blackall, correct ed anomalies in the manner of election by ratepayers of representatives on the board

to represent Fitzroy and Liv ingstone, fixed the time for election of chairman and Htff made provision for a deputy

chairman.

RECORD FLOOD

The flood at Rockh&mpton in February touched the 31ft llin mark or 3ft 8&ln h<ghw than the/previous record In 1896. Owing to there being no flood warning station at ef fective points In the Fltsroy watershed, little notification qf the oncoming flood was [given and much loss was oc casioned to stock and property that might otherwise have been avoided.

During the record February floods observations were

of the speed of flood waters running under the Alexandra and Fitzroy bridges. The ob servations were sustained dur ing a range of five to Ox fee* of flood height, during which the speeds remained constant at nine miles an hour under the Alexandra bridge and eight miles and hour under the Fitzroy bridge.

The Harbour Board deput ation authorised by the board at its October meeting In 1917 waited on the Treasurer (Mr E. G. Theodore) on May 81 to request that the Govern ment, In the words of the chairman "should wipe out the the. board's Indebtedness and let it start over again."

Mr Theodore said he waa unable to see how the Gov ernment could accede to so large a request, and was not disposed to regard the mating of a Central Queensland port as a matter. HA said "The time might come when the people would have to adopt Gladstone as the natural port for the handling of Central Queensland trade."

While not courting cantrov ercy on the subject, Mr Theo dore said that it might be wo* essary for Government to consider the question of a changed policy' in the control of harbours generally, in order t-ho-t. a fair deal might be giv en to each district concerned* While harbour boards are do ing good work, It might be come a question of whether It would not be better to re vert to a system that would utilise the best avafiabl® brains-a change in the mat ter of the control of harbours fhnf would put them in the ftnwite of some permanent ex pert commission that would have available to it the ser vices of the best expert en gineers. Such a change might lead to greater expen diture, but It might also lead to a more economical manner of doing things." .

NO DEBT BELIEF

Mr Theodore said that he could .not off-hand wipe off the board's indebtedness, but it seemqd to him that the board's difficulties were of a temporary nature, and he would see what could be done in the way of temporary ^

sistance.

Under the Act election of chairman to the board took place at the first meeting after the return of the new board, pursuant to which Mr R. s. Archer was elected to that port on May 21.

At the meeting of the board held on June 26 it was re vealed that the city of Rock haxnpton, the borough . of North Rockhampton, the town of Mt Morgan nor the shires of Fitzroy and Livingstone "preferred to take part In the deputation -to the Treasurer" to ask that the debt of the board be wiped out. Also, re presentatives of the western shires "were really residents of Brisbane, who had been pcfc-AH by different western shires to represent them at the deputation". They "met the deputation at the Treas urer's door" Mr Archer Btated

of them.

"I t.hinfc all the members of the board were taken aback by the so-called assistance we got from our western friends. In fact, it was really a case Of'save us -from our friends. They certainly asked the Treasurer to assist us and meet our request; but the strength of their remarks lay in flying that our harbour should be closed and that the whole of the trade of the Central Division should be transferred td Gladstone. -

Mr Archer said that during the past 10 or 15 years he had served on several deputations

PORT OF ROCKHAMPTON

*??? , I. ? ?? I

(Continued from Page 3)

to Brisbane on harbour board matters and his experience was that they Usually got "a stereotyped sort of answer and some sympathy, but they can do nothing for us in any substantial way". He said that even the remarks of Mr J. Larcoube, that

Central Division had In jpait yean .eanfeibated 11, MMM mere to the general ' wwmae than mrU be deblt

%» SrilmvA a j*^pBntto4eeem--'la»SR»as uri^attenttoti.-? Hor, aj»>ar

.gHffflon

revenue by the ^BatlxMtrBoard through-long twinge rates."

The OpyeRunent dredge MourUyaa forked between September and October dredg ing the deep water, berth at

Gladstone Anclcland Point wharf to 36ft at to* water.

The Increased tonnage of ships berthing at the Rock hampton town whavves was indicated by the average for 1896 being 310 tons, that for the six years 1806-1011 being 600 tons, and that for the seven years 1912-18 being 747

tons.

POET DEFENCE . COMMiraS

The chairman stated to his pnpnri report that during the year Gladstone residents "commenced an agitation with the object of inducing the Government to divert the iniiLwri trade to Gladstone harbour from Rockh ampton." This had the effect of ending "the that had ex isted In the community for so many years, and had prevent ed the adoption of one def inite policy for the develop ment of the port."

The upshot was formation of a Port Defence Committee representing Rockhampton, North Rockhamptoh and the shires of Ftteroy and Uvtog stone. Three meetings were held, at the final one of which it was decided that the port policy should be to obtain a river depth sufficient for the class of vessel using the town

wharves, and "to «£re Re

mitting attention to the build

ing up of Fort Alma until it compares favourably in com pleteness and efficiency with the great port of the Com

monwealth.

The Trasurer was as good

as his wotd In regard to re organisation of harbour con trol in Queensland; for he in troduced a Bill in 1916 ses sion to abolish local control of harbours. A Queensland Har bour Trust was to be created, and it would undertake all harbour work in the State, us ing the pooled harbour-making plant and "reducing adminis trative eosts without impairing efficiency.** It wife, in fact a reversion to the pre-1892 era of Government control of all baxbours; but the Bill did not get past the first reading. .

The triennial election of members of the Harbour Board took place in 191B, the results being: For Rockhampton, R. s. Archer, C. E. Crocker, L. p. Laadsberg, and R. MacFar lane; Mt. Morgan, Mr. C. Briggs; North Rockhampton, R. s. Hartley; Shires of Pite roy and' Livingstone, A. L. Macdonald; the eastern group of shires, Messrs. C. P. Cop land and W. H. Kettle; the western group of shires, Messrs. R. Donaldson and F. JL H Wagstaff. The Gladstone Har bour Board purchased from the Town Council the old muni cipal wharf hi Auckland Creek during 1918.

In the Fltaroy the sunk stone wall at Archer's Cross ing and an old groyne below G&vlal Creek were removed bj clam dredge .during 1918, and the least depth was 10ft. Bins at Central Island, Archer's Crossing and Upper Flats.

Craft on the river during 1918 were Archer, Curlew, Eth elbert, Hawk, Snail, Swan and Tweed. First and 5th on the list were dredges. Coastal, shipping visiting the port were Aramac, Bombaia, Bunlnyong, Caozna, Chlllago, Gabo, Moira and Wyreetria. Much of the usual shaping was absent on

war service.

Waterfront personnel during 19ie 7as: Harbourmaster and Pilot, S. Wilkinson; Pilots L. K. HoQoway and J. K. Munror all at Rockhampton. Harbour master. H. RlUle, Pilot J. Pain* Gladstone. Lightkeepers, Bal aclava Inland (R. Graham). Mackenzie Island (J. Burke),

Cape Capricorn (0. Rasmus), Bustard Head (J. A. Dent). Oatcombe Head (F. Andewon). Fort Alma (H. CJoherty), Brown's Crossing (J. Jiansea)

ANOTHER MOVE FOB

WOOL

In an effort to check .the' railage of wool to Brisbane, a Chamber of Commerce-Har bour Board deputation was sent to interview the Prime Minister to have Rookhamp ton made a war wool appraise ment centre. Mr Hughes was too busy to meet the deput ation, which was handed on to the Central Wool Commit tee, which In turn seems to have been full of sympathy "but made It clear thai our main difficulty would be, not in proving that our proposal is advantageous to the wool

| grower, tout in - overcoming

selfish Interests." Hie final reply from the Government was a refusal because ^%here should be as few ap|»ratsal centres as possible and the Ideal (war) arrangement would be to have all the wool brought to one centre. Accor ding to D&lgety's Annual Wool Review for 19X7 there are In New Zealand IS wool appraise

ment centres."

The agreement between the Commissioner for Railways and the shipping companies In re gard to using Port Alma ex pired duAng the year, and the former took the opportunity to increase the cost of hand- ; ling and carrying between Port Alma and Roekhampton" and the latter to discontinue

accepting cargo per Interstate 1 passenger vessels either for or

at Port Alma.

A Dominion's Royal Com mission's report Issued during the year contained the recom mendation far a line of large deep draught vessels and the requisite preparation at ports ot call for their accommodation. The Harbour Board Chairman reported: "Steps were taken to have Port Alma Included In the ports ot call, as It Is the nearest to the Panama Canal. It Is hardly necessary to dwell on the importance to Central

Queensland of bringing its' principle poet Into such close touch with countries overseas."

The 897-ton steamer Tim aru was the only, berthing at Broadmount during the year.

L. J. Hollowey Fas appointed Harbour Master, Roekhampton. on January 1 in place of B Wilkinson, retired.

A successor to Harboui Board member C. Brtggs, who died on November 32, 1016. should have been appointed by Mt. Morgan ratepayers. In default thereof the Governor In-Council appointed Mr. W. B. Mortimore on February 14

CALL FOB SUPPORT

On May 1 Mr. *R. 6. Archer was re-elected chairman to the board. Looking to the finances i he stated in his annual report:

"In the future, and the near ness of that future depends mainly on the enterprise and loyal unanimity of the whole community, we may recover and increase our trade to the advantage of the whole of the Central Division, by the es tablishment of local wool sales and by Increasing the produce tivity of the land. For this latter, the conservation and efficient utilisation of the rain that falls on the Immense watershed of the Fiteroy is a most Important, factor."

3. Williamson was appointed pilot, Roekhampton, on July 10, In the room of L. K. Hollo way, promoted. D. Macdonald was appointed Harbour Mast er, Roekhampton, on August 23, in the place of L. J. Hollo way, deceased. P. Rhodes was appointed Harbour Master, Roekhampton, October 9, fn the room of X>. Macdonald,

transferred.

- Shortage of shipplogaaa in ability ot the board, to restore river depths after the 1018 flood resulted In fewer ships making the town wharves. There was less disposition to take risks In the river, and extra costs were incurred when ships discharged town cargo on Port Alma wharf . To meet these exigencies the Controller of Shipping imposed a sur charge of 10/- per ton. A protest against so high a sur charge was made by a. combin ed Chamber of Commerce-Har bour Board delegation which waited on the Shipping Sub committee, Brisbane, on Nov ember 4, but little satlstactjpn was gained. The delegation stated its belief, after a careful estimate of the extra cost of lightering at Port Alma that "advantage had been taken ot

the position to increase charges here to assist in cov ering extra charges elsewhere."

During 1919 the dnd|e Archer died In harness af ter 19 yem to the sendee of the Hirtoar Board, dur ing wtiich ah* shitted 19,

165,<M tons of aaad from the bed of the rirer to be hind walls and other re clamations.

This axpounts to 72 per cent of the total sand so shifted by the board in Its 50 years of op erations to IMS. To help cope with the work and repair flood damage the dredge Cera tod us was hired for a term from Bundaberg Harbour Board. The Treasury promised, too, that the dredge Casuarine would be made available for a total of six months, but she was not at work In the Fltc roy before 1920.

The Harbour Board decided during 1918 to apply for a loan of £30,000 to purchase-among other things-a maintenance dredge capable of "dealing with the small ridges which form in the channel from time to time." This was the fore-runner of the present dredge Fitzroy.

(To be Continued).

articleText:
T HE PORT OF RQCKHAMPTON :ITS

ORIGIN AND DEVELOPMENT

(Written for the "Herald" by "Hfttoricns.")

QN January 10, 1924 (he

Harbour Board confirmed the resolution, passed on Oc tober 19, to borrow from the Government £45,000 "for the purpose of Improving the en trance to Broadmount and the river." v .

Elections completed on Ma; 19. resulted in the following personnel being elected to the board: For Rockhampton, Messrs A. Edgar, R. E. Hart ley, A. H. Paterson, E. B. Pur nell and F. Rhodes; for the shires of Fitzroy and Living stone, Mr W. Beak; for Mt Morgan, Mr R. L; McMullen; for the eastern group of shires Messrs. C. P. Copland and W. H. Kettle; and for the Western group of shires, Messrs. R. 8. Archer and A. L. Macdonald.

After a board membership of 28 years and an aggregated term of office as chairman amounting to 13 yean and 7 months, Mr R. 8. Archer was replaced in the chair on May 20 by Mr W. Beak.

Messrs Archer and Kettle attended the annual meeting j of the United Graders' Asso

ciation, held at Longreach in May. to "give reasons for urg

! lng that wool should again be. sent by sea from Rockhamp ton." The delegates were ac corded "a sympathetic hear ing, but it was pointed out that the association had not

the' power to compel its mem bers to adopt any particular means of transport."

In his annual report dated

July 38 the Engineer for Har- ! bc-urs and Rivers notified completion of 77B lineal feet of wharf frontage with three

large sheds at Gladstone, the {

installation of two wpol-dump ing presses, and the letting of a contract to Messrs Noyes Bros., Sydney, for a 15-ton electric crane, three pedestals for which had been completed.

The Government contracted during October, on behalf of the Rockhampton Harbour Board, With Messrs Fleming Ferguson (c Co. for a new Fruhling dredge. Unsuccess

ful attempts were also madej to dispose of the dredge Ar

cher.

Subject to approval of their boards, delegates from the Bundaberg, Gladstone, Mac kay and Rockhampton Har bour Boards agreed to a pro

posal, passed at a conference' held on December 10, to re suscitate the Queensland Harbour Boards Association.

CRANE FOR COAL

A steam crane was erected "with the assistance of the State Treasury" on Port Alma wharf Hin order that the State and privately-owned collieries in the Central dis

trict may be enabled to accept J

orders for coal shipment .

It now remains for the Blair I Athol companies to justify the granting of their requests

for a lower rate of railage and | for coaling facilities at the port." Although it was shown

that thfe crane had neither I the height nor the radius to

coal ail vessels visiting the f port, its erection proceeded.

The Commonwealth Gov ernment arranged during the year for the transmission dur ing flood times of messages from Rlverslea on Saturdays

and Sundays.

At a conference held at

on January 23,

1925, attended by deleg ates from the Gladstone, Mac kay and Rockhampton Bar

bour Boards, it was decided to j resuscitate the Queensland Harbour Boards' Association.

The personnel of the board was changed during the year only by the resignation of Mr A Edgar, and the unopposed election of Mr F. P. J- Conlon to fill the vacancy. On May IS Mr W. Beak was again elected chairman.

Engaged by the Common wealth Government to inspect end advise on the Harbours of the Northern Territory, the

services of Sin George Buch- j anan were placed at the dis posal of such harbour author ities as wished to avail them selves of his advice. This the Harbour Board did, and Sir

George arrived at Rockhamp- ^ ton on May 19. proceeding on j an inspection of the river onj

the following day.

The Government announced I

in September that portion of j

the loan' for Improving the en trance to the river and Broad mount was available.

Rates for the use of the

crane at Port Alma were fixed j in June, the crane being com

pleted during the year at a j «Mt aC fWtt. Ibere was aj

'i i '*

ftimiuu crane at Broadmoutit The chairman (Mr W. Beak) wrote of these appliances that they woe "installed in re sponse to urgent requests from colliery proprietors in the Central Division in order to assist in developing an export tiade. In addition to the two cranes mentioned, there is a third of the same capacity at

Gavial Creek wharf." The ex tent to which the greet cost of installing these three cranes and dismantling two of them-that at Broadmouro and Port Alma- was justified by subsequent events is re vealed by the fact that for the 10 years to 1931 the average coal exported per annum from Queensland amounted to only 44,358 tons.

The first annual meeting of the Queensland Harbour Braids' Association was held at Mackay on November 27, when Mr R. O. Johnson, Mac ks?, presided. Several matters were discussed, but finality was .reached only in appoint ing the chairman to be the as sociation's delegate at the next interstate conference of har bour authorities, and In en dowing him with power to ap point a substitute should he find himself unable to attend. Mr R. 8. Archer was appointed chairman for the ensuing year

WHARF AREAS

During the year the town wharf lights were connected with the City Council's supply, and this involved a complete re-wiring of these premises. Available wharf space was given as:

City Wharf, 839 ft frontage carrying 10 to IS 'ft at low water, deck area 792 sq ft covered and 48,158 open; Deepwater (Railway) wharf 1151 ft frontage carrying 15 to 30 ft at low water, deck area 28,174 sq ft covered and 39,625 open; Gavial Creek wharf 281 ft frontage carrying 15 to 20 ft «t low water, deck area 15,607 aq ft open; Flood wharf 266 ft frontage carrying 15 to 20 ft at tow water, deck area 11,960 sq ft all open. Total town wharves 2312 ft frontage, deck area 28,966 sq ft covered and 112,350 open or 142,316 sq ft in all. Broadmount wharf, 932 ft frontage carrying 20 to 24 ft at loir water, deck area 14,250 sq ft covered and 38,500 open. Port Alma wharf, 1000 ft frontage carrying 23 to 31 ft at low water, deck area lSjOOu sq ft. covered and 40,900 open.

The new dredge litany went into eommhsfam in

February, 1926 and proved i to be a most valuable ma- | chine for the work. So | Improved was the river that several oil tankers reaehed the town wharves, the largest of them being Rio Oan» 2538 tons net and 363 ft long,

Mr R. E. Hartley was elected chairman of the board on May 18.

On June 29 the Harbour Board carried by six votes to five a resolution that: "there shall be raised, levied, collect ed and paid every year in re spect of all rateable land in the Harbour Board district u harbour improvement rate of id in the £ of the value of the whole of such land." This by law was later confirmed at & special meeting, but the Gov ernment later refused to sanc tion it.

The 5th conference of In terstate Harbour Authorities was held at Adelaide in Sep-, Umber, the board's delegate* being the chairman, Mr R. E. Hartley.

BUCHANAN REPORT

In his preliminary survey of Queensland ports made on Oc tober 9, Sir Geor&i Buchanan justified Brisbane as the dom inating port pn the grounds that (a) earliest settlement took place in and around Bris bane, which naturally acquired the status of a trade centre, (b) tapering (railway) rates which help further to foster Brisbane trade, and (c), the unwillingness of owners to send their ships to outports for part cargoes.

He than considered the Beven outside ports, of which he con sidered there were five too many claiming status as over seas ports. Sir George con sidered that Calms and either Gladstone or Rockhampton would be sufficient for that status, and in regard to the two last-named he considered that if a considerable ontlay

m needed to develop Rock hampton It is a matter lor careful consideration whfether It would not be more econom ical to abandon this harbour as an oversea port and concen trate on the development of Gladstone." At this stage of his report Sir George had evi dently forgotten bis (a) rea son for justifying Brisbane, or that his (b) reason could not foster Brisbane without starv ing - among others-Rock hampton.

The Survey Department car ried out a survey of the river bed from Sea Beach to the Town Reach. "Permanent bench marks were established, for tide gauging, every 200 ft. and will -be of immense value when carrying out section sur veys. , Automatic tide gauges were set up at the Town Wharves and Thompson's

Point*'

On January 31, 1927, Sir George Buchanan completed his report on. the port of Rock hampton. He said of Port Alma*. "The port is well-shel tered, and-ls connected by rail to Rockhampton. It is, how ever, surrounded by tidal creeks and very extensive mud flats, which are just coveted at high water, to that before set tlement can take place around the port extensive reclamation will have to be undertaken.

"Given good land environ ment, the port could be readily developed for overseas trade, but obviously if the scheme for

rendering the Fitzroy navigable | for deep-draught Ships to I piy)f«mpti<n is taken in hand, j Port will be unnecessary, as trade will find its way na turally to the head of naviga tion at Rockhampton."

Of the Fitsroy River Sir George nid: "On the date available the physical con ditions «f the river an all that oeold be desired to as sist in the wort of improvements and regn lattoa with a view to Us becoming a ftnt-daaa wat erway. Bat the improve ment, to be of greatest ase, most be uniform through the whole length of the

navigable portion of the I river, aid, therefore, any I hmi improvement work . mast be part of a carefully j

comprehensive whole."

Mr. Nicholson resigned bis post as engineer to the board on April 18, and Mr. W. XL

Flowers 'was appointed acting

engineer.

LOAN OR CLOSE DOWN

A public meeting held on the evening of May 23 had as its objective obtaining relief for the Harbour Boaru, the alter native to which was closing down important work. The meeting was sponsored by the City Council, and was presided over by the Mayor (Aid. T. A, DunlopK After discussion the following resolutions were car'

rled:

1. "That in the opinion of (this meeting of Rockhampton citizens, it is imperative that dredging operations and the extension of Shoal Island wall should be continued In order to keep the river open for nav igation and bring shipping right up to the town wharves; and that the State Treasurer be asked to grant the Har bour Board's request for a fur ther loan of £5000 to enable the board to continue operations until loan funds are available." Moved by Aid. L. G. Haigh and seconded by Mr. K. A. Wool

cock.

2. "That in order to assist the Government over its tem porary financial embarassment, a number of Rockhampton citizens be asked to take ur Treasury Bonds to the extent of £5000, provided the amount so subscribed or taken up is re loaned to the Harbour Board.' Moved by Aid. Caldwell and seconded by Mr; I* C. Harden.

3, "That in order to give effect to the policy of terminal ports, upato which the existing tapetthg rates, are based, it is essential that tbe . loUowiag principles be observed: (a) Tapering rates on outward goods shall apply to those goods only between the point of loading and the Urst effec tive port; neither shall the pre ferential rates be allowed on those goods for carriage be yond that port; (b) That each terminal port Shall be the starting point, from

. tapering «iuhM , on

goods for carriage beyuud

port; (b) That each terminal port shall be the starting pwiii^ (from which tapering rates on

Inward goods for up-country stations shall commence; («> That the Government be asked to accept these principles, and amend the existing schedule of rates accordingly." Moved by the Mayor and seconded by Mr. K. E. Hartley.

4. "That In order to cany into effect the foregoing resolu tlons, a committee be ftwpwt which will have, the following powers and characteristics: Cat It shall be called the C.Q. Ad* vance League Committee, and shall be representative of all the producing, industrial, com mercial and financial Interests of C.Q.; <b) Hie mayors of Rockhaxnpton, Mt. Morgan, Clermont and Blackall; chair man of the Rockhainpton Har bour Board and of the shire councils of the Harbour Board area; presidents of all indus trial unions, Merchants' Asso ciation, Employers'

and Chamber of Commerce, to gether with such nominees aa any C,Q.. local producers' as sociation shall be invited to serve on such committee."

Tile effect of this gather tog is revealed in Mr. Hart. ley's annual report for the year, dated January SU VU9: "AM the -board wo* unable to obtain from the Government the M»fwt of the £45,606 loan which had

been approved of, it wa» v compelled to close down work on May 27."

Triennial' elections held In August resulted in ttie follow lng personnel being returned to represent their several areas: Rockhampton,

F^P. J. Conlon, J. A. Swing, R. EL Hartley, A. H. Paterson and E. JB. Puroell; Mt. Morgan, Mr. W. R. Humphreys; Fitz roy and Livingstone, M. M. Mo Kellar; the eastern group of shires, Messrs. C. P. Copland and W. H. Settle; the western group <>f shires, Messrs. E. W. Archer and A. L. Macrtonald. Mr. R. E. Hartley was re-decb*

ed chairman.

The crane on Port Aha* wharf loaded 1288 tons 11 ewt. of coal on the naval ' coBier Biloela daring Sep

tember "and the loading waa done expedftloasly and

at low oort."

The Irrigation and Water Supply Commission advised in January, 1928, that a stream gauging station was to be es tablished on the Isaacs afver the wet season, and promised to Inform the board when this

had been effected.

- At the board meeting In May Mr. R. E. Hartley was elected as OhalrmaiL An ad dition to the board's floating plant was the motor tug dart* ley, which arrived from Syd

ney on July 22.

In his annual report dated August 3 the Engineer for Har

bour and Rivers advised in re- - gard to Gladstone that the Harbour Board there hac\ com pleted negotiations with the British imperial Ol1 Company for a petroleum storage site, to be reclaimed, on Auckland Point, On August 38, while under the control of a pilot, 6.S. Eumaeus collided with Port Alma wharf, inflicting considerable damage.

Mr. H, Flowers, Acting En gineer, Rockhainpton Harbour Board, reported on a proposal to obtain ingress and egress to and from Broadmount via a channel to be cut between Flat Island and Obstruction Banks. His report was dated September 17, 1928. and his es timate ol dredging the chan nel was £17,300, but on the grounds of probable heavy maintenance he regarded the proposal as impracticable..

On October 14 SJS. Mildura left the town wharves carry

ing a record loading of 8901 bales of wool and 200 tons of

general cargp.

During the year the work of sheathing wooden piles la Port Alma wharf with con crete sleeves was completed. A conference of harbour author* Ities decided to adopt the uni form term "tonnase charge for dues on vessels, and a!s9 to levy It on the <-TOSS tonnage. By-law 22 was passed to give

effect to this decision.

The manner of Ailing vac* ancles on the board was ?changed during the' year so that a special meeting of the

PORT OF ROCKHAMPTON

-; *

(Continued from Page 3)

Rockhampton City Council, and the Mt Morgan Town Council elected a new member to their respective sections, and councillors of Fitzroy and Livingstone sitting together did so for their area. 80 for their area.

BOARD'S HANDICAPS

Dealing with the achieve ments of the Board, tha chairman's annual report states: "The reason that tha Intentions of the board have cot been accomplished is due to the insufficiency of funds breaking the continuity -of work, and not to any great en gineering difficulties."

In regard to diversion of trade to the railways, it said: "Id this instance, the board's loss of trade to the railways has not relieved the taxpayers of the necessity of paying for the railway deficit. Remains the question, is it worth while to develop the port of Rock hampton? The answer is that water carriage as universally acknowledged to be cheaper them land carriage, and in our case, landing goods at Rock hampton instead of at the nearest port on the coast saves the residents of the district about £100,000 per year. This, average has been worked out on the five years ending De cember 1929."

TAPERING KATES

On January 23, 1929, a con ference of representatives from Gladstone, Rockhampton and TowiiFville Harbour Boards met at Rockhampton to consider "the tapering rates of carriage charged by the railways." The Bowen representative was pre vented by floods from attend ing, and while sending no dele gate, the Bundaoerg board ex pressed its full agreement with She objectives of the. confer ence. These objectives which were presented to the confer ence as resolutions and carried unanimously, were:

"L We consider State rail ways should be entirely self supporting, and that the prac tice of subsidising them from lite consolidated should be stopped.

"2. That in order to give .ef fect to the policy of terminal ports, upon which the taper ing rates are' based, It is ea-* sentiai that the following prin ciples be observed:

"(a) Tapering rates on out ward goods shall apply only to those goods between the point of loading and the first ter minal effective port either coastwife or oversea; neither shall any preferential rates be allowed on those goods for car riage beyond that port.

! "(b) That each terminal ef

fective port shall be the start ing point from which tapering rates on inward goods for up country stations shall com

mence.

"(c) That the Government be asked to accept these prin ciples and amend the existing schedule of rates accordingly."

Tae Gladstone Harbour Board subsequently refused to endorse ttoe action of Us dele gate in voting in favour of the

motions.

In March Mr. K. E. Hartley retired from the board after servloe thereon for nearly 20 years and chairman since May, 1826. Mr. A. O. Afcderson was elected to fill the vacancy, and Mr. J. A. Elwing was elected

chairman.

Delegates from the Rock hampton and Townsville Bar bour Boards interviewed the Minister for Railways (Mr. Godfrey Morgan) on August 13, on the "injurious effect on Harbour Boards of the unfair competition of the Hallway De partment with the coastal shipping trade." The grab dredge Mourilyan was at work restoring depths at Gladstone wharf from August to October.

In response to the decisions reached .at the conference of Harbour Boards in January the Premier (Mr. A. 2. Moore) aid in September in regard to railway policy:

"... special cases would arise Involving Government policy where the .final decision must rest with the Govern ment, and is these «sases the Government must accept full responsibility for any ower-rul ing of the Commissioner's de cisions. In the case in ques tion the Commissioner con sidered that the operation of re duced long haulage rates from western stations to Brisbane would enable the railways to compete successfully with ship ping in the matter of carriage of wool from Tbwnsville and Bockhampton to Brisbane. There can be no.doubt that such would be the case and that his action would have tended to Increasing % railway revenue and to the stabilisa tion of employment in the rail way service. s

"The policy of the Govern ment, however, was in favour of decentralisation and of giv ing to each port a fair oppor tunity of securing the trade of its own district. After viewing the matter from all aspects the Cabinet had decided to re quest the Commissioner to re vert to the previous policy of providing for a long-haulage tapering rate to the hearest port only. For this action the Government and not the Com missioner must accept the re sponsibility."

The chairman of the board noted with satisfaction "that the Government had decided to give each port an opportun ity of securing Its own trade." He added, in regard to the Commissioner's ability to com pete with shipping. "He has done It for some years, 'and the taxpayer had paid for his suc

cess.'

The board was advised in December by the Permanent Committee of the inter-State Conference of Australian Har bour Authorities that the Commonwealth Government had agreed to pay port dues on any of its goods pass ing through any port in Aus tralia. To then Westers Aus tralia, South Australia and New South Wales Governments paid full dues, Tasmanlan Gov ernment paid half dues, find only the Queensland and Vic toran Governments claimed full exemption from payment of any dues. Pull dues were paid by the Government of Britain on meat exported from Rockhampton to its order.

Xt was stated in the chair man's annual report that the revival of the cattle Industry in this district would result in greatly increased output from the CQME Coy, Ltd., at Lakes Creek, and revived the ques tion of re-opening Broadmount "or possibly the opening of Thompson's Point."

The District Confererw-c ol T-n«n} prodQcere Rockhamp tonen April s carried unani mously the- following motion. 'liuA In view of the fact that tapering rates along the coast of Queensland are a serious set-back to Central Queens land agriculture, by dlsoour agtng the development of a load market, this district con ference make a strong protest to the Government and re quest that' the tapering rates be abolished."

At its meeting on April S the Chamber' of Commerce supported the stand taken by tjhe Harbour Board, as re vealed in a letter from the board's chairman:

1. "That the board's request for an enquiry into the differ ential treatment of ports must stand, and be thoroughly pro secuted, and

2. "Hie board maintains its right to expect honourable ful filment of Cabinet's solemn pronouncement, in September last, that the Commissioner for Railways would be in structed to provide that the long haul rate should apply to the nearest effective port only."

The Treasurer (Mr W. H. Barnes) visited Rockhampton on April .3 and made an in spection of the harbour works. The question of rail competi tion with the board was clearly set out, "a competition Vhich caused loss to the board and an increased burden on the taxpayer, who was called oq to make up this loss and also the interest which the board would, but. for railway competi tion, have paid to the Trea sury."

Mr Barnes recommended that, the Jboard take up this

matter with the Minister for Railways, who was shortly to visit Rockhampton.

The board also asked for a five years' moratorium on In terest payments, in which to recover Its trade and during which period the board would restrict Its expenditure to its income. Mr Barnes promised to consider fills request

The triennial - election bf members took place on April 6 for the following districts, and with the results shown: Rock hampton, Messrs A. C. Ander son, T. Conaghan, J. A. El wing, R. E. Hartley and A H. Patereon; Mt Morgan, Mr T. W. Chenery; Fitooy and Liv ingstone shires, Mr M. M. Mac

Ikellar; eastern shires, Messrs [C. P. Copland and R. Staines,

western shires, Messrs E. W.

| Archer and A. L. Macdonaid.

The two lastrnamed groups were not* elected until August

130, (he elections thus being

Bprefcd over * period of neatfy five months, Mr J. K. Swing ym J«*in elected chairman.

The Mln1**"1 tor Hallways | <Mr Godfrey Morgan) met the 'hoard- *t Rockhanvpton on i IB, and Mated at the out' I set that the railway eompeti

tion was neither unfairnor un-. profitable. He ais* a^aln^' teat the board had <lwn too wide and y ?» erroneous interpretation to me Premier's stat&nonV of Bep ten&er ot th# PWU«» year,

Le"itoe pollcyot ^

ment, however, wa» to ff*®ur

lug to «aoh port atafaroppor

tunity ol

it. own district. Aft* «Jgtog the matter from au jM««t* the Cabinet had deoM«d to reauest the commlakner to revert to the !«£«*? Wgg of ^iridlngjor^tot hw^ge tapering to tt# mw® (port only."

later* meant that the Pre I "»im» Intended the altera I tie* to apply "to wool only,

and not to the general sohe&sle of tatea."

The secretary, 'West Rock hampton Progress AswUtlon, wrote congratulating ttoa Har I bour Board on Its presentation of the long haul .rates caseto

Mr. Godfrey Morgan.

case lor Rhotfhampton wa» never more clearly or conctae ly expounded than tt

the able and WJtont addn» i of your chairman <Mr. «. ®-®

SHIPOWNER*® Off®

One ewuae put forwardln explanation oJ the tapering rates was that "if . the railway

ed. the shilling companies would increaM their oharge.

Two Royal Commissions Into the working of the Navigation Act stated that the Australian shipowner bad not aisled protection afforded by

The gridiron at Ledge Point was reconditioned to accomo date the dredge Fltvoy, so that for all but heavy struc tural work there would be no need for her to go to Brisbane. The Mtsroy was slipped there on December D.

WOOL DUES CUT

A new by-law reduced dues on wool untreated ores, fresh fish and timber by 10 per cent. In 1896 the combined dues on greasy wool were S/6 and on aooured wool 4/6 per ton "They ate now 3/3 per ton less 10 per cent on either." which made the rate 2/10 per ton.

The Associated Chambers of Commerce of Queensland met at Bo wen during the year. The Harbour Board chlarman (Mr J. A. Blwlng) represented the board.

In January the shire of Ut Morgan took the place of the town of Mt Morgan and the shire of Calllungal; the town of Blackall was abolished and Included in the shire of Ear goolnah.

On April 8,1881, the ss Pern dale collided with the Auck land Point Wharf, breaking several lender piles and two of the main concrete piles of thq

structure.

On May 26 Mr R. X. Hartley was appointed chairman of the board.

BBIGDBN BOOST

Professor Brlgden's "Report upon the Enquiry Into railway competition with Ports" was released on August II. Xt ttitirl that I*iiiesentalfres of.

trading nd

interests at Rockhampton and Townsvllle "laid great stress on the advantages of main taining these ports and the wtaWtehed trading connexions both to the slate and to their extensive hinterlands. They alleged that the railway policy as at present practised, tended towards the aggrandlsment of Brisbane and the subordin ation at the other ooestal ctties, and. claimed that the opposite policy of decentralis ation was not only a perman ent necessity for aa ana the slae of Queensland, bat that the cities had been developed with the asssmnoe that audi a (decentralisation) policy was intended to be permanent, and that all Governments had i supported it hitherto. With this, they contended, the gen eral policy of the railway Commissioner was

and required modification. At other ports similar represent tations were made."

Xrldenoe from primary pro ducers came mainly from in land, and related solely to

pastoral interests. Their «hi*f criticisms and suggestions n« lated to the high general rate

on wool:

"Their concern is that the costs of sending wool to the nearest sales should not be in creased by any protection given to the ports, and they desire to have effective competition between the railways and ship Ping 'companies. The United Graders, through its vics presldsnt, supported the pro. posal-of the commissioner tor Railways."

The Commissioner for Rail ways denied that his policy was anything but a profitable agog to the railways and to the State, and claimed that his special rates were all profit able. He also desired free dom to get as much traffle as possible, to bargain.freely for that traffic, - and to offer nidi rates as would, in his opinion, contribute something towards the heavy expenditure on

coastal lines.

"He points out that the cap ital liability incurred by the State on account of the coastal railway Is much greater than the aggregate Indebtedness to the State by the Harbour Boards. The Commissioner's point of view is that of a busi ness manager who Is oonvinced

that his policy is commercially sound, and whose concern is to produce the greatest pos sible return on capital Irres pective of the wider cpnsldera tions of policy (concerning decentralisation) raised by his

critics."

The report stated (para. 98) that while through carriage of wool by rail from the Central and Northern districts would be convenient to the Industry

and profitable to the railways, the benefits were not sufficient to justify so radical a Chang*

or policy. ;

.The transfer of the tntte (to the railways) would reduce the annual

revenue of the shipping serving Rackhamptbn ?. by some £27,000, and by mak 4of that shipping unprof itable it would imperil the prosperity of oekfcaasp ton. dependent as It Is on Its river port and lis con nexions by sea ...

The effects on Townsville would be less disastrous than on Rockhampton, but In de gree only. The transfer ot revenue (from the ports to the railways) amounting In all to about £70,000, would give no equivalent net benefit to the Btate, when the full.and simu lative effects upon these cities are taken into account Their status is worth conserving at the cost, in view of the great areas of Queensland."

PORT ALMA v. GLADSTONE Of the central ports the re port stated (para 101) that either Gladstone or Port Alma is required, but not both. "And If one Is to scrapped, there can be no question which It should be. Port Alma lias no advantages worth -consider ing over Gladstone. Its excel lent depth for deep sea ships may be a little better than at Gladstone, but not substan tially so . . « Port Alma Is a well-kept and substantial oasis in a wilderness linked by two steel rails. The advantages it has are that Its excess labour costs an borne by the over seas shipping companies (in that they pay the costs aiul charge no more freight) and Its nearness to Rockhampton. But Its nearness Is a created nearness, one to the special railway." Of the river Fltaroy the report states (para 1#7> that Its rentention and main tenance are Justified i .

"By the dependence of the city on Its trade, by the lower costs of goods shipped directly from and to other States, and by the Intangible advantage of what is called 'decentralisa tion.'"

Incidentally, the report states of Mackay (para 190) that the port needed no comment. "An Investigation of the pro posal to build an outer harbour has proved the project to be economically unjustifiable."

An amendment in the Bales Tax Assessment Act In August exempted from payment of this tax Government depart ments. But the exemption was not extended to Harbour Boards, so that while the port of Rockhampton pays the tax the port of Brisbane is ex empted from it.

On August 87 ite Flowers, Acting Engineer, supplied to the Barbour Board a report on 0)9 practicability of developing export coal loading facilities at Thompson's Point.

The Government totted la mi to .*w--Itii Bread mount. The railway line was lifted sal the' U>tes crane removed, the wharf waa handed over to the Barbour BOard, wUehmr chased the tren goods £ed then. ^

"Following the Government policy of reducing transport charges on pastoral products ' the board reduced the export dues on meat by 1/- and those on wool by 10d. per ton.

An unsuccessful attempt was made during 1081 to inaugurate a regular . chilled meat trade with southern States. The ship ping companies required some guarantee that, did they pro vide refrigerated space la the ships on the Adelaido-Bock hampton service, full use would be made of it. The guarantee was not forthcoming.' : :

At a meeting of the board on May 17, Mr R. E. Hartley was again elected chairman. A con solidated award for Harbour Board employees came Into force in August. The Btate Transport Co-ordination Act Of 1031 had a short life, being re pealed by the proclamation Ob December 22 of tto<£ estate transport Act. > f

The old Balaclava light tow ers were replaced during 'the year with two new structure!. The new lights are now unat tended, and the change (effected has proved a great improve*

Alma.

Electric lighting on the town wharves was first used in March, and at the end of the year it was held that it facil itated cargo handling at night " reduces risk of accidents, and so amply Justifies the extra cost."

At the annual election held In June, all retiring members were returned without opposi tion.

| The Harbour Board contin

by telephone. The lowest es-1 tlmated cost- of this Job was j £613, of which the Harbour Board offered to find one
