WATER HYACINTH

Water hyacinth was first mentioned as a flood nuisance, being caught up "principally from the borough of North RookhamptcpThe Harbour Board offered to pay half the cost of eradicating It from lands under control of that borough, but the chairman (Mr R. 8. Archer) stated « the end of the year that "r demand has yet been made c the board for its share of ti

-ost"

The year lfill ended a phase when the eea-borne trade of the port came either by river direct to the town wharves, ur ! was lightered from ships lying

in the bay or at Plat Island anchorage. It was the 18th year of the board's operations, and so marked a new phase in the porfs sea-borne'trade. The first consideration is the state of the river's navigable depths in 1011 as compared with those In 1886' .

The 943-ton steamer Barra bool, while making her way down the Piteroy River on the morning of May 17, grounded off the south end of Central Island. The weather was stormy and the ship's trim was 10 ft by the stem, a com bination which resulted In her becoming practically unman ageable. She appears not to have been damaged.

PORT ALMA LINE ! June 6 was gala day In Rockhampton. It was the

r dle of Carnival Week, and

addition, the Chairman of

the Harbour Board (Mr R. S. Archer) invited some 300 guests to attend at Fort Alma while the Governor (Sir William MacGregor) formally opened

the wharf there.

TUkcthmv tamed the 37-year-old wharf, that had perforated few «t the tra ditional faaetfms of wharves, Into a commercial asset linked by rail as It already was by MI WMi the trade and commerce of the world.

On arrival at the approaches to the wharf the special train halted, his Excellency alighted and with the rest of the offi cial party walked on the wharf. Here they were met by the Barbour Board party and halted while the secretary (Mr A. A. Mawdsley) read an ad dress «t welcome. After mak ing a brief response Sir Wil liam boarded the engine, pulled he lever, and drove the engine nd two carriages along the iarf, breaking a ribbon of e MacGregor tartan, which is hung from the shed to e of the wharf piles. He then glared the line and wharf ten to traffic.

FOBT AUKA TRAFFIC

Mr Archer told the board on March Si as to the agreement with the Commissioner -for Railways guaranteeing the Port Alma railway, the Com missioner has estimated that 16,000 tons of goods would go over the line each year, and that volume of trade would meet the guarantee. As a fac tor in inducing trade over the

line the board had fulfilled Its part "but last year 22.46" tons had passed ever-the line, and even that-which vw at least 4000 tons In excess of the estimated requirement- had not covered expenses. V .

While the 55-ton tender Port Stephens was loading kerosene and iftotor spirit from the steamer Toredali* at Broadmount wharf on (Sep tember 28, a Are was discov ered in the fore part of the hold. She was at once cot adrift and the flood tide and

a strong northerly wind car* ried her across the harbour to ground on the shore of Cm*

island about a third ct a mile below Rocky Petal where the become a total

The board protested to th» Railway 1 Department against the practice of landing ex plores directly into nil trucks, Instead of Into lighten to the first place, as In Bris bane, to be handled Into trucks when the wharf was clear. An accident when coas tal passenger ships were at the wharf would lead to Inde

I yHhiii 'complications; but tin

| protest 'went unheeded.

SOUTH CHANNEL IJSSD

I The South Channel as an alternative entrance to Broadmount afrd the river was opened by as WilUhlre daring IS 11 "pilots finding It much

«asle to negotiate inwards, - even In its unfinished state, ?han the Middle Channel. For leaving, thay prefer-to xm the latter . .. until ,» wider bell mouth la cut at the upper

Appointed chairman at the Rockhampton Harbour Bond

In 1913, Mr 6. B. Hoppersald In his !"««««* report for. the Tear, that from hi* oiteerra ttons fibe dredge Archerhad "not been pioyerly eared toe . .. repairs, where undertaken at all, were hurried overand due attention had not been paid to the more vital parts of machinery". '

Ha also said that there be ing no fund to cover wear and tear,, and that all future as-' Umates should. include an amount to cover. cost of re pairs to, and wear and tear of working plapt. Mr Hopper fiftraplwfoy* that the boardfe borrowing powers, based upon 10 times the income averaged

over five years, was tSOOjOOO, . whereas that of the Call us ,? and Gladstone Harbour Boards was fixed at U times the income averaged over fire years On that basis, be said,

the Rockh&mptoa*B board'*.... limit would then be aboot £500,000.

On trade Of the poet » Hopper said "I regret to say that the State Goveniment, by granting special long haotaga rates, endeavours to draw as

much trade as possible to em ~ favoured port. Railage of wool, far lnstaTwir, over 400 wnwi past the nearest port, besides starving that port, himm the tying up of trades for longer than necessary. TT*pr* more rolling stod: mart bo provided that would other wise be required."

ELECTION CHALLENGED

At the 'i"""1 election in June Messrs O. D. Connor and S- Williams were declared elec ted to represent payers of dues. lUs ? declaration was challenged by Mr R. Donald b^ti owing* to the large number of>votes which had been rejec ted by the Returning OlBeer on tae grounds that the quaH fV»aMAT\ of witnesses had not been seated as part of the I witnessing.

Legal action was taken, and the action on appeal reached the Full Court, whence an orier was issued for the Reg* istrnr of the Rockhampton Supreme Court to ascertain'if In fact the several witnesses were properly qualified. Tha recount resulted In the return of Mr Donaldson; and soma well directed criticisms from the Bench on the Inadequacy

of the Act.

"On the whole I think that the results obtaAed In 19 yean axe highly creditable, even though mistake have undoubtedly been made. Non attainment of the first objec tive: a 20 ft channel from the Ma to town Is attributable

to insufficient funds to* carry out the work of to-' provement continuously and speedily. The ultimate aim of; the board must remain the same, le^ to obtain a clear passage to town for overseas ?teamen bringing In cargo or talcing out meat and other produce of the district."

UNDER FRANCHISE

An amendment in 1914 to the Harbour Board Act in creased the number of, mem bers to 11 and abolished rep resentation fay payers of dues, and substituted representa tion by ratepayer*. In the new set up Bockhampton had four. North Rockhampton and ltt Morgan one each, the Shires of Pltsroy and Living stone shared one, the shires of Banana, -Bauhinla, Bel yando, Calllungal, Clermont, Duaiinga, Jmwrald and Peak Downs shared two, and the chins of Aramar, Blackall, Barcaldlne, Baicoo, Dlaman tina, Hfracombe, Islsford, Kar .otinah. Longreach and Twnbo shared two, or 11 In all. The manner of electing west ern members was changed tram a ratepayers' to a shire councillors' vote. Names to drop tram the new list-as

being already in shires-were Kennedy, Leichh&rdt, Spring cm re, Taroom and Westwood.

A telephone line via Alton I Downs to Craiglpe^ enabled a

flood warning station to be set up about 00 miles from Yaamba.

The old system of hand! shovel and drays was displac I ed at Upper Quarry by the In stallation of a M-ton Bucynis steam shovel that commenced | operations on September 24 Output immediately stepped up to 800 tons per day against j

180 tons hitherto.

On November 1 the 8248-ton sjk. Chyebasaa berthed at Broadmount wharf drawing 22

ft 7 indies.

STATED OUTSIDE

, The Harbour Board showed ion November 8 that In the nine yean from the opening | of Broadmount in IM08 a total of 3473 coastal ships-as dis tinguished frota river ships entered the bay and of them only 211 or 9 per cent of the total entered Broadmount The other 91 per cent anchored in the bay "just as they did be i fore a penny was spent on | Broadmount'*

River craft on the Fttsroy during 1808 were: dredge Ar | cher, x; launch Constance

(Government); tug Curlew x;

| lighter Edith; hulk Xtwood, x; [supervision steamer Xthelbert, x; tug Hawk, x; lighter Janet, lighter Martha Reid, lighter | Mew Chum; tugs Swan and I Tweed, x,' launch Wallaby, x.

[Note: .x denotes Harbour Board and Walter Reid.J

Comparison of the perform ances of the dredge Archer with those of her sister dredge Hercules (Brisbane) during j 1.906 revealed that the latter I lifted 2.4 times the amount of material per hour at *5 per

I cent' the cost of the Archer,

cher.

I A legislative committee ap pointed in 1908 to consider de sirable amendments to the [Harbour Boards Act recom mended (a) that one repre I sentatlve of Rockhampton's payers of dues be given to Mt Morgan, (b) that the qualifi [ cation to vote be reduced from £2/10/0 to £1. (c) the manner of appointing auditors to be altered, and (d) " the disqual ification of members for con tracting with the board to be

modified."

The battle for the deepwater port continued and was an is sue at the annual election in June, 1908, the result of which left the board divided. "In view, of this unfortunate con flict of opinion" wrote the | Chairman (Mr Archer) "the Government apolnted a com- j mlttee of Independent experts . . and X hope that their de cision will be accepted loyally, if not cheerfully, by all con

cerned."

j On January 12, Mr A. B. |Moncrieff, Engineer-In-Chief South Australian railways, W. iPagan, Chief Engineer [Queensland Railways, ^nd E. | A. Cullen, Engineer. Harbours

and Rivers. Queensland, were appointed by the Premier (W.

Xldston) a Board of Enquiry to consider and report

"on the question of the relative cost of making and maintaining a deep water port at Broadmount and Port Alma respectively, having a depth

at the wharf and in the channel leading thereto of 24 ft, at low water, and navigable at all state of the

tide by night and by day,"

It was indicated that in the case of Port Alma the w»i^ factor was the cost of con necting the existing wharf with the Rockhamptoa-Giad stone railway end of provid ing for a fresh water supply. In the case of Broadmount the main factor was the Improve ment and maintenance of ap proach channels, as wen as in creasing the wharf frontage to accomodate two vessels at once. The terms of reference

concluded:

"The questions submitted for your consideration are the technical and

ones stated above. You will disregard all ex parte rep resentations in favour of either port, and win deal *itli the matter solely on its business merits, and after careful *r*wnn«t|..n of the two localities, in or der that the Government In coming to a

.nay have the assurance that they are determining the matter on the

facts concerning those two'

ports."

Mr Moncrieff was appointed

M. Murchle was appointed pilot, Rockhampton, on Janu

ary u.

The Board of Kxperts pre sented their report on Janu ary 31. The report stated that the board had examined the Htsroy delta and had studied existing shipping facilities at Broadmount and Port aim* and found that "the

and nautical advantages, due to the situation of these two ports, remain most unquest ionably in favour of Port Alma, while the shore con veniences wetc no less surely In favour of Broadmount."

The heard MM, there fart, to recommend

the two ports by a 6.75 mile railway from Bread anai to Part Alma. The Km woaM eras the river by a MM ft railway bridge at Booby Point, thence via Casaarinm Isbad and creek to Port Abu.

"Looking upon the wharves at Broadmount and Port Alma as alternatively pos sible as outer ports for the PiUroy River, and Stanley Street railway station as the objective for the traffic in either ease, the cost of put ting the two places on an equal footing with 1000 ft of wharfage, rail communica . tion, and sea approaches giv

ing 34 ft at low water ln channels 400 ft wide would ha:

Broadmount

No estimate for providing a fresh water supply was given in.either cost.

x: This estimate was subject to closer survey revealing no unexpected difficulties and was subsequently increased to £141,682.

Ttoe board submitted that In the long view the Broadmount Port Alma link solved most problems and provided a deep water port and would be

"capable of Improvement if required, risk of flood would be avoided. the possible abandonment of Broadmount railway would be avoided and, if the annual cost of main tenance is capitalised at 4 percent, the scheme would be found to be the most eco . nomical."

Mr Pagan, Chief Engineer Queensland railways reported on March SB having prepared an estimate from the {dan and section of the Broadmount Port Alma railway, and it. was found necessary to add £37,791, making the new figure £141,683. This came about through (a) increased length of the railway line by 0.78 miles; (b) length of bridge increased from 6600 ft to 8484 ft; (o) the swing

®Pan ot the bridge

creased from two at 100 ft each to two at 200 ft each; and (d) increase to length Qt bridge Piers, owing to rock being found at 74 ft below low water, or much deeper than was ex

pected.

SUPPORT POR PORT ALMA JHiere were two appendices to the report, both from Rock hampton harbour masters. The flrat was from Captain Wilkin son, then occupying that post, and he was outspoken on the dangers of the Middle Channel.

These were:

' ? . . the short turns and we cross current through the Worth Passage (Nos 5 and 6 leads). There has been ves sels ashore there-the Kent Duke of Buckingham and Langton Orange. All the In tersections are bad, and that at Nos 1 and 2 leads if dredged to 24 ft would soon

nil up again."

In this he was supported by Captain E. A. Sykes, late har bour master, who was equally vehement in regard to the ex cellence of Port Alma - from a purely nautical point of view:

"The approaches to port Alma are good - PTf»n»nf There is ample room to swing large vessels, and there have been no material alterations in depths or widths during my experience of 28 years. I am favourably impressed with the idea of putting in a railway via Casuarina

with a bridge at Rocky Point

as suggested."

He visualised warping a «h»p through the swing bridge as if it were a wharf, and foresaw no difficulty. Captain Wilkin son endorsed Sykes' opinion of Port Alma, but pretended to no experience with swing bridges, though lie agreed that a width of 100 ft would be little enough.

On March J Joseph Paine commenced a term of 23 years as pilot at Gladstone.

The Turnery wall was com pleted to 9 ft above low water on March 4, the completed length being 12,605 feet. Bain Island, deposited by the dredge Archer, was removed during

the year.

Replyifcg on April 27 to the Pastoral Employers' Associa tion of Central and Northern Queensland, the Harbour Board stated that It had given "every attention to the request" and bad taken all available advice on the matter, which was that it would cost £276,000 to rnabp a 24 ft channel into Broad mount. It also pointed out that

there was:

"... a good deep channel into Port Alma, which re quired no dredging, and that there was a wharf there which, equally with the one at Broadmount, would re quire lengthening, and that It would require railway con nexion. The time and money required to make Port *»"?« available would be very much less than would be required for Broadmount, and the Government would probably

build the railway under the Guarantee Act"

A. J. H. Young was ap pointed Harbour Master at Gladstone on September 2.

THOMPSON'S POINT

Hie secretary to the Har bour Board (Mr A. A. Mawds ley) in & letter to the board dated September 22, developed a new angle to the deep-water port question. His letter read:

"In reference to the present differences of opinion existing as to the best location of a deepwater port for the Central District, and the grave objec tions which are honestly held to the adoption of either Broadmount or Port Alma, I beg.to suggest that Thompson's Point should be taken Into con sideration.

"The great objection to Broadmount as a port is that the only suitable approach is considered to be by the Middle Channel, and that to Improve this channel sufficiently to meet reasonable .requirements will cost a very large sum of money.

"The objection to Port Alma is that the railway connexion will be long abd costly, and that the expenditure, though lees than that of deepening t

tmsaa te Oiiarmel, will In no way assist In improving the en trance to the river, which, af course, the adoption of Broad

mount would do.

"Within the last few yean the conditions which deter mined the choice of Broad mount as the most suitable site on the north bank of the river

have changed. The construc- » tlon of Shoal Island Wall and the consequent scour created thereby have deepened the first reach above Rocky Poiuu con siredably, and It is qjite evi dent that, in the course of a short time, there will be a good channel of from 20 to 22 feet even without the assistance of dredging. On the east side of , Thompson's Point there Is

ample room for 2000 feet of wharf frontage with a depth of water of 22 feet at low water

and there 1s a good swinging

basin.

Thompson's Point Is now the furtherest point up the river at which the water necessary for a deepwater port and <* suit able land site are to Tie found in combination. It is certainly

7 miles further inland

Port Alma and 6i mn*n fur ther than Broadmount, if the latter is approached by the

Middle Channel.

"In considering this sugges tion It will be necessary to have a careful survey made of the South Channel and an esti mate prepared, but if the basis of the estimate by Mr Schmidt is cor rect, it would appear as If the South Channel could be deepened and the necessary wharf built with railway con nexions at Thompson's Point tot much less than the

Channel can be made suitable and for less than the Port I Alma scheme would cost, and at the same time the estuary would be deepened for river

traffic.

"Mr Schmidt estimated the cost of making a cutting 300 ft wide by 20 ft deep, with a bell-mouth at the outer end, at £34,000, calculating the cost of dredging .at 6dL a yard. The cost of a wharf 1000 feet long by 60 feet wide, without sheds, reckoning at the average cost of 10/- a square foot, would be £30,000, and a reduction might be made in this, if the super structure of the Broadmount and Port Alma wharves were used. The advantages of the scheme as compared with the proposal to make Port Alma the deepwater port are:

"(1) The cost of the railway connexion an the wharf win be about £35,000 as compared with £80,000 at Port Alma.

"(2) The money spent on deepening the South Channel, probably another £30,000 to £40,000, will attain the twofold object of providing a deep water channel and also a good entrance to the river for coastal

vessels.

"(3) Thompson's Point wharf will be nearer to Rockhampton

by about 13 miles.

.'(4) There is more space available for good wharfage than at Port Alma and the position is more sheltered. The chief and insuperable disadvan tage of Thompson's Point as compared with Port Alma is its greater distance from the sea. Thompson's Point being 16 miles distant and Port Alma

only nine.

"As compared with Broad mount the advantages bt Thompson's Point for a wharf

site are;

"(1) It is slightly nearer | town.

(2) It can be approached conveniently by way of the South Channel whereas Broad mount cannot be so ap

proached.

"(8) The making of an en trance by the South Channel will be very much less than the huge expenditure necessary to make the Middle Channel a convenient entrance.

"The only disadvantage as ' compared with Broadmount is the increased distance that vessels will have to travel. Broadmount being distant from [sea miles by the Middle Channel and 1S4 by the South Channel, whereas Thompson's Point is 16 miles distant by the*

South Channel.

SAVED DREDGING

Eagtaeer-in-Chiet J. H. Baynes reported in 1909 that the Shoal Island Reach survey revealed that some 45 million tons had been removed by the increased scour due to the partly completed Shoal Island

wall. This was equal to abot^t

trv.w«T»»y»rt ea Paga 1&)

PORT OF ROCKHAMPTON

(Continued from Page 3)

four years single-shift work for the Archer or, say, would have cost £44,000 to remove by dredging, which sum exceeded the cost of the Shoal Island Wall by about £6000.

Keen contests were the fea ture of the annual Harbour Board election in June, as a result of which tbe personnel of the board was Messrs R. 8. Archer, J. Bremner, R. E. Hartley, G. B. Hopper, A. W. Kirby, R. Macfaxiane* J. J. McEvoy, A. H. Parnell and W. H. Rudd. Mr McEvoy was elected to the chair.

During the year the deep water port question was settled in favour of Port Alma, re garding which the chairman. (Mr McEvoy) said: "It is a ! matter for congratulations that

the increase of trade of the district rendered the demand for a deepwater port so ur gent, but had it been possible to wait until the work of im proving the principal highway, the river, had been completed, some other solutiorr of the question might have been found which would have com bined the deepening of the en trance to the river with the provision of a deepwater port."

During the year the final £30,00 of the £150,000 loan au thorised in 1904 was spent.

The Governor (Sir Win MacGregor) turned the first sod of the Bajool Fort Alma railway on January 29, 1910.

Winding Reach wall was completed in June to a length of 4860 feet. After the June election the personnel of the board comprised Messrs R. S. Archer, J. Bremner, R. E. Hartley, O. B. Hopper, A. W. Kirby, R. Macfarlane, J. J. McEvoy, A. H. Parnell and W. H. Rudd, with R. 8. Ar cher again in the chair.

A wrong order given to the helsman resulted in the 2272 ton steamer Eastern stranding in the Middle Channel while entering on the evening of August 6. The ship remained agrovnd for several days, but was got off eventually, un damaged. A short wall on the north side of Humbug reach was commenced on August 19 and completed in October.

Tenders were invited in August for widening Port Alma wharf and adding 500 feet to its length. The only tender was considered too high, so the Harbour Board under took the work.

The ' old Satellite passage took its tortuous turnings into oblivion in 1610 when the new channel through Humbug Reach was completed. Of this work Engineer-In-Chief Baynes wrote in his September report

soon after completion of the work: It*was one of the largest dredging problems we have undertaken, and should in ad dition to faciltating navigation beneficially influence the ad

i joining readies of the rim by giving a more direct set to tidal currents and confining them to one main channel, for the Satellite channel hitherto used was at best only a by

pass."

Harbour Board officials pro ceeded per Ethelbert to Keppel Bay on October 24 to meet Ad miral Sir Reginald Henderson, Naval Adviser to the Common wealth Government, who was touring Australia on an inspec tion of Australian ports.

D. M&cdonald was appointed pilot, Rockhampton, on Oc tober 27. The gap of 476 feet in Satellite wan was closed and topped off on December 9 and by early December the Bajool Port Alma line was completed to Raglan Creek.

Efforts to have an adequate system - of flood warning stations established in the Fitz roy watershed were renewed in 1910, but with little suc cess. A by-law to protect river banks against damage caused by ships moving too fast was passed in 1910. The Harbour Board Installed its electric light plant in 1910 to replace the unsatisfactory lighting system

then in use.

(To be continued.)
heading: THE PORT OF ROCKHAMPTON: ITS ORIGIN AND DEVELOPMENT
snippet: A NEW [?] the harbour and wharfage dues, came into use on January 1. Mr G. B. Hopper

THE PORT OF ROCKHAMPTON: ITSt

ORIGIN AND DEVELOPMENT

(Written for the "Benlf by "Historicm.")

0OMMENCTNO to February,

1W0 the Government dredge Casuarlna worked in t the. Pitzroy until October, 'when

the re tamed to Brisbane. The Bundaberg dredge Ceratodiu also undertook minor work, the ruling river depth being 10 ft at Rocky Point.

Mr C. E. Croker, representing ratepayers of Rockhampton* re signed frtan the Harbour Board on March 1, and an election was held In April to fill the vacancy. Mr O A. Hoffman was elected to the post at the May meeting of the Harbour Board. Mr R. S. Archer was again eleoteg chairman.

A triennial election In July resulted In the following Har bour Board persona ell: Messrs T. W. Kingel, A. W. Patison, E B. Pumell, and W. G. Thompson (Rockhampton); W. Beak, (shires of Fltzroy and Livingstone); O. F. Campbell Brown (Mt Morgan); 0. P. Copland and W. H. Kettle (Shires of Banana, Bauhlnia, Belyando, Calliungal, Clermont, Duaringa, Emerald and Peak Downs; R. S. Archer and H. H. Wagstaff town of Blackall, .hires of Aramac, Barcaldine, Barcoo, Dlamantina, . Hfra combe, Isisford, Kargoolnah, Longreach and Tambo.

HARBOUR DUES RAISED

In August import harbour dues were increased from 6/6 per ton to 6/8, and those on exports from 4/- to 6/- per ton. Export dues on wool were re duced from 4/1 to 3/6 per ton. "This reduction" wrote the chairman Mr R. 8. Arcber) "in conjunction with the reduction of shipping freight to Bris bane and termination of the wool appraisement system has resulted In the increase in wool exports as shown." The in crease was from 33,137 bales In 1919 to 26,315 In 1920.

. At a conference of C.Q. local governing bodies held In Aug ust to consider tHfe advisability of supporting the New States movement, the Harbour Board was represented by Mr C. Hoff

man.

A round table port confer ence called by the Chamber of Commerce was held at the Council Chambers on Septem ber « at which were the follow ing: Messrs J. R. Phillips (Chamber of Commerce); W-. Beak, J. W. CShanesy and W. H. Mortlmore, Livingstone, Fltzroy and Mt Morgan shire councils respectively; R. S. Archer, Harbour Board); F. Rhodes, Harbour Master; J. J. Macaulay, Merchants' Associa tion; R. E. Hartley, W. G. Thompson and K. A. Wool cock, Employers Association; MT. H. Kettle (Clermont), J. (My (Emerald; and F. B. Star key, Graziers' Association; P.

8. Maries, Howand Smith, Ltd; j

W. A. Mackay, C.QMJ3. Coy.; j W. Fleming, Waterside Work- j era; F. J. P. Conlon, Carters.; j Q. Urry, A.W.U.; J. Ryan, A. UISJ3.; C. F. Knight, Q.R.U.; R. M. 'Carthy, Coachbuildere'; W. Harvey, Engine Drivers and Mremens* Unions respectively.

"KEEP RIVER OPEN"

Mr Phillips was Voted to the chair, and after general dis cussion the motion} "That thi* meeting declares that the first consideration is the policy of keeping the river open" was presented. But for the graziers whose representatives refrain ed from voting, this resolution was carried unanimously.

A mptlon: "That In view of the unsatisfactory condition ol the port facilities this confer ence, believing that the closing of the North Passage will per manently benefit the naviga tion of the estuary of the Fltzroy River, recommends that the Harbour Board take the necessary steps to close thl» passage." An amendment to this was that a sub-committe® comprising the Mayor (Mr T. W. Kingel) the president of the Chamber of Commerce, the Harbour Master (Captain F. Rhodes) and Harbour Board Engineer (Mr H. M. McCuU och) be appointed to examine the matter and report to the next meeting of the conference to be held on October 12.

GLADSTONE PROTESTS

At Its ineetlng on October ?12 the round table conference found itaalf confronted by protests, for their non-Inclu sion In the conference, from the Gladstone City Council, the Gladstone Harbour Board, the Gladstone and Port Cur tis Chamber of Commerce the Calliope Shire Council

^^..f$|tf^^nch of

ft* Waterside Workers' Un fpV «« the general grounds that Gladstone was part of Central Queensland, the port Question li s national one, ' and a« such was not one lor

any particular part or section

' to decide." <

To- this tiie conference, oy 13 rota to 0, decided: "That the correspondence be receiv ed, and the writers Informed that geographically and con 1 fitltutionaUy they were not -In

terested in the matter im^r

1 discussion."

J The sub-committee thfn j presented the following re

commendations :

1. "That advantage be taken of the visit of Mr. a P. Holmes, CJ5., late Chief Engineer to the New gfpipnd Government, to secure from him a report on this follow

ing:

2. The cutting of a chan nel to connect the Middle ana South channels through be 1 tween Flat Island and Ob

struction Bank, thus avoiding the trouble at Rocky point. Mackenzie Island, and Mnf kenzie Sands, the depth of the cutting be 14ft" with an ul timate 30ft, the spoils from the cutting to be utilised for training walls, as recommend ed by Mr. McCulloch, this recommendation to be subject to further bores being made to prove the practicability of

the work."

3. Extending the Shoal Is land Wall to Rocky Point at an estimated cost of £15,000, with the object of removing the disabilities of navigation in the vidnty, the work to be undertaken immediately, as it Is of an urgent nature."

As the sub-committee was silent on the matter it was unanimously decided by con ference to obtain the opinion of Mr. Holmes on the advis ability of building a wall to high-tide level across North

Passage.

- On October 28 P. Q. Knyvett was appointed Harbour Mast er at Gladstone. At a pre liminary separation meeting of delegates from the loval Government bodies in Central Queensland which was held in December, Mr. C. A. Hoffman represented the Harbour Board in place of the chair man, who was unable to at

tend.

Approval was given in 1820 for extension in reinforced concrete of Auckland Point Jetty, Gladstone, by 450ft. Much of the plant was as sembled, but owing to a es ment shortage work was not actually started.

Three notable obstructions were removed during the year: The rocks off Devi)'* Elbow, Derwent and Eagle Rocks, Upper Flats. Improve ment in river depths also ne cessitated deepening of berth* at the city wharves.

Finding little prospect m netting a flood warning sta tion in the northern section of the FiUroy watershed, the Harbour Board shifted its re quest to having - one estab lished at Rlversleigh, near Oogango. With proper com munications, this would giv* ttiree days warning of the im minence ' and heights of

floods.

COAL LOADING MOVE

'Two of the Blair Athol coa| companies'* requested during the year that the board should erect "suitable machinery on Port Alma wharf for loading export coal," and they offered to lend the board money to cover the cost, the loan 'to be for a term of years and free of interest." Before consider.

I ing the matter fully, «Jk> board asked for a minimum tonnage guarantee to be ex ported, to the principal of which the coal companies' re presentative orally- agreed, "but subsequently the com panies refused in writing to confirm this, and negotiations fell through." ,

The report of Mr. R. W. Holmes, M.LCJE. was re received during J&janary, la reply to the questions submitted by the round table conference. He re Ported that (a) the North Channel should not be closed, and (b) a satisfac tory channel could not be maintained between Flat hhM and Obstruction

Banks.

Mr Holmes elaborated hia ; reasons for (a)-wfclch^wsr*

mainly hydraulic-but gavs! none fpr (b), notwithstanding the opinion of Mr. McCulloch, Harbour Board Engineer, on September 15* 1920: "There la another way that has been suggested to overcome the trouble to Rocky Point, and that, is by branching Into Middle Channel above Flat Toiflpd This solution of the difficulty appears to me to be a very good one if the cost is not prohibitive. There is a ffrtyin amount of hard clay in the line where It is sug gested to connect, and there may be worse material under neath which would require re

moving.

"In any case, I estimate to mqirp a channel -800 ft. wide would mean removal of 1,070,000 yards of material; but this could be built up on the downstream side of the cut and faced with stone to form a training wall to guide the ebb through and help to fTiflfrntatn the depth. The ob jection to this scheme is its cost, which must be high. As suming dredging to cost 1 /

per yard-end It would[J****

de dealt with?

CULLEN REPORT

During February Mr. E. A. Cullen made an inspection oi the works of the board toen able fr<m to supply the Trea surer "a comprehensive re port with special reference d the various works carried out, { the cost thereof, . and their value as an improvement to the port, together with sug£ gestlons in regard to work ( now necessary and the estim , ated cost thereof." Hi* k- | port, dated April 21, mad* a review of river work from «» inception to his report dated AprU Sl, 1921, ^owtog that the area to be dredged lo maintain 12 ft. at low water had fallen from 40,600 ft. m 1876 to 4880 in 1920. .

Harbour Master, Rockhamp ton, on November 25, in p'wg of F. Rhodes, resigned. Mr r, 6. Archer was elected chair man of the board for the 12th

term.

WOOL DUES REDUCED

Dues on V7ool were reduced from 4/- to 3/6 per ton 'luring i ZB21, "conditionally on the ; shipping companies reducing j their freight." It wae com | plained that the monthly ar i rival and sailing of ships ot | the companies within a few I days of each other caused

some wool to miss important sal&, ami go was a factor w. wool-growers using the ral | ways.

fortunately,'' wrote chair j nan S. 8. Archer la lib

Mr G. P. Campbell Brown ; resigned frgm the board on

April 13, and Mr J. D. Murray was appointed to the vacancy. Mr T. J. ODonoghue, on loan from the Harbours and Rivers > Department, commenced a

survey of the Fitsoy estuary at the end of April,

LOAN DIFFICULTIES

War shortage of shipping and the resultant diversion of the board's trade to the rail ways, resulted In the inability of the board to meet its loan commitments. Hie Treasurer (Mr E. G. Theodore) visited RnrJrtmmpton, and it was agreed that one h*if or the 'hoard's income if less than.

£20,000 would be paid to the Treasury. 76 per cent of all ; Income between £20,000 and £26,000, and the whole of any income In excess pf £2&000.

That is to say, with a re venue of 25,000 the boant

j would be left with £11,250 with

.which to administer and j maintain a port. The chalr

, man (Mr R. 8. Archer) said* i "The arrangement is on the whole a generous one to the board as between debtor and creditor, but it bean hardly on ja body entrusted with the {duty of carrying but a natlon | al wort which is necessary for

i the development of the coun ; try."

On December 18 Mr R 8. Archer was again elected chairman of the board. The surrey of the estuary1 of the river, made by Mr QDonog 1 hue at a cost of £1265, was

completed in December.

During the year the Har bour Board franchise was al tered from a ratepayers' to a parliamentary electors' quali fication, with the exception of j the two groups of western

shires, where the system of election remained nnriharigprf,

A. Walsh was appointed pilot, Rockhampton, on Jan uary 1, 1923.

A Harbour Board deputation waited on the Premier at Rockhampton on February 13 to protest against "further at tempts that were being made to divert from Rockhampton trade that properly belonged to it, and can be handled as

satisfactorily and more eco- ' comically than elsewhere." The Premier assured the de putation that such attempts would not be countenanced by the Government.

McCULLOCH REPORT

In a comprehensive report ! dated February 19 on "the best means of rnaMng a channel through the estuary into Broadmount and the river, the depth to be suitable for meat vessels and others to eo Into Broadmount" the Harbour Board Engineer (Mr H. K. McCuQoch) very soon disposed of the Middle Channel and with It the Huestlon of closing North Passage. He found that to obtain 17 ft at low water the cost would bs £125,000 with no guarantee as to the channel maintaining its stab ility. On the other hand, closure of Shoal Is. wall would be whichever chan nel was selected. Turning to the South Channel he said*

"I am of the opinion that this channel, which is the rrmfopiied on

PORT qIfrockhampton

' ?» I -* ?

(Continued from faue Three) mriyi entrance to the river,, having * cross {sectional are* more than twicje that of the middle Channel, is the one to develop. 'It carries without maintenance high water depth on neap tldee of 33 feet, and spring tides up to 30 feet right up to False Point, and th°re are only two leads in a dis tance of 9 .miles, so that up .to that point awkward curves don't exfct

"Beyond 18 feet it Is unsafe to estiin^&e because the nature of the tpttom is not known on all the shoals. It Is certain however, that some costly dredging would be necessary on Cardigan Lead to get be yondthis"

"The cost of obtaining 17ft at low water In this channel would be £32,600"

On February 20 the board decided that the McCulloch report be referred to the, Treasurer for consideration' and report by his technical advisers, also that the report be discussed at next meeting

of tbe board.

On March 20 the Hnglnaar for Harbours and Rivers (Mr CuDen) reported on "the Me - Culloch report of February 19, practically endorsing tt in Its entirety. Be concluded his re port with: "To summarise I agree that the South Channel Is the most favourable of the two entrances for improve ment, that the Shoal Island Wall should be extended to Rocky Point as a first step, and that on completion the shoal area should be dredged.''

A Walsh was appointed Act* lng Barbour Master, Rock hampton, on April 18, In place of J. Bartlett, transferred.

CENTRAL BOARDS' MAN The Harbour Boaxus of Gladstone, Mackay and Bock hampton, met on June 14 to

consider two proposals. The first, trom Bookhamptoin: That Hw Government be

quested to credit the Central

and Northern Board districts with tin respective amounts

due to each it <Myn bar *e returns of receipts and expen diture from lfe89 fey tetnt oyer to that extent the debt of each board oone^md and treating It as part of the national debt."

Northern boards sniffed sus piciously at this idea, and It was shelved to perish in ob scurity. The second was the hardy annual requesting the Stete "Government to pay or dinary port dues on all of 'ts ships and goods, and this ap pears to have received no bet

ter Hate.

The Harbour J3oard decided

on June 19 to receive and adopt Mr Oullen's report on the engineer's report on the Improvement of the estuary, and to apply to the Govern ! ment with a view to obtaining

la loan of £45,000 to cany out 'the work.

O. H. liley was appointed pilot, Rockhampton, on June 29, in the room of A. Walsh, promoted.

Mr E E McCulloch, engin eer to the Board since May, 1913, died on July 1. Bis total length of service with the board was from March 1, 1910

Mr A. C. Nicholson was ap pointed, on August 28 to the

vacancy.

GLADSTONE EXTENSIONS^ In his annual, report dated August 10 the Engineer for Harbours and River* stated that the extension by 460 feet of Auckland Point Jetty, Glad stone, was practically complet ed by June 30; two closed wharf sheds each 140 z 30 feet had been built; that rails had been extended to the wharf; tenders had been accepted for a wool dumping plant with two presses; tenders had been call ed for a 16-ton derrick electric crane to be erected on the or iginal wharf; the wharf fron tage bad been dredged to 33 feet; preliminary plans and es timates had been prepared to duplicate the shore access jetty, to extend the original wharf 300 feet to the west ward; and a detailed survey of the area within the line con necting Auckland and Barney Points had been completed.

J. A. W. Bwltxer was appoint ed Harbour Master, Rock hampton on August 24, in place DI A. Walsh, transferred.

A deputation ^waited on the

Treasurer (Mr E. G. Theodore). on December 14 on the matter

of a maintenance fruhllng dredge, and it was promised that such a machine would be procured on behalf of the board.

On December 16 Mr R. S. Archer was again appointed chairman of the Board.

(To be continued)

articleText:
THE PORT OF ROCKHAMPTON :ITS

ORIGIN AND DEVELOPMENT

(Written for the "UenU" by "Bbtoifeu.")

1th® Court of Australia

decided in April 1958 in favour of the Hacbour Board in the peanut ease, with costs against the Peanut Board.

The Harbour Board on June 20 considered a letter from Bluff Colliery Coy. Ltd. and the Rangal and Clyde Coller tes. In which *!t was stated that the directorate of these

1 met the Minister for Mte« (Mr J. Slopford) to Brisbane to discuss the ques-1 Hon of expanding the coal in durtry. Nothing was decided at the Interview, but the Min ister agreed to meet C. Q. in

terests during his' visit to I Rockhampton in Carnival! week. I

Xn proposing that the Bar-! bour Board should Join the conference, the coal companies propounded the view that the best method of expanding the industry would be through ex port, and of the coal port sites offering, that at Thompson's Point "carries most advan ces" The board decided to Join the deputation "to ask him to appoint a throughly qualified man to examine and! fJPort and give an estimate of the cost of the coaling facil

ities required."

The Minister met the dep utation on June 23, when the scheme for establishing coal report faculties at Thompson's Point was outlined it was emphasised that this site "had

the natural advantages necessary to make it the Car diff of Australia." Mr Stop ford promised to ask the Pre mier-under whom was vested control of ports- lor an ex roanination of the coal loading possibilities'at Port Alma and Thompson's Point. He also saw that he would try to ar range for officials to visit Asl

countries to ascertain the cnanc« of selling Queensland

coal there.

COAL LOADING

* «P*s«tati« deputation waited an the Premier (Mr *w*an Smith) on July as to ?sk for the services of a cam- I j*te»t engineer to report on the^ coal loading possibilities u Fort Alma and Thompson's Point. The Premier said that he would be glad to have the TOWted investigation

SS».J?n2? <»«P«tation

tnat "the demand for coal was much less than it was a few generations ago," and the Oov jwjnent would require proof that a stable marieet existed for export coal en spendlnr money for this purpose on

frames at either' P^AtaS

or Thompson's Point.

Jf4*®?1®1 election started 1 ^ WM not completed until August, the results being, Rockhampton, Messrs A. c Anderson, J. E. Elwing, W. H.

J. Kerrigan and A.

Mw»w shire.

w W. R, Humphreys; Shires ?S Livingstone, M. M. MacKellar; eastern group of shires, Messrs C. p. Cop land and R. Staines; western foup of shires, Messrs E. W Archer and A. L. MacDonald.

At the meeting of the board on August 23, Mr E. W. Archer was elected chairman. Mr OTtonohue. Asst. Engineer to the Department of Harbours and Marine, waited on the Board on August 24 to get Its views on the proposal to have coal loading facilities estab lished at either Port Alma or Thompson* Point, as he was about to commence the re quisite survey.

To ameliorate unemployment intermittent relief labour com menced in August on hank protection and extension of Shoal Island wail.

On September 1 the sector light on Grassy Hill was re placed by an unwatched auto matic flashing light

Mr Plson, Engineer to the Department of Harbours

Rivers presented his report on the possibilities of bulk export coal loading at Port Alma and Thompson's Point, on Novem ber S, giving the following

summary:

1. X consider Port Alma more suitable for a coal loading) port than Thompson's Point entirely because of the diffi culty of providing and main taining a suitable channel to the latter locality.

2. Because of the necessity for rapid loading of colliers, it would be desirable to pro -JJ" tor a asperate coal load

8. The cost of such wharf and railway connexions, and two 10-ton. loading travelling cranes would be approximately

£79,660.

4. Storage of coal to enable colliers to be continuously loaded would be met by the provision of parking space and extra supply of hopper wagons. The cost of these extra wag ons might be distributed be tween other adjacent hwuting ports and the Railway Depart ment. Total cost of 200 wag ons to store (approximately 2600 tons would be approxim

ately £37,500

5. The cost of providing stor ®ge to Inns for a similar quan tity would be approximately £46,400. This method Involves extra handling of coal, with increased railway charges.

6. The annual fixed charges for working expenses and in terest cannot be detlrmlned at present. The probable maintenance annually would w® 8 per cent on the capital

expenditure.

Intermittent relief on »»«*? protection and extending Shoal Island wall ended on Decem ber 31, the cost to the board from beginning of the work being £7813, and was met by a loan of £10,000.

RAILWAYS »t.AOTp»

Answering criticism of the. financial position of the board, the chairman (Mr E. w. Arc her) stated In his xe port: "it was ^ forsee the combination of cir cumstances which brought about the disastrous deterior ation of the Qnancial position of the board resulting in its inability to meet its commit ments to the Treasury for re demptfim and Interest on imm^ The circumstances may now be stated as competition by the

railways."

Xii support of this he showed that 1936-30 a five year aver age of general cargo imports was 58,012 tons, tut had drop ped to 34,466 tons or 41 per <*&t in 1833; and that the average revenue for the 1910 14 five- year period was £31,9x1 and had dropped to an average of £21,685 over the 1928-32 five i^ar period, or by 32 per cent.

Owing the year the light at Sea HH1 was changed from watched to automatic, and Its power was increased. It was found daring the year that a Patch had developed at the intersection of Port Alma wharf and Kasatch Point leads, carrying a depth of 21ft at low water. The oil barning lights leading into Rog Creek, Yeppoon, were changed from oil burning to electric during 1933.

Mr A. A. Mawdsley, secret ary to the board for 38 years, resigned from that post in April owing to Ill-health- The* chairman recorded that "his term of service was character ised by splendid ability and tireless zeal." Mr J. j. Jones was appointed to the vacant

post.

The tug El wing, built at Thompson's Point by Barbour Board employees, went into commission during May, in which month Mr E. W. Archer was again elected <-h<.irm.n

The first shipment of drilled beef was shipped on board ie,ft66-ton u. Doric Star at Fort Alma on October & Two farther shipments were made later In the year.

The chairman gave the reasons for the board's inabil ity to meet its full commit ments to the Treasury, all of them beyond the control of the board, as: (1) reduction o*. Shipping traffic during the war; (2> railway competition; (3) vise in operating costs; and (4) falling off in revenue fol lowing successive droughts.

Tills announcement was made during March 1935, when a deputation waited on the Premier and Treasurer. The deputation stated that the board would welcome the ful lest Inquiry into its affairs, and this the Premier- under took would be forthcoming. Later in the year the board received intimation of the ap pointment of a Commission of Enquiry, one result of which .the chairman hoped "would be to assure the future of the port on a more satisfactory basis." At the meeting of the Harbour Board on May 15 Mr E. . W. Archer was elected

chairman.

The total «Mk «t tfca boat*1

to December 31. under toe scheme for relief of unem ployment amounted to £21,100, of which £15,716 was coveted by Government loans and the balance of £5390 was met from revenue. Dredgemaster C. A. Hoffman ended a term n' 10

I years service when he resigned

from the post at the end of 1635. First mate A. A. Tltman was appointed to the vacancy. I The triennial election held

in April 1936 resulted in Messrs A. C. Anderson, W. H. Good son, J. Kerrigan, A. H. Patter son and R. B. Hartley being elected to represent electors of Rockhampton: Mr M. M. Mac KeOar the shires of Fltzroy

land Livingstone; Mr E. J.

O'Brien the shire of Bit Mor gan; Messrs C. P. Copland and W. H .Kettle the eastern, and Messrs E. W. Archer and A. L. MacDonald the western shires.

INQUIRY COMMITTEE

The committee appointed to Investigate the financial pos ition of the Rockhampton and Gladstone harbour boards took evidence in Rockhampton dur ing April, and was also taken on a tour of the port and its facilities.

The Royal Commission on Transport sat in Rock hampton during September, "and here again voluminous evidence was submitted by the board."

Strenuous efforts were made during the year to have Har bour Boards made exempt from sales tax, but without re sult. Because it is a Govern* ment body. Brisbane Harbour Trust is exempt from such im post. The steamer Mareeba having struck some obstacle on the Upper Flats, a survey was made which resulted in discovery of two small - pteM nacles of rock, carrying 12 feet near Lakes Creek* lead.

The Broadmount wharf 15-ton crane was dismantled during the .year and re-erected on Gavial Creek wharf,where "it will enable the bunkering of larger vessels than pre viously, and result in Increased loadings of bunked coal."

The report of the Royal Commission cm Transport was released in August, 1937. "It is satisfactory to note that the report is emphatic that the maintenance of shipping and the necessary ports is indis pensable to the state, and Is of vital concern to our great primary industries." wrote the board chairman (Mr E. W. Archer) in his annual report "It was further held that any Interference with the func tioning of Rockhampton and Port Alma as the ports of Central Queensland is not jus tified; that the present system of Harbour Board, administra tion should be allowed to con tinue, and the debts of the board should be taken into consideration-with a view to a writing down of capital to an amount that would enable them to pay their way in

future."

BOARD OPERATIONS'

Although the Rockhampton Harbour Board had controlled1 port development for 50 years

j to IMS, Its rate of operation* j was not equal throughout that

period. The following shows bow progress has varied j the period:

articleText:
THE PORT OF ROCKHAMPTON: ITS

ORIGIN AND DEVELOPMENT

(Written for the "Herald" by "HbterienO

Owing to the * extremely hard and obstinate nature of the material throughout the Narrows cutting" operations were suspended in May, 1891, and the dredge laid up in Rockhampton. As the dredge could work only when afloat it was impracticable to use her on shoals that dried at half tide.

The Portmaster (T. M. Almond) in his annual report, dated August 26, stated that owing to heavy weather the north channel into Port Curtis had shoaleid badly, as also had Auckland Creek and Calliope Biver. On the other hand, he announced that "the floods of this year have caused no changes of importance in the Fitzroy River." ,

J^IGHTKEEPER E. BISS at

Cape Capricorn had died, and was succeeded by 1st As sistant Jas. Altkcn. Hie Port master also stated that "one small steamer and two or three small craft trade to Y*eppoon," while "no vessels excepting Ashing and pleasure boats have called at Harrisville (Emu Park) for some time." He un questionably meant Hewitt Wile. He stated, too, that only vessels seeking shelter used Port Clinton, but "the wharf is in good order, though no cattle have been shipped from here since 1887." We have not been able to obtain any in formation on this trade.

The Engineer for Harbours and Rivers (Mr A. W. Jar dine') confirmed In his annual teport dated Beptember 4, ttt. continued efficacy of training walls in the Fitzroy River. Crossings which hitherto car ried less than 6 ft now car ried 0 ft 3 in. Mr Jar dine showed that port expenditure commented at "Gladstone in 1861 with a balance of loan of £167, and was continued through a jetty loan for £12,000' in 1881-2, and a ican In 1884-5 to complete the jetty, of £6000. i With sundries, this brought I the port expenditure there to June 30, 1891, to £18,629. Of] a loan of £7000 for deepening the Narrows passed In 1888-9 there remained a balance at the end of June of £2738.

Port Alma wharf was financed by a loan of £25,000 in 1881-2, another of £10,000 in 1882-3, so that with sun dries the total expenditure to the Old of June was £36,869. Votes for Fitsroy River im provements were: Surplus revenue, 1874, £4600; loan, 1876, £20,000; repairs to dredge Bremer in 1876, £1000; 1877. £20,000; 1878, £10,000; loan. 1870 £37.000. There was a 10 years' break to 1888-0 when a loan of £20.000 was made, with none for the two fallowing years. The total expenditure on Fitz roy River improvements to June 30, 1881, as revealed by this report, was, therefore, £112,500.

The Treasurer (Sir Thomas Mcllrcralth) told the Houo-e on October 22 that the width .of dredged channels m the Mary River was 200 ft with the exception of Horseshoe Bend, where it was 150 ft. In the Fitsroy River all channels were dredged to a width of 200 ft .with the exception of No. 2 cutting, k which was 300 ft. *

In October, 1891, the dredge Saurian was laid up along with her plant, and no dredging was done in the remainder of the financial year.

RIVER COLLISION

On the morning of February

16, 1892, the pttnt New Chum1 lay at afcchor with the small steamer Vlissingen alongside, in mid-channel at the Flat Island, anchorage, South Channel. Seeing the anchor of the Vlis singen hanging at her hawse! the pilot of the 2980-ton! steamer Elginshire, presumed her to be under way, and that when he anchored the Elgin shire she would swing clear. She in fact collided with the Vlissingen and New Chum, ami the subsequent enquiry ruled that all three-pilot of Elgin shire, master of Vlissingen and master of the tug Atlanta, which anchored New Chum in mid-stream-to blame,

mulct them in the costs of the enquiry-£2/15/4 each.

In moving the second read ing of the Harbour Boards Bill of 209 clauses on August 23, Sir Thomas Melt wraith said that results of Government development of ports had not been satisfactory:

"I do not know of a more miserable failure than the Bundaberg harbour. . . . the amount uselessly squandered I at Rockhampton, if judici

ously expended might have made a magnificent harbour at that port. . . . And when we come to Mackay we can ' not congratulate ourselves on

the way we have met the difficulties there, because we have not got value for our money. At Townsville we find a harbour which it is difficult for any Government or any local authority to deal with, because It is a harbour with regard to the construc tion of which men connected with the profession will not admit having given any ad

vice."

The Treasurer then outlined the powers it was proposed to confer on harbour boards, and in regard to the Important matter of finance he said:

"The revenue of a harbour board is to consist of the moneys-first from harbour dues, and all other dues which the board may be em powered to levy or receive; secondly, from harbour im provement rates. . . . thirdly, the rents and profits of land vested in the board." The Bill received Royal as sent on November 8.

On September 2 John H. Balllie was appointed pilot at Gladstone, and on the same day s.s. Burwah grounded at the beginning of training wall No. 2, the Portmaster pointing out that no dredging had been done since May, 1890.

The Portmaster, in his annual report dated Sep tember 14, stated: "A con siderable! cattle trade is now being carried on be

tween Gladstone and New Caledonia, the ?teamen Wn| of large tonnage, and aa the trade i* likely to increase additional berthage accommodation will be KfniRd."

He said that it would re quire but little to make the Government wharf a useful and commodious berth for cargo vessels. He said, too, that the pilot launch Enid "is a very old vessel, and requires a thorough overhaul."

At Sea Hill a red sector had been placed in the light to mark the southern edge of Timandra Bank and assist In picking up the anchorage. Cap tain Almond found Broad sound in a state of dilapida tion, the trade of the port be ing confined to the visit of a -email steamer from Rockhamp ton about three times a year. The Customs Department had stripped the iron from the roots of pilot cottages and boatshed, and nothing else was

worth removal.

FORT INQUIRY

On October 7 the Rockhamp ton Chamber of Commerce de cided that a special commit tee of its members be ap pointed to:

. . make a full enquiry as to the relative advan tages of Broadmount,. Port Alma, or any other con venient port, and that the Government be requested to permit their officers to fur nish the committee with any data they may possess,

with the view of obtaining] the requisite information - such committee to submit to the chamber their report in due course"

The committee comprised Messrs A. Bertram, W. Burns, F. Clewitt, MLC, G. 8. Cur tis, Captain East, 6. W. Hart ley, T. Kelly, E. V. Reid, F. H. B. Turner and S. Wil liams.

On November 1 the Treas urer moved for the second reading of the Harbour Dues Bill, which empowered the Government to collect dues at the different ports, and either

| spend them as required or leave

them to accumulate until a harbour board was formed, when the amount in credit would be handed over. He admitted to it being "a gentle sort of squeeae to get local au thorities to undertake the re sponsibility of forming a har bour board." Hie Bill received Royal assent on November 15, but it has not to this day induced anyone in Brisbane to bestir hiipself in establishing a harbour board for that port.

A pair of leading lights on Balaclava Island, the front beacon being 30 ft. and the back beacon being 113 ft. high, was established in 1892. They led past Timandra Bank into Sea Reach.

In a letter to the Chamber of Commerce dated August 8, 1893, the Portmaster said that

for Rockhampton."

Normanton." The

torRaflways said that no com. muoication had been received

the Chamber of Co®. ®®w on the matter.

quesUon Ur

JT*** Boles (Port Curtis) was told on September 7 that the oafr estimate prepared for the ^^hampton-Gladstone rafl! jay was for section 1. extend £** """Isouth from Rock

Be then asked In the As.

*®aW' u *he Government .

^" prepared finmbh t« ' * a raO way to the een ** (BoeUumpton)

km. via Callide coal qIul on the lazul-rrmat -|-*nn The Minister for Railways "*** that theSSS!

PORT OF ROCKHAMPTON

the conditions sought."

I 1893, October 13.

Hie port inquiry of the Chamber of Commerce Com mittee was no perfunctory af fair in that it held 20 meetings, examined senior pilot C. Hajmes; Harbour Master A. E. Sykes and late Harboiir Mas ter M. S. Rundla; Resident Engineer for Harbours and Rivers Department, R. Schmidt; and Lt. Col. Amltage of the Queensland Defence Forces stationed at Rockhamp ton.

RESULTS OF INQUIRY

It also collated official esti mates to enable It to give the following estimates of the cost of Unking Rockhampton with, and providing 1000 feet of wharf at Broadmount, includ ing a railway bridge across the river at Rockhampton :

"This brleT analysis of the pros ud COBS of the two competing rites shows Broadmonnt to be a tidal port, and Port Alma en the contrary to be acces sible at all states of (he tide, and as there are no disadvantages chargeable to the Utter site sufficient to neutralise the great ad vantage of ample water at bll times, your committee unanimously pronounce In favour of Port Alma as the site for a deep water port for the central division."

The report was unanimous ly adopted by both the Chatn 1*r of Commerce and the C-Q Pastoral Employers' Associa tion. and the whole was for rtially presented to the Gov ernment. Despite this, how ever, the Government resolved to make Broadmount the

To comuct Rockhampton with North Roek

estimated in 1887 £88,400 Less savings on estimate as a result of experi

and rail 72,000

The committee actually dealt with four sites for a deep water port for Rockhampton: Sroadmount, Bluff Harbour or Mulambin, Emu Point or Emu Park and Port Alma, little of the evidence favoured Emu Park, but that of Lt.-Col. A.r rnltage strongly favoured Bluff Harbour or Mulambin. He said that estimates given him by contractors and engineers placed the cost of enclosing a deep water port there at £60, 000. It was stated at the in quiry into the deepwater port' question that in October 500 bales of wool were loaded on Port Alma wharf for ship ment on BIJ3.N. Coy's, steam er Tara, the master of which refused to allow his vessel to be placed alongside.

After this exhaustive exam ination of all available date, much of it contained in official reports, the committee pre sented its report on October 13 which embodied the following 'main conclusion:

i ceepwater port, and went

:thead -with its preparations.

RIVER WRECK

The 404-ton steamer Woono- na. drawing 13 ft. 10 in. stranded

near Central Island while on her way up the Fltzroy River on October 13. She floated off on the next tide but stranded again on the Second Flats at 0.7 a.m. on the 13th. In the attempt to refloat her the engines were used without avail, and at 7 next morning the vessel broke in two and became a total wreck. The inquiry at Rock- hampton censured the master for using his engines as he did, and ordered him to pay costs of the inquiry, but the Marine Board reversed the de- cision and ordered a remis- sion of the fine.

Mr A. A. Mawdsley arrived in Rockhampton on July £, 1694, and was temporjtrily em ployed at the Post CAlce.

Mr Harding was Informed in the Assembly on July 15 that

the nutter of an early r»- I sumption of the partly-con-- j pleted survey of the Olp.d stone - Rockhampton railway was receiving the considera tion of the Government.

The Portmnster reported on July 2« that since the dis continuance of dredging Fitr, roy River depth changed little until the floods in the earl?

I part of the year, and even

jtfcen the port "suffered less

than the ports further south

j'TTie least water was at Cen

tral Island, with 6 ft 6 in. in the natural channel and 4 ft.

[ 6 In. in the dredged channel" | Ht reported Port Alma wharf

in good order, "but is very

j rarely used," though telegraph I ic communication had been

j ^-established; and also th*f

"supervision of the port of St Lawrence devolves now upon the Harbour Mafter at Roch hampton."

BEGINNING of BOARDS

It was resolved lp the As sembly on November 28 that bills be introduced to consti tute harbour boards at Bris bane, Rockhampton and Townsville. The bills were read a ftrst time, but proceeded no

farther during the 1894 set,-' p-on. One of the provisions pf the proposed Harbour Boards Act was the appointment,

a port where it had been the declared intention of the resi dents to form a Harbour

Board, of a Harbour Ttust Board of Advice. One such v.-as appointed at Rockhamplor, and it was advised by the Treasurer of November 30 that the Government would p/ace under the control of the board "the boats, barges, etc.. belonging to the dredge service already at Rockhampton."

The Treasury advised cm March 29 that the Railway Commissioners had agreed to the Harbour Trust Board ot Advice having the we of the two rooms in the railway building, formerly occupied by thr Harbour and Rivera De lmrtment while established at Rockhampton. heading: THE PORT OF ROCKHAMPTON: ITS ORIGIN AND DEVELOPMENT
snippet: Owing to the "extremely hard and obstinate nature of the material throughout the Narrows cutting" operations were suspended in May, 1891, and the dredge laid up in Rockhampton. As the dredge could work only when afloat it was impracticable to use her on shoals that dried at half tide.

articleText:
THE PORT OF ROCKHAMPTON: ITS " i ORIGIN AND DEVELOPMENT

(Written for the "Heraid" by "Hlstoiica*.")

Whether the Gladstone-Rockhampton line should follow in the main the road between these places, with a branch line for Port Alma, or whether it should follow the south bank of the Fitzroy to Port Alma and link up with the road in the vicinty of Raglan was a contentious issue during 1895.

On August 23 the Railway Commissioner (J. 1 Mathieson) estimated that the cost of the latter project would be £300,577, much of the line being across coun try subject to flooding; and that of the former would be £281,220, the line in each case joining the road in the vicinty of Eaglan. ;

He quoted the views of H. C. Stanley, Chief Engineer of Railways, who said:

"There can be little doubt that, viewed as a matter of railway policy, the Broad mount scheme is likely to prove by far the most satis factory, both as regards econ omy. of construction and maintenance, distance to travel, prospective traZic, and convenience for working."

He then quoted the report of the Portmaster (Capt. Almond) to the Rockhampton Chamber of Commerce on the 8th in stant, in regard to the ship ping facilities offered by the port of Broadmount.

The Superintendent ot

Dredging Plant, Brisbane, ad-1 vised that on August 24 the dredge 8aurian, in tow of s.s. Reliance, left for Rockhamp ton. He added that "all the machinery and inside of hull was thoroughly overhauled and put in good condition in No vember, 1891. The dredge hav ing done no work since, no re pairs to hull or machinery were necessary." The Portmaster advised on September 17 that, except when making a sea voyage, it was not the practice of the department to insure the dredge plant, "as experi ence proves that with ordinary care very little damage need be apprehended."

Visitors from Rockhampton inspeillnc extensions to Fort AI ma wharf. The extensions became necessary after the rail

connexion was made tinder the control of the Harbour Board.

The Commissioner for Rail ways on September 24 forward ed to the Minister for Railways the plan and book of reference or the proposed Nankin-Her bert (Broadmount) line. He estimated the cost of the line to be £47,500 and of "wharf, sidings and approaches" £25,000 or £72,500 in all. He said that the wharf at Port Alma could be removed to Broadmount, but "as an alter native an entirely new wharf can be constructed." He con cluded :

"The necessity for a deep water port for Rockhampton

has long been, seen, and in view of the very marked in crease in the traffic on the Central railway, chiefly in produce intended for export, there is no doubt that the proposed branch and wharf age accommodation will prove highly remunerative to the department, as well as bene ficial to the public of Cen tral Queensland; in fact, it is estimated that the traffic from Lakes Creek works alone will be sufficient to cover working expenses and the interest on capital."

On October** the Town Clerk (Mr Wm. Davis) wired the Premier for permission to use a clam dredge lying idle at Rockhampton to clean up in front of the Municipal Coun cil's wharves. The message was referred to the Harbour Trust Board of Advice.

BROADMOUNT HARBOUR Assistant Engineer Gilbert F. Elliott made an inspection "of the approaches from Bea Reach to Broadmount Har bour," via the Soutn Channel In his teport dated October 2 he disposed of all channels but the one through the South Channel and round Egg Sand, to negotiate which he proposed cutting back a bell-mouth linked with a dredged cutting past Rocky Point He also proposed a cutting 10,500 leet

.long at the outer end of Car digan lead, which would be dredged to 17 It nt low water. Mr. Elliott also shewed the tentative position of Broad mount wharf, as fixed by the Chief Engineer for Railways. On the following day the Port master forwarded the report to the Treasurer, with the re commendation, "I am of opinion that the Chief Engin eer for Railways has selected a most suitable position for the proposed wharf, and that Broadmount Harbour offers more .advantages than any other place for a deep-water port for the Rockhampton dis trict." His report, issued on October 2, approved of El liot's plan for dealing with Egg Sand and the outer ednd of Cardigan cut. On Novem ber 13 Henry Foster began a seven year term as pilot, Rock hampton.

The Portmaster reported in October that "to obtain 17 ft through the South Channel which was then considered to be the only practicable ap Iproach to Broadmount-would

Involve the removal of oOO.OOO cubic yards of sand and mud."

The Rockhampton Chamber of Commerce appointed a sub committee "for the purpose of assisting in making the Bill for the Rockhampton harbour as perfect and complete as possible." its member* were

A. Bertram (chairman) and Messrs. W. Burns, T. Kelly, E. V. Reid and F. H. B. Turner, and on November 22 issued its circular to members repre senting the Central District. It opposed making the Mayor an ex officio member of- the Harbour Board, on the grounds that he had enough to do where he was; that «he Act should ensure there being on the board a "properly ac credited representative of a limited liability company, as sociation or firm"; the Har bour Board must be exempted from payment of local author ity rates; that the parade ground and rifle range at North Rockhampton, the ex plosives reserve and building, and the whole of the river frontage from Fitzroy bridge to Gavlal Creek be vested In the Harbour Board; that wharves erected or about to be erected within the Har bour Board area be vested in the board on payment of com pensation as determined by arbitration; the quarry opened at Thompson's Point (then Dead Man's Flat) by the Har bours and Rivers Department, the wharf area at Broadmount and the Quay Street Office site be all vested In the Har bour Board.

Hie circular reached Bris bane soon after the Rock hampton Harbour Board Bill had passed the third reading and had been sent to the Legislative Council. W. H. Corfleld, MLA (Gregory) wrote on November % openiy deprecating interfering with the Bill at that stage lest it

December 23, and vested In the board the areas "for the time being comprised within the boundaries of the city of Rock hampton, the towns of Black* all, Clermont and Ml Morgan, and the shires of Aramac, Banana, Barcaldlne, Barcoo, Bauhlnia, Belyando, Calllungal, Diamantlna, Duaringa, Emer ald, Fltzroy, Hfracombe, Isis ford, Jericho, Kargoolnah, Liv ingstone, Longreach, Peak Downs and Tambo, as consti tuted under and for the par poses of the Local Authorities Act." It was enacted that the board would comprise 11 elect ed members, of which:

(a) Five would be elected by.

Rockhampton electors; (b) one by Mt Morgan;

(c) one by the electors of the

shires of Fltzroy and Ii7 lngstone;

(d) two by aldermen -of the

town o£ Clermont, and the councillors of the shires of Banana, Bauhlnia, Bel" yando, Calllungal, Duar inga, Emerald and Peak Downs;

(e) two by aldermen of the

town of Blackall and the councillors of the shim of Aramac, Barcaldlne, Bar coo, Dlamanttna, Ilfra combe, Zsisford, Jericho, Kargoolnah, Longreach and

Tambo.

The following are the area, population and valuation of the district that, with the passing of the Act, came under the aegis of the newly-formed Har | hour Board:

"become one of the slaugh tered Innocents."

HARBOUR BOARD ACT

Hie Rockhampton Harbour Board Act, 1895 was passed on

Stock estimates for 1895 snow that Central Queensland, main ly within the Harbour Board area, had 3,436,720 sheep,

928.890 cattle, 105,761 horses and,

9420 pigs. (Continued .Pase It) '
heading: THE PORT OF ROCKHAMPTON: ITS ORIGIN AND DEVELOPMENT
snippet: Whether the Gladstone-Rockhampton line should follow in the main the road between these places, with a branch line for Port Alma, or whether it should follow the south bank of the Fitzroy to Port Alma and link up with the road in the vicinty of Raglan was a contentious issue during 1895.
