articleText:
THE PORT OF ROCKHA M PTON: ITS

ORIGIN AND DEVELOPMENT

(Written for the "Herald" by "Historical.")

At tiie end of the debate on the second reading of the Transcontinental Railway Bill on July 5 the Assembly divided, and the motion was lost by 27 votes to 17, whereupon the Premier (Mr Thos. McIIwraith) tendered his resignation to the Governor. His passing pro (oudly influenced major railway construction, and this in turn was soon reflected in the port history of Rockhampton. - The fall of «thellwraith Ministry was announced on November 13, but its commitments in regard to Port Alma remained.

The Griffith Ministry met on January 10, 1884, and 12 days later a Bill to repeal the Railway Companies Preliminary Act of 1882 passed its first reading'in the Legislative Council, and within two weeks the whole elaborate structure of Mcllwraitb's ambitious Soma. Gulf railway was a tumbled ruin.

rjiyus Bulletin" reported on

August 14 that work on Port Alma wharf was "pro ceeding rapidly under Mr Burn's direction," about 400 feet of decking had been laid and erection of sheds had been commenced." It was reported on August 19 that arrange ments for lighting shipping Into Port Alma and the river included erection of two cot tages on Balaclava Island. The contractor was John Burton.

The "Bulletin" of September 17 recorded the need for some form of medical supervision in Keppel Bay "if the proclama tion for the """"^nation of all passengers from southern ports Is to be carried out in its entirety." It stated that ships were boarded by men from the pilot boat, from the Gladstone cutter, and from the Customs craft, and passengers from southern ports were not pre vented from mingling with the passengers from British India steamers, if they were in Port Alma, and with those on the northern coasting steamers.

Frank Grosvenor was ap pointed pilot at Gladstone on October 24.

WHARVES COMPLETED

Hie engineer for Harbours and Rivers reported on Octob er 31 that Port Alma wharves had been satisfactorily com pleted and taken over by the Government in September. He said that "every credit is due to the contractors, Messrs Burns and Twifeg, for the manner in which they have carried out their contract, con sidering the difficulties they have had to encounter."

The whan was 600 feet long by 63 feet wide and had a cargo shed running the full length. It contained 186 iron screw piles bottomed in an average of 16 ft 6 In. of strong blue marine clay and had a safe load of 10,000 tons. Its cost was £36,869, and although it was not connected with the shore, appears to have been leased to the British India and Queensland SJ3. Company, no doubt for storage purposes, when there was a shortage of lighters. The report stated that the Duke of Westminster, which was the longest vessel of the .British India line to visit Queensland, was one of the first to use the wharf.

In reply to a question the Premier (Mr Griffith) told the House that he had received a letter from Lord Denbigh, chairman of the Australian Transcontinental Railway Syn dicate, suggesting that the Government should indemnify them against the expenses oc curred by the company in

connexion, with their proposal to construct a railway to the Gulf of Carpentaria. Mr Grif fith stated 'that he had de clined to entertain the claim.

It was stated in the annual report of the engineer for Har bours and Rivers dated Octob er 31, that a design and esti mate had been prepared for a Jetty at Beachton, near Sea Hill lighthouse, *'but the ex pense was considered too great, and the plans are being re vised with a view to the con struction of a jetty of a lighter character and into a less depth of water than at first pro posed."

Sir John Coode gave a sketchy outline of the trade of the port from 1861 to 1885:

Imports

tons

1861 15,144

1866 48,683 ' 1871 54,938 1876 121,791 1884 369,683 1885 243,322

On September 7 H. M. Cock burn was appointed Harbour Master at Gladstone.

Sir John Coode arrived In Keppel Bay on board s^. Gee long on November 22, prior to which the Treasurer, .in re sponse to a request from Mr Ferguson M.L.A. that Sir John be asked to report on the, pos sible advantage Of Humming the river at the rocks at the foot of Albert St, telegraphed that he had directed Sir John's attentions to ttie rocks "to ob tain his opinion as to improv ing the navigation of the river by their removal. He is not a waterworks engineer. ST, how ever, you wish to consult him on the matter of water storage you can interview him in Rockhampton."

AGAINST RIVER DAM

Sir John Coode arrived in Rockhampton on November 23, and after inspecting the rocks, left with Mr Nisbet on an in spection of the river works, re turning to town at 9 pjn. He left about midnight to take ship at Port Alma for Mackay, Townsville and Norman ton. He was then to leave for London by the Quetta which he would join at Thursday Island.

' Before leaving town Sir John said he was clearly of opinion that if the river were dammed at the rocks the result would be that in the years to come, not perhaps immediately, a long stretch of water opposite the town and for a consider able' distance below it would become gradually silted up. The effect would be that navi gation would be stopped to that distance up the river. He said that during periods of

protracted drought and conse quently less down-river current than in full seasons, the pro cess would be accelerated. If on the other hand, the rocks could be removed out of the bed of the river so as to make the current steady and even, the tendency would be to deepen the river and improve navigation.

"If the rocks are to be meddled with at all I sug gest that they be removed, as it would improve navi gation by assisting in the formation of a deep chan nel in the Town Reach."

River depth improvements m the 10 years to 1885 are shown hereunder:

1874 1885 Upper Fiats,

Section 1 .. .. 3ft 5i*t j

Upper Flats,

Section 2 . .. 4ft 6ft Second Flats,

Section 3 . .. 6ft 8ft

Exports Total '

tons tons 14,623 29,767 48,860 97,543 55,137 110,075

422,742 686,064

This shows an improvement of rattier better than 2 ft and considering the scorn that was poured over the hapless dredge Bremer, was no mean achieve

ment.

Two pairs of leading lights were established in Keppel Bay in 1885, one being south of Eupatoria Point and led across Keppel Bay through Sea i Reach. The other pair was on Cardigan Point, Balaclava Is land which led into the river and up to Rocky Point Reach. The front beacon carrying the lights of both pairs of leads were 25 ft high, and the back ones 53 ft high.

Kenneth R. Kerr started service as pilot, port of Rocfc hampton, on August 1. He re tained the post for six years, and on the same day John Forrest was appointed pilot at

Gladstone.

On September 3 xir Brown

(Townsville) moved in the As sembly that "in the opinion of this House, the time has ar rived when the ports and har bours of the colony should be placed under the control and management of local boards, to be called 'local trustees'." He said that under a central authority port facilities were not carried out to keep pace with the development of the district, which was in turn often hampered through lack of these elementary necessi

ties.

The Premier (Mr Griffith) said that he had every sym pathy for the motion as an ab stract question-something to be brought about when ports had in sight sufficient trade to

enable them to meet interest on their capital commitments. At hie suggestion the House al armed the abstract principle, but did not commit Itself to do more than keep an eye on de velopments. This was the first stage of the Harbour Boards

Act.

Two lights were established

1 in Keppel Bay during 1886, one I being on Grassy Hill Point | near the Pilot Station, screen*

led to indicate Keppel Rocks

| and Tlmandra Bank. The other

was on the summit of 8ea Hill 120 ft. above high water, with a visibility of 17 miles, screen ed to lead vessels Into Sea Hill anchorage. John Lees was ap pointed pilot at Gladstone on August 5, 1887. Stephen Wil kinson entered the pilot ser vice, Rockhampton, on July 7, 1888. He served in that capac ity for 19 years.

The Premier (Mr Griffith) agreed on August 12, 1888, that he would lay on the table of the House papers relating to the Transcontinental Railway Syndicate-known as the Kim ber agreement-and also any further documents that came to hand. The Minister for Railways (Mr H. M. Nelson) told Mr Murphy (Barcoo) on October 19, that a trial survey had been made for a railroad "from some point on the Cen tral Railway to Port Alma," and that the matter' of In cluding construction of the line in the government's pro gramme was then under con

sideration.

Sir John Coode's report on the port of Rockhampton, dated October 31, endorsed to the main the recommendations of Mr Nisbet, and recommend ed closing the passages be tween Casuarina, Mosquito and Sandfly Islands. He also sug gested "for the more ready dls" charge of flood waters" that the rocks at the foot of Albert street be cut Sown to low water level, and considered that it could be done for £2200.

PIRATE POINT CHANNEL

He considered that with the development of trade and ap pearance of longer vessels It might be "considered desirable to straighten the channel at Pirate Point" This would re duce the length of the river by four miles, lower the average low water level by six Inches and increase the tidal sange by a lite amount.

Speaking in the Legislative Assembly on November 2, the Premier said he deeply regretted that ". . . the public efilrit of the Central district is not up to the position of advocating the line from Rockhampton to Port Alma. I do believe that the making of that railway would be the making of the Central district and of Rock hampton itself . . . Somehow the people there are opposed

(Continued on Page 16.)

PORT OF ROCKHAITON

. m .

(Continued from Page 3)

to it. They stand in their own light. Had I found any incli nation towards it X would have put it in the list; but I saw nothing of the kind, and 1 have no wish to shove the rail way down their throats."

Richard Schmidt arrived in Rockhampton during Novem ber 1888 to take up the duties there as Resident Engineer. Harbours and Rivers Depart

ment.

On March 7 Henry Nichols was appointed pilot at Glad stone. In reply a question in the Assembly on May 30, the Secretary for Railways stated that instructions had been giv en for "a survey of the exten sion of the present line of railway from Rockhampton to the deep water wharves at Port Alma."

On June 13 Mr Murray, M.LA., presented a petition from 'certain freeholders, merchants and tradesmen on the electoral roll of Rock hampton, urging reasons for the construction of a railway from Rockhampton to the deepwater port of Port Alma, and praying relief in the pre mises." After the petition had been read by the clerk it was formally received by the House. Hie petition carried 1280 sig

natures.

Mr Archer tiLA., presented

a petition r^july 16 from

"certain ,ts of the muni cipality khampton and

the borow^jf North Rock hampton, praying the House

| to refuse its consent to the

construction of a line of rail way from Rockhampton to Port Alma." The petition, which carried 1485 signatures, was formally received.

On the motion for ad journment on August 1, Mr Murphy (Barooo), brought up the matter of the Rockhampton petition* regarding Port Alma. This brought from Mr ff, Pat Uaon (Treasurer) the statement that It was not the intention of the Gov ernment to construct this line "until the representa tives of Rockhampton urge the matter on the consid eration of the Govern ment."

He added that "it is well known that members for Rockhampton are pledged against the construction of the Port Alma railway. .. . This is how we hold our seats.... We found that two-thirds of the people of Rockhampton op posed it, and we cannot say that we are willing to force our opinion on people who are un willing to receive it."

The Minister for Railways told Mr Archer that it was the Intention of the Government, on competition of the Rock hampton-Port Alma railway survey, to proceed with the survey of the line from Port Alma to Gladstone. On her re turn , from Brisbane In mid September where she under went overhaul the dredge Sau rian went to work at Brown's Crossing.

In his annual report, dated September, 1880, Mr W. D. Nis bet stated that a special clam dredge was under construction at Rockhampton "for deepen ing the Narrows." He said that the cost of the punt would be £700 and that of the machin

ery £1350. Of progress on the Fit»oy .Mr NUbet stated that the dredge Saurian had re-cut Brown's Crossing, to 10 ft, dykes and training walls "in accordance with plans suggest ed by Mr Jardine" (his de puty) had been constructed at Archer's Crossing. The last named carried 7 ft., the shal lowest part of the river.

The Portmoster (Command er O. P. Heath R-N.) reported a boating fatality during the year) at Bustard Head, when of three lives lost only two bodies were recovered. He reported also the establish ment of two small red lights to lead Into Auckland Creek. Gladstone, and also that the only seaworthy portions of the pilot schooner were her bottom, masts, and gear. He reiterated the need for a roomier light ship at the Upper Flats, and a more seaworthy one tor Tlm andra Bank. Minor Improve ments were carried out during the year to the secondary lights at Cape Capricorn. His report was dated September 10.

On October 9 the Minister for Works (Mr Macrossani asked leave to Introduce a Bill "for the better regulation, management and improvement of harbours." He said v that considerable Information had been obtained from harbour boards in New Zealand and Melbourne, but stated that it was not the intention of the Government to proceed further with the Bill than to place it in the hands of members for their consideration during re cess. The motion was carried.

CLAM DBEDGE AT

WORK

The clam dredge built at Rockhampton started dredging the Narrows on January 16, 1890. Contrary to common be lief, the bottom was of "rotten clay slate beneath a layer of clay, shells and shingle, at a depth of 2 ft. 6 in. below low water." The 232-ton steam er Taldora collided with the 60 ton schooner Grace Darling in Kgtfpel Bay on ,June 4. It was revealed at the Inquiry that it was impossible to see ahead of the Taldora from her navigat ing bridge, a fact which exon erated the master (Alex Brand) and shifted the blame to the owners of the Taldora. But he was censured for not ascertaining if the Grace Darl ing was In need of assistance in consequence of the collision.

By June 30 the clam dredge at work in the Narrows had lifted 3369 cubic yards of ma terial. Tenders were called for repairs to the St Lawrence wharf, but the Engineer for Harbours and Rivers reported in June they were all too high; the work was undertaken by day labour.

In his annual report dated August 25 Mr Nisbet said that work in the Fltzroy River was going forward as planned, with less damage than he had an ticipated from the heavy floods of March. He showed the difference In the cubic yards of spoil to be lifted from the river to get a depth of 12 ft. at low water In 1876 and 1890 to be:

1676 18S0

Upper Flati, No. 1 331,561 38,261 Upper FUts No. 3 148,483 14.774 Archer'* Crossing .. 79,430 nil

Second Flati 120,881 78,908 Brown's crossing .. fts,970 nil

Central Island .. . 61,663 40,100

Total 693,668 173,044

being an improvement of 720, 624 cubic yards. -

Edward T. Curtis was ap pointed Harbour Master at Gladstone on October 17, and Henry Maxwell was appointed pilot there on October 31.

Mr Palmer (Carpentaria) moved that "a transcontinen tal railway, commencing at the port of Normanton and junctioning with the Northern. Central and Southern main main lines at their western termini, should be initiated and adopted as a luture system of construction for western railways." It was practically the land grant railway in re verse and the motion was given a good airing, at the end of which the mover said he had no desire to embarrass the Govern merit and 60 would not press the matter to a division, "though I have been pressed by urgent telegram to do so," and so the motion was with drawn.

The plans of the three miles 47 chains of railway to con nect Rockhampton with the Emu Jark line were forw arded on December 31, 1899. The es timated cost-Including Alex andra Bridge-was £47,920.

Waterfront personnel at the end of 1890 were: Rockhamp ton and Keppel Bay, A. E. Sykes, Harbour Master and pilot; pilots C. Haynes, K. R. Kerr, A. Roberts and 8. Wil kinson; Lightships, Timln dra Bank. J. W. Harper, master; Upper Flats, G. F. O. Stevens, master; Balaclave Island leads, R. Graham, lightkeeper, Port Alma, J. Boden, Brown's Cross ing, C. Llnter, lightkeeper; Lighthouses, Sea Hill, J. Aird, Cape Capricorn, E. Biss. Port Curtis: Harbour Master, E. T. Curtis, pilot H. Nicholas: LlghtUeepers, Bustard Head, T. Rooksby, Gatcombe Head, J.

Sudhofl.

(To be continued)
heading: THE PORT OF ROCKHAMPTON: ITS ORIGIN AND DEVELOPMENT
snippet: At the end of the debate on the second reading of the Transcontinental Railway Bill on July 5 the Assembly divided, and the motion was lost by 27 votes to 17, whereupon the Premier (Mr Thos. McIIwraith) tendered his resignation to the Governor. His passing profoudly influenced major railway construction, and this in turn was soon reflected in the port

articleText:
THE PORT OF ROCKHAMPTON: ITS , ORIGIN AND DEVELOPMENT

, ? ?

(Written for the "Herald" by "Histoiicns")

The " Bulletin " of February 20, 1878, announced that work on the Upper; flats training wall was suspended owing to flooding of the river, Kearney, the contractor, being unable to cart stone. " A new high level wharf is being built by Mr Carroll, and on its completion interference by floods will be materially lessened." :

On Monday, February 25, workmen on the new quarantine buildings on Mackenzie Island were driven from work by the hordes of mosquitoes and sandflies. The "Bulletin" of the 28th stated: "The men have come to town, and declare that the pests are unendurable, that they worked eight hours per day for pay, and the other 16 to protect their skins from the pests. Three kitchens were completed, and the blocks for the main

I building: were in."

?jrHE "Bulletin" reported that

on April 13 the Inward bound barque Scottish Knight berthed at the town wharf, her

I appearance round the bend

into the Town Reach being hailed by a round of sis guns which were fired from the bar* cue Scottish He/o lying at the municipal wharf. These must be among the earliest regular traders direct between London and Rockhampton wharves.

The state of the Upper Flats and inactivity of the dreage caused complaints to be dir ected against ths Government, when it was found that the cost per ton of lifting soil by the old dredge (Bremer) was too heavy. But the explana tion'did not satisfy the "Bul letin", which retorted that "Two months work by-even the Bremer would greatly Improve the river for maybe a year and the expense thus incurred wotfld be small considering the advantage that would ensue. Seeing that our customs re ceipts and harbour dues are increasing very rapidly lust

now, the mercantile public

have a right to expect the Government to facilitate pas sage over the Flats."

Construction gangs at work on the jetty at Port Alma in 1884.

The barque Scottish Hero was farewelled by a salvo of guns as she was towed from the town wharves to Central Island anchorage on May 2. She would top off her final loading there.

It was reported by the Bul letin of May 21 that much of the scrub felling on Macken zie Island had been completed over about 640 acres. Some of the work was done by kanakas. It was stated that the soil on the island was very prolific." and from its situation and natural advantages this island may yet be used as a watering place to Rockh&mpton."

The punt Kennedy was launched 'from the Bridge Works, on the north side" on May 30, her dimensions being 36 ft x 15 ft 8in. x 4 ft. The "Bulletin" surmised that she was "one of the punts which are to be' used as a floating stage in sinking the piers of the bridge."

DEEPER CHANNELS

The report of the Engineer'

for Harbours and Rivers dated June 30 stated that of the total of 12,330 lineal feet of the Upper Flats training wall 5350 feet had been completed, and a considerable amount of work had been done beyond that length.

Mr Nesbit wrote: "There is no doubt thafc as the work pro gresses, the sandbanks are moved lower down, and the channel abreast the completed portion of wall is now consid erably deeper than at any previous period."

Changes taking place in the flats across the Upper Flats, due to the effects of the training wall, were such that the "Bulletin" of July 18 notified that the two upper buoys had been shifted, and by following instructions an increased depth of from 4 to 6 in. was obtainable.

"We have full confidence in the ultimate success of Mr Nesblt's scheme for removing the shallows by equalising the breadth of the channel" said the "Bulletin", "and we ask chose who do not share our faith to suspend judgement until the work of improvement has progressed sufficiently to

place the issue beyond doubt." Apparently there were whis pers in those days, too.

It was announced on July 31

that Kearney, the contractor, for supplying the stone for the Upper Flats training wall, had finished his contract. t)unng the time he operated his men removal 25,000 tons of stone from Lake's Creek quarry.

A stir was caused on the waterfront on August IT

when ii became known !

that the Harbour Master (Captain Roadie) had is sued a summons against the Municipal Council for "causing the removal from one wharf to another of s vessel without the know ledge and/or concurrence of the Harbour Master."

The fact was that the coun cil controlled the wharf ana the Harbour Master all matters of pilotage. His case attracted a good gallerj when it was called on August 20. when the PM ruled that either the wharfinger or the

Town Clerk, and not the Mnuiclpal Council, should have been summoned, In which case the Harbour Master would have scored a win.

Writing In an indulgent mood, the " Bulletin" of Au gust 24 noted that " the Glad - stone people, under the guid ance of their Progress Associa tion, are making prodigious efforts to induce Parliament

to ' authorise the immediate

extension of the Great Central Trunk Railway to 'its natural shipping port' on the shores of Port Curtis, and we com mend them for their pluck and perseverance. But we are sorry that they entertain such a poor opinion of the noble Fitzroy and its unlimited cap acity for improvement. How ever, we suppose that Rock hampton and Gladstone must agree to differ on this delicate issue. Meanwhile, the miser able river, notwithstanding Its huge sandbanks, will carry the trade and the country will be satisfied."

GLADSTONE PETITIONS

There was a variation in the 1878 petition from Gladstone either to stop all work on the Fitzroy and so prevent the development of Rockhampton, or to build a railway from Gladstone to Rockhampton and so obtain her trade. One on the latter theme was pre sented to the House on August 27 by Mr Foote (West More ton),-who moved that the pet ition be read. The Clerk had read portion of it when the

Speaker called attention to the singular fact that the petition had not been signed. This caused a stir in the House, es - pecially as Mr Foote was un able to account for having the petition, and for not bringing it under notice of the member for Port Curtis (Mr Palmer). Mr O'Sullivan characterised it as "the most disgraceful thing he had seen in the House for a long time."

On September 6 Mr Palmer presented a petition " signed by 410 of the residents of the; Port Curtis electorate " praying for a line of railway from Gladstone to Rockhampton. Mr Palmer said that the pur pose of the petition was " pretty well known to the House" and went on to clear up some of the irregularity In regard to presentation of the unsigned one. It seems that the cohimittee arranging the petition, noted from n speecn in the House, that Mr Foote had views that " tended to the same' as our movementso

they sent him a copy of the petition. " which is now being circulated for signature". It clarified Mr Foote's action without justifying It.

It was announced In the " Bulletin" of September 11, that a contract had been let for a new set of buckets for the dredge Bremer, " which is expected to begin dredging early in January, to assist la clearing out the channel being formed at the Upper Flats by the training walls in course of construction."

The " Bulletin" stated on September 17 that a set ot mooring piles or dolphins had been driven immediately below Upper Flats, " at which vessels coming up the river can moor, in sight of the tide signals and so be ready to move on as soon as the water was shown to be sufficient."

The dredge Bremer had started work at the Upper Flats, reported the " Bulletin * of March 3, 1879. It also ut tered a note of warning, in that during the progress ol the work it would be advisablfl for even experienced masters or ships to take a pilot across the Flats, so as to get full advantage of the depths, and on the other hand, "avoid the frequent and vexatious In terruptions to trade by ground ings on the Flats."

Mr Norton (Port Curtis) presented a petition from ?21 residents of the Central Dis trict "praying that the House would take'into consideration the advisability of an exten sion of the Central line from

Gladstone to Roclfbaznptoa, and in the meantime that an lands adjacent to the survey of the line be reserved from sale or selection.*' The petition was

received.

MOVE TO STOP RIVER

WORK

On June 12 Mr Norton moved in the Assembly "that, in the opinion of this House, the works now under construc tion in the Fitzroy River should be suspended." His first reason was that it seemed im possible to estimate the cost of ; the finished work, and his sec ond was "that there is already a magnificlent harbour at Fort <?urt!s. .and the country be tween Rockhampton and Fort Curtis was eminently suited .for the construction of a low cost railway."

To buttress his case Mr Nor

I ton instanced a string of ships

that met disaster on the Fitz roy, one being the P20 ton s.s. Florence Irvmp ""wrecked or» entering Keppel Bay," whereat

(Continued on Page 16.)

PORT OF ROCKHAMPTON

(Continued from Page 3)

she really met her end when ente.1ng Port Stephens on De cembtr 4, 1877; and another, the ship Scottish Knight "which stranded on leaving Keppel Bay," though he prob ably , meant Scottish Bard which stranded on Swain Reefs about 100 miles east of Cape Capricorn on the day fol lowing her departure from Keppel Bay. Mr Norton said that that which had operated against the construction of the line:

"... *u almost entirely owing to the systematic opposi tion of the town of Rocfchamp ton; It had 7000 inhabitants, ana from them alone had the opposi tion come. He did not ponder at it, because holders of land there were naturally under the impression that if the Gladstone line were, constructed the value of Rockhampton property would be considerably diminished."

The Premier (Mr Mcll wraith) said that there was not the slightest doubt that the House had decided to carry on the Improvements now being made in the Fitzroy; and be fore they reversed thu decis ion they should be able to see the result of the experiment. The motion was withdrawn. It

was announced on July 30 that j £37,000 had been included in j

the estimates for the Fitzroy River, "besides its share of dredge plant."

An echo from over 76 years reached the Assembly on Aug ust 22, when Mr T. F. Swan wich (Bulimba) presented a petition "from the female rela tives of the late illustrious navigator, Captain Matthew Flinders, praying that their situation may be taken into account by the Government and such relief afforded as may seem due." The petition was received.

Mr Norton again introduced to the House on September 18 the matter of the Glads tone Rockhampton railway, which he said was the more import ant from the fact of the House having decided recently to carry the Central Railway 130 miles inland. This, he con tended, made even more nec essary that a really good and accessible port should be avail able for the residents who sent goods backwards and for wards." He contended that "the excellence of the harbour of Port Curtis was known to all, and the inferiority of the Fitzroy River as a harbour was equally well known."

He moved formally that £200,000 be placed upon the supplementary estimates lor the construction of the Glad stone-Rockhampton railway.

It was argued in reply that Mr Norton had not advanced any reasons beyond those which he had adduced on a previous occasion, and they had all been conclusively dis proved. On the advice of the Premier (Mr Mcllwraith), the motion was withdrawn.

On the same day Mr Paterson (Rockhampton) moved for £4500 to be placed on the supplement ary estimates for a Mai survey of a railway line from Westwood - to Miles, a distance of nearly 200 miles.

He . gave as his reason that such a line would place Cen tral Queensland in close touch with large supplies of fruit and vegetables and flour, in stead of Imparting much of these commodities from south

ern States. 6uoh a line, pass

tag through the Dawson Valley and connecting two areas of considerable population would have written a different his tory for the State, but it was defeated by 15 votes to 14 on going to a division.

Ships visiting the port dur ing 1870 were: 600-ton s.s. Alexandra (Hill); 40-ton s.s. Burnett (Watson); 202-ton sch. Colleen Dhas (Elliott) j 266-ton sjs. Edina (South); 456-ton s.5. Egmont (mil); 496-ton. 85. Elamang (M'Lean); 80-ton sch. Freddy (Dwyer); 331-ton ss. Governor Blackall (Nightingall); Ketch Hoolett; 490-ton StS. Keilawarra (South); 53-ton sch. Morning Light (Fenwick); 24-ton ketch Rein deer / (Brown); 266-ton s.s. Tinonee (Williams); 303-ton s.s. Yaralla (Edwards); 77-ton si. Vyking (Brown); 457 ton SJ5. You Yangs (Harley).

On his retirement from the public service in January, 1880, Captain Rundle went to live at Rothsay Bay, in the vicinity of Broadmount A. E. Sykes was appointed Harbour Master at Rockhampton on February 16, which post he held for a

term of 27 years.

GULF LINE SCHEME

, The Premier moved on Sep tember 29 the second reading of the Railway Companies Preliminary Bill, and revealed that it was based upon an offer by a London syndicate to build a railway from Roma 800 miles to Parker Point, Gulf of Carpentaria for 10,000 acres of land per mile of railway line. One of the conditions was that the Government would con struct spur railways from the main line to deep water at Rockhampton and Townsville. The Bill was passed on November 17, and as the west ern line from Rockhampton had reached Withersfleld (5w» miles), the Government went ahead with the construction of a screw pile wharf at Port Alma that stood lor 27 years unconnected with the shore ere it was linked by rail with Bajool and opened In 1913. Nobody in Rockhampton asked for the wharf or even knew that it was to bis constructed until the work was going for

ward.

Mr Norton (Port Curtis), on November 4, moved: "(1) That the present state of trade did not warrant a continuation of expenditure ' in the Fitzroy River such as has been lately incurred, and (2) In the opinion of the House, there fore, it is advisable that the attempt to deepen the bed of the river should be for the present discontinued." His gen eral theme was not only that it was false economy to Im prove the Fitooy River, but it was sheer folly to develop the Brisbane River, and he gave the amount spent at the two places to the end of June, 1880,

as:

Brisbane Fitzroy Dredging and

walls . . . £93,507 £72,209 Dredge plant . £91,113 £38,907 do. building . £34,578 £38,604

Total £219,198 £149,710 Mr Norton and several others said they were unable to eee that the State would benefit by such expenditure.

The Premier said that * the Nisbet scheme was designed to obtain 10 ft at low water from town to bay, and he thought

money as ta he taken right up .o FtocWiia P and

mentary estimate# _ purpose of constructlnf * 55rf »t Barney Point,

.ort Curtis." , .

He stated that the district

S?e Sef diS'omed^ln

those mines at first, ttiey h^

,S??!

JS'^pwe tin." The Prem ** Sv«i on the Information

SaSe that AucklandMg

was better situat d as a site S? a wharf than Ba«*y Stat and it would be unwise to premise anything, even had the Government the moncy lor such a project, antU they had i more information on this mat

1^ also as to the possible

Singes in the immediate

future.

mere is UtUe doubt that, to the latter regard. Mr mcu wraith had in mind the Roma Gulf railway with a spur Un® to port Alma. W. Whitfield vu appointed pUot at Glad. stone on February 25, WO.

On September 5. 1882.

plan, section and book of ret

erence of the Stanley r-nway railway line from the railway

iiu « the rt«w. ««

laid unassumingly on t«e

table of the Legislative Assem

bly.

PORT CURTIS ? PORT ALMA

By 22 votes to 8 the I bly rejected the motion of M Norton on September )fl<^ the House at its next ®l1lt^tlD resolve itself into a Committed of the Whole . . . to, consider a request to his Excellency

Governor to cause to nave placed on the nert

ales a sum of £200'°^_^

construction of a r^Uv!aLrl,^

to connect the Ce^f®V I ern line with Port Curti|.

Mr Norton was extremely , disrespectful of Port Mma. "' carding which he said they might as well have a hulk at the place for all the benefit it wovdd be to the country, un lesTthey made a railway on pUes. or carted soil down there to make a dry bed. He Bl8° believed that " if the people of Rockhampton had hall a |££n railway lines made, they would still ?"orc

money spent on thf /_ McIl.

The Premier <Mr mcu

wraith) said

of the Government had been to get main lines to the best ports. They had fixed theb0Sl ST for the central Railway to be Port Alma . . . «®g had a good port within 25

miles of Rockhampton, why should they be compelled to make a line 75 miles long to get the same thing ? . . . Port Alma was reckoned to be so good a port by private Individ uals that they were quite pre pared to make a railway a' their own expense." Th.^ Premier probably referred to the Roma-Oull of Carpentari i line, and the provision mail'1 by the syndicate that there b< a spur line therefrom to deep

water at Rockhamp' n.

Die Rockhampton Munici pal Council resolved on Sep tember 16 to request the Gov ernment to remove the sta tion-wharf railway line from Stanley Street to South Street, and so abate a public incon venience to which the com munity had been subjected for yean. It was stated, too. that with the increase of traffic to and from Stanley Street rail way station, the nuisance would grow with the years.

Mr Norton presented the annual petition on September 19 "from certain residents of Gladstone" urging upon the Government the desirability of constructing the Gladstone Rockhampton railway on the same day the Minister for Works (Mr Macrossan) moved that the House approve " of the plan, section, ard book of reference of the wharf line. Rockhampton Central Rail way. as laid upon the tablr of the House on September 5.

1882." ,

He said that an nnusoal feature of the matter was that the line had been In existence for about 10 years, and that the House had never been asked to unction its construction. He now asked for parlia mentary authority " for making the line, for keep ing it open, for Its main tenance, nnd for its reml&

(Ion for the public safety." '

He cald that the Govern ment had received no prote:

from the Rockhampton muni cipality. Be that as it may the line Is still in Stanle,

Street.

(To be continued.)

articleText:
THE PORT OF ROCKHAMPTON: ITS

ORIGIN AND DEVELOPMENT

(Written for the "Herald" by "Hiatorlcui")

The first systematic survey and subsequent charting in the Fitzroy River was made by the Portmaster (Captain Heath), before dredging was started at Upper Flats early in 1865. The immediate result.of this was given in the Billleiin of March 21, 1865, which announced that a new channel had been opened up by Captain Rundle at the Upper Flats, giving in all states

of the tide 11 in. greater depth than the old one.

'It is partially buoyed off; but for want of enough buoys, the Harbour Master has been unable to complete it. The Jolly came through this passage and the Clarence and Williams on Friday last, also took advantage of the extra depth it affords; the latter, Captain Smith informs us, would have had to wait for the night's tide had not Captain Bundle been on board, who piloted the Wil liams safely through after the water had commenced to fall. Captain Bundle, however, informs us that sufficient time has not yet elapsed for him to determine

iwnetner tWa channel will remain permanent. r

lyo mark when la transit me | line of position of Tttnan dra Bank, two lights were es tablished on Cape Keppel, near tha Pilot Station, Keppel Bay,

on July 24.

Pursuant to the direction of

I the Legislative Assembly of the (previous year the Government {started clearing the Upper (Flat with the dredge Brember ] some time prior to September, janfi according to Pilot Hayes I "the method of dredging then (in vogue left the river in a I worse condition than before I operations commenced. This ( kind of work continued until [1896." An example of Govern jment dredging was the fact

that the two bad places on the I Second Plate "carried 4 ft. and IS ft at low water when dredg (ing started, and only 3 ft. and I 3 ft. 6 in. respectively when (dredging: was completed."

( The "Bulletin" of September (8. reported:-"A serious accl i dent occurred to Mr. Brown, j master of the Government (dredge wotting at the Flats. (One of the anchors had been

caught in a bight, and Mr. I Brown placed a handle in the (steam winch for the purpose of J assisting, by turning the (handle, to raise the cable. At (the moment that he had ob j talned a hold, the handle was (lifted quickly upwards, carry [ ing Mr. Brown round with it (and dashing him head fore (moet on to the deck. Be was j immediately picked op by one (of the men, and in a few min (utes afterwards became ln I "sensible. Be was at once takra (to Rockhampton, and remain - (ed insensible till Friday even (ing; since then he has maided (gradually. He returned to the

dredge yesterday."

MAIL BOAT SUBSIDY

A subsidy of 13500 to the

(Queensland Steam Navigation Coy. for carrying mall coast wise to as far north as dowen was announced on September 8. Mr Douglas MIdk. (Port

(Curtis) wanted a subsidiary Gladstone-Eockhampton line

(via the Narrows. The idea so (to use the Narrows was not

new-Hardy used it with Al bion 10 years earlier-but it (was thee first time that the subject reached Parliamentary

level

( The following vessels visited : (Rockhampton during 1865: (373-ton as. Balclutha, (Orain j g®^: 30-ton ketch Ben Bolt

(Goodman); 445-ton SJS. Boo merang (Chatfleld); 373-ton m. Clarence (Cottier); '133 ton as. Diamantlna (Chap man); schooner Don Juan (Griffin); s.s. Bagle; 40-ton schooner Elizabeth (Hughes); 1637-ton m. Lady Bowen

(Quail); 800-ton SJS. Lady Young (Curphey); 373-ton s*. I Lelchhardt (Smith); s>9-ton

schooner Magellan Cloud (Walkley); 8-ton schooner Nil Desperandum (Walker); 320 ton «.s. Platypus (Hwmas); s-e. Queensland (Christtson>; 30-ton schooner Sacramento (Anderson): 41-ton schooner Unknown (Murray); 319-ton s.s. Williams (Smith); 330-ton brig Woodlark (Hopkins). Mas ters' names are in brackets.

I, On February 38, 1808, the upper Flats lightship was placed in position. Additional to marking the crossing place there she showed, by lights at. night and shapes during the day, the depth of available water on the leads across the

flats.

The Narrows, connecting Port Curtis' with Keppel Bay, were much to the fore in those days of small ships, but the middle portion of five or so miles, which dried at low water, limited the use of this short cut to light-draught vessels. Mr Brady (Works Department* reported in April, 1866, on dredging these shallows: "The cutting'of a low water chan nel through these flats would occupy a period of 18 to 34 months, x am not , prepared.

owing to want of detailed sur vey, to state the quantity of tilt th&t would have to be raised, but from the available Information Z think the outlay would be from £16,000 to £20,000 for a channel 3 ft. deep at low water and 200 ft wide ... I consider, however, to be of any service the channel ought not to be less than seven or eight feet at low water. I am pre pared to have made the neces sary survey, and report fully on the subject, if it Is thought durable."

When reporting in 187$ on the port possibilities at Pon Curtis Mr W. D. Nisbet, En gineer, Harbours and Rivers, stated that the flat, gravelly beach on the inside of South Tree Point was remarkably well adapted for beaching ves sels. He instanced EMA Torch as being beached there in 1854, and the ships Juno an1 Miriam in 1855 and 1856 re spectively. The ships Kate Waters and Island City were beached there in 1B65, and the ships Lombard, Eclipse and Al bion in 1866. The last five were cattle ships-presumably in the New Caledonian trade "and all were entirely re-cop pered there." He added that "the whole of the Queensland Steam Navigation Co's. steam ers have also used this place."

Tenders were called, to close on December 31, for a tele graph line from the Pilot Sta tion, Keppel Bay, "to a point yet to be determined upon, an the existing line of telegraph from Rockhampton to Bris

bane."

Assistant-pilot Smith, Kep pel Bay, was appointed opera t or-in-charge at the telegraph station, Pilot Station, Keppel Bay, on September 13, 1867. It was declared on January 24, 1868, that the wharf area be tween Queen's wharf and that cf the ASJN. Co. was "exempt ed ftS>m the Jurisdiction of the Rockhampton Municipal Council." By-laws and wharf age rates, by the Rockhampton municipality, were.gazetted on February 18.

Shipping was warned on De cember 11 that the depth of water through the Upper Flats.

Fitzroy River, was only 2 ft. 3 in. at low water.

According to a report pre sented to the Legislative As sembly In 1870 and published In part In the "Bulletin" of August 17. 1872, the dredge Bremer which started in 1868 the first dredging of the Fitz roy-at the Upper Flats-was of 25 h.p. was capable of shifting 400 tons of material per 8-hour day, and cost to build £8480. Her steam tender Mary was of 24 h.p. and cost

£6658.

The Bulletin of January 9 stated thnt purchasers of the wreck of the schooner Jane Lockhart, which was wrecked on a reef about 10 miles from Heron Island, had permission from the Government to bor row the diving apparatus, then on board the dredge at the Second Flats. On the 16th it stated that a petition was be ing signed by a large number of people on both sides of the river against the inconvenience caused by the removal of the lo"er ferry. "The-reduction of the fare from 3d: to Id. is, of course a great advantage to the public, but it proves that no loss need have been sustained by working the low ferry. Why not keep it up to 2d. or even

3d.?

The Bulletin of January 23 quoted a suggestion put for ward by the civil engineer, Mr Brady, late Engineer for Har bours and Rivers, to extend the banks at Upper Flats "by means of fascines and plant ing mangroves and the deposits accumulating be -nd them would have the effect of nar rowing the channel and giving Increased force to the current, thereby preventing deposits of shifting sand in the fairway". The Bulletin gave the idea its bhssing.

Mr Fitzgerald, MLA, was re ported in the Bulletin of Feb ruary 16 as saying that the Government had promised that it would proceed at once with the work of clearing the Upper Flats. He said that the only delay would be the procuring of a tug for the dredge. As Coxswain Neil was getting the pilot cutter Mystery under weigh from the pilot station on Cape Keppel at 11 pjxu on

March 18 she was caught by a strong gust of wind and driven on the N.E. corner of the reef that formed part of the boat protection at the Pilot Station. Efforts to refloat her were un availing, and she became a total wreck.

An excursion "to Keppel Bay and Curtis Island" was run by sjb. Clarence on Easter Mon day, March 29. Captain Cottier placed the ship within a few yards of the beach "so that all who desired to go ashore did 6o dry-shod". Dancing and sports-both on the beach provided the entertainment. This is probably what became Beachton, or the Golden Shore. The maid-of-all-work' pilot craft "Mystery" created more stir in her untimely end "on some rocks off the pilot station" in her hum,

drum life of shifting buoy3, tending lights, servicing a lightship and also the needs of pilots in their attentions to shipping. She precipitated a debate In the Legislative As sembly on April 16, which the Treasurer increased to a storm by trying to smother the Inci dent. He finished by promising tnat every effort would be made to replace the Mystery at the earliest possible moment.

un June 5 the Bulletin com mented editorially on a trade matter: "It Is a well-known fact that for some time a large portion of the traffic from the Barcoo has gone to Brisbane via Dalby, and that supplies from the stations have been received in return from Bris bane .... The people of Brisbane and their Government are fully alive to the Import ance of securing the trade of our back country for Brisbane. In the beginning of this year the railway charges on the Southern line were consider ably reduced, and the effects on the Barcoo were soon felt The carriage from there to Dalby fell to £16 per ton, whilst to Rockhampton-about the »nra» distance, it was £23. The addi tional 85 miles of railway ,to Brisbane did not bring the cost of carriage up to Rocihampton rates. . . . There can be little doubt that the trade of the Thompson as well as that of the Barcoo will soon follow this track, and Rockhampton must be permanently Injured."

Commenting on a notice to mariners that the natural channel, Upper Flats, had been buoyed, the "Bulletin" stated on July 10, 1869: 'This means that the new cutting is inferior to the old channel. This mult we long ago anticipated. WM the new cutting bej»n complet ed, and very little more was wanting, the river would have Sowed naturally through It. Both the people and Press of Rockhampton have urged on the Government the necessity for completing the cutting, otherwise all the money spent on it would be thrown away. The large sum of £10,000 has been spent in clearing the Fltzroy since 1863. The comple tion of the cutting is a matter of calculation, and to stop short and do worse than noth ing after spending so much money, is foolish economy . . . A provincial committee has been at work at Bo wen, and another at Townsville and theb action has been, If not always Judicious, in accordance with the inhabitants. There Is room for such an organisation hare."

COUNCIL'S INTEREST

Although the Rockhampton City Council controlled the wharves and collected wharf age rates, it had no power to tmprove the navigation of the river, or even the berthage. But the position was Qo^lear, and a very general fcelin; existed among pastoralists that wharfage charges paid by them on their wool went to make Rockhampton's streets. The "Bulletin" of July 13 corrected that view editorially: "Since 1863 a sum or £7652 has been received in wharfage rates. This money has b$pn paid by the people of Barcoo as well as by people of Rocki* amptoa. Tt is right that this rrftney should be spent In Improving the wharves and approaches to the river, and we find that it has been so spent We

(Continued «a Page 1?)

PORT OF ROCKHAMPTON

! ? * .

? (Continued from Page 3)

not ask the people of Bareoo or Springsure to pay tor our street* though they certainly derive eome benefit from them: but we expect that they will not object to paying their fair contribution for our wharves and for everything connected

therewith."

Mr Archer (Rockhampton) asked the Colonial Secretary on July 17 if (1) he was aware that the Upper Flats, Fltrroy River, have so silted up as to make necessary the discharge of steamers below these fiats? (3) If so, is the Government

prepared "to take Immediate steps to set the dredge, now lying there, to work in deepen* lng the river?

To which the Minister re* plied that the cutting had Un proved during the late freshes, but within the last three week* a ridge has grown up which extended almost across the cutting; "and It is probabU that a screw steamer, of heavy draught, may be unable to pass without discharging some por tion of her cargo. Instruction? have been given to put thp dredge plant in order, so as to be «ble to commence the clear ing of the channel."

The "Bulletin" of July 21 called attention to the tact that a good deal of the Bareoo traffic was finding Its way to port via Dalby. "The fact was even mentioned in the House, and not contradicted. Our carriers have formidable rivals and will lose a good deal ol trade If they do not look sha^> We now hear that a Spring sure pastoralist has been offer ed carriage from Dalby to his place at £14 per ton, and £7 ' per ton for wool back to Dalb? This is a recent offer. Quite lately contracts have been made from the same place to the Bareoo at £16 and £18, wool back at half rtaes."

The Toowoomba-Dalby line was opened on April 20, 1888. ko the "formidable rivals" had lost bo time.

MOVE TO BUT SHIPS

On August 19 a public meet ing war. held at Rockhampton "for the purpose of taking steps towards the formation ol a steamship company." Hie reason was "the treatment they bad received from the AJ9.N Coy. in respect of freights ana

mail*" and also a keen dartre to "brnk through the monop oly that now existed." Ttw i objective was to raise money t<> purchuo ttw gtitfjnm HftvlW* and Roy Roy "lor the trad* between Sydney, Rockhampton and other Queensland ports

lit wan decided that a steam ship company be formed with j a capital ot £30,000 to £1

shares, and ere the meetlnc 1 dosed shares to the value or

i eiboo* had been taken up.

When she ceased dredging I In 1869 Bremer had removed 31,720 tons of material from the npper Flats and 182,394 tons from the Second Flats, or 164.114 tons In all. The "Bulle tin" ot August 17, 1673, stated that this work was eompletert by day labour in 33 months,' at la cost of £8,267 or 1313d per

ton. The report stated both 'channels gave four feet, but I that the tot (Upper Plats> I soon filled up, and Second Flats shallowed In places.

It was notified on May 8, 1870 that the dredge Bremer i was at work clearing the chan nel across the Upper Flats. At the end of the year she had deepened the channel to five feet by removing 22,4% tons o! at a cost of fTS *>r 837d per ton. Waterfront per sonnel at Broadsound, Seppel Bay, Gladstone and Rock lhampton during 1670 were:

I Customs: Gladstone, C. W. Rich, Sub-colftctor (also acts as Harbour Master and Water Police Magistrate), O. Clarke,

and Warehouseman: Rockhampton, W. J. Brown, Sub-collector (also acts as Water Police Magistrate), W. ] J. Connolly, 2nd Officer, R. R

Gilchrist, Locker, one cox swain and two boatmen; Kep I pel Bay, Isaac Warner, coast waiter; St Lawrence, E Bur Ifcttt, Sub-collector, D. Williams. Icoastwaiter.

MARINE DEPARTMENT:

| Bustard Bead, T. Rooksby,

Bead lightfceeper; Port Curtis, C Rich Barbour Master, L. [Jansen, pilot; Gatcombe Head, D. Gorman, bead lightfceeper ; ! Rockhampton, Harbour Master

and Pilot, M. S. Rundle, Pilots, C. Hayes and A. Roberts, Up per Flats Lightship, B. West away, master, Keppel Bay Lightship, E. H. Smith, Master; Broadsound, H. Burkitt, Har ?

[ bour Master, D. Williams, pilot

PORT EXPORTS

The "Bulletin" of January 7, ,1871, gave the following ex ports from Rockhampton: "

Gold

o&

1860 62 1861 20

1862 68 -

1863 2619 - ~ 1664 18882 (Peak Downs) i 1865 16566 -

11666 15636 (Owcodlle)

1867 37570 Wool

tons

1888 25806 2065 1869 31109 2963 1870 31077 2237

Copper Bides Total

tons No. value 908 6366 £408411 987 6317 666696 768 8738 455986

The ?'Bulletin" said prophet! . rally: "Preserved meats appear for the first time, as an article of export, In 1870. Tfoe quantity b! lipped was 27,392 lb., and the total declared values, £639 the average valuation being nearly 5ld per lb. The export simply represents the trial shipments of Messrs Berkelman and Co. of Laurel Bank. That firm, and also the Central Quensland Meat Preserving Co., win be in full work by June next at the very latest, and the present year's ship ments of preserved meats from Bockhampton will doubtless form an important item in the trade returns of the port."

The Government subsidised the running of a steamer direct from Brisbane to Townsvllle, and tills Induced from the "Bulletin" of January 26: "It will take years to cultivate a paying trade between Brisbane and Townsvllle, even with the aid of the Government sub sidy. Still, the pertinacity or our Brisbane competitors is notorious, and they, will stick at nothing to gain for their port the position of the com* merclal as well as the politic al capital of the colony. We do not think that they .will suc ceed, but they may do us seri ous injury by taking portion of our legitimate trade, and by dipping heavily into the Treas ury chest to give Brisbane r. commercial pre-eminence . to which she has no claim on the ground of natural advantages"

The "Bulletin" of February 2 recorded: "For the past few days a memorial _ has been

taken about the town for slfc nature, pray in® the Corpora tion to Invite competition for the collect** ol wharfage rates next year, as the memori alist believe that a consider able saving will be thus affect ad. We have not wen the memorial, but believe It was «nt to the Town Clerk on Tuesday, 31st proximo." i

The "Bulletin" of Febru ary 18 carried the advertise ment of the proposed Queens land Steam Navigation Co., the object of which was to "reduce and equalise fares and freights between the neighbouring col onies and all Queensland ports." by the use of "modern economic screw steamers to be specially built for the trade. The capital was £60,000 in a* many £1 shares, and the pub lic was invited to subscribe at 6/- on application, the balance In three equal payments spread over nine months. Brisbane directors were: Hon. Chas. Lil ley. Q.C..M.P.. and Messrs J. Fenwick and T. B. Stephens: in Rockhampton they were : ersrs B. Brodnit*. R. it Hun (3r and D. T. Mulligan; and at Mackay, T. H. Fitzgerald.

A Roberts, pilot and C. Haynes, assistant pilot, Rock hampton, were appointed on February 22 to act also as coast waiters: and D. Williams was promoted from acting pilot, Broadsound, to be pilot at that port.

On March 18, Alderman Oaporn brough forward a mo-1 tlon "affirming the necessity of providing wharfage accom modation 'at a high level', and explained that he contemplat ed using the steam punt for the purpose. By request of the mover, the motion was ordered to stand over till next meeting to allow time for considera tion. The matter, when it came up for discussion, resolved it self into using the punt as a kind of landing stage, but It was lost to a movement to have the punt repaired to carry out her legitimate duties.

Mr W. Burns was appointed on June 33 to be Engineer Surveyor, Rockhampton, under the Marine Board of Queens land, "vice Benjamin Edgar, resigned."

Hie following new names appeared in shipping lists dur ing 1871: 272-ton sjj. Balclu tha (Hill); 1000-ton S3. Blackbird (House); Brlgantlnc Circe (Scapelhom); 309-ton s.6. Egmont (Durrell); 80-ton ketch Enterprise (Whltton); 300-ton 64. Florence Irving (Weir); 296-ton 6jb. Jamas Patterson (Saunders); 140 ton brig Prairie (Macfarlane); 286-ton s.s. Queensland (Smith); ketch Thomas Day /Mayer); 160-ton sjs. Tlnonee (Hirst). Names of masters are in parenthesis.

IN DEFENCE OF A PUNT

The "Bulletin" of January 9, 1872, hailed the fact that "the steam punt has now been run ning nearly a month, and has

fully justified the action taken by the majority of the council In refuting to sink her to the bottom of the river, or sell her for old Iron, a5 was persistent* ly urged upon them to do." It vent on to say that "column after column of unreasoning fulmlnatlon, speech after speech of dogmatic assertion have been brought to bear on the unfortunate punt; and yet as soon as she Is taken In hand and refitted by practical men, she becomes the object of ful some admiration." After cool ing down the "Bulletin" con cluded: "Although she Is not the best punt that could be built for our river, she Is a vast Improvement on the old wood en punt, ^ and far too useful to be either sunk or -sold as old iron."

A memorial to the Minister for Lands was despatched on March 7, praying for the sale of portion of the pilot station reserve, Keppel Bay. An Immi grant from the Light Brigade was "desirous of building a marine residence near the pilot station for himself and hie family, and also for the ac commodation of visitors from Rockhampton."

Loyal to Emu Park, the "Bulletin" on March 7 said that the spot had few of the attractions of that resort, "but It Is approachable by steamer, Is connected with Rockhamp ton by telegraph, two very im portant considerations to a business man compelled to visit the seaside In search of health."

_^Jwo enterprisesJteve. Jbecn

lately set afoot which deserve the warmest support of every person interested In the trade of Rockhampton, of every per son who Is either a consumer of Imported merchandise or u producer of exported commodi ties, and of every person who will derive direct or Indirect benefit from cheap fares and freights," B&ld the "Bulletin" of March 23. "These are (1> the laying on of the good ship Light Brigade at this port for London direct, and (3) the laying on of the fine s*. Lord Ashley as a competitor for our coasting trade. Both of these enterprises Involve a certain amount of risk to their pro motors, both are calculated to confer advantage on th? people of this port and of Its back country, and both there fore are entitled to the sympa thies of everyone desirous of assisting to promote the public weal." What the "Bulletin" of that day would have said of merchants who 76 years later signed agreements to import all goods by rail is best left to the Imagination.

In the "Bulletin's" Glad stone notes on April 0, it wu stated that The cattle trade between this port and Mew Caledonia Is about to be re sumed. Zt Is reported that two vessels are already laid on."

(To be continued)

articleText:
THE PORT OF ROCKHAMPTON: ITS

ORION AND DEVELOPMENT

(Written for the "BenUT fcjr "HWortem.")

The NanKlu-Broadmoiini railway was opened to publictraffic on January 1, and appear* to have been a very quiet business. The "Bulletin" of the 3rd saidr^There was no ceremony or formality of any kind, and if the day had not been a1 holiday it is doubtful if there would have been any passengers. Even with the close holiday on Saturday, and all the attraction of

novelty only 32 travelled by the train."

It is on record that the journey was made safely though rather slowly. One or two matters had yet to be attended to, but the line was practically complete. The passengers on arrival at Broadmount examined the station buildings, and the hotel, which were the only buildings erected, had hmch, and then returned to town, arriving at North Bockhampton early in the afternoon.

The plan and specification*, or the proposed dredge were handed to experts who pre sented tteir report on January 5. On offer by Fleming and Ferguson, Paisley, tor £28,220 was refused, as was an offer from the New York Dredging Coy. for £38,780, plus £3/6/ per lineal foot of pipe line.

Engaged by the board to re port on Engineer Schmidt's river scheme, Mr C. Napier Bell arrived at Rockhampton during January. Be handed In his report on the Schmidt scheme on February 16, and with few modifications "he thoroughly endorsed the origin

al scheme."

Owing to unsatisfactory pro gress because of plant being unable to deal with the mate rial to be shifted, contractors for dredging liie Narrows ceased work on April 7 and re quested permission to abanlsn the contract and remove their plant This was granted, and payment made only for mate rial actually shifted.

Due to the rapid railway de velopments along the -North Coast the Postmaster-General (State) decided in April to In vestigate the prospects of a fast mall service from either Gladstone or Keppel Bay to Townsvllle, the port for the then booming town of Char ters Towers. Hie result was the calling of tenders to dose on July SO.

ANOTHER COLLISION

Soon after S a-m, on Jupe 13 the steamers VUssingen and

Lelchhardt met In the cutting,

at Archer's Crossing, the re

sult belqg that the former was1

cut down by the larger vessel and sank in a few minutes. At the subsequent enquiry the blame was apportioned In the ratio of two-thirds to Lelch hardt and one-third to Vlissln gen. ^

, On June 23 the chairman of the Harbour Board (Mr W. Burns) protested to the Trea surer (Mr R. Phllp) against "opening up by dredging the so-called Central Channel Into Broadmount Instead of the South Channel." The protest stated: "All the engineers who have as yet been called in to report on the Fizroy River have unanimously declared themselves in favour of treat ing the South Channel as the only satisfactory entrance to the river. .. . Further, X wish, on behalf of the board, to re spectfully protest against the

Government or any branch of it undertaking work within the Jurisdiction of the pott with out first having consulted it and obtained its consent."

Hie Brisbane-Northern Ports mail contract between the AUSN Coy. and the Postmas ter-General expired on June 30. Malls are carried by ordinary cargo and passenger vessels, and with stays in port the con tract amounted to little better than an 8-knot per hour pro position. f

ThePortmastertCaptata T. M. Almond) in his annual re port stated that he was pre paring to undertake the work of deepening Hie Narrows by hand labour, and hoped to make a start by the end of July. He estimated that an outlay of £800 would remove two or three feet from the shallowest parts by the end of October. The route' was already beaconed and lighted. He concluded: "If after deepening the shallowest part of The Narrows by two to three feet a greater depth should be re quired in order that the sjb. Premier may be aide to keep up the regular communica tions between Gladstone and Rockhampton, special appli ances will have to be obtained for the purpose."

SOUTH CHANNEL LIGHTS Use North Channel into Fort Curtis was causing . trouble, and the Portmaster considered on July 1 that the class of vessel coming to the port would necessitate the lighting of the South Channel. He gave the estimate as £2007 with £286 for annual mainten

ance.

Of Rockhampton the Port master said: "The wharf and shed Broadmount are rapidly approcning completion. The approaches from" the shore re

main to be finished.

He stated that whereas he had given 600,000 cubic yards as the spoil necessary to be shifted to obtain 17 ft in the South Channel, "the floods of 1896 had increased this to 700,000 cubic yards, and in creased the estimated cost of the work from £15,000 to SlljOOO."

Mr G. Higgins, Mel bourne, was Instructed In June to design a new dredge for the Rockhampton Harbour Board. Mr Higgins held the patent rights of the von Schmidt suction bridge.

At the Harbour Board elec tion In June Messrs E. 8. Archer, A. Bertram, W. Burns, J. J. Dunlop, T. Kelly, R. MacFarlane, A. Paterson, W. H. Budd and' H. Williams were returned. Mr Burns was appointed chairman.

The Treasurer referred the letter of the Harbour Board to the Fortmaster, Captain Al mond, who lost no time in in dicating that his interpreta tion of the Nesblt and Coode

reports differed fundamentally with that accepted by the Har bour Board. B£ thai declared the proposed works to be for convenience of the public; were beyond the capacity of the Harbour Board to carry out; and would not injure or pre judice any work already con structed or contemplated by the board;, and that rather than that the' Government should obtain permission of the Harbour Board to under take this or any other work, it was necessary, for that body to (Attain permission of the Government before commenc ing any work. He then -sum marised his points:

L There already exists at Broadmount a pexzqapent area of deep water some MOO tt by 1000 to 1900 ft, and carrytag generally low water depths of varying from four to seven fathoms-in fact, a safe and commodious harbour for V large fleet of. vessels. . . -

2. The wharf already con structed provides accommoda tion for ships of the largest tonnage, and there is ample deep water frontage for addi tional wharves to the extent of

fully 4000 ft if required.

3. The dredging of the Middle Channel, as proposed, to a depth of 17 ft at low water (equal to 31 ft at high water springs and 25 ft at high water neaps) will provide ac cess to the terminus of the Central Railway for vessels of the deepest draught -

1 All coasting vessels will be aide to approach the wharf; practically at any state of the;

tide.

5. The Middle Channel isj the shortest, widest and safest! approach to Broadmount j harbour.

6. Middle Channel is the most permanent and will be less costly to dredge and maintain than the present (South) chan nel.

When dredged, the Middle Channel will remove an the difficulties of Navigation antici pated by masters of vessels in rounding the upper end of Bgg

Sand.

8. Broadmount wharf and channel, when completed, Broadmount win be one of the finest and most accessible ports in Australia.

An example of the passenger

traffic that moved datiy be tween BocMiamptoa and Glad stone via Broadmount and the Narrows, to link with die rail service from Gladstone and Brisbane, the following Is the passenger list of Q.G.SJS. Pre mier (Capt. J. Tait) for Glad stone on July 29:

Fox, McDonald, J. North and two children, CKeefe and J. D. Pickering; Misses Coase, Flem ing, Marwedal and CKeefe; Messrs A. Bawden, T. Birch, J. D. Chataway, W. D. Davey, P.

Dutton, R. Farrington, A. O. ' Hauenscend, N. Howard, X Kingel, A. Kronlng, J. Lyons McDoftald,' W. MiiT^nnw;, J. North, CKeefe, J. D. Pale* thorpe, F,' Pile, W. Richards, Jl Swansea, Capt Tielden, W, Webb and D. Wright, and 65 ta the steerage.

Hart work to deepen the shallows In the Narrows by Z It was started during Jidy. From 15 to 20 aim were employed with a side . delivery barge for removal

of the spoiL

MIDDLE v. SOUTH

CHANNEL % The Postmaster's report was handed to Mr R. Schmidt, the bOanfe. engineer-in-chief fat his comment, and after outline tag his views be gave the fol lowing summary (on August 16) j

1. The South Channel la the main entrance to the Rtzroy River, but the Middle Channel can be made a good entrance into Broadmount, if provision is made for establishing the permanency of the Inner cut ting.

2. The distance from Sea Hill to Broadmount through the South Channel Is 13.75 miles,

and that via the Middle Chan- ; nel is U. miles.

3. Both channels have their weak spot, he.: Rocky Point shoal In the South Channel and the inner cutting in the

Channel.

- 4. The upended line of edi ting in the' Middle Channel gives the quantity of spoil to be removed as 50,000 cubia yards in favour of the South

Channel.

6. The lighting of the South Channel is simple, bnt that at

nhntiwrt miiBtMBeea

sarily be very intricate.

The board's dredgemaste* (Mr Haynes) reviewed the problem from the navigator's point of view, i.e. from the completed plan In both cases and reported on August 15 that "having carefully taken " Into consideration the whole mat* ter, I unhesitatingly give ft as my opinion that the Middle Channel is the best undo' all conditions of time and tide."

A special meeting of the board was held on August 24 to consider these reports. It' was unanimously decided that

(Continued on Page l&)

PORT OF ROCKHAMPTON

(Continued from Page 3)

"the board approve of the Portmaster's suggestion to open out the Middle Channel Into Broadmount with the amend ment proposed by the board's engineer in tlis report dated the 15 instant."

lb his annual report dated September 2 die Commissioner for Railways, discussing the linking of the northern and southern rail systems "by means of .the steamer plying through The Narrows," stated that the revenue "due to bs. Premier alone was £3108 for the year, earned at a cost of £4041, showing a loss of £633 on the steamer, but when It Is consid ered that the total receipts from the through traffic were £13,486, it will be apparent that this' ; connexion has been the means of adding very consid erably to the general revenue of lines both north and south of'Oladstone."

On September 15, in response to an order made by the As sembly a week earlier, a return was tabled showing the har bour dues collected at Glad stone from 1893 to August 1898, also expenditure defrayed from such .dues*

£

3

?3 -2

I -

w £

£ £

109 1 185 28 258 1392 710 88 726 442 295 25

Totals 2329 1976

]$ems of expenditure were: Engineering expenses, £165; cattle race and yards, £287; dredging, £645; moorings, £630; jetty-repairs, £249.

« Thf Railway wharf was pur chased by the Harbour Board for £2(>0, plus the right of all government goods crossing it to be exempted from harbour dues, though this condition ap plied later to all government goods crossing all harbour Board wharves. The Wharf was taken over in September. About this time construction of a small wharf at North Roclc hampton was authorised "In response to the request of the Yeppoon Sugar Co., supported by the Borough Council of North Rockhampton.

NORTHERN MAIL RUN

For both the express GlatJ s tone-To wnsvllle mall and Brisbane-northern ports' malls only, one tender was received, and these the Postmaster General (State) decided were unsatisfactory. But an interim one-year 12-knot contract was negotiated with the A.UJ5.N. Co. to begin on October 7 with 6:6. Barcoo. The mail train left Brisbane on Friday evening and connected with the mall steamer at Gladstone on Sat' urday. Barcoo left for north at 2 p.m., called at Flat Top on Sunday morning, Bowen on Sunday afternoon and arrived at Townsville at 4 a.m. ?n i Monday. The subsidy was

£13,000, and for the three-year period which involved more stringent speed conditions It was £16,750 per annum. This famous service, known to many thousands of people through out Australia, continued for 23

1693-4 1894-5 1B95-6 H96-7 1897-8 1898-9

years until the last* link of the coast railway was Joined on June 4, 1921.

The Harbour Board at a meeting held on October 19 received a letter from the Treasury stating that the Port master's plan for the Middle Channel would be adhered to. Trie channel in The Narrows between Boat Creek and the Cod Hole-over a mile-had been deepened by October by the requisite 2 ft, at a cost of £750. in the six miles between Monte Chris to landing and Black Swan Creek 10 lights were established, and a resi dent lightkeeper was ap pointed.

The Government steamer Premier occupied the Harbour Board's gridiron on November 15 and 16.

Mr J. Bain arrived from Melbourne on November 24 to assume charge of the dredge Elwood when completed.

The work of closing Boat Channel, between Central Is land and Hawk Point was com pleted on November 36.

Mr Linden W. Bates, who had been engaged by the Gov ernment to advise on the best method of dealing with the Brisbane, arrived at Rock hampton on November 30 to advise similarly on the Fltjsroy

River.

THE BATES REPORT

His report on the Ataroy River and Broadmount Har bour was dated December 19. Beginning with The Rocks, re specting which Nlsbet <1877), Coode -(18888) and Napier Bell (1898) had all recommended a measure of removal, Bates found himself In agreement with them, but especially with Bell "who recommends that The Rocks be cut down to 10 ft below low water, in order that the tidal flow may. have in creased volume and increased scouring power in the lower reaches of the river."

He recorded the tidal datum point to be the covering of a tide slab opposite the lightship on the Upper Flats. "This slab marks the low water of spring tides." He found, too, that "the sittings which take place at the Upper Flats dur ing normal tide conditions .seem to indicate that only a small amount of material is carried by tides." He considered that the river presents no in superable difficulties "There are few rocks, and the bottom is such that it can be easily dredged."

Bates said it was accepted that No 1 training wall "has not been at all satisfactory. The Uppfr Flats have been during a period of 15 years re peatedly dredged to 12 ft be low low water, and after beipg left for four years they silted back to 9 ft 6 in. The results obtained from all other walls are reported to be good."

After inspecting the deltti channels Bates considered that under the topographical set up at Rocky Point "Egg Band and the shoal under Rocky Point in the South Channel, are natural and Inevitable."

He continued: "In view of the superior facilities afforded by the Middle Channel and the difficulty of remedying the shoals below Rocky Point with out interfering with Broad mount Harbour, it Is now ac cepted that the Middle Chan nel shall be the future ap proach to Rockhampton and

Broadmount harbours. The South Channel will still be of use-to sailing craft and light ers going to the anchorage near the iron wharf at Port Alma in deep water at the mouth of Casuarina Inlet. The approach to Middle Channel is so wide and deep that questions relat ing to the mouth, to littoral drift, and to the general con ditions of the sea have at the present time little interest "

PIRATE PENINSULA

Bates was cautious about Pirate Peninsula, though he gave principles to be observed were it decided to cut a canal, which he recommehded to fol low the lines of the Grande

Coupure at Antwerp. ' "In

view of all the circumstances," he concluded, "it does not ap peal to me that its considera tion is yet justified, though it saves eight miles and looks like an attractive dredging proposi tion-36,650 ft. long, and aver aging 1500 to 1600 ft. wide (for it must have an expanding sec tion) and excavated to 20 ft. below datum." .

Other than removal of por tion of No. 1 wall his departure from the plan being fpllowed was In detail rather than in

1 principle. His suggestions

showed a saving of 1,511,220 cubic yards of dredged mat ter and of £45,549 in cost, and concluded with:

"With the river in new har ness, sweeping round easy curves and over short cross ings, gaining scouring power as basin after basin supplies more volume, and having its floods discourages from converting re taining walls into groynes, there is a certainty that the full 20 ft. channel to the sea cav be maintained when se cured.

"Then may Roekhamp ton rest assured that ships of deepest draft will seek its wharves in accordance with the unvarying princi ple that commerce makes its conquering way to the bead of navigation."

Of Bowen and Gladstone harbours, Bates said that they "belong to the class of ports which Nature in a kindly mood predestined to commerce-they are the very proteges of the sea. That in this comprehen sive report on all the ports and waterways on the east coast of Queensland there should be two harbours that call for no de-| tailed review is gratifying. I merely greet them in passing and wish them 'god-speed* to the commercial prosperity that awaits them."

For the first few weeks in December the dredge Tridnaca was at work clearing the Auck land Point Jetty berth to ac commodate the steamer run ning the new Gladstone Town$vMe mall service. The berth was deepened to 21 ft at low water. Several shipments of cattle and horses were

made from' this wharf during

1898.

Preparations for lighting the South Channel into Gladstone went forward during 1898, plans of and locations for the necessary light towers being arranged, and optical apara tus "was placed on order in Great Britain.

During 1898 Saurian dredged 29,886 tons from the Town Reach and Lakes Creek; 258,686 tons from Sec. 1 of Cut No. 1, Upper Plats; 113,066 tons from Sec. 2 of Cut No. 1, Upper Flats; 68J906 tons from Sec

ond Flats; 43,306 tons from Ram Sand; and 15,576 from Central la. cut, or a total of 529,706 tons at an average cost of 336d per ton. Stone was de posited at wharf and slip ap proaches (3195 tons); Elbow Wall, (450 tons); Brawn Island dykes (1760 tons), or 37,835 ions at an average cost of 3.28 shillings per ton. This com pleted the Brown Island dykes.

An engineers' strike in Eng land set back the Harbour Board's hopes of obtaining a suction dredge there, and the board considered the ofier of O. Higglns, of Melbourne, to sell the dredge Elwood. Mr Burns (chairman) . Inspected the dredge during 1808 and re ported the machinery to be worth the price asked. It was decided to purchase it and build a hull for it at Rock

hampton.

Elver craft on the F!terojr during 1898 were: Barges for dredges, x; Clam dredge, *; tug Curlew, x; lighter Edith *; supervision steamer Ethelbertx tug* Fltzroy (Govt.); tug Hawk, x; lighter Janet, .; New Chum, *\ s.s. premier (Govt.); dredge Saurian, x; stone punts, x; tug Tweed, x; lighter Waterwltch, *

Note, x denotes harbour and * denotes Walter Reid.

(To be continued.)
heading: THE PORT OF ROCKHAMPTON: ITS ORIGIN AND DEVELOPMENT
snippet: The Nankin-Broadmount railway was opened to public traffic on January 1, and appears to have been a very quiet business. The "Bulletin" of the 3rd said: "There was no ceremony or formality of any kind, and if the day had not been a holiday it is doubtful if there would have been any passengers. Even with the close holiday on Saturday, and all the attraction of
