articleText:
THE PORT OF ROCKHAMPTON?

ORIGIN AND DEVELOPMENT

(Written for the "Herald" by "Hiitoricm")

The "Bulletin" was compelled at times to wage war against distant foes who assailed Rockhampton through the columns of the Brisbane "Courier.1' One such was over the re spective merits of Rockhampton and St Lawrencte as a port for Clermont, when the "Bulletin," on April 16, conceded the right of controversialists "to choose their own battle ground; and it may also be allowed that during the silly season the "Courier" must be excused for padding its columns with such fustian as the Broadsound advocates have been moved to supply."

In his final blow at Rockhampton George Fox, aBroadsoimd advocate, stigmatised it as " the seat of envy, hatred and malice." "But we," said the" Bulletin " editorial, "will not retort. On the con trary we will assume that St Lawrence is the borne oflove, peace, truth and virtue. So pleasant an assump tion will not affect our argument in the slightest degree-will not improve the port nor reduce the length of

thft rniul " >- : -

rr*HE Portmaster advised <jn 1 June 7 that the cutting | through the 9 ft bank above! the Upper Plats was completed1 to a depth of 10 ft 6 in. at low water, with a width of 200 ft.

The cutting woe marked by the ! traditional beacons. |

"The southern papers are Iterating and reiterating the miserable accusation of Messrs Groom and King that - the people of Rockhampton have been bought with Government grants," complained the "Bul letin" on June 20. There is really not the slightest founda tion for this charge; and its being brought forward so re peatedly is proof that* the enemies of the Government are perfectly at a loss for any sub stantial ground of complaint."

On June 22 Captain Hunter's

yacht Florence brought down | from No. 6 island, Broadsound ; (now Marble Island! some three 1 or four tons of marble. The | "Bulletin" stated: "We are in formed that there are three distinct kinds of marble-the red vein, the blue veto and the pure white ... "it Is hoped that attention having been drawn to the matter, capitalists

will be induced to assist Cap- j tain Till, the lessee of the j island. In turning his discovery

to account." j

DREDGING COSTS j

Intimation that the dredge Bremer, which had been laid up for two years, was again to be set to work clearing the Upper Flats, led the "Bulletin" on August 17, 1872, to proceed to some analysis of costs and results. It showed that the dredge cost £8460, dredging £9070, watchman on dredge plant for two years to 1872, £422 surveys, supervision and sundries £4008, or a total of £21,960 for removing 154322 tons, or 2/10 per ton. The "Bulletin" said: "For this we are told that the channel was Increased by 3 ft, but ib the document was prepared two years ago and the channel has been silting up during the in terval; the probability Is that the navigation of tJie river has beeru#ilt very slightly improved

-if Wall."

Henry Bur re 11 was appointed

to be a Bockhatnpton pilot on |

i. Vtfi

posterity « a public bene

factor." ^

There wits some opposition to

. . ' thnm Heine con

f actor.'

the approaches to Broadsound.

Weverley Creek wharf, built under Government supervision collapsed wearily into the stream, and reconstruction was commenced In June, 1875. Vis iting Rockhampton in June the Engineer of Harbours and Rivers (Mr W. D. Nisbett stated in bis annual report, dated May 28, 1876, that he found "the' dredge and punts had been laid up for some time and were considerably out of repair-also that the dredge loaded over the stern, a . method quite unsuitable and sometimes dangerous in a tidal river." He found that the punts were "of a very inferior description, and if much work is done by the dredge, will soon require to be replaced." Mr Nisbet also reported that the lay-out of the proposed training wall "for confining the current and maintaining a permanent channel through Upper Flats," and assembly of plant for carrying out the work were completed, the for mer being marked off for two miles by driven piles. "The work will be commenced at the upper end above the slip and continued downwards, the re sults being carefully watched as the work proceeds, and its extent and character regulated thereby." The site of this, the beginning of the first training wall in the Fitzroy, is near the old magazine and windmill on the south bank of the river opposite Upper Flats.

After considering the reports of Civft Engineers Brady and Flews (1864), the plan made in 1865 by the Portmaster .Captain Heath) and his opin - ion of April 26, 1874. Mr Nis l>et, on July 19, considered training walls or dykes to be more effective than groynes, and in the long run no more costly. He recommended a composite dyke of timber and stone, and estimated the cost at £6 to £7 per lineal yard, or nbout. £30,000 "for the work proposed at the Upper Flats."

He proposed to make such structural alterations to the punts that they could deposit behind the training dyke, in stead of going 10 to 12 miles to dump their spoil. He added that "As thin is the first wort or the kind undertaken in the colony ... I. have some dif fidence in recommending 30 large an outlay for this pur pose; but 1 am satisfied that, if it is thought the advantages to be gained will warrant the expenditure, the result win be permanently beneficial to the navigation of this portion of the Fitzroy River."

PORT CURTIS PLANS

On August 26 Mr Nisbet pre sented his report on Port Cur tis in response to "the request of inhabitants of the town that he make an inspection and re port to the Government on its advantages and capabilities." He said that a proposed patent slip would be better either at Barney Point or at the head of Auckland Creek.

He considered that the bar at the entrance to Auckland Creek could be easily treated, and that HM, ships Salaman der (17 ft) and Virago (21 ft), and steamers Gothenburg (1? ft). Hero (18 ft), Lady Darling (10 ft), Omeo <15 ft) and Tar aroa (12 ft 6 in.) had all used it. The cattle ships Camilla (14 ft 6 in.), Eclipse (10 ft). Island City (13 ft), Kate Waters (13 ft 8 in.), Lombard (10 ft 10 in. V Restless <11 ft 6 in.) and Union (15 ft) had also berthed there. At the time of his inspection there were two private wharves and one Government wharf.

He considered that a dry dock "could be conveniently constructed at the head of Auckland Creek"; and that Barney Point was preferable for a deep water jetty. t/> wither Auckland Point or the shore !>etween the two. Of the Boyne and Calliope rivers for naviga tional purposes, Mr Nisbet pre ferred the Boyne, "but unfor

lunately ttie land on either side is low and swampy, and unfavourable for settlement," The Narrows, he described as "three statute miles in length, with four to six fathoms at either end, and about five miles dry at low water in the centre." To make it available for vessels of any size would, he thought, involve a consider able outlay. He reported fav ourably on the building storl on Facing Island, and also ou marble on the Calliope River.

On September 2 Mr Pal mer (Port Curtis) moved for * preliminary survey between Gladstone and Koekhampton, because It would be an enormous . advantage ot the colony to

know whether the expense

stone to Bockhampton would not be better for the country than going1 on with the more expensive im provements in the Ftto-oy".

Hie Treasurer said that the House had voted £25,000 for the improvement of - the Fitzroy, and "until they knew whether the experiment cucceeded, had no right to spend money on a rival route." The motion was carried. Then on the motion of Mr Palmer in the Assembly on September 8, the House in Committee resolved that the Governor be requested to place upon the Supplementary Esti mates £2000 "for the expenses of a preliminary survey for a line of railway from Gladstone to join the existing line from Rockhampton to Westwood."

Visiting the work on the wharf at Waveriey Creek la November, the engineer of la bours and rivers "made several important alterations In the design and construction of the wharf, to remedy former de fects. This suggests that they gained their experience in thost days as they went.

WHARF TROUBLES

On December 7 ominous

(Continued on Page 16)

from Glad

PORT OF ROCKHAMPTON

(Continued from Page 3)

cracks becam*. evident in the new "Vockbampton Municipal Council wharf, but the "Bul letin" refused to panic with the rest, and held that "the wharf was simply settling down In a manner expected and allowed fc by the Town Surveyor."

By December 15 It became clear that the freak wharf was collapsing under the weight of its infirmities. The Town Sur veyor admitted having econo mised on stone, and to have bottomed his piles on shale

of rock for the same reason. But the "Bulletin" was loyal to the official, and scorned the shrill demand for someone's head on a platter. If the Town Surveyor had made a mistake be erred in good company, for: "The first pile wharf con structed on the Fiteroy by the jthen Government Engineer for Roads (Mr Roberts) slipped bodily Into the river; the West wood railway was badly con structed under Civil Engineer Plews; the dredging of Upper Flats had been botched by Civil Engineer Brady; L:m Creek dam, built by Chief Engineer Byerley, bad been twice washed away; and Broadsound wharves, built under close Governmental Inspection, collapsed, and much the same had happened at Mackay."

The "Bulletin" also took com fort from the fact that tbe cost of the wharf "did not come out of the ratepayers' pockets. Residents of Clermont, Spring sure, Tambo and Blackall, who paid In wharfage dues for much of the new wharf, have as much right to complain as have the ratepayers of Rockhampton".

During 1875 a light revolving every minute was shown from a white tower 310 feet above high water on Cape Capricorn. Its visibility was 23 miles. At th; same time a fixed white light was shown from the north slope of the cape, and when In line with the main light N 70 W. led clear of Cottier bank. An other white light was also shown from the east slope, and when in line with the main light led clear of Rocky Islet.

Detention of steamers at

Upper Flats was diminishing, owing to the work of the dredge. The "Bulletin" of February 3, 1876, learned "that steamers may now calculate on an increased depth of at least 12 in. in tbe shallowest places. We observe that Maryborough folk are angry with the Trea surer for not sending one of the dredges at once to the Mary River, but Mr Hemmant, in a letter to Mr John Douglas, MP. for Maryborough, shows that the Mary River will very fairly accommodate the traffic pend ing the completion of the new dredge".

It added that the Portmaster, giving the least depths in the Brisbane, Mary and Fitzroy rivers showed 10 ft 6 in. In the Brisbane with 6 ft spring rise; 6 ft 6 in. in the Mary with 10 ft spring rise, and 3 ft in the Fitz roy with 3 ft spring rise.

FIRST POWER UNIT

The "Bulletin" of April 25 recorded: "A step in the right direction has been made by Mr Powis, stevedore, who yesterday commenced working on one of the wharves with a 7-horse power donkey engine. The new apparatus is for tne purpose of discharging cargo from vessels, and is certainly a great im provement on the primitive method hitherto adopted here. The ship now being discharged is the Star of Jamaica, and no doubt the engine will hence forth be constantly employed." Such was the beginning of mechanisation on Rockhamp ton's wharves.

The new Waverley Creek wharf to replace the one which coi^psed was completed in April. In his annual report, dated May 29, Mr Nlsbet stated that the Fitzroy dredging plant would leave Rockhampton on June 7 for Maryborough, but would stop at Gladstone to dredge the bar of Auckland Creek that, he estimated, would occupy about one month. It was proposed that the channel carrying 7 ft at low water would be deepened to 10 ft, with a width of 150 ft James NeUl began a term of 12 years as pilot at Rockhampton on July 1.

Mr Palmer (Port Curtis) asked the Treasurer In the Assembly on July 26 what had become of the motion, carried on September 8 of the previous year, regarding funds for carry ing out a prelimi ary survey for the Gladstone-Rockhamp ton railway. The Treasurer frankly admitted, amid Ironic

laughter, that "the natter toad j escaped bla attention, but It was not beyond being rectified, and It would be the duty of the : Government to see that It was (inserted before the estimates were passed through commit

tee."

Mr Bnsacott (*ock hampton) moved la the AMembly on Aagut 17 that there be plaoed on the aup ptemenUry eettmates tlOM "for a im w> of a ttae of railway to the Government township of Herbert,JBroad moant, or to some toae dis tant site on the north or sooth bank of the FiUroy River, equally available aa . port for web of large

tonnafe".

Mr Da Satge (Normanby) asked, pertinently, "Were they to go on dredging rivers at enormous cost, and then lay down railway lines along the banks? They spent now upon dipping what would pay for two or three railways."

Mr P. F. MacPonald (Black all) said that the motion was very indefinite, and he would have liked It to have stood at Broadmount, which "was Quite equal, if not superior, to Glad* stone in every respect". Be reminded the Bouse that when Meadow, Flats were thrown open he made application to | the Government to have a {reservation made for a railway from Rockhaxnpton to Broad mount". The motion was car

ried.

Following this the Legislative Assembly decided on .September 14 to recommend the placing on the estimates of £1000 for the purpose proposed by Mr Busacott. Staff - Commander Bedwell, R-N, surveyed the Fitsroy River during 1870.

The Railway Department re ported in April, 1877, that the plans «»"< section of the Rock hflfyipt/in . Herbert (Broad mount) railway line of 22 miles were almost completed. It was believed at the time the sur vey commenced "that a bridge capable of carrying . railway would be erected in the line of Fitzroy Street"

VOBk ON UPPER PLATS

It was reported that an June 30, 4700 lineal feet of the Up per Flats training wall "was in a more or less forward state ! 17374 cubic yards of stone and 2800 cubic yards of matresses and fascines having been de posited. An opening 100 ft wide had been left opposite the Government sllp" "but the out rush of tide through scoured out the bed the river to a depth

three feet, and it was fouim necessary to clow it" Hence forth vessels came up behind the wall from the downstream end of the wall to reach the

slipway.

In his report dated October 16 the Treasurer on Fitzroy River improvements (Mr Mis bet) said that from the town wharves to a mile below Lakes Creek river depths at low wat er were from 20 to 40 feet, and ifrom there to the commence ment of the training wall

the upper end of Upper Flats a distance of seven miles from Rockhampton, the depth was from 10 to 16 feet at low water The river width was from 80p to 1400 ft. and so for that dis tance from town "there exists no impediment of any kind the navigation of the river every class of vessel."

Mr Nisbet had nothing

add to the plans which he had laid for the development and maintenance of a cutting through the Upper Flats. He gave the total length of train ing wall here as 51,000 lineal feet or upwards of 9.8 miles and the cost would be £05,818 of which £23.834 had already been voted. He gave the depths at low water as: Upper Flats 3 ft.; First Flats (below light ship), 8 ft.; Archer's Crossing 8 ft.; Second Flats, 6 ft

Brown's Crossing 5 ft.; Hawk Point Crossing, 6 ft. Total dis tances carrying under 10

25,000 ft. or nearly five miles

His next recommendation was In relation to opening

an entirely new Humbug Chan nel, which necessitated closing ultimately Alllfcator Passage Casuarlna, old Humbug and Satellite channels. He consid ered that the required training walls would cost £38,233. Mr Nisbet made no recommenda tlons for below Humbug Chan nel, other than to suggest that "the depth over banks; out

side the river heads, could be! improved by partially closing up the North and Middle chan nels, and confining the cur

rent to the South Channel or. probably, the depth might be Increased by dredging. But it Is unnecessary to recommend r-'ch a course, as the present (jptii is, I consider, quite suf ficient for aU practical pur poses for some time to come."

SOME LAND SALES

With river development mov ing apace and Broadmount coming into increasing prom inence, it.appears to have oc curred to someone that the time was propitious for hold ing a land sale, so one was duly held at the Lands Office on October 23. Of the 282 lots submitted onlf 32 were sold, and of them 25 4Cre at Broad mount, and one each at Hewlttville (Emu Park) and Yeppoon. The purchasers were Herbert - Mr H. E. Aldrldge, 14 lots at £* each, 1 it is and two at £10 each; Hon W. P. Lambert, 1 at £5/5/- and one at £4; Mr George M. Leigh, 1 at £4 arid one at £7/15/-: Mr T. S. Hall, 1 at £4. Town of Hewlttville Mr James Corcoran, 1 at £4. Town of Yeppoon-Mr W.

Nelll, I at £8/7/-.

The "Bulletin" of October 24 was loftily scornful of land seekers at Broadmount: "Per haps some official personage and some private Individuals afflicted with the Broadmount craze, will be glad to learn that no less than 25 lots In the paper township of Herbert were sold at auction yesterday at the Crown Land sale. Fourteen years ago, when the land In this city of the future was first j oQered to a gullible public, the Government put on the .prohibi tory upset price of £100 an acre.

Only four or five allotments j were then sold and from that | day to this no human hablta- I ttan has been erected on the i site. No wonder, therefore, that in submitting 149 lota yes terday, the village upset price

of only £8 an acres was affixed, i or that the total proceeds from { the 25 allotments were only | £118. The principal buyer was Mr H. E, Aldrldge, a resident of Maryborough, who obtained no less than 14 lots. The re mainder were local purchasers, who thought it worth while to throw a few pounds into the speculation on the distance chance of some enterprising Government running the rail way to Broadmount. We should really like to see an adventur ous person starting a building of some kind on the site of that embryo city. A good opportun ity now presents itself, at any rate, of acquiring the distinc tion of "the oldest inhabitant" and of handing down one's name to posterity as ojie of the benefactors of the human species. It may be hoped also that the Government will offer Herbert allotments at every quarterly sale in future, in order that the Interest upon the capita] expended upon the Broadmount railway survey may not press on the already over-burdened taxpayers."

The Municipal Council de cided on December 13 that It would, from May 1, 1878, take over from Mr G. B. Shaw the collection of wharfage. It was the termination of a custom that had grown up with the port, and would be the better for being incorporated in the activities of the parent body.

H.M.S. Pearl, under Staff Commander Bedwell and Nav. Lleut. Connor, completed sur veying the approaches to Broadsound In 1877. Names as sociated with the ship and her officers, which are now on charts of the area, are: Bed well Group, Connor Islet and Rock, Pearl Bay, Pass, Rock

and Shoal.

RIVER EXCURSION

On January 1, 1878, ss. Lady Bowen (Capt. Cottier), left Rockhampton at 8 a.m. with

about 700 excursionists lor what became Beachton. below Sea Hill lighthouse on Curtis Island, A short stay was made at Lakes Creek to pick up some more pasengers, after which the run was continued and anchor was dropped at noon.

After a "very substantial lunch laid out in the saloon" the people landed for a short stay, and a start was made for

homeiat 2.30.

On tanuary 5 the "Bulletin" reported that the ship Scot tish Bard had completed her loading "and Is awaiting tow age from Central Island to Keppel Bay" on the first stage of her voyage to London. This appears to be the first men tion of this anchorage about 21 miles from Rockhmnplon. and was much used by ships for some years.

While the p.s. Queensland was negotiating Boat Passage on January 18 while bout; 1 down the river, she gToundcJ on a sand bank and when the tide fell she opent up amid ships, but "came together again when the tide arose." The Queensland got off and towed to town, where she was repaired.

The "Peak Downs Advertis er" on January 19, set out the frieght rates to Clermont via Broadsound and by Rockhamp hampton: "Including an aver age of £4/10/- per rail freight from Rockhampton to Black water, the currcnt rate of car riage from Rockhampton to Clermont is £13/10/- per ton, whereas by the Broadsound route the charge is only £10. Including £1 steamer freight from Rockhampton to St. Law

rence."

The "Bulletin" was frankly unconvinced, saying that ac cording to its contemporary the rail freight worked out at over 9d per ton per mile. "Thi-, however, must be an exaggero - tlon, for the Minister for Rail ways some months since state 1

that the average was 7d. Wc think, however, that the pic sent rail freight is excessive and might, with safety, be re duced to 6d per ton per milr '

A correspondent, who signfi himself "Importer" complalnct of the shed-less condition of the corporation wharves, ;:i reply to which the corporation pleaded that it had no money. To this "Importer" rejoined that it extracted £2600 from him and his kind, and he wanted to know what they got In return The "Bulletin" of February 18 said "No doubt h considerable stun has been spent in wharves and ap proaches, but there teems rea son to believe that a not In considerable amount of whnrf revenue has gone into the for mation and repair of streete." The "Bulletin" suggested that lest hlnterlanders who pay wharfage rot to hear of this state of affairs, "these thoughts are worth consideration by our City Fathers."

(To be continued >.
heading: THE PORT OF ROCKHAMPTON: ITS ORIGIN AND DEVELOPMENT
snippet: The "Bulletin" was compelled at times to wage war against distant foes who assailed Rockhampton through the columns of the Brisbane "Courier." One such was over the respective merits of Rockhampton and St Lawrence as a port for Clermont, when the "Bulletin," on April 16, conceded the right of controversialists "to choose their own battle ground; and

articleText:
EARLY HISTORY:

R'TON & DISTRICT

at

* ®y

" HistoricT "

Clermont was proclaimed on February 2, 1872 to be a place, for the holding of a District Court. A. T. H. Blair, eon of Sir David H. Blair, was found dead beside a lagoon on the Port Curt'.s Road some days prior to February 5. Pleuro pneumonia was reported on February 2 to have appeared

; in the Peak Downs district.

"That Rockhampton will soon be numbered among the sugar growing districts of the colon/ was already predicted," said tthe "Bulletin" of February 13 "But we have now the satisfac tion of saying that Mr John Murray, of Pandora, on the Ag ricultural Reserve (Alton Downs), has 35 acres of cane growing most luxuriantly. Mr Murray starts this morning for Sydney, via Maryborough and Brisbane, for machinery with which to commence the manu facture of sugar in September next."

The river bridge had reached the stage when, on February 6 the "Bulletin" was able to enumerate three proposals: A pontoon bridge to cost.£10,000; a wooden pile bridge to cost £25,000; and an iron. girder bridge, to cost £35,000 to £40, 000. By a process of elimina tion the "Bulletin" selected the last-named, and recommended that London capitalists be en

ticed by a land grant and a, franchise to secure to them the toll. Aid. Nobbs took the first

official move by giving notice of, motion on February 28 "thatj immediate steps be taken by the City Council towards the erection of a bridge over the Fltzroy River on the site ap proved by their resolution of March 2 iasv, and that a com mittee of the whole council be appointed to consider ways and means of constructing such bridge."

Abljah Goode was appointed n February 20 to be pound zeeper at Nebo for the ensuing year. Batholomew's Royal Mail soach Westwood-Clermoht ser vice started on February 21 opened by leaving Westwood "immediately after the arrival of the train" and would reach Clermont on Saturday evening. The coaches for this service were expressly built by Cobb and Co., Bathurst, and had but lately arrived per ss. James Paterson. J. Wilson was ap pointed on February 28 to be poundkeeper for the ensuing year at Gladstone.

The immigrant ship Light Brigade arrived in Keppcl Bay under Captain Holden on Feb ruary 28 after a smart passage from Gravesend of 87 days. She brought 321 souls, who were brought to town by the tender Mary. Rockhampton's second sub-Collector of Customs, W. J. Brown, died suddenly at Emu Park on March 4. Bird wrote. "It was felt that the commun ity had lost one of its most valued members." Mr F. Kil ner succeeded to the vacant post

F. Batho was appointed to be T.<n« Repairer in Charge at Springsure on March < and R. Halloran, line repairer at Cler mont was made Line Repairer in Charge at Gopperflsld. New regulations for the Gainsford i ferry were gazetted on March 8. providing for punts 30 x 10 x 8 feet principal dimensions Among those exempted by the regulations from payment of fees were those "proceeding to or returning from divine wor ship on the Lord's Day."

n*> *. - I

March 11 as a member of the] Legislative Assembly for Leich hardt in place of C. 'J. Xtoyds, resigned.

On March 16 Lord Kimber ley replied, on behalf of the Orbwn in regard to the separa tion movement at Rockhamp ton, that her Majesty had "re ceived the petition very gra ciously, but I have not been able to advise that any steps be taken upon the subject." On March 18 "The Rockhampton Bulletin . and the Central Queensland Advertiser," with out either notice or explana tion, changed its title to "The Rockhampton Bulletin, with which is Incorporated the The Gladstone Observer."

The Philharmonic Society gave its second subscription concert on March 27, and seems to have been badly served by the weather, which interfered with rehearsals. "This, as may be supposed," said the Bulletin, "did not tend to make members more perfect in their parts."

On April 6 P. F. MacDonald offered to settle with the Queensland Government for £15,000 the verdict which he obtained for £16,026 and costs that, it was estimated, would amount to £6000. In view of the Government having moved for a new trial, the offer was made without prejudice. He wrote, "I am free to confess that the long conflict against unlimited public resources, has both crip pled me in means and fatigued me In spirit, so that X am now prepared to submit to a con siderable reduction on what 1 believe to be barely a sufficient; reward, rather than ihcur the anxiety and delay and expense which would be involved in a renewal of the contest." !

In a Gladstone message In she "Bulletin" of April 8 it was stated that "the cattle trade be tween this port and New Cale donia Is about to be resumed, It being reported that two vessels are already laid on. With this trade and the de mand for meat pressrving, there should be an excellent market for fat stock this year." Wm. Cave, CPJ5. at Cler mont, was appointed on April 15 to be Registrar of the Dis trict Court thereat. Cemetery reserves at Rockhampton and St Lawrence were notified on April 18. Messrs Wm. Adair, Wm. Armstrong, Wm. Christian, Geo. Fox, Thos. Hatfield, and Thos. F. Tagg.were appointed on April 18 to be trustees of the cemetery at St Lawrence. F. Kilner, sub-Collector of Cus toms, Bowen, was appointed on April 19 to a like post at Rock hampton, vice W. J. Brown,

deceased.

? IThe prospectus of the Kroom

bA Copper Mining Coy., Ltd was published in the '"Sydney Morning Herald" of Afcril 23, and provided for a capital of £60,000 In shares of £1 each. The directors were Messrs G. S. Caird, R. Holdsworth, J. G. L. Innes, R. F. Pocklsy and J. Trickett, Half of the shares were offered to the public', and of them the "Bulletin" said, "There seems little doubt that the company will be successfully floated, in which case a great stir will be originated in the neighbouring town of Glad

stone." j

LONDON, July 29. - Sever,

teen were killed and 23 Injured when a bus plunged into a rav ine near Fez in French Mor
